LEAD: Laugh Off: LEAD: Viktor P. Nikonov, a rising star in the ruling Soviet Politburo and the man in charge of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's drive to rejuvenate Soviet agriculture, will arrive in the United States on Tuesday for a week of farm tours and superpower diplomacy.
LEAD: There are signs of life on Woodward Avenue, the once vital, tumbledown main street that some here long ago left for dead.

LEAD: Interstate Properties, a New Jersey-based developer headed by Steven Roth, said yesterday that it was seeking permission from Federal regulators to buy more than 50 percent of the stock outstanding in Alexander's Inc., a 14-store retail chain based in New York.

LEAD: The House Speaker, Jim Wright, who took the unusual step two months ago of agreeing to collaborate with President Reagan on a peace plan for Central America, today called the White House's latest Nicaragua strategy ''ridiculous'' and a creation of ''the extreme right wing.''

LEAD: Jimmy Carter and Senator Paul Simon outside the former President's home Sunday in Plains, Ga. Mr. Simon, a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination, said he visited Mr. Carter for political advice. (AP)

LEAD: Overheard in a crowded downtown elevator. Young Man: ''Who are we going to get for a President this time around anyway?'' Female Companion: ''I don't think any of the names who have appeared in the last year are capable of running the Government.'' In the back of the elevator, Pete du Pont, one of the Republican competitors, decided this was not the time or place to add another debate to his political schedule.

LEAD: A defendant in the Howard Beach murder case who is cooperating with prosecutors admitted to the grand jury that he had taken a baseball bat from another defendant to have a weapon with which to hit the three black men, a defense lawyer said yesterday.

LEAD: Robert C. Byrd, the Senate majority leader, said today that he would vote against confirming Judge Robert H. Bork and called on President Reagan to withdraw the Supreme Court nomination, calling it ''doomed.''

LEAD: When Mikhail Baryshnikov makes his first guest appearance with the Martha Graham Dance Company tonight, his initial gesture as a frontier farmer in ''Appalachian Spring'' will be to touch the wood on Isamu Noguchi's Shaker-inspired frame of a house. What does the gesture mean?
LEAD: Q. Have astronomers been able to use the location, speed and direction of the observable galaxies to identify the probable location of the Big Bang?

LEAD: The Bregmans and the Belzbergs, two of Canada's wealthiest families, have jointly purchased a 7.4 percent stake in the International Multifoods Corporation and said they might seek control of the Minneapolis-based concern.

LEAD: The Lotus Development Corporation will introduce within the next month an unusual program called Agenda that incorporates several artificial-intelligence techniques. Company officials said it would enable computer users to analyze ideas and text much as spreadsheets allow them to analyze numbers.

LEAD: The St. Louis Cardinals seem to be people in perpetual motion. If they were commuters, they'd be running for buses; if they were travelers, they'd be running through airports. They always seem to be running. Often, they run home after having run from first base to second and from second base to third.

LEAD: Five Republican Senators opposed to confirmation of C. William Verity Jr. as Commerce Secretary have placed a ''hold'' on his nomination, thereby delaying a Senate vote on the matter and possibly inviting a filibuster if Senate leaders try to force a vote.

LEAD: Catchers (Average, home runs, r.b.i.) 5 Tony Pena (.214, 5, 44) Acquired last spring from Pittsburgh at steep cost in talent, giving Cardinals the front-line catcher they needed, but then suffered broken bone in thumb on April 10. Hit poorly and struggled to regain stature as prime defensive catcher.
LEAD: The Supreme Court refused today to hear arguments on the legality of a test that has kept women from being hired as New York City firefighters since 1984.

LEAD: Mike Bossy, with his hands in his pockets and his delivery unemotional, announced today that he has resigned himself to a season of physical therapy in place of an 11th year of professional hockey. But even though the back ailment he has suffered with since last spring appeared to make his retirement a foregone conclusion, Bossy said emphatically that he was not ready to give up playing.

LEAD: Calor Group P.L.C., a British heating gas distributor, rejected as inadequate a takeover offer of $:821 million, or $1.33 billion, made Monday by Burmah Oil P.L.C. and SHV Holdings N.V. Burmah, a British oil company, and SHV, a Dutch energy group that is Calor's biggest shareholder, had conditioned their offer on Calor recommending it to shareholders.
LEAD: The replacement Jets returned to practice today, wounded and bandaged but eager for another game.

LEAD: THE Federal Government is moving ahead with plans to put nuclear reactors and nuclear rocket engines in space for both civilian and military uses. Orbiting reactors, officials believe, will be essential for powering antimissile weapons and future scientific missions, including deep-space probes, space stations and manned outposts on

LEAD: TWO years in the making, ''Dancing for Life'' turned out to be one of the smoothest-run benefit performances in New York history - thanks to Jerome Robbins's supervision -and also one of the most emotionally stirring.

LEAD: ''The name of this room is 'Where the Dalai Lama Stayed,' '' the old monk said, glancing over his shoulder to make sure he was not overheard. Then he sat on a small platform covered with a matted rug.
LEAD: SEVERAL recent announcements about cholesterol-lowering drugs have been encouraging both to medical specialists and investors in the companies that reported the advances.
LEAD: Since the severe earthquake in Southern California last Thursday, calls for help to the public mental health agency's crisis intervention unit here have increased dramatically.
LEAD: New York State filed a Federal lawsuit yesterday to force the cleanup of a hazardous dump site said to be owned by a group that includes a man accused as a Mafia leader.

LEAD: Chinese policemen occupied the third floor of Tibetan Buddhism's holiest place Sunday night after two pro-independence protests, one of which is reported to have left at least nine Tibetans dead.

LEAD: ''THE Closing of the American Mind'' by Allan Bloom has been on the New York Times best-seller list for 23 weeks. Apparently this angry book has been mis-titled: if so many are reading it, the American mind must be wide open.

LEAD: INTERNATIONAL A3-14 Representative Jim Wright decried the White House's latest Nicaraguan strategy as ''ridiculous,'' after taking the unusual step two months ago of agreeing to collaborate with President Reagan's peace plan for Central America. Page A1 Chinese police entered a shrine, the Jokhang Cathedral in Lhasa, and occupied one floor of what is Tibetan Buddhism's holiest place, in the aftermath of pro-independence protests that are reported to have left at least nine Tibetans dead.

LEAD: The United States Virgin Islands, where the average temperature is in the upper 80's and the notion of snow is remote, will field a Winter Olympic team for the first time, a team spokesman, Bill Beer, announced yesterday. The nine-member squad that will travel to Calgary for the 1988 Winter Games will consist of two bobsled teams, two skiers and two lugers.
LEAD: President P. W. Botha said today his Government planned to permit some multiracial neighborhoods, but is not ready to scrap the law that segregates public facilities.

LEAD: Public-school employees, on strike here since the school year began 27 days ago, returned to work this morning without a contract just hours before court-imposed sanctions would have cost them their jobs.

LEAD: In the eerie twilight under the bobbing Goodyear blimp, striking Giants were joined by striking Jets and about 500 members of other unions to picket before tonight's game between the Giants and the San Francisco 49ers.

LEAD: Canada was a sharply divided nation today as details of the free-trade agreement with the United States became known, with business generally supporting the pact and trade unions and nationalist groups adamantly against it.

LEAD: The end of the Von Zedtwitz Double Knockout Team championship for 1986-87 will overlap with the 1987-88 event. The entries for that and the Harter Cup close Oct. 15. Information is available from Alan Osofsky at (212) 697-9379.
LEAD: Companies
LEAD: Hundreds of French and British engineers are gearing up for a brutally hot, humid and deafening grind that promises to fulfill a centuries-old dream - a tunnel beneath the English Channel.
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation agreed today to pay $500,000 in fines to settle what Government officials described as a pattern of underreporting job injuries.

LEAD: In a further breach of the half-century barrier separating the banking and securities industries, the Supreme Court today allowed state-chartered banks that are not members of the Federal Reserve System to underwrite corporate securities.

LEAD: United States factory sales of electronic equipment, components and related products are expected to reach nearly $225 billion this year, a 5.3 percent increase over last year, the Electronic Industries Association said today. Consumer electronics manufacturers were expected to realize the largest gains, with projected growth of 7.1 percent, the association said.
LEAD: SCIENCE is still a long way from a cure for the common cold. But maybe that does not matter anymore.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: In spring training this year, Manager Sparky Anderson said the 1987 Tigers were better than his 1984 team that won the World Series. He said this was the best of the nine Tigers' teams he had managed, and it would win the American League East.

LEAD: Ronald A. Brierly, a New Zealand corporate raider, has amassed a fortune acquiring small, neglected companies in old-line industries. His methods were considered so unorthodox at a time when unfriendly deals were unusual that his applications for a listing on the New Zealand Stock Exchange were rejected seven times before Brierly Investments Ltd.
LEAD: While the Democratic Presidential campaign has dissolved into grim uncertainty, the Republican contest, like the party itself, is considerably more orderly.

LEAD: Fred Wertheimer, president of Common Cause, has had season tickets to the Washington Redskins' home games for 20 years, but he boycotted the game Sunday with the St. Louis Cardinals because of the players' strike. He worries about how the strike might affect the close relationship he sees between the football team and other activity in the capital.

LEAD: Cars that had been caught in flooding lay piled up on a road near Barcelona. At least 10 people were killed in storms, accompanied by heavy rains, that swept across northern and eastern Spain over the weekend.

LEAD: An article yesterday about the Italy on Stage festival in New York gave an outdated schedule for the exhibition ''Giovanni Pisano in Genoa'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. It will run Oct. 30 to Dec. 6.
LEAD: DREAMS AND DELUSIONS. The Drama of German History. By Fritz Stern. 323 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.
LEAD: THE Feld Ballet brought a romp for blithe spirits to the Joyce Theater (175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street) on Sunday night when it revived Eliot Feld's ''Meadowlark.''

LEAD: THE sun may be shining outside a cavernous building here at Japan's National Center for Disaster Prevention, but inside, researchers move about, umbrellas in hand, watching how soils respond to rains ranging from prolonged drizzle to torrential downpour. A platform tilts like the bed of a gigantic dump truck, until the soil within it slumps and slides.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Federal Communications Commission has approved the transfer of broadcasting licenses held by the Taft Broadcasting Company, clearing the way for a $1.44 billion buyout of the company. Taft shareholders are selling the media company to an investor group, TFBA Limited Partnership, that includes the FMI Financial Corporation, which is headed by the Cincinnati investor Carl H.

LEAD: The Florida House and Senate each voted unanimously today to close a loophole in a new gun law that allows people carry weapons openly in public The bills differed slightly, which means the issue will have to be addressed again Tuesday.
LEAD: Opening its new term with only eight members, the Supreme Court agreed today to hear arguments in several significant cases while declining to review nearly 1,000 other appeals.

LEAD: Chiropractors say they the image of their profession will improve as a result of a Federal court injunction barring the American Medical Association from ''restricting, regulating or impeding'' its members from associating with chiropractic practitioners.

LEAD: Charles E. Hurwitz, chairman of Maxxam Group Inc., denied accusations today that he made an illegal arrangement with Jefferies & Company to conceal his ownership of stock in the Pacific Lumber Company in the days before he began a successful hostile takeover of the company in 1985.

LEAD: Only one thing was missing from what residents here call the world's largest garage sale, and it was not the kitchen sink. Joe Groff, a tree trimmer for the Niagara Mohawk Power Company, was selling that in front of his house on Main Street for $12.

LEAD: When Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. dropped the gavel last week to conclude the hearings on the Supreme Court nomination of Judge Robert H. Bork, he may have brought down the curtain on the last performance in the Senate Caucus Room, the scene of some of the most dramatic moments in national political history.

LEAD: In the first week of replacement play, the legal bookmakers here took in only about 10 percent of the $30 million to $40 million they would normally take in on a National Football League Sunday, and most said they lost money because of the predictability of the results.
LEAD: Fans outside Tiger Stadium waiting to buy playoff tickets. The Tigers captured the division title Sunday. (AP)

LEAD: ''Let's begin again,'' Senator Dennis DeConcini entreated the President yesterday as the Arizona Democrat joined in the lopsided 9-to-5 Judiciary Committee vote against the Supreme Court nominee Robert Bork. Nothing doing, said Mr. Reagan. ''There's no backing off. I'm going all out.'' Unchastened, he passed the word that he was disappointed with Republicans and peeved at Democrats for ''politicizing'' the confirmation.

LEAD: Dr. Henry I. Fineberg, a retired pediatrician and former deputy commissioner of hospitals for New York City, died of a stroke Sunday at Huntington (L.I.) Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived in Dix Hills, L.I.

LEAD: Rilwanu Lukman, president of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, left today to visit Persian Gulf oil states to bolster support for OPEC price policies. Mr. Lukman, who is also Nigeria's oil minister, told reporters that OPEC members must stay within their production quotas before oil prices can improve.

LEAD: Donald W. Brooks, who led an unsuccessful attempt to take over the Fairchild Semiconductor Corporation, has resigned as the company's president and chief executive. The acquisition of Fairchild, a unit of Schlumberger Ltd., by the National Semiconductor Corporation is expected to be completed later this week.
LEAD: The Reagan Administration plans to send four small Coast Guard patrol vessels and several search-and-rescue aircraft to the Persian Gulf to join the Navy there, Pentagon officials said today.

LEAD: Richard A. Greenawalt has been named president and chief operating officer of the TSO Financial Corporation, a $1.2 billion financial institution that has come far from its days as a loan service for Philadelphia teachers.

LEAD: A resident theater company in Los Angeles, the Mark Taper Forum, will receive the 1987 Jujamcyn Theaters Award. LEAD: The House voted final passage today of a multibillion-dollar bailout of the Farm Credit System. The legislation includes creation of a secondary market for farm mortgage loans.

Congress voted for sanctions over the President's objections precisely because the signals he had sent Pretoria were mixed.

Once an attractive woman with a full mental and physical life, she is now a drooling dependent sustained by machines, her existence reduced to only one wish: that she be allowed to die.

LEAD: President Reagan and Crown Prince Akihito of Japan discussed ties between their two countries during a brief meeting today at the White House. The Prince, 53 years old, and his wife, Crown Princess Michiko, began a three-day visit to Washington on Monday.
LEAD: Mayor W. Wilson Goode and former Mayor Frank Rizzo called each other liars tonight as they clashed in their only televised debate before the Nov. 3 election.
LEAD: Stocks ended mixed yesterday in volatile trading as the market found itself trapped between buyers hunting for bargains and sellers fearful of higher interest rates.

LEAD: * Alexander & Alexander Services Inc. an international insurance brokerage and risk management firm, agreed to sell its Shand, Morahan & Co. division to a new corporation principally owned by Fairfax Financial Holdings Ltd. and Market Corp. Terms were not disclosed.
LEAD: A civil suit against the Federal Government in which 30 Haitian men contend that their breasts became enlarged because of their treatment in Federal detention has ended its third day.

LEAD: HAVING matched wits with Moriarty and other Napoleons of crime, Sherlock Holmes now attacks racism in the performing arts. At least that is one of the themes of Alexander Simmons's ''Sherlock Holmes and the Hands of Othello,'' a new melodrama at the Westbeth Theater Center.

LEAD: The National Book Awards, a nonprofit literary and educational organization, has designated Nov. 8 to 14 National Book Week and plans readings and receptions in New York and Washington. Winners of awards for the best fiction and nonfiction books of the year will each receive $10,000 at a dinner at the Pierre Hotel at 8 P.M.
LEAD: A homeless girl from Poughkeepsie, N.Y, is to attend school today for the first time this school year as a result of a Federal court ruling yesterday.

LEAD: Continuing to focus on the jacket as the key to contemporary dressing, Giorgio Armani proved that fashion can be relevant without being ridiculous. Obeying the law of moderation, he raised hemlines above the knee, softened the construction of his jackets and paired them with filmy chiffon skirts. Using a pale watercolor palette, he made tailored clothes look feminine.

LEAD: They are young and without much experience in these kinds of games, but the Minnesota Twins did not seem shaken by their predicament tonight. On the mound, they were facing a pitcher of perfection. In the eighth inning, they were staring at a defeat.

LEAD: A SUCCESSFUL Metropolitan Opera debut was made Monday night by Barbara Kilduff, who took prizes in an impressive series of closely spaced vocal competitions last year. The young coloratura soprano sang Zerbinetta in ''Ariadne auf Naxos,'' the same high-flying role that introduced her earlier this year in Vienna and Munich.
LEAD: The Philadelphia Electric Company is offering $200 million of bonds, equally divided between 10-year and 29-year maturities. Both issues were sold competitively.
LEAD: Both Britain's Saatchi & Saatchi and America's Omnicom Group have announced a wee bit of consolidation.
LEAD: The soprano Montserrat Caballe will make her only New York appearance this season Oct. 16 at Carnegie Hall, in a program devoted primarily to music from Spain. The recital begins at 8 P.M.

LEAD: There were no surprises yesterday at the Rockwell International Corporation as the big military contractor announced plans for changes at the top. LEAD: Although he outpolled the eight other candidates, Amadou-Mahtar M'Bow, whose tenure as director general of Unesco has divided the organization, failed to receive a majority when the 50-member executive board voted tonight on a new leader.

LEAD: Libya and Algeria have reached agreement in principle on a treaty of political unity, Libya's chief delegate to the United Nations, Ali Treiki, said today.

LEAD: A House committee voted Tuesday for a measure that would allow civil servants to run for office and to actively take part in politics, easing stern restictions that have stood for 48 years.
LEAD: Joseph B. Flavin, chairman and chief executive officer of the Singer Company, died yesterday at Norwalk Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived in New Canaan, Conn.

LEAD: Q. As a result of an accident a board in our living room floor is badly split and warped. First split up the damaged board with a chisel so you can remove the pieces without damaging the boards on either side.

LEAD: The American Honda Motor Company said today that prices of its 1988 Legend models would increase by an average of 4.4 percent, or $1,016 a car. The new Legend, which is sold by Honda's Acura division, ranges from $21,010 for the basic sedan to $29,127 for the LS coupe with automatic transmission. The sedan carries the new engine that was introduced in last year's coupe.

LEAD: Terry Simpson sat in a seat halfway up an empty Nassau Coliseum last month, his hooded eyes staring out over the unpopulated ice. Five months had passed since his Islanders lost in seven games to the Philadelphia Flyers, ending an exciting playoff run with a disappointing 5-1 sleepwalk in the final game.
LEAD: The constitutional right to an attorney was the crucial point that resulted in the acquittal of a teen-ager who confessed to killing four members of his family, the defense attorney said today.

LEAD: A religious corporation and a political action committee run by the Rev. Jerry Falwell have both been fined $6,000 by the Federal Election Commission because of an illegal series of transactions between the two.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Closer to home and slightly on the shady side, Grey Advertising, New York, has picked up the account of Levolor Lorentzen Inc. of Parsippany, N.J., maker of window blinds and similar products. The billings, expected to exceed $5 million, formerly went through Muller, Jordan, Weiss.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Not long ago, Michael Olajide Jr. was anticipating the impact his entrance would have when he steps into the ring Saturday to fight Frank Tate for the vacated International Boxing Federation middleweight title.

LEAD: The Mitsubishi Electric Corporation said that a Court of Appeals in Washington had upheld a lower court ruling favorable to it in a suit brought in 1984 by the Tandon Corporation. Tandon had appealed last year's ruling by a Federal District Court in Los Angeles, which found that Mitsubishi had not infringed on Tandon's double-sided disk drive technology.

LEAD: The Devils acquired George McPhee from the Winnipeg Jets yesterday for a fourth-round draft pick in 1989. The move came a week after McPhee, a 29-year-old forward, had been sent to the Jets by the Rangers.

LEAD: Scores of people were still missing today in the sinking of a boat loaded with Dominicans trying to enter Puerto Rico illegally. Estimates of the death toll in the Tuesday disaster ranged from 70 to more than 100.

LEAD: THE idea of two fellows from Leningrad being able to portray quintessential American Yankees might stretch the imagination. But that is what Mikhail Baryshnikov and Rudolf Nureyev actually pulled off Tuesday night through their first-ever joint performance in Martha Graham's ''Appalachian Spring.''

LEAD: ON Monday evening at Merkin Concert Hall, the New York Women Composers sponsored a program of works by one of its charter members, Ursula Mamlok. Mrs. Mamlok, who has since the mid 1970s taught composition at the Manhattan School of Music, is a kind of miniaturist composer, crafting delicate, artful pieces on a small scale.
LEAD: After a harrowing month that threatened not only its season but also its survival, the venerable Troy Music Hall is to reopen tomorrow night with a concert by the Albany Symphony.
LEAD: Short- and long-term interest rates rose slightly yesterday as securities dealers were disappointed by weaker than expected demand for new seven-year Treasury notes.

LEAD: Chancellor Helmut Kohl today rejected complaints that his country was not doing enough to spur the world's economy and warned against a ''trend toward protectionism'' in the United States Congress.

LEAD: A Vatican official told a group of medical professionals yesterday that test-tube fertilization reduces human beings to objects and degrades their ''being, value and dignity.'' But he was challenged by a leading gynecologist, a Roman Catholic who argued that the method permits devoted childless couples to have children.

LEAD: ''I WONDER how many people keep their car in their garage,'' said Oliver Cope, an architect with David Handlin & Associates, Cambridge, Mass. ''The problem with the typical two-car garage is that half is used for the car and half for junk.''

LEAD: A Washington dispatch in Business Day on Tuesday, about opposition to the confirmation of C. William Verity as Commerce Secretary, misstated the position of Senator Robert Kasten. The Wisconsin Republican has not participated in placing the nomination on ''hold,'' and he says he does not intend to participate in any strategy to delay a final vote.

LEAD: One of Congress's traditional tricks for making budget deficits look smaller has been to shift expenditures by 24 hours, so that they fall on the first day of a new fiscal year, Oct. 1, instead of the last day of the old one, Sept. 30. A year ago, for example, the Sept. 30 distribution of revenue-sharing grants to states was put over to Oct.

LEAD: There have been two account switches of national interest involving San Francisco agencies this week. Goodby, Berlin & Silverstein has boarded the Royal Viking Line, and Grey Advertising found its cup running over courtesy of the Seagram Classics Wine Company.

LEAD: The General Electric Company, buoyed by strong gains in its financial services, aircraft engine and medical systems divisions, said yesterday that earnings in the third quarter rose 16.4 percent despite roughly flat sales.

LEAD: The chief spokeswoman for Pat Robertson acknowledged tonight that Mr. Robertson, a Republican Presidential candidate, and his wife were married more than five months after the date that they publicly celebrate as their wedding day and that their first child was born 10 weeks after they were married.
LEAD: An organization of organ transplant centers has established a committee to assure that a limited number of organs will be allocated to foreigners, the panel's chairman said Tuesday.
LEAD: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

LEAD: AFTER centuries on the shelf, the humble basket is now in the spotlight. At auction houses, collectors vie for rare American Indian, Shaker and Japanese basketry; museums devote whole exhibitions to the craft, while contemporary craftsmen translate ancient basketry techniques into sculptural forms.

LEAD: With graphic detail, the prosecutor in the Howard Beach murder trial said yesterday that three black men desperately sought to flee a gang of white youths who mercilessly chased one of the blacks to his death on a busy highway and savagely beat another victim.

LEAD: The New York City Board of Estimate's approval of the Koch administration's proposal to build 11 transitional residences for homeless families and individuals ranks as one of the largest boondoggles in the city's recent history.

LEAD: Black bears and grizzlies are bellying up to a natural bar here and are getting drunk in the process.
LEAD: Drive to work and your employer can pay for your parking, tax free.

LEAD: Not everything was the way it seemed in the second game of the National League playoff today.

LEAD: Two ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries have indicated that the 13-nation group's oil price and production policy could change at its next full conference, scheduled in December.

LEAD: Eleven present and one former employee at the Kingsboro Psychiatric Center in Brooklyn were arrested yesterday on charges of sale and possession of cocaine and marijuana or the abuse of patients.

LEAD: The Holly Sugar Corporation, the target of a recent series of unsuccessful takeover bids, said it had received a merger offer of $91 a share, or $102 million, from an investor group led by the Illinois financier Peter Harvey. LEAD: Debt
LEAD: Frank Kleinholz, a painter known for his realistic depictions of city life and city dwellers, died Saturday in Miami Beach. He was 86 years old.
LEAD: An Air Force pilot exposed to what the Pentagon believes was a Soviet laser last week did not suffer permanent eye damage, a Pentagon spokesman said today.

LEAD: A 2-year-old child was shot and killed tonight in an area where a number of protests were occurring as part of a general strike called by a labor group against the regime of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, the police reported.

LEAD: Federal payments for defaulted student loans reached $1.3 billion last year. That's more than the $1.13 billion the Department of Education allotted to Head Start. In fact, it constitutes the third largest expenditure of Federal education funds. It's also a national scandal.

LEAD: The Long Island Lighting Company is offering a free booklet on planting trees and shrubs. The guide describes 26 trees that will grow to heights of 30 to 80 feet and have a mature spread of 12 to 60 feet.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The Dalai Lama, Tibet's exiled spiritual and national leader, urged his supporters today to continue their campaign against Chinese rule but to do so peacefully.
LEAD: I PLEDGE ALLEGIANCE. . .The True Story of the Walkers: An American Spy Family. By Howard Blum. Illustrated. 438 pages. Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

LEAD: Judge William S. Sessions, the newly confirmed Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, must undergo further tests to determine what caused intestinal bleeding that led to his second hospitalization in a week, his doctor said today.

LEAD: If the old homestead doesn't look quite like a castle anymore, remodeling might be the answer, or perhaps it's time to look for a new place. Either way, the Government has booklets that can help.
LEAD: A report in the Advertising Column of Business Day on Monday incorrectly reported the new position of William S. David. He has been named publisher of Sports Afield.
LEAD: Americans took out $4.66 billion more in credit than they paid off in August, the biggest rise in consumer debt in 10 months, the Federal Reserve said today.

LEAD: Toby Rowland-Jones, a former caterer and fund-raiser, decided that the Bay Area needed a calendar of charity fund-raising events. So, about a year ago, he began to publish a magazine called Benefit using a computer in the basement of his home.

LEAD: A supertanker caught in a storm in the Gulf of Alaska last weekend spilled about 15,000 barrels of Alaska crude oil into the sea 200 miles west of Canada's Queen Charlotte Islands, the United States Coast Guard said today.
LEAD: Little new information was available yesterday about the situation in Tibet as telephone and telex communications were interrupted and travel there by foreigners was banned.
LEAD: New Company and Play

LEAD: Inflation rose by almost half in Latin America last spring, according to the International Monetary Fund, with annual rates topping 100 percent for the third world's three biggest debtors - Brazil, Mexico and Argentina.

LEAD: American consumers' confidence in the economy rose to the highest level in almost 15 years in September as people were cheered by the declining jobless rate, the Conference Board said yesterday.

LEAD: Under harsh criticism from members of Congress and advocates of the elderly, the Reagan Administration today backed away from its plan to substitute telephone hearings for face-to-face hearings in most disputes involving Medicare benefits.
LEAD: Talks aimed at ending the 25-year-old civil war in Guatemala got off to a shaky start here today, nearly stalling after only a few hours.

LEAD: Jane C. Murray, director of communications and development for the Alan Guttmacher Institute, died of cancer of the pancreas and liver Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 48 years old.
LEAD: POLYURETHANE foam in pressure cans is a relatively recent product that home and apartment dwellers should know about.
LEAD: To borrow a phrase from Dickens, it has been the best of times and the worst of times for Joe Biden.

LEAD: The Howard Hughes Medical Institute announced $45.5 million in awards yesterday under a new 10-year program that will eventually provide $500 million for education in the medical and biological sciences.
LEAD: BASEBALL

LEAD: At nightfall, when the sun slips behind the tall maples and hickories on Long Mountain, George Clahr can amble out to the dirt road in front of his 200-year-old farmhouse and hear nothing but crickets, tree frogs and the gurgling of a nearby stream.

LEAD: The small number of countries that do not participate in international competition has diminished and is continuing to do so. Bulgaria competed this year for the first time, and the Soviet Union remains almost the only absentee.

LEAD: The Rockland County Legislature unanimously endorsed in principle Tuesday a proposal to suspend the 1988 property tax by using, instead of tax revenues, a $50 million surplus accumulated in the last four years. The suspension will come up for a formal vote when the county budget is considered in December.
LEAD: Both sides claimed victory today after Mayor W. Wilson Goode and former Mayor Frank L. Rizzo called each other liars and worse in the only televised debate of the mayoral campaign.

LEAD: The magic that moves Mexico has worked its wonders again. A political system strained by six years of economic stagnation, high inflation and a dramatic drop in the standard of living of millions has nevertheless emerged successfully from a crucial test. For the 10th straight time in more than half a century, political power is to be transmitted peacefully and on schedule.
LEAD: Debt

LEAD: While the Knicks continued their feverish efforts to make changes for the coming season, Bernard King said he was keenly disappointed that the first of those changes appears to have brought his once-brilliant career with the team to an end.

LEAD: Seven Texas businessmen were indicted by a Federal grand jury here today on charges of participating in a scheme that gained more than $100 million from five savings and loan associations through the use of fraudulent real estate loans.
LEAD: Grant Adams, deputy chairman and co-founder of Equiticorp Holdings Ltd., was named chairman of Guinness Peat P.L.C. yesterday, succeeding Alastair Morton, who resigned Monday night.

LEAD: AN estimable young violinist, Leonidas Kavakos, was introduced by the 92d Street Y Tuesday evening in a recital with Anne Epperson, a pianist. He began with the enormous Chaconne from Bach's D minor Partita, and identified himself at once as a player of clean, severe lines, concentrated energy and secure technique.

LEAD: More than 160 people were killed Tuesday night and today in a series of attacks by ethnic Tamil guerrillas in Sri Lanka, prompting India to warn that its forces would use ''all the force at our command'' to stop further violence there.

LEAD: Compagnie du Midi, a French insurance company, appeared certain to take over Equity and Law Life Assurance Society P.L.C. after making a bid worth $:457 million, or about $750 million. The British life insurer welcomed the offer, Christopher Brocksom, its chairman, said.

LEAD: A debate here today among the six Democratic Presidential hopefuls, organized by the party to emphasize unity, turned instead into a fierce argument over military policy and over how Democrats should conduct their Presidential campaign.

LEAD: Don't be too supportive of the uprising in Tibet, the State Department insists, for it comes just as China has been easing a tradition of repression. Reacting to Congressional condemnation of Beijing, the Reagan Administration points out that too much empathy for the Tibetans and too little for China's policy will undercut that moderation.

LEAD: Good for Jim Wright, who rejects the Reagan Administration's demands on Nicaragua as ''ridiculous'' and as evidence that ''someone advising the President is trying to torpedo the peace process'' haltingly under way in Central America.

LEAD: President Reagan today declared a major disaster in Southern California, ordering Federal aid for temporary housing and opening the way for grants and low-interest loans for reconstruction of homes and businesses.

LEAD: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua said yesterday that he was willing to consider the withdrawal of all Soviet and Cuban military aid if the United States agreed to negotiate directly with his Government.

LEAD: ''THE HEALTH CENTURY'' finds medical research at work in different places -creating new parts for the human body, for example, or listening to the songs of male canaries. The four-part series, which marks the centennial of the National Institutes of Health, celebrates 100 years of health care.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: MARIO VILLA, a Nicaraguan who is now based in New Orleans, is a 33-year-old architect who combines metals in the chairs, tables, lamps and cabinets he designs. ''Furniture From New Orleans,'' a display of his work, opens today at the Gallery of Applied Arts.

LEAD: Administration strategists conceded today that Judge Robert H. Bork had no chance of winning confirmation to the Supreme Court, and, despite a plea from President Reagan to keep fighting, the judge told supporters he might ask for his nomination to be withdrawn before it reaches the Senate floor.

LEAD: * American Standard Inc., a supplier of air-conditioning, heating and plumbing equipment, announced that Richard H. Francis had resigned as senior vice president and chief financial officer. James C. Huntington Jr. will replace him.

LEAD: Kara Ulizio, 11 years old, and her brother Ryan, 10, looking for their grandfather's name on a plaque that was unveiled last night during a ceremony at the Sheraton Centre Hotel. Their grandfather, James J. McElroy, was killed covering the Battle of Iwo Jima in 1945. The ceremony was attended by correspondents and photographers who covered World War II, Korea, Vietnam and other conflicts.

LEAD: Scientists have found evidence that a gene long associated with cancer development in laboratory experiments is activated in lung cancer tissues and, in its active state, may be a factor in development of the malignant disease.

LEAD: All members of Congress would mark one date on the calendar if they could. That is the elusive date for adjournment for the year. At the start of each session, their leaders set a target date, which is rarely met. This year it was early October, but all hope for that goal was abandoned long before the summer recess.
LEAD: The Legal Aid Society has charged serious violations of prison and hospital standards in the care of jail inmates at the Bellevue Hospital Center's psychiatric unit.
LEAD: Herbert A. Steinberg, a portrait painter and muralist, died of a heart attack Sunday in Exeter, N.H. He was 59 years old and lived in Roosevelt, N.J.

LEAD: Thirty-five more players - including some of the National Football League's top performers - broke ranks with striking teammates yesterday to rejoin their clubs in time to play this weekend's games.

LEAD: MUSIC TODAY, Gerard Schwarz's series that opened its seventh season Tuesday night at the Merkin Concert Hall, offers a valuable alternative to most other Manhattan new-music forums. It is certainly no wild-eyed ''downtown'' presentation. But it is also more deliberately conservative than the fiercer uptown contemporary-music groups.
LEAD: Ceramics Exhibit
LEAD: The Economy

LEAD: A Congressman, remembering a Massachusetts family killed in a house fire caused by a cigarette eight years ago, proposed legislation today that would require tobacco companies to manufacture only ''fire-safe'' cigarettes.

LEAD: John McCarthy, a former senior vice president of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, died yesterday in London, where he was undergoing treatment for cancer of the throat. He was 55 years old and had been living in Porto Ercole, Italy, since his retirement a year ago.
LEAD: A former Washington lobbyist for the Wedtech Corporation pleaded guilty yesterday to a misdemeanor corruption charge stemming from his efforts to give a Federal official $10,000 in cash.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Scientists have assembled a map of genetic signposts covering all 23 pairs of human chromosomes, an accomplishment that foreshadows a new era in the study of human heredity and the search for genes that contribute to many serious diseases.

LEAD: When Don Baylor, that 38-year-old, ambulatory brick building, came to the plate with the game on the line in the bottom of the eighth inning tonight, it wasn't too much to expect that he might try to win it not so much with his bat as with his body. It wouldn't have been the first time. The score was 5-5 in this first game of the American League championship series, and the bases were loaded with one out when Baylor was called in by the Twins' manager, Tom Kelly, to do damage.

LEAD: The Data General Corporation announced an usual alliance yesterday with the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, the Japanese communications giant, to jointly develop a digital switching technology for sale in the United States and Japan.
LEAD: Jimmy Springs, who was lead singer of the Red Caps for three decades, died Sunday. He was 75 years old.

LEAD: Keith Miller, the Mets' second baseman, underwent surgery yesterday to repair ligament and tendon damage to the little finger of his right hand. Miller is expected to begin therapy next week. He was recalled from Tidewater on June 16, but injured the finger sliding into third base during his first game and was placed on the disabled list June 29.
LEAD: Let's meet by the Musial statue, at the corner of Broadway and Walnut, an hour and a half before the game.

LEAD: The opposition of Southern senators to Judge Robert H. Bork reflects a crucial political reality in the region: the electoral fortunes of many Southern Democrats depend on overwhelming support from blacks.

LEAD: SINCE his return to the American concert stage in 1985, Vladimir Horowitz has become a documentary perennial. ''Vladimir Horowitz, the Last Romantic,'' celebrated his first recital in the United States in more than two years. His much publicized visit to the Soviet Union was commemorated on television in ''Horowitz in Moscow.

LEAD: The Bechtel Power Corporation of San Francisco and the Consumers Power Company of Jackson, Mich., said today that they had agreed to establish a joint venture to own and operate the Palisades nuclear power plant in South Haven, Mich.
LEAD: Margie Lynn Inman, who performed on the wings of airplanes in her youth and later battled local officials for the right to live in a lean-to with a menagerie of pets, has died at the age of 76.

LEAD: The Economic Scene column in Business Day last Friday misstated the range at which advocates of gold, like Robert A. Mundell of Columbia University, believe that its price should stabilize. The range is $400 to $500.

LEAD: Bobby Joe Young of Steubenville, Ohio, has been replaced as a welterweight challenger against Lloyd Honeyghan of Britain to avoid a clash with the World Boxing Council, British promoters said yesterday. Honeyghan's defense, scheduled for Oct. 28, was to have been held under International Boxing Federation rules at a time when the rival W.B.C.

LEAD: Some of 75 drums that were discovered yesterday in a truck parked on Chrystie Street. The street was closed until 6 P.M. while the drums, which contained nitric acid, paint waste, adhesives, phosphoric acid and other chemicals, were removed. The truck was stolen last month and recovered in Paterson, N.J., but its cargo was not inspected until yesterday.

LEAD: The Strategic Air Command announced today that crew ejection systems in all B-1 bombers will be inspected before each plane is allowed to fly again, suggesting that a flaw was found after a crash in which three aviators died.
LEAD: The BankAmerica Corporation said today that it would sell $350 million of new securities to Japanese financial companies, an action that will strengthen the ailing bank.

LEAD: Walt Frazier, the former Knick guard who was inducted into the Basketball Hall of Fame this year, will serve as analyst on selected Knick cable television and radio broadcasts over the Madison Square Garden network this season. Frazier will discuss the Knicks' opponent and game strategy as the pregame studio guest of Greg Gumbel, the broadcast host, on telecasts.

LEAD: An obituary of Bob Fosse on Sept. 24 misstated, in in some editions, his involvement with the musical ''How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying.'' It was Abe Burrows who directed the Broadway production; Mr. Fosse choreographed it.

LEAD: MUSIC critics, looking back fondly to those dear departed decades in which they enjoyed, for all practical purposes, a four-month summer vacation, can often be heard lamenting the end of the seasonal divisions of New York's musical life.

LEAD: One of every six men at Wagner College plays football for the Staten Island school. That is not a ratio typical of successful programs and not just at the large Division I schools with huge student bodies but also at the Divison III level where Wagner plays.

LEAD: The board of directors of the Negro Ensemble Company has named Leon B. Denmark producing director of the 20-year-old theater group, the chairman, Lucius P. Gregg, announced this week.

LEAD: ''Mr. Reagan is attempting to rewrite the plan in accordance with U.S. interests. He is now in open confrontation with the Central American presidents.'' - President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua. [ A12:1. ]

LEAD: Charles A. Atkins, the New York financier accused of engineering one of the largest illegal tax shelter conspiracies in history, was described by prosecutors yesterday as a man who descended into a ''world of fraud'' because of his own ''greed and lies.''

LEAD: Reports on Capitol Hill have it that the White House is planning to nominate James H. Burnley 4th, the Deputy Secretary of Transportation, to succeed his former boss, Elizabeth Hanford Dole, as Secretary.
LEAD: Eleven members of one of the nation's largest marijuana smuggling rings have pleaded guilty to drug charges and more indictments are pending, a Federal prosecutor said Tuesday.

LEAD: THE small group of investors that took over New York's Bowery Savings Bank have cause to celebrate. Less than two years after spending $100 million to acquire the once-troubled Bowery, the owners will double their money by selling the savings institution to H.F. Ahmanson & Company of Los Angeles for $200 million.

LEAD: THE collaboratively choreographed dances of Eiko and Koma have never been action-packed spectaculars. Rather, each work by these Japanese dancers has contained only a few carefully chosen images evoking the forces of nature and the struggles of life. One of the sparest of all their productions is ''By the River,'' which they presented Tuesday night at the Kitchen.

LEAD: From the start, the idea has captured the imagination of aerospace scientists around the nation: an experimental craft, perhaps a successor to the space shuttle, that takes off like a plane and booms into space at hypersonic speed.
LEAD: A national chain of business schools said yesterday that it had hired a new spokesman, the Rev. Jesse Jackson, who is also a candidate for the Democratic presidential nomination.
LEAD: Cedric Phatudi, who rejected South African Government attempts to make his tribal homeland of Lebowa an independent nation, died today. He was 75 years old.

LEAD: Political advertising, which was lent new prestige and allure by President Reagan's campaign in 1984, is again drawing Madison Avenue image makers away from selling soft drinks and computers and into a Presidential race.
LEAD: For a writer, freelancing can be a frustrating, uncertain and unprofitable effort, but, occasionally, it provides a windfall. The odds are perhaps a little better for a freelance hunter.

LEAD: A longshoreman's union official was cited for contempt of court yesterday and ordered to appear for questioning into whether union funds are being illegally channeled to a former union leader, Anthony M. Scotto.

LEAD: The Rev. Peter J. Halligan, a Maryknoll priest who was a missionary in Peru for 33 years, died of a pancreatic disease Sept. 30 in Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 63 years old and lived in Lima, Peru.

LEAD: And speaking of the Saatchis -these days it seems difficult not to -Weidenfeld & Nicolson, a London book publisher, has just brought out ''The Saatchi & Saatchi Story,'' written by Philip Kleinman. Mr. Kleinman, a member of London's advertising trade press, is editor of the World Advertising Review.
LEAD: Marge Schott, the Cincinnati Reds' owner, says she intends to retain Bill Bergesch, the general manager, and Pete Rose, manager, for 1988 but she expects better results.

The more we learn about the characters and their problems, the more we want to know. In varying degrees, however, each of the Goodwater Theater

LEAD: ONE year it was sedums, and another it was alliums - 19 kinds of the former, and 14 of the latter. From time to time, I like to plant several species within one genus close to one another, so I can get to know them as a group, observing the similarities and differences, much as one observes the same things in a family of people.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Dr. Frank Jobe, the Los Angeles-based orthopedic surgeon who performs operations on most ailing Dodger baseball players, had a busy day Tuesday at Centinela Hospital Medical Center in Inglewood, Calif. He removed cartilage from the right knee of Orel Hershiser, the pitcher; from the back of the left shoulder of Dave Anderson, the shortstop; from the front left shoulder of George Hinshaw, a minor-league outfield prospect, and examined Ken Howell, the pitcher, before performing a bone scan on his right shoulder today.
LEAD: The Democratic National Committee today resolved its fierce dispute with Minnesota and South Dakota over the scheduling of their nominating contests.

LEAD: President Reagan said today that he would fight for $270 million in renewed aid for the Nicaraguan rebels that would continue until a cease-fire is in place ''and full democracy is established.''

LEAD: LONDON has more major resident orchestras than New York, but they are organized differently from the New York Philharmonic - more like the American Symphony, which is made up of freelancers who gather together with considerable but not absolute consistency from concert to concert and go off to other jobs in between.
LEAD: George Garvy, a former vice president and senior adviser of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, died Tuesday at his home in Manhasset, L.I., after a long illness. He was 74 years old.

LEAD: SHOPPERS along Columbus Avenue have been briskly buying up oversize chrysanthemum plants at the Korean fruit and grocery markets in the neighborhood. The sidewalks outside the markets are flooded with the intense colors of the plants, which are the size of small bushes. The chrysanthemum, a symbol of autumn's arrival, comes in taxicab yellow and a range of Victorian mauves.

LEAD: LASERS flashed. Spotlights swiveled. U.F.O.-shaped light trusses swooped across the stage. Surreal film clips lighted up a circular screen. And, incidentally, Pink Floyd played new and old songs Monday at Madison Square Garden, opening a sold-out three-night stand; the show goes to the Brendan Byrne Arena in East Rutherford, N.J., Saturday through Monday.

LEAD: The Rev. John Urban, who was kept alive for nearly 11 days by an artificial heart before receiving a human heart and kidney, died after multiple organ failure Tuesday at the Milton S. Hershey Medical Center of the Pennsylvania State University. He was 51 years old. Mr. Urban was the third recipient of the Penn State artificial heart.

LEAD: PEOPLE have asked Neesha Nicks if she sees double, if she writes upside down, if she runs backwards when playing sports. Friends at the public school she used to attend even asked her if her dyslexia was catching.

LEAD: The opening of the new Stephen Sondheim-James Lapine musical ''Into the Woods'' has been postponed. No date has been set for the new opening.

LEAD: HBM/Creamer, a subsidiary of the WCRS Group of London, is selling its Providence, R.I., office to Potter Hazlehurst of East Greenwich, R.I., effective Nov. 1. HBM/Creamer has a large Boston office and has been troubled by account conflicts with Providence. The Rhode Island office ended last year with about $17 million in billings but has had some account losses since then.

LEAD: Warning that ''the spirit of NBC is being sapped'' by the longest strike in the network's history, Tom Brokaw and 15 other NBC news correspondents sent a letter yesterday to the president of NBC urging him to end the strike.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: This morning, just one day before the season opener, Phil Esposito, the Rangers' general manager, ventured into the locker room of his club's training facility to tell the 24 players who survived camp that they had indeed made the team, and only by playing themselves off it would they lose their foothold here.

LEAD: TENNIS Lozano Upsets Mayotte: Jorge Lozano of Mexico upset second-seeded Tim Mayotte, 6-4, 6-3, yesterday in the second round of the $303,400 World Championship Tennis Scottsdale Open in Arizona. Sixth-seeded Kevin Curren and seventh-seeded Eliot Teltscher both won. ''I just didn't play very well,'' said Mayotte, the 15th-ranked men's player in the world.

LEAD: Talley Industries said it plans to sell its apparel and clock-making operations to focus on its aerospace, industrial and real estate businesses. The company said the restructuring would result in an unspecified loss for the year, its first in five years. After a 30-minute halt in trading today on the New York Stock Exchange, Talley stock rose 87.5 cents to close at $22.625.

LEAD: She stands like an urban seductress, San Francisco does, a stunningly beautiful city of steep hills on the bay, attracting newcomers like a Venus flytrap. They come, they stay, even with the knowledge that the city sits atop a seismic time bomb that could explode into a fearsome earthquake at any time.

LEAD: Westchester County and a not-for-profit agency headed by Andrew Cuomo, Governor Cuomo's son, proposed today a plan that would ease the county's homeless crisis while later providing housing for the elderly.

LEAD: For a decade, Frederick Brodsky has represented a half-dozen wealthy families from around the world on investments in the United States. Now he is broadening his business through a joint venture with Elders Finance, a leading Australian company.
LEAD: Former President Constantine Tsatsos, a philosopher who was head of state from 1975-80, died today, his former secretary said. He was 88 years old.

LEAD: New York City police officials, shaken by the murder of a crime witness after a death threat against her had been reported to the police, said yesterday that they would adopt comprehensive guidelines for handling reported threats.

LEAD: Randy Wood broke a 1-1 tie with the second goal of his National Hockey League career, and the Islanders held the Los Angeles Kings to one shot on goal in the third period for a 4-1 victory tonight.

LEAD: The unexpected death of Joseph B. Flavin has thrust William F. Schmied into the top posts at the Singer Company but he said there would be continuity of management policies.

LEAD: THE recent flurry of takeover proposals in the retail industry has proved of fleeting interest to investors. The stocks of three target companies - Dayton Hudson, Zayre and Alexander's - rose on the takeover announcements but have lost value in the last few days.

LEAD: A member of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today that a bid made this week by the Ford Motor Company to acquire the struggling Financial Corporation of America ''is not an attractive option'' because it would cost the Government too much money.

LEAD: Since the attack on the frigate Stark in May, there has been a series of clashes involving United States forces in the Persian Gulf . Here is a list of key incidents. May 17 - The Stark, a United States Navy frigate, is hit by two missiles fired by an Iraqi plane, and 37 American sailors are killed.

LEAD: Pergolesi's ''Stabat Mater,'' in a performance conducted by Alberto Zedda and directed by Roberto de Simone, will be presented tomorrow at 8 P.M. and Sunday at 3:30 at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine (112th Street and Amsterdam Avenue). The performances are part of the Italy on Stage festival.

LEAD: Representatives of several unofficial Moscow political clubs took a halting step onto the official stage tonight, appearing at a news conference sponsored by a Government press-feature syndicate in an odd, sanctioned show of political independence.

LEAD: ''THREE O'CLOCK HIGH,'' which opens today at Loews New York Twin and other theaters, is as well made as a film about a schoolyard showdown can be. It's even better made than that, which is precisely the problem. The director, Phil Joanou, has turned every shot into a portentous marvel, from the close-up view of an earring going into an ear to the 360-degree spin around the schoolyard as the nice-guy hero (Casey Siemaszko) awaits his dreaded confrontation with the mean-spirited bully (Richard Tyson).

LEAD: Mayor Dick Hackett easily defeated five challengers today to win a second four-year term in office. With 98 percent of the city's precincts reporting in the nonpartisan election, Mr. Hackett had 96,021 votes, as against 36,626 for his closest challenger, City Councilwoman Minerva Johnican. Ms. Johnican, who is black, had made a campaign issue of a police shooting in which four white officers killed an emotionally disturbed black man.

LEAD: RICHARD SERRA as a sculptor can be all delicacy, all nuance, all finesse. Few things now on view in New York are as subtle as his ''Even Level'' at the Pace Gallery. It is built with two identical beams of hot rolled steel. They measure 72 inches by 8 by 4. One of them sticks out from the wall at an angle of 90 degrees and a height of 6 feet, give or take a few inches.

LEAD: WASHINGTON - A significant crack has opened in the official stance on third world debt. The major international lending agencies now admit that some very poor, very weak developing countries cannot service their debts and simultaneously resume economic growth. The agencies are asking industrial country governments to forgive debts outright, and commercial banks to accept some inevitable losses.

LEAD: A Federal appeals court yesterday upheld a lower court ruling that ordered a change in the structure of the New York City Board of Estimate because it violates the constitutional principle of one-man, one-vote.

LEAD: Crown Prince Akihito and his wife, Crown Princess Michiko, as they viewed the newly opened Japanese Gallery at the Metropolitan Museum of Art yesterday. With them were Yasuko Betchaku, right, associate curator of Asian art, and behind her, Luers Williams, president of the museum. The royal couple are on a 17-day tour of the United States and are scheduled to meet with President Reagan.

LEAD: ''Raphael and his Circle,'' an exhibition of more than 90 drawings by the Renaissance painter and his closest followers, opens today at the Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street. The show runs through Jan. 3.

LEAD: The Mets let Jeff Reardon get away in a deal they would prefer to forget. The bearded relief pitcher and Dan Norman were traded in 1981 to the Montreal Expos for Ellis Valentine. But now the Minnesota Twins have Jeff Reardon after a deal with the Montreal Expos they almost let get away. And he is the primary reason why Sparky Anderson, the Detroit Tigers' manager, acknowledged that the Twins have the better bullpen in this American League Championship
LEAD: Michael J. Babcock, who was named president and chief executive of the Hooker Corporation's Bonwit Teller unit on Sept. 1, has taken a step up in Hooker.

LEAD: A man with a police record and possible ties to organized crime was shot and killed on a Brooklyn street yesterday afternoon by two gunmen who fled in a car. The police said the killing was similar to a series of gangland-style murders in Brooklyn in recent months.
LEAD: William McCaw, a former deputy comptroller of the United Nations, died of cancer Sept. 26 at his home in Southbury, Conn. He was 80 years old.

LEAD: IT'S difficult to imagine anyone's remembrance of World War II as idyllic, but it's not impossible. In John Boorman's radiant ''Hope and Glory,'' the autobiographical hero is a young boy of just the right age, humor and sensitivity to savor the adventure of which he finds himself a part.
LEAD: Bargainers for the General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers reached agreement on a tentative new labor contract today.

LEAD: The Fourth Annual Hellenic Cultural Festival will be held from 6 to 11 tonight, and from noon to midnight tomorrow through Monday, at Public School 85 on 29th Street, between 23d Road and 24th Avenue, in Astoria, Queens. There will be a traditional taverna, serving Greek foods, as well as a pastry booth and additional stands with regional specialties.

LEAD: As if the brilliant fall panorama were not enough, Dutchess County arts organizations plan to greet Hudson Valley explorers this weekend with a cultural extravaganza, as nature and the arts join forces.

LEAD: Larry Spector, one of the founders of Calet, Hirsch & Spector Inc., the New York advertising agency, died Wednesday at the North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 58 years old and lived in Kings Point, L.I.

Numerous analysts and brokerage houses echo his enthusiasm. The superlative tossed out by David Hale, chief economist at Kemper Financial Services, is ''profitflation.

Rutigliano, 54 years old, said that when Single was athletic director at Northwestern University, he had offered him the head coaching job.

The procedure was performed by Dr. John Bonamo, the Yankee physician, at New York University Medical Center.
LEAD: The Reagan Administration today liberalized the rules for illegal aliens seeking amnesty under the new immigration law and predicted that at least 100,000 aliens would benefit from the change.

LEAD: American helicopter gunships sank three small Iranian patrol boats near the center of the Persian Gulf tonight after at least one Iranian vessel opened fire on a patrolling helicopter, the Pentagon said. At least two Iranians were killed. The American helicopters were not damaged, and there were no American casualties, the Pentagon said.

LEAD: Jim Abbott, the University of Michigan pitcher who was born without a right hand but was an outstanding hurler for the Wolverines and for Team USA last summer in the Pan American Games, received the Golden Spikes Award yesterday as the nation's outstanding amateur baseball player. Abbott, a 20-year-old junior from Flint, Mich., who dreams of winning the College World Series with Michigan and of pitching in the 1988 Olympic Games, was honored by the United States Baseball Federation at the Downtown Athletic Club.

LEAD: The Rev. Jerry Falwell and the entire board of the troubled PTL television ministry resigned today, asserting that a ruling by a Federal bankruptcy judge had made it impossible to rebuild the ministry.

LEAD: Burlington Industries plans to sell three industrial fabrics divisions under a restructuring aimed at helping pay off debt incurred when it went private in a $2.5 billion leveraged buyout, the company said. LEAD: A valuable piece of real estate -227 acres of wooded land draped over a rocky ridge that runs across northern Princeton, N.J. - has, for the last decade, seemed to defy development.
LEAD: The Rangers entered this season with a brand-new coach and an opening-night cast that featured only nine returnees from the squad that inaugurated the 1986-87 season.

LEAD: SPECIFIC places, at specific times of year, have always been key to the methods and the manners of Eric Rohmer's splendidly singular comedies. In ''My Night at Maud's,'' the wintry, non-picturesque streets and chilly apartments of the city of Clermont-Ferrand had the effect of prompting characters to argue long into the night, as if to stay out of cold, lonely beds.
LEAD: Pat Robertson, a Republican Presidential contender, said today that he had sown plenty of wild oats as a youth but that Jesus Christ had changed his life and forgiven him.

LEAD: Although Kenny Walker has been on the Knicks' roster for almost a year, he remains a considerable unknown. He was the team's first-round draft pick in 1986, a respected prospect from Kentucky who was known for his diligence and hard work. But a succession of injuries to his back and hamstring limited him to sporadic appearances last season - 68 largely forgettable games - as he struggled to cope with playing with pain.
LEAD: A Senate study asserts that the Government has failed to interview a number of defectors from the Soviet bloc and elsewhere who could provide valuable insights about their native countries.
LEAD: Hiram Walker Inc., has decided to give its advertising for Canadian Club whisky to the Chicago office of Eisman, Johns & Laws of Los Angeles. Billings are expected to be around $7 million.

LEAD: A BETTER title for ''Dogs in Space'' might have been ''Sid and Nancy Meet the Secaucus Seven.'' This is a story about 60's survivors in 1978, drugged-out musicians who look and sound as if they're straight from the 80's. The large cast of men and women live in a communal house in Melbourne, a 60's relic where garbage fills the fireplace and huge joints are passed around.

It will join such Welsh Publishing Group winners as Muppet, Barbie and He-Man and the Masters of the Universe magazines and, of course, will carry advertising.

LEAD: AFTER 13 years and 50,000 chivalrous hand pecks to the ladies, Sirio Maccioni is still wowing them. A consummate impresario and choreographer, he is forever refining his international act known as Le Cirque. Like any showman riding a long-run hit, the Italian-born owner brings changes to his production ever so carefully.

LEAD: George R. Swift Jr., a former sailboat racer for the Vanderbilts and the Morgans, died Wednesday at his home in Asheville, N.C., after a long illness. He was 68 years old. Mr. Swift, a member of the New York Yacht Club for most of his adult life, was manager of Luders Marine Construction Co. in Stamford, Conn., from 1935 until 1952.

LEAD: The Carnegie Deli, the Seventh Avenue emporium whose very name evokes certain alimentary truths about New York City, has opened a branch on the edge of Washington's Beltway, in a northern Virginia suburb.

LEAD: DESPITE last Sunday's devastating snowstorm north of New York City, the colors of the changing fall foliage survived in almost every wooded area, presenting opportunities for a day's outing in the Hudson Valley by bus or train, as well as by car.

LEAD: Derek Bailey, Roulette, 228 West Broadway, at White Street (219-8242). Free improvisation, not tied to any idiom but the connection of sound to sound, has one of its most articulate champions in Derek Bailey, an English guitarist who rarely performs here. Mr. Bailey makes his guitar generate noise rather than melody - clinks and scrapes, bongs and crackles, an occasional chord - but from those noises he builds music with its own moment-to-moment drama.

LEAD: Golf Mahaffey Leads on Birdies: John Mahaffey sank long birdie putts on his last two holes yesterday to cap a five-under-par 66 and take the first-round lead in the Pensacola Open. The 16-year PGA Tour veteran had seven birdies and made putts of 30 and 20 feet on his last two holes to take a one-shot lead over Bobby Cole, Jeff Sluman, Phil Blackmar, Danny Edwards and Trevor Dodds on the 7,154-yard course at the Perdido Bay Resort.

LEAD: THERE once was a time when musicians, dancers and actors confined themselves mainly to theaters and concert halls, auditoriums and nightclubs. But, in the age of outdoor happenings and offbeat ''performance spaces,'' performers have seemingly usurped every conceivable nontheatrical nook and cranny.

LEAD: The publisher and editor of Greece's second-biggest newspaper were sentenced to two months in prison today for printing material obtained from an illegal wiretap of the Athens bureau of The New York Times, a court spokesman said.

LEAD: Washington's Supreme Court today ordered a trial on some aspects of bondholder suits against the Washington Public Power Supply System, its professional advisers and others involved in the system's $2.5 billion bond default on two defunct nuclear power plants.

LEAD: There seemed to be no obvious front-runner today as Justice Department officials, outwardly vowing to fight on with Judge Robert H. Bork's apparently doomed nomination for the Supreme Court, sifted names of other possible nominees.

LEAD: In this era of daringly trendy reinterpretations of the ''Ring,'' there ought to be room for a brilliantly untrendy one. Despite a slow start, the Metropolitan Opera could be building just such a welcome oddity, judging by the premiere performance last evening of ''Das Rheingold.'' The promise that was never quite delivered last season by a somewhat confused ''Die Walkure'' was fulfilled in this stylistically coherent new production.

LEAD: As long as ''Fire From the Mountain'' stays close to Omar Cabezas's notable book, subtitled ''The Making of a Sandinista,'' the documentary makes a forceful case in behalf of the Nicaraguan revolution. Firing off news clips that document Mr. Cabezas's vigorous prose, the movie, which plays at 6 o'clock tonight at the New York Film Festival, contrasts the poverty of Nicaragua's campesinos with the gaudy display of the Somoza set that ruled the country for decades.

LEAD: This week's sharp new violence in Sri Lanka has forced India to shift its position dramatically in the island's long ethnic conflict and side militarily with the Colombo Government. After years of sympathizing with ethnic Tamil rebels, India now appears ready to train its own guns on them.

LEAD: The Defense Department, complaining that it will be able to launch even fewer military payloads from the space shuttle than it had expected, is planning a major expansion of its capacity to launch medium and heavy satellites with its own rocket fleets, officials said yesterday.

LEAD: The Irving Bank Corporation formally rejected the Bank of New York Company's takeover offer yesterday and, in a move to foil the bid, said it would issue options to its shareholders that would allow them to buy stock in the acquiring company at half the market price.

LEAD: The fall foliage is deceptively beautiful here this weekend. Beneath a canopy of crimson and gold maple leaves is a carpet of fallen trees, broken limbs and downed power lines, the legacy of the sudden, devastating snow storm that struck last Sunday.
LEAD: The State Health Department identified yesterday where it will collect blood samples for a large-scale test to measure the extent of the AIDS epidemic in New York.
LEAD: Perhaps the Devils were inspired tonight by the song, ''Catch Fire,'' which was played during their introductions for the season opener at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena.
LEAD: Pat Robertson, a Republican, is the latest Presidential candidate to run afoul of a torpedo that has already sunk two Democratic candidacies and shaken another: truth.

LEAD: The Cooper Companies, formerly known as Coopervision Inc., said today it had signed a letter of intent to sell its contact lens solution business to the Ciba Vision Group, a subsidiary of Ciba-Geigy Ltd., for about $155 million. Sale of the unit, which is expected to be completed by Nov. 30, does not include Coopervision's worldwide contact lens business.
LEAD: Eleanor M. Johnson, founder of My Weekly Reader, which was first published on Sept. 21, 1928, died Thursday in Gaithersburg, Md. She was 94 years old.

LEAD: The bodies of six murder victims will be exhumed from a rural cemetery this weekend so that autopsies can be performed to confirm the cause of their deaths, J. E. Blinn, the Webster County Coroner, said today.

LEAD: The acclaimed family-entertainment series ''Wonderworks'' returns to WNET tomorrow evening at 7 with a lovely adaptation of the Katherine Anne Porter short story ''The Fig Tree.'' Calvin Skaggs is the director and the co-executive producer, along with Patricia Perini of the Texas station KERA-TV. Mr.

LEAD: The Communications Satellite Corporation and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company said they had agreed on a plan for future use of Comsat's international satellite capacity for overseas telephone traffic. The agreement proposes to eliminate the Federal Communications Commission's role in deciding how to split transmission of A.T.&T.

LEAD: President Reagan's description of James H. Burnley 4th as ''easygoing'' and ''congenial'' brought chuckles throughout Washington's transportation circles, for the nominee to be Transportation Secretary has a reputation for being strong-willed, aggressive and, at times, stubborn.

LEAD: THE YEAR 1927 WAS WHEN LONdon theater-goers turned on that enfant terrible, Noel Coward, heckling two of his new plays into premature oblivion. It was the year Rodgers and Hart's ''Girl Friend'' arrived from Broadway, and everyone seemed to be humming ''My Heart Stood Still,'' the song they'd contributed to a West End revue called ''One Dam Thing After Another.

LEAD: SOME YEARS AGO, YOU MAY OR may not remember, hard-nosed skeptics throughout the musical world diverted themselves immensely by making fun of a British medium named Rosemary Brown. An amateur pianist, she had entered into communication with Mozart, Liszt, Beethoven and others of like fame, all of whom transmitted posthumous works and sometimes friendly messages through her.
LEAD: AT THE ONSET OF AU-tumn, life turns indoors, and in anticipation of long evenings of music, many listeners tantalize themselves with thoughts of a new sound system.

LEAD: HE is the ''Charles Raymond of the 1980's,'' said a sales broker in describing David M. Evenson, a 37-year-old home builder in this town of 10,000 people near the Mississippi River, two miles north of the city of La Crosse, Wis.
LEAD: Seven interceptions stymied Texas, and Oklahoma raced to a 44-9 rout today behind Jamelle Holieway and Lydell Carr.

LEAD: EVERY workday 3.4 million people converge on Manhattan in movement so massive that the city's transportation commissioner, Ross Sandler, says it can only be compared to the tides. It falls to Mr. Sandler to smooth out the eddies and maintain the flow as best he can. That task has grown progressively harder since the mid-70's, when the number of commuters started to climb.

LEAD: Penn State ran up a 28-7 lead on Rutgers today and then relaxed. But Scott Erney kept throwing the football for the Scarlet Knights and put a little fear into the mind of Joe Paterno, the Nittany Lions' coach.

LEAD: Mary Elizabeth Daly, an account executive at Margeotes, Fertitta & Weiss Inc., an advertising agency in New York, and Dwight Frederick Norrgard, the vice president of Sea Safety International, a ships' supply company in Hoboken, N.J., were married yesterday at the First Congregational Church in Old Greenwich, Conn.

LEAD: Frank Lusk, a member of the Central Park Model Yacht Club, preparing model of the Clearwater, a Hudson Rover sloop, yesterday in centrl Park. In background were other boats being sailed by members of the club. (NYT/Keith Meyers)
LEAD: TURN-OF-THE-CENTURY CABARET Paris, Barcelona, Berlin, Munich, Vienna, Cracow, Moscow, St. Petersburg, Zurich. By Harold B. Segel. Illustrated. 418 pp. New York: Columbia University Press. $30.

LEAD: I REMEMBER it was 2 A.M. I had just come home from a date and was very thirsty. Everyone was sleeping. I opened the refrigerator and saw this glass of orange juice. I gulped two fast swallows and realized this was not orange juice, but unsettled chicken fat my mother had placed in the ''icebox'' after cooking chicken.

LEAD: To the Editor: Regarding the request for information on touring Madagascar (Q & A, Aug. 9): Having just returned from a two-week tour of Madagascar (visiting scientists from the Duke University Primate Center on a lemur preservation project), I feel I am able to offer some suggestions.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: FROM THE TIME HE FIRST ELEC-trified the New York art world with a series of paintings consisting of black stripes on raw canvas, Frank Stella has been an artist who always seems to be working on the leading edge of contemporary art. The black-stripe paintings of 1959 were avatars of Minimalism; the mid-70's series of painted reliefs called ''Exotic Birds'' heralded the return of decorative painting; the increasingly three-dimensional series that have followed have spoken to grafitti art and neo-Expressionism, among other trends.

LEAD: I WONDER IF ALL EFFECTIVE THEA-ter pieces, serious or otherwise, aren't in some way musical underneath. It's easy enough, for instance, to hear - and even to see - the quiet, stabbing, funny counterpoint that helps build Alfred Uhry's ''Driving Miss Daisy'' to such a touching climax.

LEAD: This opening was particularly important because the President has tried vainly for almost seven years to persuade Congress to enact his views on such ''social issues'' as abortion and school prayer. Mr. Reagan saw Judge Bork as a justice who would push the Court toward positions that Congress had repeatedly rejected.

LEAD: Jeffrey Leonard made playoff history tonight when he hit his fourth home run in four games and led the San Francisco Giants to a 4-2 victory that squared their series with the St. Louis Cardinals at two games apiece.

LEAD: Up, up and away went the prime rate, as banks raised the key barometer to 9 percent, from 8 3/4. The increase was the fifth so far this year, and, although it was expected, it still sent a chill down the spines of the people who had been thinking about borrowing money. Short-term interest rates have been on the rise - indeed, yields in the bond market have been at or near two-year highs - and the prime has followed suit.

LEAD: In recent years, Alan Ayckbourn has found an American theatrical home at the Alley Theater in Houston. That regional company has produced seven of his plays, only a few of which have been seen in New York. The Alley-Ayckbourn alliance culminated last night with the U. S. premiere of the playwright's newest work, ''Henceforward .
