LEAD: Georgine Fleming Hall, an actress, and David DuVivier, a retired lawyer, were married yesterday at Trinity Episcopal Church in Rocky Hill, N.J., by the Rev. Samuel W. Ishibashi.

LEAD: I'm tired of watching A.L. pitchers embarrass themselves at bat. Let's make it really interesting: when the Series is played at N.L. fields, the designated hitters should be forced to pitch. Just what kind of fastball do you think Bill Madlock has?

LEAD: In recent years, no rivalry in pro football has been more intense than the one between the Giants and the Washington Redskins. Their games have always been bruising, and they have invariably been keys to deciding division and conference champions.
LEAD: A review by Carl Sagan on Sept. 27 identified him incorrectly. He is the author of ''Cosmos'' and ''Contact'' and is writing a book with Ann Druyan about the human past and future.

LEAD: WHEN Nancy Reger decided to become a physical therapist 13 years ago, the emphasis was on rehabilitating stroke and accident victims and using heat treatments and exercises to soothe sore backs and necks. Physical therapy was called ''shake and bake.''
LEAD: A RECORD number of people in the state are seeking licenses to sell real estate and mortgages, even though officials say the housing boom that fueled the increase may have crested.
LEAD: THE state is having second thoughts about a proposal to let a parent choose any surname - like DiMaggio, Hemingway, Reagan or Beethoven - for a child.

LEAD: Cairo's exotic Khan el Khalili bazaar is an obligatory stop for visitors, but not necessarily the best place to spend money. Crowded, cluttered and chaotic, it is a bit like the old New York store S. Klein-on-the-Square, a place where customers must pick through mounds of junk before finding something worth taking home.

LEAD: CHIEF Thomas Rotunda of the Ridgefield police said he knew first-hand Northeast Utilities did not play favorites in restoring power after the snow storm last Sunday that cut electricity to 75,000 residents for up to four days.

LEAD: That Samuel Loring Morison was not a classic spy of the John LeCarre mode has never really been in dispute. But two years ago Mr. Morison, a former civilian naval analyst, was convicted under national espionage laws of disclosing classified documents to the press.
LEAD: What with Bangor's many cultural attractions and nightlife opportunities, Margo Cobb was saying, the citizens find little time for late-night television.
LEAD: BACK TO SCHOOL Starring Rodney Dangerfield (in photo), Sally Kellerman, Ned Beatty, Burt Young, Robert Downey Jr., Adrienne Barbeau. Color. 1986. HBO Video. 96 minutes. $25.95.

LEAD: There is a sense of energy and purpose these days on this incongruous campus of pink Spanish-mission-style buildings with red-tiled roofs deep in the heart of Flushing, as Queens College prepares to celebrate its 50th anniversary today.
LEAD: PURSUING a livelihood in America is increasingly a family enterprise, where success is no longer measured by the earning power of a single job.

LEAD: LAST weekend I secreted myself in a country hideaway three hours north of Manhattan to experience firsthand the joys of photographing fall foliage. First it rained. Then it snowed. Then it snowed some more.

LEAD: Four educators interested in becoming New York City's next schools chancellor sought the support of Hispanic educational groups at a forum yesterday where the overriding concern of the audience was that the seven-member school board has no Hispanic members.

LEAD: An article on Corona, Queens, on Sept. 27 omitted Our Lady of Sorrows Roman Catholic School, at 35-23 104th Avenue, in listing the neighborhood's parochial schools.

LEAD: A HOT DEMAND for jobs has risen in the Pacific Northwest in the wake of the push to clean up hazardous-waste dumps and base waste consulting companies there. Also encouraging this search for technicians, scientists, geohydrologists and biological engineers is the expectation that Washington State will soon pass stiff laws governing toxic materials.

LEAD: At the Roman Catholic Church of Christ the King in New Vernon, N.J., Kathleen Ann Clancy, a daughter of Dorothy Clancy of Morristown, N.J., and Richard J. Clancy of Boston, was married yesterday to Hallett R. Gates 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gates Jr. of New York and Lyme, Conn. The Rev. James Mahoney performed the ceremony.

LEAD: It shouldn't! Last week's great pitching duel between the Blue Jays' Flanagan and the Tigers' Morris was a typical game that magnifies why the d.h. is wrong. Just imagine the intricacies that were lost in that big game alone.

LEAD: Bill Whittington stood in the field, rocking slowly in his boots, and watched the big John Deere cotton picker heave down the snow-white rows. Once the picker had roared past, he studied the sinewy stalks. Bending down, he yanked a clump of cotton off one of them. ''The picker's missing some,'' he said.

LEAD: A Copious Marketplace At Van Cortlandt The Marketplace at Van Cortlandt Manor in Croton-on-Hudson is in full swing in celebration of the fall colors today and each Saturday and Sunday through Oct. 25 from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Browsers and buyers will find a country scene with fresh farm produce, breads, preserves, woven willow baskets and handcrafted items such as stained-glass ornaments, hand-stenciled scatter rugs, wooden welcome signs and Blue Sponge and Rinney Pottery.

LEAD: Like many other cities around the nation, Chicago is riding the crest of a boom in downtown investment. New office buildings, new stores, new residents and whole new neighborhoods are being added at a record pace to the heart of America's third-largest city.

LEAD: Industry is deeply divided over pending legislation that would require the identification, notification and medical counseling of workers exposed to a high risk of cancer and other disease on the job.

LEAD: A SUMMONS TO MEMPHIS, by Peter Taylor. (Ballantine, $4.95.) The story of Phillip Carver, called to Memphis by his sisters to stop their widowed father from remarrying, won the Pulitzer Prize. As in his past works, Peter Taylor writes about the ways we use conventions and manners to circumscribe the world, making it an easier, if duller, place to live.
LEAD: IN his three-day visit to New York last week, President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua evinced the air of a man watching events play out to his satisfaction.

His words serve aptly to capture the sometimes uneasy but always respectful tone of the 15 essays in LE CORBUSIER (Princeton University, Paper, $19.95; Garland, Cloth, $60), edited by H.

LEAD: Movie titles that don't ring an immediate bell can often slip past the most diligent readers of lengthy program listings, along with some worthwhile diversions. Take ''It.''

LEAD: ALL'S FAIRS As if one full-fledged, traditional fair - the Long Island Fair at the Old Bethpage Village Restoration - wasn't enough this weekend, here comes the Riverhead Country Fair today to entice suburbanites with a taste of what used to be in really rural America. So from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M., the parking lot at the Peconic River will be the scene of the customary fair activities - old-fashioned contests like spelling bees (and one new-fangled mini-marathon), rides, games, exhibits and, naturally, agricultural competitions.

LEAD: For five years in a row, more than 90 percent of the young men and women enlisting in the armed forces have been high school graduates. Sergeants and generals alike argue that this the best evidence that the ranks can be filled with good people without a draft.

LEAD: THE director of a chamber-music ensemble retained by the New Jersey Historical Society has uncovered several obscure works from the Federal period, some of which probably have not been heard since about the time their composers died.

Lieberman of Yonkers.

LEAD: FIVE KIDS ARE CROWDED into a dank, low-vaulted cellar that resembles a tomb, two of them hunched over electric guitars, a third in tight zebra-striped pants and a sweat shirt that reads ''Community College.'' A fourth youth straddles a tarnished set of drums, a fifth is wrestling with the stem of a long black mike and screaming in a voice like a cymbal.
LEAD: IT'S ALMOST a game to open a book calling itself ''New Jersey'' and wonder how it will differ from the hundred or so others (including a novel) bearing the same title.

LEAD: To the Editor: I wish to alert travelers to Thailand about a recent credit card scam in which I was a victim.

LEAD: PRISCILLA FERAL of Norwalk is the national president of Friends of Animals Inc., a 30-year-old organization that advocates animals rights. Initially started to address the growing problem of stray cats and dogs, the group now also concerns itself with the protection of wild animals and laboratory animals.
LEAD: WHILE million-dollar houses make up only ''a thin slice of the market,'' the market is there, says Henry J. Paparazzo, and he is prepared to build for it.
LEAD: A proposal to make affordable health insurance available to all Massachusetts residents has met heavy resistance from state legislators, who call the proposal too expensive and unwieldy.
LEAD: Eight Indian soldiers trying to capture and disarm ethnic Tamil guerrillas were killed in violent incidents in Sri Lanka's Jaffna Peninsula today, according to the Sri Lanka authorities.
LEAD: What a gutsy, judicious thing to do.

LEAD: EVERYONE WHO HITS BOTTOM seems able to pinpoint the moment it happened. Mine occurred during an agitated depression a year and a half ago. I woke up one night obsessively aware of the gun that lay in a box under my bed and of my desire to place that gun in my mouth and pull the trigger.

LEAD: THE GOOD NEWS for workers in New England is that salaries and wages are rising rapidly; the bad news, for their employers, is that there are generally not enough able bodies to fill job openings.

LEAD: A legislative committee has voted unanimously to recommend repealing a unique law that raises tuition for foreign students attending state colleges.

LEAD: THIS SERIES OF photographs is from the book ''Athletes,'' edited by Ruth Silverman (Knopf, $35), to be published Oct. 21. Its focus is the art of sports photography, and the images are mostly from museums and galleries.

LEAD: Like many of the desk-bound of this world, Thomas Simmons seems determined to take gratuitous risks (motorcycles being chief among them), just to be sure he's alive (About Men, ''A Sense of Drama,'' Sept. 13). Too bad he can't teach his son to take risks for a stronger purpose than joy-riding -risks such as working construction, joining the Peace Corps, or living on the edge of poverty - for a dream.

LEAD: At the Episcopal Christ Church Christiana Hundred in Greenville, Del., Susan Gray Crittenden, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Dwight Crittenden Jr. of Wilmington, Del., was married yesterday to Michael Vactor Chambers, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Shearer Chambers of Cos Cob, Conn. The Rev. Adam Lewis, the church's rector, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Dublin, Limerick, Killarney, Galway and even the oft-maligned Cork all possess signal Irish charms.

LEAD: FROM Claudio Arrau to Pinchas Zukerman, the great musical artists of the world appeared regularly with the White Plains Symphony Orchestra, which was founded in 1961 as the Music for Westchester Symphony Orchestra. Now the 25-year legacy has ended. Less than two weeks before what should have been next Saturday's opening concert, a terse press release announced that the board of directors, ''with regret,'' had voted to cease operations.

In London he might have outfitted you for the City, but in Cork the effect would be more the rakishness of J.

LEAD: SOUPS for early fall that take advantage of the continuing harvest of vegetables and herbs should also be hearty and well-flavored. The three suggested here comply with these requirements.

LEAD: I am puzzled that the case of the St. Louis high school newspaper was ever granted an appeal (''From Hazelwood to the High Court,'' by Mark A. Uhlig). Calling a public-school publication a ''public forum'' is sheer varnish. Do pupils buy the newspaper or is it subsidized by the board of education?

LEAD: OVERLOOKING the World War II invasion beaches of France, I stood and contemplated how differently I viewed war now that I was the mother of two boys.
LEAD: ''CRAFT and business'' is frequently discussed, but rarely from the viewpoint of how crafts fit into the overall economy.

LEAD: SKILL and experience are far more important in most outdoor pursuits than the quality -and cost - of the gear used. However, most of us who camp, canoe, fish and hunt are to some extent enamored of equipment, and the possession, care and maintenance of a nearly perfect tool can be a deeply satisfying part of sport.

LEAD: Thomas Simmons's celebration of life at the edge carries the implication that the rest of us are leading tame, backwater lives. For a person whose mind and senses are open, a ''sense of drama'' and ''joy in action'' are everywhere: running down a country road, watching a flower unfold or watching a cat play with its tail.
LEAD: LONG ISLAND'S foreign trade compares favorably with that of most regions in the country. Even so, the subject has become an issue in the campaign for Suffolk County Executive.

LEAD: FEW amenities add more charm to the setting of a home than a well-tended street tree or two lining the curb. On a densely built city block with only tiny front yards, a street tree can also provide welcome privacy from neighboring houses and a shield from the hot summer sun.

LEAD: THREE years ago, when Carol and Elaine Anthony presented their first show as a tribute to their father, they were surprised at the response. But since then, the show has become a tradition, both for them and for viewers who find it helps them to feel close to their own fathers.

LEAD: MANY ANALYSTS are offering a cautious glimmer of hope for the Southwest as its recent downward employment spiral hits bottom. However, some disagreement exists as to how soon a significant upswing might occur - a few months or a few years. ''We've probably started to turn some kind of corner,'' said Nicolo Santangelo, chief of the economic analysis and information office of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics office in Dallas, ''and we should start to see the first reason for optimism in the next couple of months.

LEAD: KIRK Buckner, a 14-year-old farm boy who had never been in trouble, went to his grave branded a mass murderer. And it is one of the apparitions in this town's nightmare that he might always have been remembered that way.

LEAD: PATRONS at Sullivan's Tap, in the shadow of the Boston Garden, were settling down on a June day last year to watch their beloved Celtics on television when agents from the Massachusetts State Revenue Department burst in, snapped off the T.V. and, before anyone could say ''Red Auerbach,'' shut Sullivan's for tax evasion.

LEAD: AS CORPORATE AMERICA restructures itself to meet the needs of a changing marketplace, career opportunities for science and engineering graduates have waned considerably over the last three years.

Anthony Lukas) reveals as a positive contribution toward peace a proposal for which Adlai Stevenson was viciously attacked and almost driven from his post as chief delegate to the United Nations.

LEAD: ALL MY TRIALS. By John William Corrington. (University of Arkansas, Cloth, $22.95; Paper, $10.95.) He is Albert Sidney Johnston Finch, a recent widower and a retired Louisiana judge whose nostalgic vision of his hometown makes clear the route that John William Corrington (the author of ''Shad Sentell'' and other novels) has chosen to follow here.

LEAD: THE latest guest conductor in the New York Philharmonic's young season is Kurt Sanderling. Mr. Sanderling is a German who apprenticed under Furtwangler, Klemperer and Kleiber in the 1920's but who also spent a third of his life in the Soviet Union. His program at Avery Fisher Hall on Friday afternoon seemed a convergence of these experiences.
LEAD: Iraqi warplanes attacked a ship in the Persian Gulf today, and Iraq said its jets hit an air base and three oil centers in Iran after a powerful explosion shook the Iraqi capital.
LEAD: Penn, the defending Ivy League football champion, scored 25 second-half points to rally from an early 17-0 deficit and stun Brown, 38-17, today at Franklin Field.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. George L. Payne Jr. of Ridgewood, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Leslie Payne to Edward J. Gerrity 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerrity Jr. of Rye, N.Y. A February wedding is planned.
LEAD: Re the article on Hewlett's struggle for a fence alongside a stretch of railroad tracks [ ''Hewlett Seeks Fences Near Railroad Tracks,'' Sept. 6 ] :
LEAD: When are men like Simmons going to grow up? I read ''A Sense of Drama'' and could feel my stomach turn with disgust at yet another example of today's ''I-gotta-be-me'' mentality.

LEAD: ONE day this summer, Lewis S. Ranieri had one of the best jobs on Wall Street. The next, at the instigation of Salomon Brothers' chairman John H. Gutfreund, Mr. Ranieri was out; out as vice-chairman of the powerful company and out of Salomon Brothers altogether. The 40-year-old Mr. Ranieri went home with millions of dollars and a reputation as a brilliant competitor that he earned in 21 years as Salomon's rising star.

LEAD: At the San Onofre nuclear power plant 60 miles south of here, the severe earthquake that killed six people in Southern California last week was a mere rattle, barely strong enough to be felt by the personnel and not nearly enough to interrupt the reactors' operations.

LEAD: WHETHER you love chamber music or prefer the full-spectrum sound of the symphony orchestra, you have a difficult choice to make Saturday: the Vienna Chamber Trio and the Abegg Trio of Germany are playing in Ossining and Tarrytown respectively, and the season opener for the Westchester Symphony has been scheduled that same evening.

LEAD: UNEMPLOYMENT RATES have been a puzzling indicator of economic health in the Rocky Mountain West during the last year. In Idaho, Montana, Wyoming and Colorado the number of people out of work has dropped, but state labor specialists do not call the change an improvement. Meanwhile, Utah's unemployment rate inched upward to 6.6 percent in August, though John Mathews of the Utah Department of Employment Security sounds more optimistic than his counterparts.

LEAD: AFTER all the gloomy predictions that heavy summer traffic would cause an increase in flight delays, a report last week by the Federal Aviation Administration came as a surprise. LEAD: CHINA REPORTING An Oral History of American Journalism in the 1930s and 1940s. By Stephen R. MacKinnon and Oris Friesen. Illustrated. 230 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $20.

LEAD: The United Nations peacekeeping force in southern Lebanon faces what could be a crippling financial crisis as a result of moves in the United States Congress that threaten to cut off all American money for the operation, according to United Nations officials and diplomats.

LEAD: Robert Reich (''The Expanding Economic Vista'') is to be commended on his excellent history of the commerce clause's 200 years.

LEAD: Ideally, the bashful, solitary giant pandas should be seen on their own turf, in the remote bamboo forests of central China. But even scientists have difficulty finding the reclusive and increasingly rare animals.

LEAD: IN WHAT is believed to be the first suit filed under a year-old state statute, the former national sales manager of a Japanese-owned electronics company in Mount Laurel has asserted he was dismissed for complaining about defective computer parts that the company knowingly shipped to dealers and sold to the public.

LEAD: If a middle-age Soviet literary gentleman wears a pinkie ring, likes to hang out in SoHo, and wants to have an international crime-writers clubhouse in New York City, can he possibly be an officer in the dread Soviet intelligence agency, the K.G.B.?

LEAD: ALTHOUGH poorly sealed windows generally are touted as the greatest source of heat leaks in an insulated home, weatherstripping a main entrance door can have the same effect as sealing several windows.
LEAD: A teacher has brought a legal challenge to being removed from his classroom because he has AIDS.
LEAD: A charter fishing boat carrying 61 people caught fire in the Atlantic Ocean today, forcing everyone to jump overboard. But all were rescued by other vessels, the boat's captain said.
LEAD: ONCE A CATHOLIC Prominent Catholics and Ex-Catholics Reveal the Influence of the Church on Their Lives and Work. By Peter Occhiogrosso. 371 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $18.95.

LEAD: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission is halting its review of plans by the Philadelphia Electric Company to restart the Peach Bottom nuclear plant because the company has not shown it can prevent operators in the control room from sleeping on the job.

Palmer of Cedar Rapids, Iowa. Miss Cologne and her fiance both graduated from Iowa State University.

LEAD: ON THE SET OF EACH NEW movie he produces, Michael Hausman hangs a sampler stitched with the words: ''All mistakes happen in preproduction.'' He remembers doing so with trepidation in the case of ''House of Games,'' the psychological thriller that closes the New York Film Festival tonight.
LEAD: Seven years after the first scruffy Greens elbowed their way into the stodgy world of West German politics, the environmentalists are finding that success can be the bane of radical politics.

LEAD: SOMETIMES the late 1980's seem to be the late 1960's turned inside out. Consider folk-rock. In the 1960's, it was a commercial hybrid; in the late 1980's, it has become the style of choice for iconoclasts, nonconformists and oddballs. Foremost among them is R.E.M., a band from Athens, Ga., whose asymmetrical, often obscure songs are so tuneful and its concerts so galvanizing that the band is fast reaching the mainstream pop audience almost despite itself.

LEAD: Robert Kiley, chairman of New York's Metropolitan Transportation Authority, and David Gunn, Transit Authority president, deserve appreciation and applause. They have shown municipal agencies everywhere how to deliver an essential service.

LEAD: Massachusetts will become the first state to require insurance companies to pay for all medical treatment of infertility.

LEAD: In your special issue, you neglected to discuss the relationship between the United States Constitution and the American Indian. Indeed, you failed even to mention this problematic aspect of United States history. Your oversight was irresponsible and inexcusable. MARK S. WEINER Stanford, Calif.

LEAD: For at least one of the teams playing along the northern end of the New Jersey Turnpike, the football strike ended last week. Not for the Jets or the Giants, but certainly for the Minutemen of Elizabeth High School, who play in the shadow of the oil refineries near Exit 13.

LEAD: A way to improve standard tests is to correctly identify the recipients of the scores. The Connecticut Mastery Tests should be called Tests for Teachers When teachers use tests as curriculum goals, they invariably begin to teach to the test. The test results become the evaluation of effective teaching.

LEAD: ONE problem for cosmetic dentists has been that patients have trouble visualizing the results of cosmetic alterations - and often back off because of uncertainty. Dentists are hoping computer technology can ease those doubts.

LEAD: In the name of scientific inquiry and local tourism, two dozen sonar-equipped boats are patrolling the slate-gray waters of Scotland's largest lake in search of that most enduring of natural mysteries, the Loch Ness monster.

LEAD: TWO new members of the county's Rent Guidelines Board have their work cut out for them: they have four weeks to listen to 10 to 12 hours of tapes from four noisy public hearings so they can vote on new rent levels on Nov. 4.

LEAD: Frank Aikman Jr., president of the Long Island Rail Road in one of its most turbulent periods, died of cardiac arrest Wednesday at the Kimball Medical Center in Lakewood, N.J. He was 77 years old and lived in Lakewood.

LEAD: In a letter to the Long Island editor headed ''How Sweet It Isn't'' [ Sept. 20 ] , Ebinger's is taken to task for providing ''large quantities of sugary, pasty, greasy 'goodies'.'' The Brooklyn-based bakery also made a product much appreciated by our family.

LEAD: The Food column (''Seafood of the Desert,'' Aug. 30, by Susan Herrmann Loomis) was an unintentional parody of the trendy invasion that has turned much of the Southwest into a wasteland of tourists and yuppies. Although real food can still be found in Santa Fe and northern New Mexico, it seems The New York Times would not care to say so.

LEAD: An article July 26 on Bay Ridge incorrectly described its two Lutheran schools. The Lutheran Elementary School of Bay Ridge and Leif Ericson Day School both cover nursery through eighth grade. The article also omitted one private school, Adelphi Academy.

LEAD: THE Silicon Valley has cooled off as California's occupational hot spot. Today, Los Angeles leads the nation in creating new jobs, and the fastest-growing job category in the state is for secretaries. New job opportunities will remain abundant in the nation's most populous state, which added 350,000 jobs last year, according to a report by M/PF Research Inc., of Dallas.

LEAD: The police yesterday identified the driver of a car service who was beaten to death with baseball bats on Staten Island Friday night.

LEAD: TRYING to get a fix on the $9 billion-or-so car rental industry is like carving an ice statue on a hot day. You can do it - but it's not going to hold its shape for long.

LEAD: ONE hot summer night not long ago there was at the window near my pillow a sudden racket. I leaped from the bed and grabbed a petrified stick I keep behind the door. ''Who is it? What do you want? Get out of here!'' I shouted. My wife awakened, startled. There was no answer from the outside, just the same strange noise.

LEAD: IN his 1975 novel ''The Autumn of the Patriarch,'' Gabriel Garcia Marquez imagined a Latin American despot so aged that he was ''older than all old men and all old animals on land or sea.'' To Latin Americans familiar with Juan Peron, Alfredo Stroessner of Paraguay or Arnulfo Arias of Panama, among others, the portrayal was less a fantasy than a deft rendering of an all-too-familiar prototype.

LEAD: Golf Palmer Closing In: Arnold Palmer moved a step closer to his first victory in 28 months on yesterday, knocking in two eagles eagles in shooting a 67 for a four-stroke lead after the second round of the $250,000 Senior Challenge in Roswell, Ga. The 58-year-old Palmer, who shot an opening round 66, was at 133, 11-under-par entering today's final round for the $37,500 first prize.

LEAD: IN the Samuel Beckett play, ''Waiting For Godot,'' the central characters await the arrival of a special person - who never comes - while they watch the world pass by. The analogy with United States manufacturing management is startling. Manufacturers are waiting for new technology that will make them competitive in the global market without any risks or modifications in the way they currently do business.

LEAD: Sicilian desserts are the kind that children might dream up. Thick, rich and sugary sweet concoctions made with unstinting proportions of cream, sugar, chocolate, fruit and nuts, all oozed into crispy pastry rolls, spread onto spongy layer cakes or hidden inside soft pastry pockets. Then there are the mounds of buttery cookies, the fooled-you marzipan lookalike fruit and vegetables, the ice mountains of fruit- or coffee-flavored granitas, and ice cream that barely begins with vanilla, chocolate and strawberry.

LEAD: The story goes that the Pleasant River, a narrow strip of water not much bigger than a stream, once was so full of Atlantic salmon that a fisherman could walk across the river by stepping on the backs of fish.
LEAD: Army ran out of time when a pass fell incomplete in the end zone at the final gun, and heavily favored Boston College hung on for a 29-24 victory today.

LEAD: Your special issue of The New York Times Magazine (''The Great Voyage: Two Hundred Years of the Constitution,'' Sept. 13) could not have appeared at a more opportune time for us. On the following day we became naturalized citizens of the United States. We consider ourselves very lucky to become citizens during a month of such historical importance to the United States.

LEAD: Carol Jean Worley, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert D. Worley of Brookside, N.J., and Thomas Edwin Swaim, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David G. Swaim of Leonia, N.J., were married yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in Mendham, N.J.
LEAD: A proposed memorial to Vietnam veterans in a small but historic park here has divided neighborhood residents and the project's supporters.
LEAD: The official residence of the Anglican Archbishop of Cape Town is not hard to find.

LEAD: Hopatcong $124,000 1 Wildwood Shores Drive 2-bedroom, 1 bath, 30-year-old ranch; enclosed porch, cathedral ceiling in living room, w/b stove; taxes $1,615. Maplewood $225,000 45 Courter Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2 bath, 45-year-old colonial; fireplace, patio, den, 2-car garage; taxes $3,380.

LEAD: The case of Guarini vs. New York may have lacked the emotional impact associated with courtroom custody battles, but it was undeniably a monumental dispute. It ended last week when the United States Supreme Court denied a claim by two Garden State politicians that New Jersey, not New York, should have sovereignty over Liberty Island and the statue thereupon of Miss Liberty.
LEAD: About 4,000 refugees from the civil war in El Salvador returned home today after years in Honduras.
LEAD: THERE will be three United States teams taking part in the world team championships beginning today in Jamaica. Two of them will be on the sidelines for the first nine days.

LEAD: Soviet and American officials boast that they are near agreement on banning chemical weapons. Ridding the world of these repulsive weapons would truly represent progress for humankind. It is far from clear, however, that the ban can be effective and verifiable - even though the two sides now accept provisions for on-site inspections.

LEAD: Kathleen Louise McNamara, a daughter of Francis J. McNamara Jr. of Darien, Conn., and the late Noreen E. McNamara, and Robert John Hugin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Hugin of Lakewood, N.J., were married yesterday at St. John's Roman Catholic Church in Darien.
LEAD: Clifton, usually a group title contender in New Jersey high school football, took on the familiar role yesterday when it overcame Nutley, 15-12, in a battle between unbeaten teams at Nutley.

LEAD: The superiority of authentic National League baseball is obvious through scrupulously objective observation. Baseball fans everywhere should have access to the game free of the vulgar intrusion of past-prime, variously ailing half-athletes who have profited much from, but contributed nothing to, the splendor of the game.

LEAD: DO you dream of having a cover-girl smile? Dr. Jeff Golub of New York can create one for you. Or he can give you the smile of a barracuda - as he recently did for a film actor playing a cannibalistic visitor from outer space.

LEAD: Practical women have rediscovered new versions of the glamourous suits that Hollywood designers inspired in the 1940's. Today's suits have long jackets, subtle shaping and are cut from sturdy men's suiting material, such as a birdseye pattern in worsted.

LEAD: A Washington dispatch last Sunday about an American group's recommendations on Soviet relations carried an incorrect title supplied by the group for B. William Mader of Time magazine. He is a deputy chief of correspondents.

LEAD: MAKING his first cuts as the Knicks' head coach, Rick Pitino yesterday trimmed his crowded training-camp roster by three players. Gone are Elmer Anderson, a 6-foot-2-inch guard from St. Bonaventure; Richard Mudd, a 6-9 forward from Michigan State, and Howard Triche of Syracuse, a 6-5 swingman. They were made expendable by the signing Friday of Rory Sparrow, who reached a one-year agreement for $350,000, a large cut from his previous salary, and Ron

LEAD: IN THE ENGLISH-SPEAKING OPER-atic world, we use the expression ''bread and butter repertory'' for the works without which theaters would have to close their doors, but ''aglio e olio repertory'' might be more apt, since most of them are Italian. A lot has changed in style, standards and repertory over the last few decades, but the Italian perennials are still basic.
LEAD: ON a visit to Tibet this summer, Robert Thurman watched as the Chinese authorities took truckloads of Tibetan children hundreds of miles away for schooling in other parts of China.
LEAD: REPRESENTATIVE Bernard Dwyer, Democrat of Edison, has introduced legislation that could make a cottage industry out of alternative housing for the elderly.

LEAD: I suppose the simplest solution would be for the home team to select the rules of play. That should be equitable as long as the rules remain vaguely recognizable to the visiting team.

LEAD: WHEN Brian Fox converted what had been a pornographic movie theater into an art cinema in 1979, not many people thought he would succeed because of the location - on Washington Street in South Norwalk.

LEAD: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi says he welcomes the United States Congress's recent vote to suspend aid to Pakistan because of concern about that country's nuclear program, but he rejects Washington's proposal for a treaty between India and Pakistan banning nuclear weapons.
LEAD: With the opening of a string of radio stations free of central government control, Greece is liberalizing its broadcasting laws, eroding a state monopoly that has existed for decades.

LEAD: Kevin Enterlein completed a school-record 26 passes in 50 attempts for 322 yards and two touchdowns to lead Pace to a 27-22 upset of St. John's in a Liberty Conference game yesterday in Pleasantville, N.Y. Enterlein connected on an 8-yard scoring pass to Rob Fehrenbach and a 60-yarder to Alphonso Scott on the final play of the opening half as the Setters (1-2, 2-3).

LEAD: At the Princeton University Chapel, Cynthia McCollum, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Wayne McCollum of Etna, N.H., and John Thomas Spellman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Spellman Jr. of New Bern, N.C., were married yesterday by the Rev. William K. Fuller, an Episcopal priest.

LEAD: At Christ the King Roman Catholic Church in Los Angeles, Maria Victoria Montgomery, a daughter of Mrs. Michael Montgomery of Los Angeles and the late Mr. Montgomery, was married yesterday to Jeffrey Alan Sarnoff, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Sarnoff of New York.
LEAD: ''No one likes higher interest rates, but it is a necessary part of the process to prevent upward pressure on prices.'' - Lyle E. Gramley, chief economist, Mortgage Bankers Association.

LEAD: LAST winter, a company that makes a machine for quickly measuring how much cholesterol people have in their blood offered tests for $3 in downtown Indianapolis and at four suburban shopping centers. To the company's surprise, as many as 30,000 customers showed up.

LEAD: Like many unreconstructed English majors, I have a weakness for literary pilgrimages, a form of travel based on the principle that homage must be paid to genius. So I have found myself at Ernest Hemingway's house in Key West, Mark Twain's boyhood haunts in Hannibal, Wordsworth's cottage in the Lake District and Karen Blixen's house on the outskirts of Nairobi.
LEAD: Two major American companies are battling the Government for the right to launch communications satellites on Soviet rockets.

LEAD: THE 275 cartons of cheese delivered to the Long Beach City Hall one recent Thursday were not intended as a gift. On the contrary, they came from the local branch of an angry antipoverty agency that wanted to drive home a point.

LEAD: The play will become a footnote or a trivia question in future accounts of the 1987 American League pennant playoff, but today it might have served as the catapult that thrust the Minnesota Twins to the threshold of the World Series.

LEAD: THE Brooklyn Museum has never even approached completion of its original master plan, designed in 1893 by McKim, Mead & White. But last year it held a competition for a completion on more modest lines. The museum's decision on how to treat its 1930's lobby will indicate how far the pendulum is swinging away from orthodox modernism.
LEAD: A toxic rocket fuel component that the Air Force is shipping by truck around the country threatens a ''Bhopal on our highways,'' an environmental group has charged.

LEAD: In discussing regional market trends, Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics, said: ''I don't like to hear people in Westchester talking about growth problems. The problems of growth are easier to deal with than the problems of decline. I know many other communities that would love to change places with Westchester.

LEAD: TWENTY YEARS AGO, WHEN China began a decade-long descent into the violent political madness of the Cultural Revolution, Chen Zuohuang graduated from the high school attached to the Central Conservatory of Music and was shipped to a village near Shijiazhuang, 175 miles southwest of Beijing, to plant rice.

LEAD: The Democratic Presidential campaign of Representative Richard A. Gephardt has had some encouraging developments in recent days, with valuable endorsements and the elimination or wounding of some competitors.

LEAD: The American Civil Liberties Union has filed a Federal lawsuit in an effort to stop the city's practice of allowing Roman Catholic nuns and priests to ride free on buses and streetcars.

LEAD: DESPITE the football strike, Bristol did some Monday morning quarterbacking last week, analyzing a surprise announcement that a Pennsylvania-based company was closing the 141-year-old Lake Compounce amusement park. Meanwhile, city officials responded to the withdrawal by revoking the company's tax breaks and tallying up a bill of $250,000.

LEAD: A half hour went by, but Jeff Reardon did not move. He sat alone in the trainer's room, his mind still occupied with the eighth inning and the home run that had landed somewhere in the upper deck. He watched its flight for only a moment, and then he turned away quickly.

Rabbi Martin Zion and the Rev. Gwen Buehrens, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Americas Society in

LEAD: I hope Yale Kamisar's faulty comparison of AIDS testing with illicit drug testing, dragnet searches at airports and regulatory searches for health and safety violations will be cautiously avoided by those with judicial power (''Drugs, AIDS and the Threat to Privacy''). A person harboring the AIDS virus has not committed a criminal act by virtue of being infected, and, furthermore, poses no risk to other individuals who themselves refrain from unsafe behavior.

LEAD: The d.h. ought to be eliminated not only from the World Series but also from the American League regular season as well. If for no other reason than it isn't fair to compare the earned-run averages of current A.L. pitchers with those of the N.L. and past American League pitchers.

LEAD: Trips to Disney World challenge parents. ''Your whole sense of values gets turned upside down,'' said Betsy Davis of Demarest, N.J. ''You see a sign that says there's only a 45-minute wait for this ride, and you rush over to get into the line. Forty-five minutes! You get into this maze, and around the corner you see there are ten thousand people in line ahead of you.
LEAD: A fishermen's group is hiring an independent ''sound keeper'' to watch over Connecticut's coastal waters and ''bring a lot of pressure, including lawsuits,'' against polluters.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Tobey J. Nemser, a daughter of Joan Cooledge of Arlington, Mass., and the Rev. Rudolph Nemser of Moorestown, N.J., and Gregory Tang, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Chung L. Tang of Ithaca, N.Y., were married yesterday at the Unitarian Church in Winchester, Mass. The ceremony was performed by the bride's father, minister of the Unitarian Church in Cherry Hill, N.J.

LEAD: The hottest tickets in town have cooled off considerably since the players strike led National Football League clubs to assemble replacement teams of dubious quality. In Denver, where Bronco games have been sellouts since 1971, the club's community relations director, Charlie Lee, came up with a way to avoid acres of empty seats at Mile High Stadium when the Broncos take on the Los Angeles Raiders tomorrow night.
LEAD: The usual rules of hospitality should prevail - the host determines the rules, quite simply. In the A.L. ball park, there will be a d.h. In the N.L., there will not.
LEAD: THE No. 62 bus out of Newark traveled south along Route 1. As it lumbered past the hazy outskirts of factory towns, there was no hint of the life stirring between the smokestacks.

LEAD: OF all the Western-type businesses that Beijing seems to be warming to these days, perhaps the most unlikely is a gaudy nightclub here in the commercial district where cognac sells for $113 a bottle and 1,000 ''hostesses'' sell their services to a pin-striped clientele.

LEAD: AS a chilly rain lashed Reykjavik exactly a year ago, the second summit between Mikhail S. Gorbachev and President Reagan ended in failure. It has taken 12 months to reassemble the pieces that nearly fell into place that weekend. This time around, with more careful preparation, both sides appear to have a more realistic idea of what they want and how to get it.

LEAD: FOR the last few months, Syosset has been buzzing over Mim's, a hip new Manhattan-style restaurant. First impressions include neon, potted palms and old-fashioned wicker chairs in the window. But, 10 feet inside the restaurant, the decor ends and the scene begins. Straight wooden chairs replace the wicker; plants disappear; walls and lighting are stark.
LEAD: HECKLING HITLER Caricatures of the Third Reich. By Zbynek Zeman. Illustrated. 128 pp. Hanover, N.H.: University Press of New England. Cloth, $25. Paper, $14.95.

LEAD: A LAW library where laymen as well as lawyers can look for answers to legal problems is being established in an upstairs room at the Field Library, Peekskill's public library -and the founders raised enough money in three weeks to start it.

LEAD: In a recent essay, ''Improving Standard Tests for Children'' [ Opinion page, Sept. 20 ] , Dr. Nicholas P. Criscuolo, the Supervisor of Reading and Language Arts for New Haven Public Schools, expressed ''support'' for the Connecticut Mastery Testing Program, but concluded that the program needs ''refinement.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The first month of the tax amnesty program in New Jersey has resulted in about $13.9 million from delinquent taxpayers, treasury officials said.

LEAD: The University of Vermont's student newspaper inserted a free condom in 5,000 of its Oct. 1 issues. The condoms were part of a ''safe sex'' package that included two pamphlets, one on venereal diseases, another on AIDS.

LEAD: At the Guardian Angel Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn, Mary Heather Robinson, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Charles W. Robinson of Sharon, N.H., was married yesterday to Scott Lawrence Marks, the son of Peggy Dahl Peeters of New York and Sarasota, Fla., and Donald M. Marks of New York. The Rev. John Baptist performed the ceremony.

LEAD: SCRIPTWRITERS could have a field day with this plot: Two media giants come together to discuss a joint project. The talks fall apart. Each agrees to go its separate way, but then one company hires a key employee away from the other. The battle is on. Both organizations race to get their product out first, and within a week of each other the products are unveiled.
LEAD: NOT all of Saturday's heroes are performing on the gridirons this fall. Some of them are playing the summer game - baseball - well into autumn.

LEAD: President Reagan notified Congress today that the Defense Department would exempt the pay and benefits of military personnel from any cuts that have to be made under the newly revised budget-balancing law.
LEAD: A 2-year-old boy died in a fire in New York City early yesterday morning as firefighting units were delayed in reaching the blaze because of illegally parked cars.

LEAD: Judging from your selection of commentators and Anthony Lewis's comment that finding the Constitution's meaning is ''lawyers' work,'' I was surprised that your bicentennial issue didn't suggest that the Preamble be changed to begin ''We, the lawyers. . . .''

LEAD: In Paris, a candidate for the French presidency asserts that the Nazi gas chambers were ''a historical footnote.'' In London, a new play says the Holocaust was a joint conspiracy of the Zionists and Nazis. In New York City, an institute for ''historical review'' distributes publications that ''prove'' that the destruction of European Jewry is a fabrication of Zionist propaganda.
LEAD: Mark McGowan passed 6 yards for a touchdown to Rich Curtis with 7 minutes 35 seconds left in the third quarter to give Lehigh a 7-6 victory over Colgate today.

LEAD: The Federal Aviation Administration has reported that Trans World Airlines has paid $252,000 to settle a civil action. Federal inspectors had cited the carrier for technical violations of F.A.A. maintenance and operational rules. The penalty, like one of $512,000 against Braniff, is small by comparison with the record $9.5 million penalty that Eastern Airlines agreed to pay earlier this year after a special F.A.A.

LEAD: A German short-haired pointer, Ch. Robin Crest Lorien Corniche, owned by Anthony Attalla and Rita and John Remondi, was named best today in a field of 1,433 dogs at the Palisades Kennel Club Show at Liberty State Park.

LEAD: William Safire's assertion that the war power ''has been wrested back and forth through two centuries, and the answer seems to lie in the inability of either branch to dominate the other'' (''Tug-of-War'') seriously misstates the true nature of the power over war. In fact, as we celebrate our Constitution's bicentennial, the power to initiate and risk war has moved steadily and inexorably into the hands of the President alone.

LEAD: AFTER two years of opposition from homeowners, the real-estate developer Edward S. Gordon has changed his plans for the oceanfront site of the Bridgehampton Racquet and Surf Club, from building an elaborate tennis court enclosure on the property to subdividing it.
LEAD: A notoriously docile generation of college students has found something to protest at a tiny school in Maine: rules barring dormitory visits by the opposite sex.

LEAD: THE games of the great players of yesteryear are primarily useful for inspiration and not absolute truth. Nevertheless, one must beware of rushing to fault the thinking of the titans of the game.
LEAD: I've been organizing a 50th anniversary reunion of the Lindenhurst High School class of 1937. The experience is a mixture of joy, sadness and fear.

LEAD: Columbus Day is Monday, and closings vary. Following are holiday schedules: NEW YORK Parking: Because of Succoth, the Jewish Feast of Tabernacles, alternate-side parking is suspended today and tomorrow; it is also suspended on Monday, for Columbus Day. Parade: Starts at 11:15 A.M.

LEAD: THE horse, a pacer known as Dewey Dynamo, had managed only 1 victory in 21 starts and had been ill for a month with a mysterious ailment. So when it came time for the third race at Freehold Raceway in New Jersey Friday night, his owner-driver, Jim Pfeiffer, didn't bother to waste $2 on a futile bet.

LEAD: LESS than two months after becoming effective in August, a law limiting the cancellation fees that caterers can charge consumers is being reconsidered by the Suffolk County Legislature, a body known to favor regulation.

LEAD: A woman who spent six months in jail for refusing to disclose the whereabouts of her 8-year-old daughter was freed Thursday. A court will investigate her contention that her former husband sexually abused their daughter.
LEAD: A picture caption on page 35 in some copies of the Arts and Leisure section today misidentifies the actor who plays Vincent in the CBS-TV series ''Beauty and the Beast.'' He is Ron Perlman.
LEAD: THE MADWOMAN'S UNDERCLOTHES Essays and Occasional Writings. By Germaine Greer. 305 pp. New York: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $17.95.

LEAD: Some of the early arrivals for today's Princeton-Columbia football game stopped by Jadwin Gymnasium to watch the Nets practice.

LEAD: Pleasantville, continuing a difficult schedule by facing an opponent that had not yet yielded a point in 1987, maintained its own strong season yesterday with a 28-0 shutout of visiting Irvington.
LEAD: IT was a routine Tuesday on Long Island's beaches, when suddenly a deafening noise drowned out the rhythmic sound of the waves against the beach.

LEAD: Road construction projects and unexpectedly heavy weekend traffic combined yesterday to produce some of the worst delays of the year for New York City-bound drivers at the Lincoln Tunnel and its New Jersey approaches.

LEAD: Carolyn Ann Castle and Michael Ottmar Schmidt were married yesterday at the Congregational Church in New Canaan, Conn., by the Rev. Charles Crawford Smith and the Rev. Kermit Morrison, a United Methodist minister who is the bride's cousin.

LEAD: Union officials announced an agreement early today on a new contract for Boston school bus drivers and said the buses would begin rolling Tuesday morning, ending a monthlong strike. William J. Foley, New England district director of the United Steelworkers Union, which represents the drivers, declined to disclose the details of the agreement, but said it was signed immediately by the union and representatives of private school bus operators that serve the public schools.

LEAD: It is a new experience for Americans to live under a Government driven by ideology. We have had activist Presidents, but not ones fastened to a theory. Franklin Roosevelt, the modern exemplar of vigor, was an utter pragmatist. Richard Nixon went to China. Lyndon Johnson urged us to reason together.

LEAD: LAST winter the Detroit Tigers ignored the 29 home runs and 85 runs batted in Darrell Evans produced, looked at his salary instead and decided they were in no hurry to tender him a contract for this year. Evans thus became a free agent, but no one but the Tigers expressed interest in his services.

LEAD: ''YOU don't know what you're in for,'' a friend who had recently renovated her kitchen said. We had just told her that we were contemplating some renovations of our own. ''The contractors are very independent,'' she went on. ''They have so much work these days that after they get started with you they disappear to go on another job and don't show up again for ages.

LEAD: GOING into the 1980's, the dental industry appeared headed for some trouble - brought on, ironically, by its own impressive achievement in helping to reduce tooth decay in this country by 50 percent in two decades. But just as the need for traditional dental work declined, cosmetic dentistry began to flourish.
LEAD: IN THE cavalcade of Sir Noel Coward's stage works - 27 in all - ''Present Laughter'' somehow is not thought to have come out of the top drawer.

LEAD: CARMELLA R. IABONI said she had never realized how many courts there were in New York state until she had to appear in most of them.

LEAD: THE buying and selling of commercial buildings in Manhattan has fallen to its lowest level of the decade, according to real-estate experts. They say that high taxes and even higher hopes have prompted owners to cling to their Manhattan holdings.

LEAD: Mr. and Mr. Frank R. Campanaro of Eastchester, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Christina Campanaro to Tino Juarez, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Abel Juarez of Los Gatos, Calif. Miss Campanaro, a graduate of Skidmore College, is the associate director of advertising and public relations at Oscar de la Renta Ltd.

LEAD: THERE are no illusions either within the Reagan Administration or on Capitol Hill that an embargo against Iranian imports will have a serious economic impact. Since 1981 the United States has bought an average of three per cent of its foreign oil from Iran, and with Iran's attractively low prices and high-quality crude, other customers are certain to come forward and buy.

LEAD: Sloan Taylor Miller and Hardwick Simmons were married yesterday at l'Eglise Paroissiale in St.-Paul-de-Vence, France. The Rev. Thomas E. Duggan, a Presbyterian minister who is pastor of the American Church of Paris, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: FOR a century, the Beaverkill Valley in the Catskills has been a mecca for naturalists drawn by the great floral beauty covering the mountains, for sportsmen attracted by abundant turkey and deer, and especially for anglers who cast into its streams for the maddeningly elusive rainbow trout and then touted the region as a world-class fishing spot.

LEAD: Tennis anyone? Or perhaps golf? County Chamber of Commerce Inc. is sponsoring the first Golden Apple business community golf and tennis outing, to be held Oct. 20, at the Westchester Hills Golf Club in White Plains.

LEAD: AFTER fatally shooting her husband in 1984, Constance Y. Moorehead of Linthicum, Md., was accused of manslaughter, but the charges were dropped. Investigation showed that he had beaten her often and that she had acted in self defense.

LEAD: WITH frenetic ballyhoo, as though the concept were entirely new, the fashion industry has introduced its ''new look'' - a rerun of abbreviated skirts. The fashion-obsessed faithful have flocked to the couture showings, applauded their favorite designers and stampeded to buy their styles, price no object.

When Mr. Waits burst onto the Los Angeles pop scene in the early 1970's, he brought a strong flavor of Beat poetry to the confessional singer-songwriter mode.

LEAD: The state has begun mailing a booklet describing how to avoid AIDS to every household in Massachusetts. It also urges parents not to keep the facts from their children.

LEAD: Use both the d.h. and let the pitcher hit. By doing so, it allows the d.h. to take his spot in the lineup, keeping A.L. strategies intact, while ''old-fashioned'' N.L. baseball would still be a part of the fall classic. Of course, fans would see less of their top- and middle-of-the-lineup favorites, but this would be offset by the inherent fairness to both teams.

LEAD: Hofstra took advantage of Wagner's listless defense in the first half to build a 24-0 lead today, then had to withstand Wagner's relentless offense in the second half for a 35-28 victory in a match of unbeaten teams. The victory gave Hofstra a record of 5-0; Wagner dropped to 5-1.

LEAD: TWENTY YEARS AFTER MARSHALL McLuhan's heyday, and a decade after he might have seemed passe, what he said seems to have come incontrovertibly true. We really do live now in a ''global village'' where nearly everyone - or at least the more sensitive among us, meaning our artists - is affected by everyone else.

LEAD: A new particle accelerator, causing electrons and positrons to collide at energies higher than those of any other such accelerator, is restoring Japan's prewar position near the front rank of experimental physics.

LEAD: WITH fewer than 105,000 residents, the city of Stamford, in southwestern Connecticut ranks fifth in terms of the state's population. But when it comes to cash, it ranks first. Of $1.3 billion in venture capital available in Connecticut, for instance, $1 billion of it is in Stamford, which ranks fourth in the nation in terms of venture funds.

LEAD: WHEN it comes to marathon performances, there is usually a crowd at the beginning and at the end, but much less so in the middle. I figured the annual Labor Day weekend ''Moby Dick'' reading at Canio's Books in Sag Harbor would be much the same.

LEAD: Benefits for nurses at the Veterans Administration Medical Center here include the usual: medical insurance, paid vacation, sick leave and a pension plan. But in an effort to alleviate a nursing shortage and retain staff, the hospital has added a new benefit: a free college education.

LEAD: THE Feld Ballet did not bill the fourth program of its current season at the Joyce Theater as a retrospective. But the selection of ballets, presented on Wednesday, did offer an enjoyable and thought-provoking look at Eliot Feld's career.

LEAD: PORCELAIN has been used by dentists for decades, but it was only a few years ago that porcelain veneers, and the bonding techniques to secure them to existing teeth, were fully refined. When that happened, the dental cosmetics business took off.

LEAD: For a good part of the 19th century, the winds off the Atlantic on the eastern end of Long Island turned the wooden blades of the windmill that anchored the green in the hamlet of Water Mill. Wheat and corn were ground there and farm families were fed for miles around.

LEAD: While Iona Prep escaped with a victory over Mount St. Michael last week without Beau Snell, their star running back who was out with pneumonia, they were not so lucky this weekend and lost, 48-15, to Cardinal Spellman yesterday.

LEAD: Kirk Schulz completed a school-record 28 of 38 passes for 359 yards for Villanova (4-0). Central Connecticut fell to 1-4. Villanova had a school-record 45 consecutive points in the second half. A wide receiver, Robert Brady, caught 9 passes for 114 yards and a touchdown for the Wildcats.

LEAD: A nine-year-old outbreak of rabies in skunks, raccoons and other wild animals is continuing, but no people have been infected with the disease in the United States in two years, researchers have reported.

LEAD: John C. O'Reilly and Jack Phillips own a sheet-metal fabricating plant in the Jackson Heights neighborhood of Queens. ''We really don't belong here,'' said Mr. Phillips of the one-story building, on 35th Avenue at 70th Street. ''This is a prime residential area.''

LEAD: The oldest resident of the Milwaukee County Zoo, an Andean condor believed to be 66 years old, has died. Zoo officials said Friday that an examination showed the bird, a male named Connie, died Wednesday of heart artery collapse related to old age. In 1922 Milwaukee's city engineer, George F. Staal, brought Connie and another young condor here from Argentina in 1922 and gave them to the zoo.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Jack Futterman of West End, N.J., and Eileen Tepper of Old Westbury, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter Stacy Ellen Futterman to Bruce David Katz, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Katz of New City, N.Y.

QUITE early in ''House of Games,'' David Mamet's entertaining, deadpan, seriocomic melodrama about con artists, there's a back-room poker game that sets the tone for everything that comes after. Though the players could withdraw at any point, they don't, this being a serious game. Raises are seen, and raised again. The pot accumulates. ''Everybody stays. Everybody pays,'' says the dealer. Tensions mount and tempers shorten like fuses burning in slow-motion. Somebody must be bluffing, and somebody must lose, though there's nothing in the book that says the bluffer must lose or that the best hand wins.

LEAD: NEXT year, when this Camden County township dedicates its memorial to the veterans and dead of four wars, it will be on a site other than the one originally proposed - a traffic island - because, according to veterans here, no one wants to dodge traffic to get to the memorial.
LEAD: There are times when the loneliness of being the only American living on the Pacific coast of the Soviet Union gets to Bill Turner.

LEAD: THE good citizens of Budapest and Prague seem born with a distinctive sense of how the violin should be played - with an easy, unselfconscious pliancy that outsiders copy but find ultimately elusive. This Central European tradition obviously reaches farther east as well. The Sofia Chamber Orchestra, which played at the Metropolitan Museum on Thursday night, understands it well.

LEAD: A scuffle that disrupted a meeting at Local 1199 of the hospital workers' union on Thursday was the latest outburst in a five-year struggle that, many observers believe, has seriously tarnished the reputation of the union that the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. once called his favorite.

LEAD: About 300 members and supporters of Local 560 of the International Brotherood of Teamsters rallied outside the union's headquarters here today, demanding elections to replace court-appointed trustees who have run the local for 16 months.

LEAD: IN the five years since Judy Carmichael arrived in New York with a repertory focused on the stride-piano compositions and solo performances of Fats Waller and James P. Johnson, she has been gradually expanding her range of material as well as the settings in which she plays. At Weill Hall on Thursday evening, she gave a concert in which she was joined by Michael Hashim on alto and soprano saxophones and Howard Alden on electric guitar.

LEAD: A LITTLE-KNOWN BALLET TOUR-ing company from the Soviet Union directed by a well-known Bolshoi star has elicited an unusual amount of interest from within the American dance public. After the Moscow Ballet, led by Vyacheslav Gordeyev, recently opened its current two-month American tour in Baltimore, a cascade of inquiries and comments, from New York to Anchorage, flowed back in response.

LEAD: President Reagan sent letters to Congressional leaders today advising them that American military forces in the Persian Gulf took ''limited defensive action'' last week when they fired on Iranian gunboats.

LEAD: IT WILL PROBABLY HAPPEN sometime during the next few months, and it will probably look something like this: The President of the United States and the General Secretary of the Soviet Communist Party will sit side by side on a raised dais in the classic simplicity of the East Room of the White House.

LEAD: I NEVER FOLLOWED THE AMER-ican idea of age,'' Boris Aronson said near the end of his remarkable half-century career as a designer for the theater. ''I slowly crawled from one rung on the ladder to the next. It is not the American way. In America, you are a genius at 18 and finished at 30.''

LEAD: IN this era of daringly trendy reinterpretations of the ''Ring,'' there ought to be room for a brilliantly untrendy one. Despite a slow start, the Metropolitan Opera could be building just such a welcome oddity, judging by the premiere performance Friday evening of ''Das Rheingold.'' The promise that was never quite delivered last season by a somewhat confused ''Die Walkure'' was fulfilled in this stylistically coherent new production.

LEAD: IT took a lot of foreigners to get British art started: Germans, Lowlanders, Italians, Frenchmen and strays from as far afield as Rostock and Prague. Most came as mercenaries and many stayed to become citizens.

In the dining hall, in the library, and at the supermarket in Exeter, N. H., the dismantled fence was eagerly discussed, the first tangible evidence of what the new principal would be like.

LEAD: SOUTH PACIFIC Question: How does one visit Norfolk Island north of New Zealand? Is it a good place to stay? Where can information on hotels and activities be obtained? - A. L. K., Austin, Tex. Answer: Norfolk Island is about 500 miles northwest of Auckland on New Zealand's North Island, but it is part of New South Wales, Australia.

LEAD: Tenancy of a Spouse Question: When my wife and I were married some 20 years ago we moved into a rent-controlled apartment that was in her name. My name was never added to her lease and since the apartment was rent controlled no subsequent lease was ever sent.

LEAD: A MAN who spent his career building golf courses and a woman who spent hers tearing them up have been inducted into the PGA-World Golf Hall of Fame. At ceremonies in Pinehurst, N.C., Robert Trent Jones, the 81-year-old golf course designer, was honored Friday along with Betsy Rawls, the 59-year-old former champion.

LEAD: In the heart of what he called ''the new South,'' where he is running well ahead of the other candidates, the Rev. Jesse Jackson today officially announced his candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

LEAD: It is the year 2167. Mom, Dad, the kids and Bruno the dog lounge around the simulated sun room of their life-support pod in Westchester. A heap of brochures litters the carpet. The family vacation looms a few weeks away. They have already decided to visit New England, where the nitrous oxide count is lower.
LEAD: For the first time in the Nicaraguan conflict, Sandinista and rebel troops today held positions within shooting distance of each other, but did not attack.

LEAD: An official of the National Football League Players Association today revealed the latest of what he called several union proposals to club owners designed to address their concerns about a system of free agency.

LEAD: When Louis Armstrong performed, he wore a smile that seemed a mile wide. He punctuated his singing by repeatedly mopping the sweat from his brow with a pocket handkerchief; when he played the trumpet he pointed the bell heavenward, and reflected stage lights danced in the horn's polished brass. To some, Armstrong was a great musician first and foremost; to others he was an entertainer, a clowning Southern bumpkin.
LEAD: For all the sorrowful post-mortems, the most poignant commentary on the Jets' dismal performance today was the expression on Joe Walton's face after their 6-0 loss to the Indianapolis Colts.

The Soviet Union decides to send a poet to the moon. ''Theme of Project: humanization, not militarization of cosmos.'' A Polish general suffers ''severe gastric distress'' at the idea.
