LEAD: Last November, at least 30 police officers surrounded a building in the South Bronx where, they say, they hoped to question a man about the murders, two weeks earlier, of four reputed drug dealers in an apartment.

LEAD: Marjorie Anne Harris and Donald Andrew Dripps, 1983 graduates of the University of Michigan Law School, were married yesterday at the Hyatt Ravinia Hotel in Atlanta by Rabbi Fred Raskind. Mr. Dripps is an assistant professor of law at the University of Illinois College of Law in Champaign-Urbana. The bride was most recently an associate in the Manhattan law firm of Sullivan &
LEAD: AN oatmeal war is brewing and it's going to get mighty mushy.
LEAD: The Rev. Jesse Jackson says no, he wouldn't want to live in New York City, ''wouldn't even try it.'' The prospect of visiting the city was ignored altogether.

LEAD: For the fourth time in three years, the world championship chess match, starting today in Seville, Spain, will pit the same antagonists against each other - the 24-year-old titleholder, Gary Kasparov, and his 36-year-old challenger, Anatoly Karpov, both of the Soviet Union.

LEAD: Dr. Judith Halperin and Dr. Joel Neil Goldstein were married yesterday at the Menemsha Inn in Chilmark, Mass., by Rabbi Balfour Brickner. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley D. Halperin of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., and Menemsha. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Goldstein of New Rochelle, N

LEAD: A significant number of prominent criminal cases have recently been characterized by a troubling breakdown in confidentiality. Simply put, prosecutors and their agents have selectively leaked to the media damaging information about subjects of grand jury investigations and other legal proceedings that are supposed to remain secret until disclosed in open court at the appropriate time.

LEAD: Ideas, some new, but most old, bounced through this summer community this weekend as about 300 academics, industry leaders, politicians and artists gathered for three days of discussion and, to some, not a little celebration of ''the Hamptons.''

LEAD: Faith Linda Florer and Arthur Philip Kleiner were married yesterday at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in New York. The ceremony was performed by the bride's father, the Rev. Herbert Washburn Florer Jr. of Kerhonkson, N.Y., and Rabbi Joseph Gelberman.

LEAD: An article on Thursday about grants from the Howard Hughes Medical Institute incorrectly described the amount given to the Institute of Medicine of the National Academy of Science. It received one $5 million grant, not two.
LEAD: A week after Canadian and American negotiators agreed on a free trade pact, most analysts said it would create more winners than losers in the United States.

LEAD: Hyatt Hotels, whose main target is the business traveler, introduces tomorrow its first campaign by its new agency, Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos in Boston. Adam M. Aron, Hyatt senior vice president, marketing, said that an interesting facet of the effort is that instead of using magazines exclusively for the campaign as in the recent past, 60 percent of this year's spending will be in newspapers.

LEAD: IN her recent song ''Warriors of the Sun,'' Joan Baez conjures a characteristically blunt vision of the tattered remains of the 1960's peace movement: We are warriors of the sun Fighting postwar battles that somehow never got won It may be crazy and it may be the final run.

LEAD: QUESTION: If the San Francisco Giants make it to the World Series and become champions, Kevin Mitchell, who was with the champion Mets last season, would be a member of his second consecutive Series winner, but with a different team? Has it happened before?
LEAD: Judge Robert H. Bork made no sense either in deciding to insist on ultimate defeat in the Senate or in explaining why he refused to withdraw his name from nomination to the Supreme Court.
LEAD: OVER the weekend, the theatrical part of the Italy on Stage festival started to pour out on the stage of the Mark Hellinger, and the first tasting was pleasant to the palate.

LEAD: As the dust clears from a tumultuous month in the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination, Senator Paul Simon is not only still standing, in the eyes of some political professionals, but he also looks a little taller.

LEAD: Environmentalists are expected to gather late Wednesday afternoon in the Rayburn House Office Building to commemorate the 25th anniversary of the publication of Rachel Carson's ''Silent Spring,'' the book that was among the earliest to warn of modern threats to nature.
LEAD: The United States Sugar Corporation, the nation's largest producer of raw cane sugar, will be acquired by the Sugar Acquisitions Corporation for $80 a share in cash.

LEAD: Stuart D. Root, a former president of the Bowery Savings Bank, is heading to Washington to become acting director of the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, the agency that guarantees deposits in 3,100 savings and loan institutions.

LEAD: Ilene Cathy Popkin, the daughter of Mrs. Bernard Weiler of Rockville Centre, L.I., and Delray Beach, Fla., and Mitchell Alan Make, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Sydney Make of Lower Merion, Pa., were married yesterday at the North Shore Synagogue in Syosset, L.I., by Rabbi Aaron Petuchowski.

LEAD: THE Feld Ballet took two trips into never-never land on Saturday night when the company presented the fifth program in its current season at the Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street. ''Straw Hearts,'' a sunny opening ballet Mr. Feld has set to period parlor music, is a dance for summer lovers of a gentler age and time.

LEAD: Rosemary Moore, a daughter of the Right Rev. Paul Moore Jr., Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of New York, and the late Jenny McKean Moore, was married yesterday to Joshua David Shneider, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold M. Shneider of Carlisle, Mass. The ceremony was performed by the bride's father at the Pinewood Lodge in Hurley, N

LEAD: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday None Wednesday Retail Sales U.S. Balance of Trade... August Thursday None Friday Industrial Production
LEAD: Harold J. Drescher, who practiced law in New York York City ifor more than 60 years, died Oct. 5 at Beth Israel Hospital. He was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan.
LEAD: Of all Americans who receive a pension, more than one in six supplements his or her income by working on the side, a new study by the Census Bureau says.

LEAD: A burglar stole a passport, $400 and jewelry from Sir Georg Solti and his wife as they slept in a hotel room, hours after a weekend celebration of the conductor's 75th birthday, the police said today.

LEAD: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he would decide within 10 days whether to dismiss Dr. Elliot M. Gross as New York City's Chief Medical Examiner, as recommended by a mayoral advisory committee. Dr. Gross, who faces state charges of negligence and incompetence, has vowed not to resign.

LEAD: Redskin, a 3-year-old chestnut colt driven by John Campbell, caught Jate Lobell, the favorite, midway through the stretch to win the 32d annual Messenger Stakes by two lengths in 1:58 last night at Roosevelt Raceway. Trained by Jerry Smith, Redskin, who went off on the second tier from the No. 11 post position, earned $223,655 to push his career earnings to $1,865,702.

LEAD: Peter R. Harvey, an Illinois businessman, has amassed a diverse portfolio of investments in public and private companies that range from a maker of artificial silk flowers to manufacturers of scientific instruments and costume jewelry.

LEAD: Marchers dressed in traditional Costa Rican costumes stayed under the protection of their umbrellas as they made their way up Fifth Avenue during the Hispanic-American Columbus Day Parade. (NYT/Dith Pran)

LEAD: Mary Unterberg Arno, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence E. Unterberg of New York and Tinton Falls, N.J., and Charles A. DeBare, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Nat Jacques DeBare of Jamaica, Queens, were married yesterday at the bride's summer home in Elberon, N.J. Mayor Joseph Frankel of Eatontown, N.J.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Updating their analysis of New York's ethnic stew, Nathan Glazer and Daniel Patrick Moynihan wrote in 1970 that while the cultural and social style of Italian-Americans had produced attractive families, neighborhoods and friendships, ''somehow the ethos has not gone beyond that to create a presumption of leadership in city affairs.
LEAD: The Economy
LEAD: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Wagner's ''Rheingold,'' 8.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: During the last few months, Israel and Yasir Arafat's Palestine Liberation Organization may have come a little closer to peace negotiations than at any time since their conflict began.
LEAD: For one week, Greg Mathews's problem did not seem to be a problem.

LEAD: The congregation of Freemason Street Baptist Church here voted overwhelmingly this morning to accept Pat Robertson's resignation from the ministry, but there was considerable doubt whether it would also vote for him for President.

LEAD: FIVE of the principal roles in the New York City Opera's production of Puccini's ''Turandot'' have changed hands, three of them to people making debuts with the company. On Sunday afternoon, the strongest impression was made by a singer who performed her role two years ago at the house, Edith Davis as Liu.
LEAD: Holiday Festivities

LEAD: On the same spot in the living room where Mario Cuomo has twice taken the oath of office as Governor, his daughter Maria was married in the Executive Mansion today to Kenneth D. Cole, a shoe designer, as 300 friends and political figures looked on.

LEAD: The director of the National Security Agency has said the United States will lose the ''intelligence war'' unless the flow of leaks to journalists is stanched and Government agencies stop treating security problems with ''disdain.''

LEAD: Joanne Chesimard, a leader of the black radical movement who escaped in 1979 from a New Jersey prison where she was serving a life term for murdering a state trooper, has been living in Cuba for three years and was interviewed there recently by Newsday.

LEAD: Tropical Storm Floyd picked up strength today in the western Caribbean as its winds reached 60 miles an hour, and forecasters posted hurricane warnings for southwest Florida and the Florida Keys.

LEAD: The European Community's economy will expand by 2.3 percent in 1988, well below expected growth rates for the United States and Japan, the community's commission said. It said in a report on Friday that the United States and Japanese economies would probably grow by 2.7 percent and 3.5 percent, respectively, in 1988, compared with 2.3 percent and 2.9 percent this year.

LEAD: Charles J. Carney, who was a labor leader before he served four terms in the House of Representatives, died Wednesday at St. Elizabeth Hospital Medical Center of a heart ailment complicated by pneumonia. He was 74 years old.
LEAD: Guns have always been a part of life in this Panhandle town, even before a new Florida law seemed to invite pistol-packing on city sidewalks.

LEAD: Although stopping short of a formal declaration of candidacy, South Korea's most prominent opposition figure left virtually no doubt at a public rally here today that he was running for president.
LEAD: Twenty years ago, when Jacinto Camacho came to the United States from Ecuador, he worked two shifts a day, doing carpentry, painting and plastering.
LEAD: While the economy seems healthy, with no sharp rise in inflation and good prospects for continued growth, the financial markets are beset with doubts and worries.

LEAD: A sigh of relief could be heard round much of the world a year ago when Amadou-Mahtar M'Bow announced that he would not seek a third, six-year term as Director General of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization. By general consent, his incumbency has been a calamity for a once-useful agency.
LEAD: THE International Business Machines Corporation has just finished a rough week on Wall Street. On Friday alone, I.B.M.'s stock fell 4 1/8, to 147 3/8.
LEAD: Iraq staged aerial attacks on Iranian oil targets today, and an Iranian surface-to-surface missile exploded in Baghdad, the Iraqi capital.

LEAD: NO one is quite prepared to describe events here as an advanced case of Orangemania. Chances are, some people would think you were talking about a new soft drink, anyway. There is, however, no denying the Growing interest in the Syracuse football team. It is evident in the pink message slips multiplying on Dick MacPherson's desk when the coach returns from lunch or a meeting, and in the recent involvement of the city fathers, who have scheduled a pep rally for Friday evening at the city hall, in preparation for Saturday's showdown against Penn State.

LEAD: At Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I., Nancy Beth Fischer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin A. Fischer of Woodmere, L.I., and West Stockbridge, Mass., was married yesterday to Frank Steven Levin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Levin of Silver Spring, Md. Rabbi Gilbert S. Rosenthal and Cantor Tibor Kelen officiated.
LEAD: Some New York judges must retire at 70. Others may continue as judges until age 76. Still others may serve into their 80's and 90's if they choose.

LEAD: At the Chanticler restaurant in Short Hills, N.J., Judith Ann Elleen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Elleen of Morristown, N.J., was married yesterday to Neil Alan Smith, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Emanuel Smith of Springfield, Mo. Rabbi Z. David Levy officiated.

LEAD: The players strike may not have brought the National Football League to its knees, but as the N.F.L. limps along with replacement rosters, the strike has wreaked havoc among the nation's semipro leagues.

LEAD: Three doctors who owned an abandoned radiation therapy clinic have been charged in the release of radioactive material that contaminated 40 people, 10 of them critically. Orlando Teixeira, 37 years old, Criseide Dourado, 40, and Carlos Bezzerril, 43, directors of the Goiania Radiation Therapy Institute, were indicted Saturday on charges of causing grave injury to 10 people.
LEAD: One of the great European paintings of the late 19th century, James Ensor's ''Entry of Christ Into Brussels'' was a matter of public scandal almost since the day it was painted.

LEAD: Five fraternity brothers from Trenton State College and a 20-year-old woman were killed when their cars collided head-on early yesterday on Interstate 95 outside Philadelphia, the authorities said.

LEAD: Vice President Bush waving to the crowd as he and his grandson, Sam LeBlonde, toured the fairgrounds Saturday at the Fryeburg Fair in Maine. The Vice President is scheduled to announce his candidacy for the Republican Presidential nomination today (AP)

LEAD: With near-record numbers of travelers expected at Kennedy International Airport this year, the authorities there are reporting sharp increases in pickpocketing, luggage theft and other property crimes.
LEAD: A new Federal complaint has been filed against Federal District Judge Alcee Hastings, who already faces possible impeachment in Congress, it was reported Saturday.
LEAD: A second suspect was arrested yesterday in the execution-style slaying of a taxi dispatcher who had testified before a Queens grand jury about a shooting she witnessed, the police said.
LEAD: For weeks now, Lalitha Masson has found herself standing before her open bedroom closet, filled with a bitter resignation.

LEAD: The head of an umbrella group of 45 American Jewish organizations has assured Israeli leaders that American Jews will not meddle in matters involving Israel's security, despite the call by one of its member organizations for an international peace conference to resolve the Arab-Israeli conflict.
LEAD: NEW YORK

LEAD: NOT far away Darrell Evans was talking about having been ''half a step too far off'' when he was picked off third base to kill the Tigers' sixth-inning rally. More than any of his teammates, Evans was the goat of last night's 5-3 loss that enabled the Minnesota Twins to grab a 3-1 lead in the American League Championship Series that could end here today.

LEAD: Madeleine Rose Singer, a research analyst at the New York University Medical Center, and John Russell Leigh, a supervising specialist with Coopers & Lybrand, an accounting concern in New York, were married yesterday at the Pierre by Rabbi Martin Zion. The bride, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd I.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Late last Thursday evening, the Senate passed a bill that would give the State Department $3.6 billion to conduct its affairs in the current fiscal year. But as the 85 senators voting in favor of it approved the Foreign Relations Authorization Act of 1988, they were adopting more than just a broad financing measure for the State Department, its embassies, the Voice of America and the United States Information

LEAD: The hot rumor of last week was that the Interpublic Group of Companies is planning to merge two of its operating units: SSC& B:Lintas worldwide network and Campbell-Ewald, the Detroit agency historically linked to the huge Chevrolet account.

LEAD: A golfer making his first outing at the Malibu Golf Course, a private links north of Los Angeles, may come back raving and ranting. The raves would be for the 6,205-yard course's challenging layout, its rolling beauty and its well-maintained fairways and greens. The rants would be for what might be regarded as a bizarre emphasis on golfing decorum.

LEAD: Obituaries dutifully describe the obvious and the copious about Clare Boothe Luce. Almost till her death at age 84, she starred as a playwright, politician and diplomat. What doesn't get into print, indeed what eludes print, is how she was able to disarm those she well knew were disposed to dislike her, especially males determined not to be taken in by a woman they believed to be too smart and ambitious to be up to any good.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: ONE of the disheartening legacies of the late-70's disco boom has been its reduction of so much mainstream pop-soul music to formulas in which strong voices are packaged in cookie-cutter arrangements. Now and then, of course, a conceptual iconoclast like Prince or a great singer like Anita Baker transcends this kind of homogenization.

LEAD: The wedding of Andrea Louise Bozzi, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce E. Bozzi of New York, to Alfred L. Thimm Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thimm of Burlington, Vt., took place yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York. The Rev. Nicholas R. Reid performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Two years after the United States and Israel signed an agreement for free trade - the first such American pact with another country - commerce between the two nations has increased substantially and decades-old obstacles are beginning to be cleared. Israel has shifted some of its trading focus from Europe to the United States, and the United States may be starting to look upon

LEAD: The Federal Government filed suit against the LTV Corporation Friday in a bid to make the company take responsibility for three pension plans and to assure payment of full benefits to retirees, officials said.

LEAD: Across the country, on the perimeters of the big metropolitan areas, gleaming clusters of office skyscrapers, department stores, hotels, restaurants and theaters have shot up in what some students of urban affairs say is a new stage in the evolution of the American city.

LEAD: Syria expects to have warmer relations with France after two days of talks in Damascus with the French Foreign Minister, Jean-Bernard Raimond, a Syrian Cabinet member said today. ''The Syrian and French republics are to bolster their relations and expand cooperation in all fields,'' Najah al-Attar, the Minister of Culture, was quoted by the Syrian radio as saying.

LEAD: In a demonstration reminiscent of the civil rights marches of the 1960's, 200,000 people, gay Americans and a diverse coalition of their supporters, marched here today, calling for more Federal money for AIDS research and treatment and for an end to discrimination against homosexuals.

LEAD: Fearful of being taken to hospitals against their will, mentally ill homeless people have been changing their routines and disappearing from their usual haunts, according to health workers who seek them out to offer food and other assistance.

LEAD: In a move to compete with such higher-paying employers as investment firms and commercial banks, Price Waterhouse has given its beginning accountants a 20 percent pay increase, to $30,000 a year, while eliminating overtime pay.

LEAD: Shortly before 7 A.M. recently, Cindy Seitz, a service manager for Northwest Airlines, entered a miniature control tower at the Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport to help oversee another day of operations.

LEAD: In the wake of several well-publicized magazine pop-up ads by several advertisers that frequently angered other advertisers in those publications, Toyota Motor Sales is planning a little print extravaganza of its own.

LEAD: Jane Shauna Razzi, a marketing manager for the Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino in Atlantic City, was married yesterday to W. Thomas Hagy, the associate editor of Mealey Publications, a publisher of specialized legal journals in Devon, Pa. The Rev. Dr. Kenneth Collier, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at St.

LEAD: Smith International Inc. said Friday that two creditors that had objected to the oil service company's bankruptcy reorganization proposal had agreed to a modified repayment plan. The revised plan calls for unsecured creditors to receive $145 million in notes bearing 13 percent interest, instead of 12.5 percent, and disallows
LEAD: * BankAmerica Corp., San Francisco, elected as a director Kathleen Feldstein, president of Economic Studies Inc., a private economic consulting firm in Belmont, Mass.

LEAD: Twins and Giants Win Minnesota used sharp relief pitching to top Detroit, 5-3, and lead 3-1 in the American League baseball playoffs. San Francisco defeated St. Louis, 6-3, to lead 3-2 in the National League series. SportsMonday, page C1. N.F.L. Attendance Grows

LEAD: Last Monday, one day after Mexico's ruling party named Carlos Salinas de Gortari as its standard-bearer in next year's presidential election, the stock market here rose 7.5 percent in the first 90 minutes of trading. Twice during the day the Government had to suspend trading briefly to prevent what it called a ''disorderly'' surge by the market.
LEAD: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.
LEAD: The Democrats are staggering into a Presidential election crisis, and even ''the brightest and the best'' of them aren't coming to the aid of their party.

LEAD: No industry has experienced more rapid change in recent years than international finance. New financial instruments become obsolete from one year to the next. Bank strategies for coping with the debt crisis are as disposable as yesterday's newspaper. And regulations once considered the bedrock of the financial system are virtually ignored as bankers leap from one loophole to another.

LEAD: The sound of sobs and the reading of names punctured the early morning quiet as pieces of material were unfurled and hooked together, creating a huge quilt intended as a personal memorial to 1,920 AIDS victims.
LEAD: WHEN working parents are away, their children play, go to school and often misbehave. Trying to impose discipline from afar becomes a challenge.
LEAD: Ronald L. Ziegler, press secretary to President Nixon from 1969 to 1974, was named today as president of the National Association of Chain Drug Stores.

LEAD: A few days after he joined eight colleagues on the Senate Judiciary Committee and voted against the nomination of Judge Robert H. Bork to the Supreme Court, Dennis DeConcini came home to Arizona this weekend, on an inspection tour of sorts, to inventory the damage his stand had wrought among the state's wide majority of conservative voters.

LEAD: International A3-13 Guerrillas attacked India's forces in Sri Lanka's Jaffna Peninsula with mortars, machine guns and rocket-propelled grenades, Sri Lankan Government radio reported, on the third day of India's peacekeeping effort. Page A1 Foreigners took part in unrest in Tibet, according to some of them.

LEAD: Java Gold went lame shortly after his surprising defeat in the Jockey Club Gold Cup on Saturday and will not race again this year because he has sustained a deep bruise at the base of his right front foot.

LEAD: Across a lovely stretch of southern France best known for its sunshine and beaches, unlovely racist sentiments have seeped into the mainstream of political debate as France gears up for a presidential election next spring.

LEAD: DUCKS over decoys, quail and grouse over pointing dogs and corn-field pheasants are all superb sport for the shotgunner. But the opening of dove season each September brings not only the earliest but also some of the most enjoyable and, without question, the most challenging wing shooting of the year to millions of

LEAD: TWELVE days after he suffered an accident while working on his car, Lloyd M. Crenshaw had to have his right foot amputated. Mr. Crenshaw's insurer, the Bankers Life and Casualty Company, refused to pay a $20,000 benefit under his policy for loss of limb. The company insisted that the amputation was not covered by the policy, saying it resulted from a degenerative disease.

LEAD: Scores of whooping cranes and cranes of related species appear to have recovered from a mysterious illness that killed 15 of the birds at the Patuxent Wildlife Research Center in suburban Laurel, Md., the Fish and Wildlife Service says.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: RAQUEL WELCH in her most demanding major dramatic role - that's the come-on implied in the publicity surrounding the made-for-television movie on NBC at 9 this evening. But the fact-based ''Right to Die'' adds up to considerably more than just another ambitious turn for a glamorous star determined to prove that anything Farrah Fawcett can do, she can do better.

LEAD: Kathleen S. Silloway, a daughter of Janet L. Silloway of East Windsor, N.J., and Frank F. Silloway of Baltimore, was married yesterday to Roger Grossman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Grossman of Riverdale, the Bronx. The Rev. Joan O'Gorman, a Unitarian minister, officiated at the Dockside Harbor restaurant in Cold Spring, N

LEAD: One of the enduring mysteries that is likely to remain unresolved in the Iran-contra investigations is whether there really were any Iranians hoping to have better relations with the United States.

LEAD: Centennial milestones have had a good run recently: 100 years for the Brooklyn Bridge and the Statue of Liberty, 200 for the Declaration of Independence and the Constitution, and 400 for Roanoke Island's first colony. But those were only the warm-ups. In nineteen hundred and ninety-two, it will be 500 years since

LEAD: Erica Munford Leshan and Bruce David Taterka, who graduated in 1985 and '84, respectively, from Vassar College, were married yesterday in Plymouth Meeting, Pa., at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Harris. Rabbi Susan Schnur officiated.

LEAD: A surge in attacks by shadowy groups of anti-Government rebels has cast fear over white farmers near this city, and has prompted the Government, which has linked the rebels to its main political opposition, to all but ban the group.

LEAD: Yael Ben-Ishay, a daughter of Professors Drori and Zina Ben-Ishay of Jerusalem, was married yesterday to David J. Shapiro, a son of Rabbi and Mrs. Robert W. Shapiro of Swampscott, Mass. Rabbi Shapiro officiated at Dag Hammarskjold Tower in Manhattan. Mrs. Shapiro graduated from Hebrew University in Jerusalem.
LEAD: Elaine Potwardoski and Anthony Green were married yesterday in the Constitution Pavillion on Independence Mall in Philadelphiaby Judge Lynne Abraham of the Common Pleas Court there.

LEAD: MORT SAHL, the comic scourge of the 1950's and 1960's, opened his one-man show last night at the Neil Simon Theater on Broadway. Though the comedian has shifted some of his animosity, age has not mollified his temperament or lessened his aptitude. He is still out there in the satiric combat zone, flailing sacred cows (and sitting ducks) with his caustic wit.

LEAD: THE Beaux Arts Trio came to the Metropolitan Museum with its new cellist on Friday night. He is Peter Wiley, whose arrival has come with the departure of Bernard Greenhouse into retirement at the end of last season.
LEAD: The regular weekly auction of Treasury bills will be held tomorrow rather than today, when the Treasury securities market is closed for the Columbus Day holiday.

LEAD: Golf Tewell Wins in Pensacola: Doug Tewell shot a three-under-par 68 that included his third eagle of the tournament and won the Pensacola Open in Florida yesterday by three strokes over Danny Edwards and Phil Blackmar. Tewell shot a 72-hole total of 15-under-par 269 on the 7,154-yard Perdido Bay Resort course.(AP)

LEAD: The baritone Hermann Prey will teach a master class in art songs and arias from the German repertory Thursday at the Manhattan School of Music. The class, which is to start at 7 P.M. in the John C. Bordon Auditorium, is open to the public at no charge. The school entrance is on the northwest corner of Broadway and 122d Street.

LEAD: A Manhattan man was shot and killed in the crowded lobby of the Roseland dance hall early yesterday after an argument that began when another man stepped on the feet of the victim's companion, the police said.

LEAD: California agricultural groups report that fewer alien farm workers than expected are applying for legal status under the new immigration law, intensifying the debate over whether the supply of farm labor here will be sufficient in coming years.

LEAD: After six consecutive days of bargaining, the longest period of time they have spent together, negotiators for the National Football League's owners and striking players broke off their talks today, almost as far apart as they were when they began last Tuesday.

LEAD: New York State's Task Force on Life and the Law proposes to give patients the right to designate an ''agent'' to make life and death decisions should they become incompetent to do so for themselves. It's a wise initiative that sets an example for other states. It does not promote ''the right to die'' but sensibly extends people's right to take charge of their lives.

LEAD: While hundreds of earthquake victims jammed disaster relief centers today seeking funds to rebuild or relocate, a small aftershock jolted the metropolitan area. The aftershock, measuring 3.0 on the Richter scale, struck at 3:34 P.M. along the Whittier Fault, said Robert Finn, spokesman for the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena.

LEAD: As swords go, the foil is a gossamer weapon, a nearly weightless ribbon whose scoring touches are a fencer's caresses. Derived from the courtier's delicate dress sword, the foil, by chivalric tradition, has been the only weapon wielded by female fencers.
LEAD: Not only is Craig Heyward big -6 feet, 260 pounds - he is faster than one might believe, indefatigable and apparently indestructible.

LEAD: GRIEF comes in many sizes and shapes, and it is for each of us to choose his own way to mourn. Saturday night's ''Stabat Mater'' at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine could never quite decide, and that is what turned it into such a confusing and unresolved search for proper scale.

LEAD: For more than two years, the Vietnam Women's Memorial Project has been asking that a statue of a woman be added to the Vietnam Veterans Memorial in the capital to reflect the service of more than 10,000 women, mostly nurses, in the long conflict in Vietnam.

LEAD: The San Francisco 49ers won, but the Atlanta Falcon replacement team inflicted a minor embarrassment on a group of 49er regulars today by making a game of it before losing, 25-17, in front of only 8,684 fans.
LEAD: The Chicago Bears, unbeaten with their regulars, won their second straight game with replacements today, beating the Minnesota Vikings, 27-7.

LEAD: It makes no sense for the Pentagon to test the new Trident submarine missile with more and more warheads. Yet that is precisely what Defense Secretary Weinberger has ordered. Perhaps his decision represents a mischievous effort to complicate nuclear arms talks. Perhaps worse, he may not realize that the Soviet Union would benefit more from his ploy than the United

LEAD: ''PRIMITIVE MYSTERIES'' and ''Judith,'' performed by the Martha Graham Dance Company for the first time this season Saturday night, are typical of the wider repertory the company has presented in recent years.

LEAD: Tamil guerrillas attacked Indian peacekeeping forces in the Jaffna Peninsula today with mortars, machine guns and rocket-propelled grenades, according to Sri Lankan Government radio, and the Indians responded with heavy counterattacks.

LEAD: The vocabulary of disaster employed by the Foreign Service these days -words like ''tragic'' and ''catastrophic'' - is being applied not to crises in the Middle East or Central America, but to the State Department itself.

LEAD: When this is over, the players who tossed eggs, who spit, who waved shotguns, who called their teammates names, and the men who withstood all of this will do something as hard as any job in sports - play football together.

LEAD: Stephen J. Jatras has held the top position at the Telex Corporation through the recent good times for the company. The producer of computer terminals and peripheral equipment, which is based in Tulsa, Okla., has posted seven years of rising profits.

LEAD: Bill Belichick stood in the rubble of adhesive tape and excuses that filled the locker room at Giants Stadium tonight, his mind on escape, his eyes on the door. Still, he stood there, answering all the obvious questions with courteous and predictable answers.

LEAD: In August 1985, squatters advised by community organizers seized 25 vacant, city-owned buildings in the East New York section of Brooklyn. City officials were furious, 11 people were arrested, and the contretemps became an issue in the Democratic primary that year between Mayor Koch and City Council President Carol Bellamy.

LEAD: For a change, Jeffrey Leonard didn't hit a home run today. But that was just about the only thing the San Francisco Giants didn't inflict on the St. Louis Cardinals as they won their second straight playoff game and moved to within one of taking the National League pennant.
LEAD: A Burma Airways plane caught fire and crashed about 20 miles short of a popular tourist town in central Burma today, and all 49 people aboard died, the Government said.

LEAD: Restoration work on the West Front of the Capitol is finally finished. That is the good news. LEAD: Because of the small number of people applying for permanent residency, immigration officials in the New York region are reducing and redeploying staff workers assigned to the amnesty program for illegal aliens.

LEAD: A picture caption on Friday about the removal of a painting from a Capitol committee room misidentified Representative Ben Nighthorse Campbell. He is from Colorado.

LEAD: FOR the opera ''Rake's Progress,'' Stravinsky transformed Hogarth's engravings of a downwardly mobile young gentleman into tragic Faustian drama. LEAD: AS an indicator of a trend, the August deficit in American trade, to be announced this morning, has little value. The deficit might rise, as it did in June and July, or it might decline - the most likely scenario. But whatever the August inning, the outcome of the game should remain the same: The nation's huge deficit in merchandise trade is not likely to shrink much in this decade.

Until her death in 1972, Moore, with her Mary Poppins innocence and wisdom, flowing cape and trademark tricorn hat (''I like the shape - it conceals the defects of the head''), was the unofficial poet laureate of the boroughs in which she lived, wrote and flourished most of her life - in Brooklyn, at 260 Cumberland Street, and in Manhattan, at 35 West Ninth
LEAD: Suddenly, the usually taciturn Joseph A. Rice, chairman and chief executive of the Irving Bank Corporation, is inviting reporters to see him for personal chats.

LEAD: The old man in the rumpled sport coat smiled when someone stopped him in the lobby of the Minnesota Twins' office to offer congratulations. LEAD: Randy Weston's roots are in the music of Duke Ellington and Thelonious Monk, but his music also reflects the years he spent living in Africa. In traditional African music, rhythms are layered vertically, and each layer of rhythm is given its own specific timbre, its own voice. This is a difficult concept to translate into ensemble jazz, which uses independent voices to both reinforce and elaborate on a common pulse.

Tractors began shoving quarry rock brought by barge from Santa Catalina Island into the sea a mile off Will Rogers State Beach.

LEAD: Randy Weston, Mikell's, 769 Colum-bus Avenue, at 97th Street (864-8832). Randy Weston is a nomad. He gave some of the first concerts tracing the evolution of jazz from African sources, which led to a mid-60's African tour and a period of residence in Morocco.

LEAD: In several ways, though not necessarily the most important ones, Vladimir Krainev is an extraordinary pianist. LEAD: THE Center for Molecular Medicine and Immunology of Newark received a patent this week for a preparation regarded as important in the treatment of cancer.

LEAD: Futures prices of crude oil and petroleum products surged yesterday in heavy trading amid widespread anticipation that the United States would avenge a missile attack in Kuwaiti waters against a Kuwaiti oil tanker flying the American flag.
LEAD: Business sales advanced 1.3 percent in August, the biggest gain in seven months, while inventories grew at just half the rate of the previous month, the Commerce Department reported today.

LEAD: The Lear Siegler Holdings Corporation said it had agreed to sell three aerospace units for $97 million to the BFM Aerospace Corporation, a new company whose principals include Robert M. Bass, the Texas financier. The units are the Lear Siegler Romec Corporation of Elyria, Ohio, and the Lear Siegler Energy Products Corporation and the Lear Siegler Transport Dynamics Corporation, both of Santa Ana, Calif.
LEAD: Solid defense, sharp goaltending by Alain Chevrier and intelligent play in the last period carried the Devils to a 4-3 victory over the Montreal Canadiens tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.
LEAD: Buoyed by increased market activity, the Charles Schwab Corporation today reported income for the third quarter of $11.5 million, or 41 cents a share, on revenues of $116.3 million.

LEAD: Michael Owens, who was rated as Pennsylvania's top high school player in 1985, grew up in Carlisle as nearby Penn State forged its reputation as a national power. But he decided to attend Syracuse.

LEAD: The Marine Midland Bank and the Republic National Bank of New York raised their prime lending rate by half a percentage point yesterday to 9 3/4 percent, following the lead set Thursday by the Chemical Bank.
LEAD: PUMPKINS will be somewhat smaller and somewhat scarcer this year. They also will cost about the same as they did last year, and, because of harder shells, could last until Christmas.

LEAD: UNLIKE some corporate executives who became entrepreneurs, neither Thomas A. Fahey nor Sheldon Jacobs is inclined to bite the hands of the corporations that once fed them. On the contrary, both Mr. Fahey, who spent 21 years at the General Foods Corporation, and Mr. Jacobs, with 25 years at ABC and NBC, praise their former employers for providing lessons that have helped them in what have become highly profitable second careers.

LEAD: TODAY, MANY WOMEN are lavishing as much attention -and spending as much money - on caring for their hair as they do for their skin. What was once a simple quest for squeaky clean hair has mushroomed into a search for texture, thickness, shine, softness and shape. ''In building a style, a woman can wind up using four or five products,'' says James W.
LEAD: YEARS FROM NOW By Gary Glickman. 263 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95.
LEAD: IT'S AN ORDINARY FRIDAY night at Bay Ridge Billiards, a pool hall in Brooklyn, and the place is filled almost entirely with men.
LEAD: SINCE, when the Hatch Act was enacted, civil servants have been forbidden to take part in partisan political campaigns or to solicit campaign funds from colleagues.
LEAD: After strumming the blues in an Iowa roadhouse for the last time, Eric De Wolf packed his bags and his guitar and lit out for the bright lights of the music world.

LEAD: Sally Ann Stoller, a daughter of Herbert Stoller of New York and Harrington Sound, Bermuda, and Shirl E. Stoller of San Diego, was married last evening at the St. Regis-Sheraton Hotel in Manhattan to Gary L. Eisenreich, the son of Mrs. William F. Eisenreich of Alton, Ill., and the late Mr. Eisenreich.

LEAD: Bernard King is a tenacious player, a team leader, the kind of captain the Knicks desperately need. When I think of the inspirational qualities of Bernard King, I am reminded of the play of Willis Reed (who rose above the circumstances of his injured knees to lead the Knicks to two championships).

LEAD: JUST half a mile or so north of Wall Street, the Federal District Court in Manhattan has long been home to business and commercial disputes. But rarely has it seemed so much like an annex to a securities trading floor as this month, with the opening of two high-profile trials involving allegations of high financial chicanery.

LEAD: SAINTS AND SCHOLARS. By Terry Eagleton. (Methuen, $14.95.) ''Having a pain in my foot, in short, isn't the same as having a mongoose down my trousers.'' So argues an off-the-deep-end Ludwig Wittgenstein in this first novel by the noted Marxist critic Terry Eagleton. Other characters include the Irish labor leader and revolutionary James Connolly, Wittgenstein's sidekick Nikolai Bakhtin and, in a delightful cameo, Joyce's Leopold Bloom.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: What began in the House of Representatives as a sensible response to outrage over air travel delays has turned into meddling. Air travelers as well as airlines ought to hope for greater wisdom from the Senate.

LEAD: My hat is off to Mrs. Tuchman for speaking so boldly about the appalling state of our nation's leadership. My fear is that human nature thrives on avoidance, however, and lawlessness and incompetence don't directly reach one's doorstep unless one is specific party to a disaster.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH ABSTRACT EXPRES-sionism is so familiar that it seems to have been exhibited and examined forever, ''Abstract Expressionism: The Critical Developments'' at the Albright-Knox Art Gallery, is in fact the first museum attempt to survey the entire territory in more than 20 years. It is particularly welcome now, after a decade of retrospectives on all the major members of the New York School, at a time when Abstract
LEAD: WHILE most people are aware that environmental hazards exist, Dorothy Noyes, a public health educator from Hamden, maintains that children suffer the consequences more than adults.
LEAD: ALTHOUGH Richard Taracka has seen many unusual sights while diving beneath the waters of Long Island Sound, nothing, he said, compares with the current scene.

LEAD: COLLEGE recruiters were once recent graduates just past acne who were given a credit card and a late-model car and pointed in the general direction of St. Louis. Their brochures described the 110 rolling acres above the Missouri, Ohio or Colorado River, the 10.5 million bound volumes in the college library, and the minimum test scores needed to enroll.
LEAD: BELLE MOSKOWITZ:

LEAD: An Army appeals court has ruled that results of a test for the AIDS virus may be used to help prosecute a soldier who is accused of having sexual0relations with three people after learning he was infected.

LEAD: If American homes undergo a radical change in the coming decades, it will almost certainly be the addition of a new room or area: an office. In fact, according to several government and industry estimates, some 10 to 20 million workers have already moved home. Although their offices' design may become of increasing concern, current considerations involve the selection of telephones, computers, copiers and other instruments of commerce.

LEAD: ''BASICALLY, IT STARTED OUT with a house, a boat and a fence that I built,'' says the artist Jennifer Bartlett, referring to the objects that have provided her predominant theme for the past two years. Exhibits of her work - one of paintings, one of pastel drawings, all with the three images -have already been held at the Paula Cooper Gallery in the SoHo section of Manhattan.

LEAD: At first the attraction is purely physical: a shapely leg, a graceful back, the silhouette of an arm, the expression of the eyes. To any novice the experience is haunting, the purchase irresistible. To the veteran, it is a symptom of the embryonic collector. Similar tales have been recorded over and over again.

LEAD: OVER THE LAST 15 YEARS, James Levine has appeared in occasional chamber and even symphonic programs in this city, has led the Chicago Symphony at the summer Ravinia Festival since 1973 and has made numerous orchestral recordings, in particular his Mahler cycle on RCA, which has recently been reissued on compact disks.
LEAD: WE do not shoot at birds in the dark because the law and common sense forbid it. Hunters who never pattern their shotguns are metaphorically shooting in the dark.

LEAD: Shortly after St. Louis won the final National League playoff game against San Francisco, Whitey Herzog said he expected to use John Tudor as his starting pitcher in the second game of the World Series and Danny Cox as the starter in the third game. After thinking about it for 24 hours, though, the manager reversed the order.

It's not Brienz - it's Brienzwiler, about three miles away, from which there is a forest path going uphill from the lakeside station to the museum. There are no taxis at Brienz.

It has paid nearly $500,000 to repair bridges on the 18-hole course and lay sod on the stream bed. However, the water is so swift and deep that even the contractor for the job, MEI Environmental Services of Atlantic

LEAD: There is a corner of Rome, a tangle of crooked streets and alleys, a hardy survival of the Renaissance famous for six centuries, that yet is unknown to most Americans. It lies west of the Piazza Navona and behind the stately buildings that line the broad modern Corso Vittorio Emanuele. The painter Raphael dwelt in this corner, so did the Florentine sculptor and silversmith Benvenuto

LEAD: Don McPherson, the Syracuse quarterback, threw an 80-yard touchdown pass on the first play from scrimmage against Penn State today. And that was just the beginning of a surprisingly easy upset over the 1986 national champion Nittany Lions.

LEAD: NOW may be the time to go to medical or law school. Applications are down significantly, and the schools are scrambling for candidates. In 1974, when medical school applications peaked, there were 2.8 applicants for each available slot; now there are just about 2 prospects for each seat. The peak for law schools was not until fall 1980, but the valley is just as deep.

LEAD: In the assessment of Benjamin B. Braunstein, the special kinds of shops, galleries and eateries that have come to define SoHo are missing on West Broadway below Broome Street. And for no good reason.
LEAD: ''HELLO, as you probably can guess, I am out circulating,'' began the message on the recording machine. So the day introduced me into the way things do not work.

LEAD: VAUGHN PAUL and Duncan Soldner, two smalltime mushroom farmers, thought they had hit pay dirt when some bankers from Citicorp Industrial Credit wanted to help them do a leveraged buyout of Mushroom King Inc., the country's second-largest mushroom farm.

Jay Tanenbaum of Lawrence, L.I., to Stuart Graham Arthur. He is a son of Mrs. Donald Arthur of Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., and Manhattan, and the late Mr.

LEAD: In one sense, the Columbia Business School course taught by Asher B. Edelman promised to be the most rewarding class offered by the university this year. Mr. Edelman, an expert on corporate takeovers who is teaching a class on the subject, announced last month that the student who scored best on the final exam could get $100,000.
LEAD: The military filed charges today against 68 officers and 17 enlisted men for their part in an unsuccessful mutiny Aug. 28, a spokesman said today.

LEAD: BACK IN 1985, WHEN THE DE-sign for the skyscraper that has been proposed to replace the Coliseum at Columbus Circle was announced, the project, called Columbus Center, seemed certain to be built. It did not matter that Columbus Center was too big by half and was a ghastly piece of architecture to boot.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Gregory Peck is to receive the George Eastman Award for Distinguished Contribution to the Art of Film at a ''Hooray for Hollywood'' benefit ball at 8:45 P.M. on Oct. 24 at the George Eastman House, 900 East Avenue, Rochester.
LEAD: A map of Switzerland on Aug. 23 located the town of Kilchberg incorrectly. It is on the western shore of Lake Zurich.
LEAD: Jersey Joe Walcott, the former world heavyweight champion, took a fall of his own after the Mike Tyson-Tyrell Biggs fight Friday when he fell off a stage and cut his forehead.

LEAD: An aide to the Senate Judiciary Committee telephoned a law professor scheduled to testify in favor of Judge Robert H. Bork's nomination to the Supreme Court to warn him that he could expect a grueling public examination of both his academic career and scholarship.
LEAD: MISS UNDINE'S LIVING ROOM By James Wilcox. 275 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $16.95.
LEAD: Linking Pay to Profits
LEAD: A baby who received a heart transplant just hours after birth awoke and moved his arms and legs today on his second day of life.

LEAD: Shortly after the Communist victory in South Vietnam, a Cuban Air Force officer visited Vietnam and was given an opportunity to fly one of the American-made F-5 jets that were among the spoils of war.

LEAD: I KNOW where the beach plums grow. Down a side road near a solitary, sandy beach. Behind a lonely stretch of dune. In a privately owned garden close to the seaside. On Long Island, the wild beach plums are getting scarce.

LEAD: AT THE AGE OF 25, THE ANNUAL New York Film Festival, which closed one week ago tonight at Lincoln Center, has been running almost as long as Johnny Carson's ''Tonight Show,'' possibly for many of the same reasons. It has no overwhelming personality that turns audiences into fanatics who either love it or hate it.

LEAD: CHUCK BERRY The Autobiography. By Chuck Berry. Illustrated. 346 pp. New York: Harmony Books. $17.95.

LEAD: With belligerent questioning and pugnacious persistence, two defense lawyers in the Howard Beach case have emerged as the most aggressive of the four attorneys defending four Queens youths charged with murder or manslaughter.

LEAD: The scaffolding has been rising and falling around the facade of the Bolshoi Theater this year but, as of sometime next spring, it will be up for the long haul as the home of the world-renowned opera and ballet companies undergoes a major reconstruction.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Heroin with an estimated street value of $5 to $8 million was seized Friday night in a hotel in midtown Manhattan as undercover police officers concluded a 10-month investigation by arresting two suspected drug dealers and their four bodyguards.

LEAD: Kevin Sweeney working at Lilly's cafe at the Embarcadero Center in San Francisco. Mr. Sweeney was the national press secretary for Gary Hart, the former candidiate for the Democratic Presidential nomination. He found himself without a job when Mr. Hart withdrew from the campaign. (AP)

LEAD: Amid indications that well-intentioned tourists may be threatening the whale population off New England, the Federal Government is considering restrictions on a whale-watching industry that has become a mainstay of the Cape Cod economy.

LEAD: Julia Severance Robbins, a daughter of Louise N. Robbins of Greenwich, Conn., and John C. Robbins of New York, was married yesterday in Greenwich to Joseph Anthony Pierson, the son of Ann Roberts Harris of New York and the Rev. Robert L. Pierson of Columbiaville, N.Y. LEAD: PAULINE WOODRUFF is 74 years old, lives alone in her house in Montauk and depends on the sympathy of strangers to get by. LEAD: Nancy Reagan and her doctors chose to remove her entire left breast despite a variety of recent findings that less extreme surgery is as effective for small breast tumors like hers.

LEAD: When Stig Bergling, Sweden's best-known spy, broke out of prison recently, he did not have to carve a gun out of soap or tunnel under a wall. LEAD: TWO trends in contemporary camera design have converged in the Minolta Weathermatic Dual 35. As the name suggests, it is a 35-millimeter, automatic camera impervious to the elements. It can be submerged to a depth of 16 1/2 feet and it offers a choice of two focal lengths. While there are a multitude of 35-millimeter cameras with one or the other of these features, this is the first camera to have them both.

LEAD: Q. The paint on my bedrooms walls had alligatored, so the painter scraped and spackled the alligatored areas, then painted with latex. As he finished, areas that had not been spackled started to alligator. The painter says that there are three layers of paint on the wall and the bottom layer was probably oil paint, and that is why his latex paint alligatored.

LEAD: THE greatest menace while I was growing up came from abroad, from the Germans and the Japanese, our enemies because we were American. I still remember my terror as a 9-year-old when, running in from playing on the street after school, I saw the banner headline ''Corregidor Falls'' on the evening paper in our doorway and understood that the United States actually could lose the war it had entered only months before.

LEAD: AS THE LIGHTS DIM IN THE OPEN-ing moments of the Lincoln Center Theater revival of ''Anything Goes,'' the first sound one hears is a scratchy vintage recording of Cole Porter jauntily singing his 1934 title song about a world gone morally topsy-turvy.

LEAD: Massachusetts drivers, who file more property damage and theft claims than drivers anywhere else in the country, are facing double digit rate increases and a growing reluctance by insurers to continue writing policies in the state.
LEAD: Dr. Jane Ellen Brown, a psychiatrist, and Jon Warren Green, a lawyer, were married last evening at the United Nations Plaza Hotel in New York by Rabbi Abraham Klausner.

LEAD: ON a recent afternoon at Stew Leonard's, the huge supermarket in Norwalk, Richard Ash was busy sweeping up around the 24 checkout counters in front of the sprawling store, which says it draws about 100,000 customers each week.

LEAD: THERE'S ALWAYS SOME-thing to be learned from a hit - something about quality, if we're lucky; something about marketing or the Zeitgeist if not. Intentionally or despite itself, a hit crystallizes a cultural moment; its popularity ratifies some pervasive feeling. So I like to keep an eye on hits, and this summer's long-running, top-of-the-pops best seller among nonfiction books, Allan Bloom's ''Closing of the American Mind'' (Simon & Schuster), is a long-running No.

LEAD: JACOB TWO-TWO AND THE DINOSAUR By Mordecai Richler. Illustrated by Norman Eyolfson. 85 pp. Alfred A. Knopf. $10.95. (Ages 8 to 12) THE TAR PIT By Tor Seidler. 153 pp. New York: Michael di Capua Books/ Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $11.95. (Ages 10 and up)
LEAD: Whitey Herzog, managing in his third World Series in the past six years, received his answer early tonight.

LEAD: The Rangers didn't play well enough tonight to stave off a desperate charge by the Capitals, who earned a 4-3 victory on the strength of obstinate offense in the game's waning moments. The loss was the first of the season for the Rangers, whose record is 2-1-2, and it stunned them.
LEAD: On Sept. 6, you published anonymously a short, supposedly true story called ''My Night in Jail: A Driver's Story'' [ Opinion Page ] .
LEAD: EMANUEL Lasker's favorite piece of advice was: When you see that you have a good move, look around before playing it; there may be an even better one.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: A former University of Delaware football player says he allowed caustic oven cleaner to be poured over his head during a fraternity hazing ritual in 1980 because he ''wanted to be a brother.''
LEAD: New Jersey is offering $3,000 bonuses to attract registered nurses to work in the state's four psychiatric hospitals.
LEAD: In Maine, One Way To Sell a House

LEAD: WHEN Manfred Ohrenstein, the minority leader of the New York State Senate, was indicted last month on charges of misusing state funds, it was more than just the latest in a series of scandals that have shaken state lawmakers this year.

LEAD: Accusing a fellow rider of fondling her, a 27-year-old Queens woman angrily dragged a 31-year-old man off a crowded Lexington Avenue subway train Friday morning below Grand Central Terminal and beat him, according to the transit police.
LEAD: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 23 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

LEAD: Nebraska netted 617 yard, led by the quarterback, Steve Taylor, and the tailbacks, Ken Clark and Keith Jones, to extend its domination of Oklahoma State to 26 years with a 35-0 trouncing today in a Big Eight Conference game. Oklahoma State entered the game 5-0 record, its best start in 42 years.

LEAD: Weeks On Fiction List 1 A TASTE FOR DEATH, by P. D. James. (Warner, 3 $4.95.) Inspector Adam Dalgliesh investigates a brutal double murder. 2 IT, by Stephen King. (Signet/NAL, $4.95.) 9 Childhood horrors haunt six men and a woman who grew up in a small Maine town.
LEAD: A facsimile edition of a medieval manuscript of exceptional beauty will be published next year through an unusual collaboration between the Library of Congress and a Hungarian publisher.

LEAD: Dawn Andrea Dankner and Alan I. Rosen were married last evening at the Park Avenue Synagogue by Rabbi David H. Lincoln. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Dankner of Suffern, N.Y. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joel Rosen of Seaford, L.I.
LEAD: To The Sports Editor:

LEAD: Last call to finish lawn work; seed planted this late may not germinate, but since the seed is hardy, it will remain until early spring when it should sprout, if the birds don't get it first; place conifer branches over seeded bare patches to protect them. Keep mowing as long as the grass is growing and set mower to cut low, one to two inches.

LEAD: IN ''Biloxi Blues,'' the Neil Simon play now at the Arena Players Repertory Theater in East Farmingdale, Eugene Morris Jerome, the teen-ager of ''Brighton Beach Memoirs,'' has grown older and joined the Army. It is 1943, and basic training is for the serious business of war, but as viewed through Eugene's eyes, the

LEAD: IN CHER'S BEDROOM, there is seating for maybe a dozen. Opposite a wall of floor-to-ceiling windows that overlook one of the Beverly Hills is a long banquette. In front of the bed two enormous armchairs don't quite surround a vast ottoman. Like the walls of the living room downstairs that, reminiscent of an ancient tomb, open up to let visitors in from the driveway; and like the huge, supposedly mystical, crystal mounted in the family room, the bedroom arrangement seems reasonable.

LEAD: Robert A. Heinlein turned 80 this year. The title of his latest book, TO SAIL BEYOND THE SUNSET (Ace/Putnam, $18.95), comes from the conclusion of Tennyson's ''Ulysses,'' where that retired hero proclaims his desire to go down to the sea once more in search of adventure and ''a newer world.''

LEAD: Art, Antiques and Shows ORT Celebration Oct. 20 - Founded in 1880 to train the Jews of eastern Europe in industry and agriculture, ORT (Organization for Rehabilitation Through Training) has grown into a global network of schools and training centers for 158,000 adults and children in 18 countries.

LEAD: Walter Chatham is an architect who prides himself on the unconventional: His two-year-old sleeps in an industrial-size laundry bin, his dining room has columns but no walls and he treats cheap building materials such as salvaged pillars and corrugated steel with the same kind of reverence as he would hand-gilded cornice moldings or imported marble.

LEAD: At St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Hillsborough, Calif., Elena Bowes, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John G. Bowes of San Francisco, was married yesterday to Peter Damien Marano, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Rocco J. Marano of Chatham, N.J. The Rev. Jerome Politser performed the ceremony.
LEAD: THE SHIFTING POINT 1946-1987. By Peter Brook. Illustrated. 254 pp. New York: A Cornelia and Michael Bessie Book/ Harper & Row. $22.50.

LEAD: WHEN the Manchus toppled China's Ming Dynasty in 1644, supporters of the Ming emperors fled to southern China and the island of Taiwan, vowing that they would soon recover the mainland. They never did, of course, although the invading Manchus were gradually assimilated into Chinese society and culture.

LEAD: PRECISELY one year - and five opening nights - after East Coast Arts made a splashy debut in New Rochelle, its artistic director, Joe Cacaci, was reflecting upon the unusual organization, with its professed purpose of showcasing and developing new plays away from critical pressure. ''We're doing exactly what we had conceived,'' Mr.

LEAD: DESPITE HIS thick glasses, rumpled jacket, a tie that barely reaches past his sternum and the obligatory chalk-covered pants of a professor, he cuts a handsome figure. Striding across the room in long, sure steps, he conducts his lecture like a maestro, the rat-a-tat-tat of the chalk on the board providing a counterpoint to his high, breathy, sometimes inaudible voice.
LEAD: JENNIE ZACHS can recall the days when talking during services at the Agudas Achim synagogue in Hartford could bring a 25-cent fine.

LEAD: Barbara Tuchman's article successfully delineates the malaise afflicting this country. The New York Times Magazine itself is a prime example of our illness. Mrs. Tuchman's article should have been the cover and the lead story in the magazine. Instead, you featured Marcello Mastroianni - a perfect example of the use of image over substance and shallowness over relevance, and a significant indication that The Times will not make the effort to ''raise the level of public understanding from frivolity to a readiness to take serious things seriously .
LEAD: In an abrupt shift from its policy of the last eight months, the United States is allowing the dollar to decline against the West German mark, a senior Administration official said today.

LEAD: I WOULD like to give a cheer, a resounding huzza for that generally considered dubious position of ''being in the middle.'' By that I refer to the very comfortable circumstances of being neither at the top nor the bottom of whatever it is that you do or are.

LEAD: UNTIL THIS MONTH, prospects had been dim for improvements of the technical quality of American television. While Japan and several European countries were eagerly experimenting with advanced transmission systems that yield pictures far superior to those seen at present, the United States appeared stuck with standards formulated 50 years ago.

LEAD: A HOMEOWNER who signed up for a $50,000 equity loan last year could have obtained an introductory interest rate that put the monthly cost at $300. Rate increases would have brought the monthly payments to $438 by January and, after four more increases this year, the payment would have increased to $504 this month.

LEAD: The Vatican announced plans today to restore legal standing to a rebel French Archbishop and his outlawed following of traditionalist priests, in a move to mend fences with one of its most vociferous critics.

LEAD: When President Corazon C. Aquino handed out the first 237 grants in her land redistribution program last summer, she told the recipients she felt like a poor father who has only 100 pesos to divide among his 10 children.

LEAD: THINGS are definitely amiss, awry, amok on the Isle of Swans. No sooner does older sister Alexandra (Rosemary Hochschild) set foot on the sandy shore with the family handyman Tom (Lindzee Smith) in search of Isabelle (Rhonda Wilson), who has been living there with a sailor named William Clare, who has lately disappeared, than everybody starts giving out with platitudinous poeticisms and picking on each other.

LEAD: GIANNI POLI, an Italian who had never won a major marathon until he captured the event in New York last year, will defend his title in the race Nov. 1. Poli defeated a field that included the two-time defending champion, Orlando Pizzolato of Italy and the 1983 world champion, Rob de Castella of Australia.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: FEW bureaucratic conflicts are more bitter or more deeply rooted than the feud between the Commerce and Defense Departments over control of exporting sensitive technology to the Soviet bloc nations.

LEAD: EVERY time I return from clothes shopping, no matter how little or how much I buy and regardless of the amount of money I spend, I almost immediately sink into a state of depression. Based on my readings of self-help articles in women's magazines, I have unearthed many plausible explanations for this ''post-shopping depression syndrome.

LEAD: MUSIC lovers on the prowl for offbeat programming have much to cheer about this week, because several concerts around the county have put aside the war horses in favor of less frequently heard pieces of the repertory.
LEAD: ''CIRCE,'' which the Martha Graham Dance Company presented for the first time this season at the City Center on Thursday night, is one of Miss Graham's mythological pieces with a difference.

LEAD: Sylvain Turgeon deflected Dave Babych's shot from the right point into the net 3 minutes 59 seconds into overtime tonight to give Hartford a 4-3 victory over the Devils. The Whalers snapped their losing streak at five games.

LEAD: Re: ''Iranian Jews' Request Stirs Ire in Great Neck'' [ Sept. 20 ] : We appeal to those opposing an Iranian Jewish presence in Great Neck to consider the cause and effect that brought an exotic group to their doorstep.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Edward S. Tishman of New York and Warren, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Leslie Ann Tishman, to Gary M. Inman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bobby R. Inman of Mount Airy, N.C. A May wedding is planned. Ms. Tishman, a graduate of the Purnell School, is the assistant to the publisher at Columbia Communications Inc., which publishes trade magazines in New York.

LEAD: Gary Wilkos set a Monsignor Farrell school record yesterday when he passed for 378 yards in Farrell's 35-7 victory over St. John the Baptist. He completed 27 of 36 attempts in the Catholic High School Football League game as Farrell improved to 4-0. Four of Wilkos's passes were for touchdowns, and Farrell's other touchdown came when Wilkos ran the ball in.

LEAD: The only pitcher ever to lose three games in one World Series honestly is back in the Series six years later. George Frazier, however, will not lose three games this time. Unlike Bob Lemon, who managed the Yankees in the 1981 Series, Tom Kelly will not give him the opportunity to lose three games this time.
LEAD: BLUEBEARD By Kurt Vonnegut. 300 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $17.95.

LEAD: Mrs. Benjamin Hoffman Barnett Jr. of Haverford, Pa., has announced the engagement of her daughter Elizabeth Anne Barnett to Jeffrey Dean Schmidt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Schmidt of Greenwich, Conn. The couple plan to marry in November.

LEAD: Despite inflation in Europe and the dollar's tumble from its high in early 1985, it is still possible to get a decent hotel room in London, Paris and Rome for about $100 a night for two people. You may have to go off the beaten path, and you will not find such amenities as full room service, free air-conditioning or on-premises parking.

LEAD: THE American car has been the stuff of legend - in lyrics, literature, even love - since the early part of this century. But in the last 10 years, it has been transformed more drastically than at any other time in the previous 50 years. Faced with two energy crises in the 1970's and fierce competition from Japan,
LEAD: A Columbia University panel has proposed that the graduate schools of architecture, the arts, journalism and library service pool some staff and resources.

LEAD: TWO young boys carrying baseball gloves and strolling along Johnson Avenue, Riverdale's bustling shopping thoroughfare, told a visitor recently that they liked living in the community, which hovers on a bluff overlooking the Hudson River. ''I would hate living in the city,'' said one.

LEAD: It is quite safe to make long-range forecasts. By the time reality catches up with you, everyone has forgotten what you said. It is short-term predictions that often leave you with egg on your face. Luckily, home electronics is an exception to this rule. Even short-range prophecy is relatively risk-free, because the future is so close its main features are already clear, even if details and timing are not.

LEAD: A vital but largely ignored component of our national security policy - the treatment and resettlement of Soviet and Soviet bloc defectors - is receiving some long-overdue attention this month by Congress.
LEAD: First-half touchdowns by Anthony Stafford, Jamielle Holieway and Lydell Carr today led top-ranked Oklahoma to its 15th consecutive victory, a 59-10 trouncing of Kansas State.

LEAD: The cultural highlights in Europe this fall and winter range from the opening of a new Chinese Export gallery in London to a dance festival in Paris and carnival in Venice. The listing is based on information from New York Times bureaus in London, Paris, Rome, Bonn and Madrid. Dollar figures are approximate.

LEAD: A LARGE part of the growing trade problem facing us today has occurred simply because the American people continue to show that they will go anywhere for quality. Unfortunately, ''anywhere'' often means straight to a department store or auto dealer to buy products or services from one of our offshore competitors.
LEAD: ZERO GRAVITY By Richard Lourie. 284 pp. San Diego. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $16.95.

LEAD: BERGEN COUNTY officials have begun a major consolidation that will put about 600 county employees under the same roof here while relieving congesting in or eliminating six separate buildings throughout the city.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Richard McIlwaine Lilly of London and Essex, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Catherine Huse Lilly, to Peter Osborne Frisch, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Frisch of Rye, N.Y. A May wedding is planned.

LEAD: A few weeks ago at the training camp of Tyrell Biggs in Lancaster, Pa., Biggs's trainer, George Benton, was walking his man through a fight plan that was calculated to unravel Mike Tyson.
LEAD: ONE had to admire the enterprise of the young Concert Opera of Manhattan, which presented the New York premiere of ''Il Viaggio a Reims'' by Rossini in concert form Friday night at Town Hall.
LEAD: THE ARTFUL ALBANIAN Memoirs of Enver Hoxha. Edited by Jon Halliday. 394 pp. Topsfield, Mass.: Salem House Publishers. Paper, $9.95.

LEAD: Dr. and Mrs. Ernest Maurice Vandeweghe of Bel Air, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Tauna Kay Vandeweghe, to Robert Kennish Mullarkey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas F. X. Mullarkey of Locust Valley, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

LEAD: The wedding of Susan Michele Epstein to Morton Jay Fertel took place yesterday evening at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I. Rabbi Neil Kurshan performed the ceremony, assisted by Cantor Marcus Ehrlich.

LEAD: A Washington dispatch last Sunday about a statement by law-enforcement officials that the Justice Department was likely to indict E. F. Hutton & Company misstated the company's connection to two previous incidents. The company had no legal involvement in the cases, which involved a company broker, Andy Yurowitz, and a company executive, Arnold
LEAD: ''I believe in a strong defense; he believes in a strong defense, I'm a Southerner; he's a Southerner.''
LEAD: AT one time or another, most dog owners have thrown a Frisbee, hoping their dog can catch the disk on the fly. Not all can, and more often than not the Frisbee misses the mark and hits the dog.

LEAD: A Warmer Grave One of the most painful decisions in mountain climbing is whether to try to bring down the body of a dead comrade. This is from ''Degrees of Difficulty'' (Mountaineers Books) by Vladimir Shatayev, a Russian climber.

LEAD: Indian peacekeeping troops, moving only yards a day in some places in their advance on the Tamil guerrilla stronghold of Jaffna, are being attacked by snipers in trees, bunkers and fortified houses, an Indian official said today in an unusually candid description of the fighting.

LEAD: Tony Rice, a sophomore option quarterback who started his first collegiate game today, ran for two first-quarter touchdowns, and Tim Brown provided an insurance score with a 74-yard punt return in the final period as Notre Dame routed the Air Force Academy, 35-14.

LEAD: Q. The paint on my bedrooms walls had alligatored, so the painter scraped and spackled the alligatored areas, then painted with latex. As he finished, areas that had not been spackled started to alligator. The painter says that there are three layers of paint on the wall and the bottom layer was probably oil paint, and that is why his latex paint alligatored.

LEAD: GLITTERING IMAGES. By Susan Howatch. (Knopf, $18.95.) Susan Howatch's 12th novel takes place in pre-World War II England, just after Edward VIII abdicated to marry the divorced Wallis Simpson. The event is emblematic, for this novel is about marriage and divorce and proper behavior within a religious context.

LEAD: Bernard King has signed an offer sheet with the Washington Bullets. A source said that the offer sheet, signed Friday, will pay him $2.3 million over the next two years. In order to retain King, the Knicks must match the offer within 15 days from the signing.

LEAD: ONE of the few faces that would have been familiar to fans at Riverfront Stadium in Cincinnati today has declined to appear. Ken Anderson, the Bengals' five-time Pro Bowl quarterback who retired before this season, was to have been honored at halftime of the Bengals-Browns game. ''It's personally up to him, and I guess he wanted to have it when the regulars are back,'' said a team spokesman, Allan Heim.

LEAD: Athletes who reach the Olympic level in sailing tend to be the best and the fittest. Yet they are vulnerable. A trick knee, a bad wrist or a nagging weight loss can spell disaster in the final throes of competition. A new opportunity has come along that may reduce those risks significantly.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Strollers in the quiet Celestins quarter of Paris, between the Place de la Bastille and the Ile St.-Louis, are sometimes startled to turn a corner and see clattering toward them, as if from another century, a mounted troop of the Garde Republicaine, glorious in plumed helmets, white breeches and crimson-piped blue uniforms.

LEAD: Hoping to bring new life to at least five darkened Broadway theaters, Mayor Koch yesterday proposed the creation of a theater trust fund to be financed in part by a $1 surcharge on tickets to other Broadway shows.

LEAD: Taiwan was virtually assured of a semifinal place in the world contract bridge team championship open series, and the United States was equally well placed in the women's series as qualifying play resumed today.

LEAD: ''Most of the people in our office, who are younger than we are, are much more conservative, and much less flexible.'' - Alan Wanzenberg, 36, a Manhattan architect, as quoted in Progressive Architecture magazine 'Modernism lasted 80 years before it was severely attacked, but post-modernism has only lasted eight years.

LEAD: In the world of gardening, no word is more peculiar than new. Mail-order nursery catalogues, especially the more sensational ones that like to promise miracles, tend to use it a lot, in boldface type followed by an exclamation point, or maybe three. But if a catalogue lists something as new, it generally means only that the plant so described is new to that particular nursery.

LEAD: As the season nears when the nor'easters pound Cape Cod Bay, hundreds of volunteers are being organized and trained to rescue the pilot whales and other large marine mammals that are often driven ashore by the storms.

LEAD: Columbia scored two touchdowns yesterday, one on a faked punt early in the game and the other with eight seconds left, and blocked a couple of kicks. But the team's overall picture continued to be a nightmare.

LEAD: As harvesters cut their way last year through the sugar cane fields that surround this tiny sunbaked village, the tough, well-organized farmers who live here moved in behind them, seizing the land for themselves.

LEAD: Iran's missile attacks against Kuwait's main oil port have increased pressure on the Reagan Administration to take action against Iranian missile sites to prevent strikes that might destroy Kuwaiti fuel plants, according to Government officials familiar with the situation.

LEAD: YOU stay where you have been asked to sit for a minute. You are blindfolded and wear padded earmuffs that exclude sound. For all practical purposes, you are blind and deaf. You sit there in utter darkness and stone silence, confident that the promise will be kept, that you will be retrieved in a minute.

LEAD: The Federal Aviation Administration, under attack from private pilots for closing a special air corridor over the Los Angeles International Airport, is planning new procedures to allow these pilots guaranteed passage through the heavily congested airspace.

LEAD: Nobody sings ''I'm Still Here,'' Stephen Sondheim's song about surviving the ups and downs of show business, with more knowingness than Julie Wilson. LEAD: Additional titles of interest:
LEAD: IN 1984, Louisa Whitlock, a soft-spoken Bernardsville resident, walked along the Nicaragua-Honduras border with a New Jersey peace group.

LEAD: A radium-supply company in New York City, under fire for radiation-safety violations since 1983, pledged last night to empty its radioactive plant within two months and to accept full legal responsibility for decontaminating the premises.

LEAD: PUNK ROCK'S PROMISE, WHEN it arrived on the mid-70's pop scene in a burst of apocalyptic fury, was that from now on, things would be different. In England, punk anger and punk style signaled a social upheaval. But punk's most far-reaching impact was within rock itself. The music was dominated by middle-aged stars, relics of the 60's who had distanced themselves from the driven intensity and nose-thumbing irreverence of their early years.
