LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: The world's most stable parliamentary democracy will go to the polls Sunday and most of the world will not take notice. To tell the truth, the Swiss are not too excited, either.

LEAD: ''SAYONARA,'' the musical version of James A. Michener's 1952 novel at the Paper Mill Playhouse through next Sunday, is purely and purposefully sumptuous, and that is the most instantly gratifying thing about it.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: The city has many names: Bankfurt, Krankfurt, Angstfurt, Mainhattan. All are pejorative and allude to Frankfurt-on-Main's postwar reputation as the city Europe loves to hate. Why? Because it became West Germany's commercial center, the country's business and financial capital.

LEAD: BASED on a combination of oil market fundamentals and OPEC policies, oil prices are expected to fluctuate around an upward trend for the balance of the decade. LEAD: A new picture emerged in a State Supreme Court hearing last week of the events leading up to the arrest last year of Larry Davis, the 21-year-old South Bronx man accused of killing four suspected drug dealers and, last November, wounding six officers in a shootout with the police.

LEAD: Polemics have raged over the bright colors used in the restoration of Michelangelo's Sistine Chapel frescoes, but there is one Roman monument, now surrounded with scaffolding, that everyone agrees should remain dark and gloomy even after it is refurbished.
LEAD: Pat Robertson, a Republican candidate for President, refused today to apologize to Nancy Reagan for a remark he made Friday night that was interpreted as being critical of her.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: Hundreds of people jammed a tribal community center as the Penobscot Indians played high-stakes bingo games for the first time since the practice was halted four years ago. Many paid $50 to get into the $10,000 jackpot games. Nobody won the grand prize.

LEAD: Henry Kamm has made a crucial point that needs emphasis (''A Broken Country,'' Sept. 20): eight years after the killing fields, Cambodia today is still a broken country inhabited by broken-hearted, underfed and uneducated people with little hope and practically no help from the rest of the world.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Because of a transcription error, an article last week about Edward S. Gordon's plans for the Bridgehampton Racquet and Surf Club site included a misattributed quotation. It was Ulrich Franzen who said he was concerned that ''in order to turn the club property into a profitable venture, Mr. Gordon will sell lots on the periphery of the club, leaving the club itself intact.

LEAD: HERE in Ossining, only 40 minutes by train from the heart of New York City, my neighbor Carole keeps hens. In her lingo, they are the ''girls,'' a modest flock of them. There are just enough birds to supply eggs for her family of three plus a few friends. And the eggs are not really the payoff.

LEAD: LAND AND LABOR Peter MacDonald, chairman of the Navajo Nation, will address the Economic Club of Connecticut in Stamford on Friday, urging companies to consider situating manufacturing facilities on the Navajo Reservation, which covers parts of Utah, Arizona and New Mexico.

LEAD: Susan Wu, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Wu of Kingston, N.Y., was married yesterday to Richard Eng, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kai Eng of Jackson Heights, Queens. The Rev. Gregory J. Sutterlin officiated at Augustana Evangelical Lutheran Church in East Elmhurst, Queens. The bride, a summa cum laude graduate of Mercy College, is a buyer for the Mine, a specialty apparel store in Scarsdale and Mount Kisco, N.Y.

LEAD: IN EXHIBITIONS, AS IN MANY AN-other department of life, there is no mistaking the hand-sewn look. Hand-sewn tailoring calls for exceptional skills, long experience, superfine materials and fine judgment at every stage along the way. Hand-sewn work looks right, feels right, is right, and it cannot be counterfeited.
LEAD: In Burlington, a city better known for frigid weather than heated politics, a battle is under way over a crusade conducted by the socialist Mayor.

LEAD: When it was over, the Islanders stood in the middle of Nassau Coliseum, refusing to leave the ice or to recognize that there was no time remaining. Finally they left, but it took them some time to accept their first loss of the season.

LEAD: Pat Cash of Australia, the Wimbledon champion, scored a 6-3, 2-6, 7-6 victory over the defending champion, Boris Becker of West Germany, tonight to advance to the final of the $345,000 Australian Indoor tennis championships. Cash will play Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia.

LEAD: To the Editor: I believe that Mr. Dornberg erred in saying that Girar-det in Crissier ''has three Michelin stars.'' While I feel that Girardet is one of the two greatest restaurants in the world, second only to Taillevent in Paris, I have never been able to find it rated by Michelin.

LEAD: WHERE COMES A TIME when the nature of one's interest in a tragedy becomes historical, to use the word loosely; not human, to use that word loosely. When I was 13, I was taken to Pompeii, and the guide spoke about the phenomenon and dealt only macrocosmically with the human tragedy. LEAD: THE next man elected Islip Town Supervisor might well ride into town atop a garbage barge.

LEAD: Unbeaten Paterson Kennedy built a 17-0 lead but had to rally for two touchdowns in the fourth period to subdue Clifton, 30-26, yesterday in Hinchliffe Stadium in Paterson. It was Kennedy's fourth triumph and the first defeat for Clifton in four games.

LEAD: THE 1965 act that established Medicare began with the ringing declaration of a principle that the American Medical Association considers as fundamental as the separation between church and state: Nothing in this law shall be construed to authorize any Federal employee to ''exercise any supervision or control over the practice of medicine'' or over the compensation of any person providing health services.

LEAD: COLD weather and German food are made for each other. October's nippy air calls for hearty food rather than summer's lighter fare. The Smithtown Haus doesn't have an Oktoberfest extravaganza, but it has added a special item to the menu and labeled it Oktoberfest.

LEAD: IT has been two and a half years since both the Guggenheim and the Whitney museums announced their intentions to build major additions to their buildings. The fate of the Guggenheim's plans may be decided this week, but the Whitney still has only just begun to work its way through the city's lengthy approval process.

LEAD: THE pace of home-building and waterfront redevelopment has picked up in this shipbuilding town of 10,000 on the Kennebec River after a period in which it lagged behind development in Maine coastal villages and suburban housing centers.

LEAD: Q. The paint on my bedrooms walls had alligatored, so the painter scraped and spackled the alligatored areas, then painted with latex. As he finished, areas that had not been spackled started to alligator. The painter says that there are three layers of paint on the wall and the bottom layer was probably oil paint, and that is why his latex paint alligatored.
LEAD: Nancy Reagan's cancerous left breast was removed today in a 50-minute operation without complications, the White House said.

LEAD: THE idea of outsiders wandering through a co-op building, a condominium or a homeowner association complex has always been troubling to the residents. That is why the rental of a facility, like a clubhouse or a community room, for use by nonresidents has long been controversial.

LEAD: The Athens skyline is supposed to bristle a little with antiquity. These days, the bristling comes more from the ravages of modernity on older things, symbolized in the gantries and scaffolding atop the Acropolis, which in recent years have grown to enfold the Parthenon.

LEAD: AMID THE HOTHOUSE ATMOS-phere of the Martha Graham Dance Company gala opening at the City Center - with a historic if not necessarily compatible trio of Russian guest stars - the program on display suddenly clarified a strangely overlooked aspect of recent Graham seasons: Unlike other modern-dance troupes and even many ballet companies, the Graham company has increasingly expanded the range of its repertory during the 1980's.

LEAD: GIVEN the glut of art that now prevails, a time when there wasn't enough to go around can hardly be imagined. Yet according to Audrey McMahon, this was the situation as recently as the 1920's, when she became head of the College Art Association and, as quoted by Francis V. O'Connor in ''The New Deal for Art'' of 1972, found that knowledge and appreciation of the subject went no farther west than the Alleghenies.

LEAD: Associate Justice Thurgood Marshall of the Supreme Court vowed today to outlive critics who have called for his retirement.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article about bottle laws in The Week in Review Oct. 4 misstated the status of legislation in California. A recent California law, designed to encourage recycling, involves no deposit but gives consumers a penny per container turned in. It represents a compromise between the beverage industry and environmentalists.
LEAD: THE Speyer School, at 514 West 126th Street, is an empty derelict, its windows broken or blocked up, its elaborate ornament gradually decaying.

LEAD: Children are a nation's greatest future resource; that's why America is heading for trouble. In the next 12 weeks, President Reagan will either seize - or forfeit - his last chance to do something about it.

LEAD: When Barbara Tuchman writes that ''In the Iran-contra affair, the most egregious case of incompetence . . . is the sale and delivery of arms to Iran without obtaining fulfillment of their side of the bargain,'' she misses the forest for the trees. LEAD: I grew up in a household dominated by old-fashioned principles of thrift. ''To buy'' was not a verb my mother liked; ''to save'' was preferable. Browsing through downtown department stores was never her habit, although no one doubted her eye at an antiques shop. She ran a tight ship -lights out when you leave the room, the thermostat at 60 degrees, save the leftovers and don't throw anything away that might prove useful.

LEAD: The outlawed Solidarity trade union has given no discernible reaction to the Polish Government's proposed package of political and economic changes, announced last weekend, despite pressure on the union to respond formally.

LEAD: For most of this year, one of London's most photographed monuments, the statue of Lord Nelson in Trafalgar Square, has been wrapped in scaffolding. For most of that time, only the cocked hat atop Nelson's head was visible above the thick green brattices attached to the scaffolding. By the end of this month, amid much hoopla, the 144-year-old statue will be unveiled again, with the cracks in Nelson's brow and sword newly plugged with epoxy resin.

LEAD: Lou Piniella, the current Yankee manager, confirmed today that he met for at least two hours Thursday with the team's principal owner, George Steinbrenner, although there was apparently no resolution regarding Piniella's status. LEAD: THE Thai food craze hit Manhattan years ago. Until recently, Long Island had only one Thai restaurant. Once you left Manhattan, after passing a scattering of Thai outposts in Queens, the Seeda Restaurant in Cedarhurst was the sole bastion of Thai food.

LEAD: The Rev. W. Herbert Brewster Sr., a leading gospel composer, died of a heart attack Wednesday at St. Joseph Hospital in Memphis, where he lived. He was 90 years old. Two of his compositions, ''Move on Up a Little Higher'' (1946) and ''Surely, God Is Able'' (1949) were the first black gospel recordings to sell more than one million records, according to The New Grove Dictionary of American Music.

LEAD: A 4-year-old boy, playing at an uncle's security company office, picked up a .38-caliber revolver and shot his 3-year-old sister to death, the police said Friday. ''It appears to be totally accidental,'' a police spokesman said. The shooting occurred Thursday night when the boy, David Dallas, and his sister, Maggie, were at Dallas Security Patrol while relatives prepared guards for a night shift.
LEAD: An unexpected 66-yard touchdown run by the Bruin quarterback, Mark Donovan, and a blocked punt leading to another touchdown were the big plays as Brown upset Cornell today, 23-15.

LEAD: The stereotype of antiques dealers is that they have too much in common with their wares. Or, as Wheelock Whitney, a 38-year-old Manhattan art specialist who still looks like a prep-school boy with loafers and no socks, puts it, ''They're all antiques themselves.'' But in recent years, Whitney and a host of other dealers in their 20's and 30's have entered the field, proving that it doesn't require decades of either expertise or earnings to develop a business and an eye for quality.

LEAD: Margaret Louise Howell, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William B. Howell of Atlanta, was married there yesterday at her parents' home to John Pearson Wright, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Wright of Newport News, Va., by the Rev. Austin Ford, an Episcopal priest.

LEAD: To many a traveler passing through, nothing could be better than to bring home a piece of the land itself - hand-painted with the thistles of the fields, or an old vendor on a country road, or barnyard buddies cackling and crowing - a piece, for instance, of the tin-glazed earthenware called faience.
LEAD: ANIA MALINA By Lawrence Osborne. 201 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $14.95.

LEAD: After years of ups and downs, Jerusalem's soccer fans can be forgiven for feeling that they are no closer than they were 10 years ago to getting the new stadium that has become something of a symbol of Israel's modern strife.

LEAD: The sleek silver building at 23 Ames Street is formally part of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. But instead of physics or engineering students, it is populated by rock stars, corporate executives, computer hackers and visionaries.

LEAD: Jill Stauffer, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John E. Stauffer of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to James Ware Cobbs Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. James W. Cobbs of Greenwich and Eaton, N.H. The Rev. Ralph E. Ahlberg performed the ceremony at the Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich.

LEAD: Linda Livingston Packer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William B. Packer of Ambler, Pa., and James Peter Nicholas, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas J. Nicholas of San Diego, were married yesterday at St. Thomas' Episcopal Church in Whitemarsh, Pa., by the Rev. Richard T. Hawkins.

LEAD: It is the time to think about apple pie again. Apples are at their peak now, with a wide choice available in the markets at low prices. Pears are coming in, too, and as winter draws nearer more varieties will become available.
LEAD: FOR more than 100 years the village of Niantic has been the thriving business district of East Lyme, but business owners there say that is beginning to change.

LEAD: FRANCO ZEFFIRELLI'S two-year old production of ''Tosca'' lumbered onto the stage of the Metropolitan Opera again on Friday. It is a monument to men's need to create things larger than themselves. Indeed, people seemed somewhat puny next to the soaring Baroque interiors, gargantuan castle parapets and a jail cell that rose and descended - Otis-elevator-like.
LEAD: Quiet, stalking play by Anatoly Karpov was met by wary resistance from Gary Kasparov to produce a draw in the third game of their world championship chess match in Seville, Spain, Friday.
LEAD: ''LET Reagan Be Reagan'' has long been the cry of the President's conservative supporters.

LEAD: For the next 15 months, two pale yellow boxes will migrate around the Place de la Concorde in Paris. The official euphemism for these giant crates is architecture of protection, but they are in fact esthetically acceptable coverings for scaffolding that will progressively envelop eight statues of women representing eight cities of France: Lille, Rouen, Strasbourg, Marseilles, Lyons, Nantes, Brest and Bordeaux.

LEAD: SO what's the matter with youngsters today? When it comes to clothes, they seem to have this idea that it's O.K. to be a free spirit, to show some imagination, to break the rules. Or worse, to make up their own rules. Some of them look as if they reached into a dark closet and put on whatever they grabbed first.

LEAD: Thank you to Barbara Tuchman for her article ''A Nation in Decline?'' (Sept. 20). How clearly she defined the decline in values and competence that threatens us as a society and as a nation. MADGE EVANS Lake Worth, Fla.

LEAD: FROM THE DAWN OF HISTORY, sages have intertwined numbers with magic to create the gods, demons and world views needed by the rest of us to make existence seem comprehensible. The resulting lore has led to vast bodies of superstitious rigmarole, but it has sometimes spawned the luminous visions that draw scientists toward truth.

LEAD: AS the President of Costa Rica was being congratulated last week for winning the Nobel Peace Prize, the Reagan Administration was continuing to plan for the collapse of the peace agreement for which he was honored.

LEAD: Sgt. Clayton J. Lonetree, the former guard at the American Embassy in Moscow sentenced to 30 years in prison for spying, turned down a CBS News interview under pressure from the Marine Corps, according to the network and his civilian defense lawyers.

LEAD: Jeff Wiley threw for 389 yards and 3 touchdowns today as Holy Cross, ranked first in Division I-AA, routed Bucknell, 48-10, to clinch the Colonial League title.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about physics experiments in Japan misstated the nature of electrons and positrons, elementary particles of matter. Although apparently without internal structure, both have mass.

LEAD: LAST month, when RJR-Nabisco named as its chairman Charles E. Hugel, Combustion Engineering's chief executive, eyebrows shot up throughout the business community. Why, people asked, would an Atlanta consumer products company pick an Easterner who has no packaged goods experience, has never worked for RJR, and has his hands full running a $2.7 billion company some 900 miles away?
LEAD: When the Senate allows Hollywood-produced television spots to take over in its confirmation of justices, good lawyers make bad mistakes and innocent witnesses can be ground up in the process.

LEAD: LIKE so many non-English speaking singers of passionate temperament, Mercedes Sosa, the Argentine folk singer who performed at Carnegie Hall on Thursday evening, has elicited comparisons with Edith Piaf. Indeed, Ms. Sosa, like France's ''little sparrow,'' possesses a compelling populist voice, but instead of an urban music-hall tradition, her sensibility belongs to the Latin American folk movement known as nuevo cancion.

LEAD: Q. The paint on my bedrooms walls had alligatored, so the painter scraped and spackled the alligatored areas, then painted with latex. As he finished, areas that had not been spackled started to alligator. The painter says that there are three layers of paint on the wall and the bottom layer was probably oil paint, and that is why his latex paint alligatored.

LEAD: In ''Henri Cartier-Bresson: The Early Work,'' at the Museum of Modern Art through Nov. 29, Peter Galassi, a curator in the museum's department of photography, has changed our way of seeing an artist we thought we knew. He has done so by focusing attention on the work Cartier-Bresson did in the early 1930's, before the photojournalism for which he is best known.

LEAD: Well past the half-century mark, renovators and interior designers were more likely to strip, dismantle and paint over whatever they found in a building rather than preserve it. Flat-painted walls, industrial-style lighting and wall-to-wall carpets replaced or covered the original elaborately carved mantels and trims, wood floors and intricate wallpaper patterns.

LEAD: Heavy spring rains have transformed Johannesburg's well-groomed parks into green oases offering a refuge from the stresses of urban life. But the parks have also become the center of a heated dispute after a violent confrontation between whites and blacks last weekend.

Mozart's Symphony No. 41 (the ''Jupiter'') is also on the program. Although there is no charge, tickets are required; they may be obtained at the Juilliard Concert Office, 144 West 66th Street, Monday through Friday from 11 A.M.

LEAD: Marvin Sands, chairman of the Canandaigua Wine Company, jumped into the wine cooler business three years ago. He spent millions on machinery and promotion to make his company's Sun Country Cooler a hit. In so doing, he turned down the chance to buy out his company's outside shareholders.
LEAD: Nearly $1.4 million from an emergency program to shelter homeless people in New York City may have been improperly spent, according to an audit by the City Comptroller, Harrison J. Goldin.

LEAD: Jean-Luc Ponty, a jazz-fusion violinist, is to perform at Carnegie Hall tonight at 8 o'clock. Mr. Ponty, who has performed with Frank Zappa, Elton John and the Mahavishnu Orchestra, will play music from his new album, ''The Gift of Time.'' Tickets, $20, $22.50 and $25, are available at the Carnegie Hall box office, 57th Street at Seventh Avenue, or from Carnegie Charge: 247-7800.

LEAD: Cuts in foreign aid, plummeting commodity prices and rising African debt threaten hard-won economic gains made by African countries since the famine on the continent two years ago, according to a report by the United Nations.

LEAD: The Soviet Union dominated the Konica Cup international rhythmic gymnastics invitational, taking the team championship and sweeping the first three places in the all-round standing today. Marina Lobach won the all-round competition with 39.85 points out of 40.
LEAD: Treasury auctions this week start with today's sales of three-month and six-month bills, continue with a two-year note issue on Wednesday and end with a one-year bill issue on Thursday.
LEAD: Stopping illegal drugs at the border may take more drugs off the market at a lower cost than enforcing drug laws inside the United States, according to a study for the Customs Service.
LEAD: Personal Ensign, racing's newest star, remained undefeated by returning from one week of rest to beat all of New York's leading fillies in the $303,500 Beldame Stakes yesterday at Belmont Park.

LEAD: JACK JOHNSON, Frank Frost and Sam Carr, who made their first New York appearance at the Lone Star Cafe on Wednesday and Thursday, have been playing blues in the Mississippi Delta for more than 25 years. They recorded for Southern record labels in the 60's as Frank Frost and the Nighthawks, and more recently for the Chicago-based Earwig label as the Jelly Roll Kings.

LEAD: When the season finally moved into October, the Minnesota Twins were still in first place and still defying the critics who called them unworthy of an appearance in the postseason. But in a triumphant playoff and a stunning start to the 84th World Series, they have become baseball's darlings.

LEAD: At the age of 39, Viisha Sedlak would seem to be a mite old for a national track team, especially in an event she took up just two years ago, but then Sedlak is not an ordinary athlete and her's is not an ordinary event.
LEAD: India said today that it was sending 2,000 more troops to fight ethnic Tamil guerrillas in the Jaffna Peninsula.

LEAD: THE latest caper of the advertising department of the Reader's Digest is a 32-page insert in November. It will contribute an estimated $3 million to an issue with a record-breaking $16 million of advertising revenues.

LEAD: Timothy M. Fenton, 44 years old, will be joining Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt/Direct as president Monday. He is leaving McCaffrey & McCall, where he has worked since 1976, most recently as executive vice president, creative director of the direct marketing division. B.J.K.&E./ Direct is the 16th-largest direct-response agency in the United States, with billings of $50 million.
LEAD: The semifinal stage of the world team championships will begin here Monday with Taiwan opposing the United States and Britain clashing with Sweden.

LEAD: IN the most democratic of professional basketball worlds, every player would represent just one of 12 equal parts. But there has never been a basketball democracy because the difference between success and failure is so tenuous that it is often defined as much by a player's happiness as it is by his performance.

LEAD: It has been almost a year since four unions formed a coalition at Pan American World Airways and hired high-priced investment bankers to help them find an investor who would buy a large stake in the company, bring in new management and give the employees a sizable portion of stock in return for concessions.

LEAD: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan spent the first half of this year tailoring a welfare reform bill to win the widest possible support in the Senate. Now he's catching flak from welfare advocates in his home state who call the bill a ''sham reform'' -short on money and benefits and long on burdensome requirements.

LEAD: Kuwait sought Western help today to acquire a new anti-missile defense system as salvage workers confirmed that it was an Iranian Silkworm missile that blasted an American-registered tanker there on Friday.

LEAD: Danny Cox, the big-game pitcher for the St. Louis Cardinals, got into a really big game tonight. He didn't survive the fourth inning, chiefly because three of his pitches strayed higher than targeted. So, he was left with every pitcher's lament: ''I hope I'll get a second chance.''

LEAD: The New United Motor Manufacturing Inc. announced its third cutback in six months of Chevrolet Nova production. Nummi, the sole producer of the Nova, will reduce production to 450 of the cars a day, from 550, effective Nov. 30. The cutback is in anticipation of reduced 1988 model sales. But the General Motors Corporation and the Toyota Corporation, co-owners of the venture, said they had no plans to slow production of Toyota Corolla FX automobiles or lay off any of the factory's 2,500 employees.
LEAD: Could someone explain how a majority of Senators opposes Judge Robert H. Bork but not one of them last year voted against Antonin Scalia's nomination to the Supreme Court?

LEAD: The Noble School District in Norman, Okla., is reluctant to call an aide an aide. Last week it announced that library aides and teacher aides will be called assistants because of public anxiety over AIDS.

LEAD: Benjamin V. Lambert, the independent real estate deal maker who last year sold half his company, Eastdil Realty Inc., to Nomura Securities and then disappeared from the marketplace, has come out of hibernation.

LEAD: Richard Nixon learned it the hard way in 1960. Hubert Humphrey couldn't avoid it in 1968. Now George Bush is getting a taste of the unpleasant truth: it's not easy for a sitting vice president to be elected to the White House.

LEAD: Unesco's executive board voted today to nominate Federico Mayor Zaragoza of Spain to be the organization's next director general after Amadou-Mahtar M'Bow, the incumbent, announced his withdrawal from the race.

LEAD: James Tucker, the principal at Public School 93 in the heart of the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, remembers that a decade ago his school boasted a thriving parents association. By last year, three parents regularly visited the school; this year, none have turned up.

LEAD: Lynn Ann Ackerman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert W. Ackerman of Oceanside, L.I., and Daniel Marc Berger were married yesterday afternoon at the Harmonie Club in New York. The bridegroom is a son of Rabbi and Mrs. Philmore Berger of Oceanside. Rabbi Berger performed the ceremony.
LEAD: When Sheila Nagy invited President Reagan to have dinner with her ''normal American family,'' she asked him to call in advance so she would have time to defrost extra meat.

LEAD: As Treasury bond yields rose above 10 percent last week and stock prices plummeted, the financial markets were focused on the dangers from abroad and unimpressed by assurances from senior Government officials that interest rates were needlessly high and based on exaggerated fears of inflation.
LEAD: Florian Kempf joined the New Orleans Saints just in time to knock the Chicago Bears from their perch as the last undefeated team in the National Football League.

LEAD: W. Putnam Livingston, a retired vice president of the Bankers Trust Company and a leader in the use of computers in the banking industry, died of Alzheimer's disease Friday at a nursing home in Keene, N.H., where he was a longtime resident. He was 82 years old.
LEAD: If regular players couldn't stop Steve Largent in 142 games, replacement players weren't going to stop him in one.

LEAD: Borje Salming did not show up at Maple Leaf Gardens when the Leafs skated this morning despite a public apology from Harold Ballard, the team's owner, that opened the door for the veteran defenseman's return after a two-game absence.
LEAD: SECURITY COUNCIL

LEAD: THE Ballet du Nord, based in the northern French industrial city of Roubaix, near the Belgian border, showed off a new aspect of France's current dance boom in its United States debut Saturday night.

LEAD: Jessye Norman is hardly the first name that comes to mind when one mentions Duke Ellington. While her plangent soprano is one of the reigning voices in opera, when it comes to popular music, she has been on the quiet side. At least, up to now. Tonight, the acclaimed diva will sing at a benefit for the Duke Ellington Memorial Fund, along with her friend and president of the fund, the pianist Bobby Short, and the Amherst Saxophone Quartet.
LEAD: Trans World Airlines, which assigned its domestic account to Young & Rubicam in May last year, now follows that with the rest of its business.

LEAD: Martha Graham, a vital and busy force in American modern dance at the age of 93, continues to choreograph and oversee the running of her 32-member company, one of the world's leading dance troupes and currently performing at the City Center. Not much happens in the company's daily activities that escapes her notice.

LEAD: For her first venture in a television commercial, Liza Minnelli is appearing in a spot with four locations in New York, New York, singing a song she sang briefly in 1975 as star of the show ''Chicago.''
LEAD: Five dancers with American Ballet Theater are being promoted on Nov. 1, the company's artistic director, Mikhail Baryshnikov, has announced.

LEAD: Since Italy rebuilt after World War II, Mediobanca, the nation's most powerful merchant bank, has been known as ''il salotto buono,'' the good salon. Although the Government has held a controlling interest in the bank, its board room has served as a place for Italy's top capitalists to work out deals and settle disputes among themselves.

LEAD: Margeotes, Fertitta & Weiss has become the ad agency for Fred, the Fur Vault, a division of the Fur Vault. Billings are expected to exceed $4 million. The division has eight outlets in the New York area and Washington and is opening another in Scarsdale, N.Y., next month.
LEAD: If you like the Buffalo Bills, the game was horrible, but at least your team won. If you like the Giants, the game was worse than horrible.

LEAD: THE ECONOMY The stock market's big drop should be no cause for panic, members of the financial community said. Rather, they suggested, it should serve as a warning for certain policy steps that are much needed. [ Page A1. ] The drop in buying by foreign investors is worrying the credit markets.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: A picture caption Thursday with an article about homelessness in rural New York misidentified the woman holding a child at a welfare motel in New Hampton. She was the child's aunt, Ruth Decker, not his mother, Barbara Decker.

LEAD: Pat Ryan, the 32-year-old Jet quarterback who crossed the picket line Wednesday before the players' strike ended, had not played in four weeks. He had not thrown a pass in pads until Friday, and was suffering from rotator-cuff problems. Despite all of that, Ryan dominated the Miami Dolphins' replacement defense today and led the mostly replacement Jets to a dramatic 37-31 overtime victory in front of 18,249 fans at Giants Stadium.
LEAD: ANNA FERRARA's chief complaint about her husband, Joseph, was that he refused to talk to her in the morning.
LEAD: Douglas W. McMinn, Assistant Secretary of State for Economic and Business Affairs, is expected to offer his resignation today.

LEAD: Vladimir Feltsman leaned into the piano keyboard, filling a rehearsal room on the campus of the State University College here with the music of Franz Schubert. His audience listened intently, some followed on sheet music.

LEAD: A radium supply company in New York City, cited since 1983 for more than 100 radiation safety violations, has promised State Attorney General Robert Abrams that it will soon empty and decontaminate its plant in Queens.
LEAD: QUESTION: Is there any record for a World Series game that surpasses the major league one for a regular-season game?

LEAD: President Reagan tonight summoned Congressional leaders to the White House for a briefing, hours after he had declared that he had decided how to respond to the Iranian missile attack on an American-registered ship off Kuwait.

LEAD: More than 800 people formed a line through Central Park yesterday, opening black umbrellas on cue in a symbolic protest of the shadows that would be cast at certain times in the winter by the huge office towers planned on Columbus Circle.

LEAD: A $73 million expansion of La Guardia Airport's main terminal over the next four years, with new roads for arriving and departing traffic and an enlarged Central Terminal Building, was announced yesterday by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

LEAD: Officials of the United States Petroleum Corporation have announced plans to build a $100 million oil products refinery here. The company's president, Gene Blendermann, a retired Exxon Corporation executive, said the plant would process ''waxy crude'' oil from eastern Utah's Bluebell and Altamont fields.

LEAD: An article in Business Day on Thursday, about automobile sales in early October, misstated the light-truck sales of the Ford Motor Company. Ford sold 30,681 light trucks, 28.1 percent fewer than in the comparable 1986 period.

LEAD: Wine and malt coolers, the fruit and alcohol concoctions that just a few years ago were hailed as the savior of the alcoholic beverage industry, have hit a plateau. It seems that everyone has seen their advertising and tried them, but far fewer people are drinking them than the industry had predicted.

LEAD: Full of wonder and trust, the Alves family and their friends marveled at the mysterious capsule, in no way grasping that the force that made it shine in the dark could bring a slow and painful death.
LEAD: Martina Navratilova celebrated her 31st birthday today with a 7-5, 6-1 victory over Chris Evert in the final of the Virginia Slims women's tournament.
LEAD: Three at the Gate
LEAD: The police in the northern state of Punjab today detained three Sikh high priests whom officials accuse of having supported extremists there.
LEAD: THE FORDS. An American Epic. By Peter Collier and David Horowitz. Illustrated. 496 pages. Summit. $22.95.
LEAD: MORE than nine hours after it begins, Peter Brook's production of ''The Mahabharata'' is still not over - but at least the world is coming to an end.

LEAD: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday Capacity Utilization Sept. Tuesday Housing Starts Sept. Wednesday None Thursday None Friday Consumer Price Index Sept. Durable Goods Sept. Real Economic Growth Third Quarter

LEAD: A typhoon, designated Lynn, knocked out power on Guam and swept across the northern Marianas Islands in the western Pacific early today with winds over 100 miles an hour. Communities were evacuated and some damage was reported but but there were no reports of injuries on Guam or the islands of Rota, Tinian or Saipan, according to Civil Defense officials.
LEAD: IF duck and goose hunters will cease their lamentations about the widening legal obligation to use steel shotgun pellets, they can adapt to and possibly profit from the steel era.

LEAD: The Detroit Tigers and the other victims of the 1987 Minnesota Twins hardly need a couple of guys with slide rules to tell them what they learned the hard way this season -that it's no picnic taking on a team playing under its own cozy roof. But in case there are still some skeptics, two sociologists have come up with convincing statistical evidence that a dome magnifies the traditional home-team advantage even as it amplifies the cheers of the crowd.
LEAD: Roberto Lorca, a Spanish dancer and founder and director of the Spanish Dance Arts Company, died of an AIDS-related illness on Tuesday at Bellevue Hospital Center. He was 49 years old.

LEAD: The Whirlpool Corporation of Benton Harbor, Mich., said Friday that it had formed a joint venture with Sundaram-Clayton Ltd. of Madras, India, to make 100,000 washing machines and 100,000 refrigerators a year starting in 1989. Whirlpool's initial investment of $4.2 million gives it 33 percent ownership of the Indian company, the same as Sundaram-Clayton's share.
LEAD: International A3-14
LEAD: Women with AIDS are sicker and are dying more quickly than men who have the disease, a finding that is shocking and puzzling AIDS researchers.

LEAD: THE computer age could not help but affect dance sooner or later. Would Bill Young, who performed with his company on Friday evening at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater, have thought of or desired to create ''Interleaving'' in any other time? The new piece is made of four separate dances, with the beginnings of the four all being performed first, all the middle parts second and their endings last.
LEAD: A driver of a medallion cab was shot dead early yesterday in Washington Heights in what the police called an apparent robbery.

LEAD: On and off for the last year, Sam Lauter has driven around Washington in his black jeep, picking up Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. at his Senate office and delivering him to his numerous appointments. But now Mr. Lauter, of the Biden for President campaign, is looking for other work.

LEAD: Palestinian leaders from the West Bank and the Gaza Strip boycotted a scheduled meeting with Secretary of State George P. Shultz today, drawing a rebuke from Mr. Shultz for acting in contradiction to their stated desire to be heard.

LEAD: Because of a mechanical error, a dispatch from Paris on the Style page in some copies Saturday about a fashion collection by Christian Lacroix omitted the first paragraph. The article should have begun this way: ''Three months after he captured the attention of the fashion world with his first couture collection, Christian La-croix has scored a second hit.
LEAD: Three days after he shoved a newspaper reporter to the ground, Norman Adler, the top adviser to the New York State Assembly Speaker, Mel Miller, resigned yesterday.

LEAD: Ida Nudel's going-away dinner at the Vilnius Restaurant in Moscow last week must have been a joy. The ''mother of the Soviet refuseniks'' was bound for Israel after 16 years of trying. Iosif Begun, Moscow's unofficial rabbi, was there; his permission to emigrate came last month. Vladimir Slepak arrived waving the permission he and his wife had just received.

LEAD: Louise Simone Jacobs, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Myron S. Jacobs of Tenafly, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Steven Bernard Laster, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Oliver Laster of Hewlett, L.I. Cantor David Benedict officiated at the Lord Baltimore Clarion Hotel in Baltimore.
LEAD: * L. (Kay) Schultz was named president of Simmons Major Market Research.

LEAD: Two buses collided head-on near here early today, killing 14 people and injuring 26 others, the Anatolia news agency reported. The agency said one bus was carrying people home from a wedding. Aksehir is about 300 miles southeast of Istanbul.
LEAD: The Government of Malaysia has begun a campaign to convince American consumers and politicians that edible palm oil is not a proven health hazard.

LEAD: Jackets are losing their shoulders, bosoms are popping out of deep decolletages and long gloves and hats are returning to fashion. These are some of the trends emerging for next spring and summer from the full schedule of ready-to-wear openings over the weekend. The avant-gardists have dominated runways in the tents at the Louvre and at other locations all over the city.

LEAD: The statistics are so stark they scream off the page as loud as the Metrodome fans scream from the stands: Vince Coleman, Ozzie Smith and Tom Herr, the first three batters in the St. Louis batting order, the people who generate the Cardinals' offense, have two hits in 24 times at bat and a .083 batting average in the World

LEAD: The last time chic was a skirt that measured 21 inches from waistband to hem, Emma Peel and John Steed of ''The Avengers'' fought crime in England the way David and Maddie of ''Moonlighting'' fight crime in California. Mr. Steed and Mrs. Peel were cool enough to freeze water, however; they never got horizontal; and Emma had a judo kick that could stop a mule.

LEAD: ''I know of no safe depository of the ultimate powers of the society but the people themselves.'' Thomas Jefferson penned those words in September 1820. President Oscar Arias Sanchez of Costa Rica could have written them yesterday.

LEAD: THERE is something saintly about taking on both books of the Chopin Etudes in public concert. It is as if for an hour or so the sins of struggling pianists everywhere are lifted from their shoulders and somehow expiated by a single act of sacrifice.
LEAD: Renegade soldiers telephoned reporters before dawn today, asking them to witness their theft of an armored personnel carrier, which they drove around a university campus before abandoning.

LEAD: Two recent steps aimed at sending better-prepared teachers into public-school classrooms show that teacher quality has become the overriding issue in efforts to improve American public schools. Earlier this month, a City University of New
LEAD: Fan support will be a factor in the Houston Oilers' decision to stay in Houston or move to Jacksonville, Fla., the club's general manager, Ladd Herzeg, said today.

LEAD: VIEW the world of corporate law from the perspective of the First Amendment and it could look dramatically different, a former senior lawyer with the American Civil Liberties Union told an audience of Federal judges and lawyers here last Friday.
LEAD: Forty-two-year-old Suad al-Hadidi is a symbol of what Yasir Arafat calls the Palestinian ''demographic bomb.''

LEAD: The Tallgrass Technologies Corporation, which had dazzling growth with its computer accessory products after it was founded in 1981, has fallen on difficult times in the past several months and has a new president and chief executive, David F. Horton.
LEAD: From the beginning months ago, the affair was known as the Hot Suit Case.
LEAD: For 101 years, the Statue of Liberty has stood in New York Harbor, facing the Empire State, New Jersey at her back.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: NOW that all the real pro football players are expected to return to work, the heart of the National Football League season is about to resume pumping. Its soul, however, has been lost.

LEAD: Dorothy Ellen Bean, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert L. Bean of Bangor, Me., was married yesterday at the Bangor Theological Seminary to William Jackson Lippincott 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lippincott Jr. of Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Ansley Throckmorton, a United Church of Christ minister, officiated.

LEAD: When longshoremen unload the Tropical Morn's 187,849 boxes of bananas, pineapples and coconuts at Pier 42 today, they will be performing a Manhattan waterfront ritual that began more than three centuries ago. It may be performed for the last time next month.

LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company is expected to announce today that it plans to offer a computer workstation that would use a specialty microprocessor developed by Sun Microsystems Inc., according to sources close to both companies.

LEAD: Karen Anne Stang, who will join the Manhattan law firm of Dewey, Ballantine, Bushby, Palmer & Wood next month as an associate, and David Glen Smith, an associate at the Manhattan law firm of Latham & Watkins, were married yesterday. Judge Laurence C. Stamelman of New Jersey Superior Court officiated at the Shadowbrook restaurant in Shrewsbury, N.J.

LEAD: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi has come under some pressure to avert what military analysts say would be extremely heavy fighting if Indian troops complete their assault on the city of Jaffna, a senior Indian official said today.
LEAD: The crack trade in southeast Queens has turned middle-class neighborhoods near the Nassau County border into some of New York City's bloodiest drug battlegrounds.
LEAD: Proposed changes in the tax law have thrust the merger-and-acquisition world into a state of fearful anticipation.

LEAD: Baptist Tensions Rising Fundamentalists, who have controlled the Southern Baptist Conventin for eight years, are seeking power at seminaries and colleges. Page A18. Nancy Reagan on the Mend Doctors said tests of tissue removed in breast cancer surgery showed no spread of the malignancy and called her prognosis excellent.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Two Fulton County Commissioners were indicted Friday by a Federal grand jury on charges of extorting thousands of dollars from developers in exchange for supporting zoning changes.
LEAD: For weeks now, hardly a room in a motel, hotel or any of the ubiquitous Ozarks bed-and-breakfast country inns and cottages within 50 miles of here has been available for this weekend.

LEAD: The chairman of a large savings and loan institution in Atlanta has been asked to take over as chief executive of a troubled Government-owned corporation set up to sell property from bankrupt savings institutions, a Federal Home Loan Bank Board spokesman saiooFrFriday.

LEAD: Thirty-five members of militant Jewish groups holding a rally to protest anti-Semitic vandalism were ejected from Temple Emanu-El today by the police at the congregation's request. Members of the Boston chapter of the Jewish Defense League and of two other groups said patrols would be started to prevent anti-Semitic vandalism.

LEAD: There are those who believe that Thomas Deiker has accomplished a lot as head of New Mexico's state hospital for the mentally ill and disabled, and there are those who hate him for the changes he has wrought.
LEAD: Dr. Helene Fischer and Dr. Paul Rosenberg, who are physicians, were married yesterday at the Harrison Inn in Southbury, Conn., by Rabbi Norman Koch.

LEAD: IN ''Comedy Faces of '87,'' a downtown comedy troupe, the First Amendment, has compiled a promising experiment in humor that blends the normally exclusive genres of stand-up comedy and group improvisation into a revue. With additional skits and some fine tuning, the company hopes to take the show, which plays Thursdays through Saturdays in its basement theater at 2 Bond Street, to the Village Gate next year.

LEAD: Despite nearly seven years of the Reagan Administration's military buildup, a senior official says the Defense Department has still not gotten producers of weapons and equipment ready for an emergency.

LEAD: In a radical departure from standard medical practice, doctors in Canada last week kept alive a baby born without most of her brain so that her heart might be salvaged for a transplant operation.
LEAD: Sam Bowie, the Portland Trail Blazer center whose injuries have kept him sidelined through much of his basketball career, was in the hospital again today with a broken right leg.

LEAD: HOCKEY Flyers Edge Penguins: Dave Brown snapped a tie with a third-period goal to give Philadelphia a 3-2 victory over Pittsburgh last night, stretching the Flyers' home unbeaten streak against the Penguins to 38 games.

LEAD: Noboru Takeshita, a former Finance Minister and a master of political compromise, was virtually assured today of becoming Japan's next Prime Minister when the incumbent, Yasuhiro Nakasone, designated him as his successor.

LEAD: THERE is a small irony about the American Symphony Orchestra. LEAD: Nolan Ryan will return to the Houston Astros in 1988 after a bizarre season in which he lost twice as many games as he won (8-16), but led the majors with 270 strikeouts and tied the Toronto Blue Jays' Jimmy Key for the lead in earned run average with a 2.76 figure. LEAD: It isn't fake anything. It's real costume jewelry. And it's being worn -without apology - by women of every age and financial bracket. Even Brooke Astor has been known to wear bogus gems.

LEAD: THE STOCK MARKET PLUNGE The stock market had its worst day in history. The Dow Jones industrial average plunged an estimated 508 points, to 1,738.74, on trading so heavy that reporting was delayed for hours. More than 604 million shares changed hands, dwarfing Friday's record of 338.5 million shares, and the decline of 22.6 percent was far greater than the drop of 12.82 percent on Black Monday in 1929, which ignited the Great Depression.

LEAD: A report in Business Day on Wednesday about the Bristol-Myers Company's earnings misstated the company's third-quarter sales and the percentage increase. Sales totaled $1.38 billion, up 9.5 percent from $1.26 billion in the third quarter of 1986.

THERE can't be a creepier sight on Broadway right now than Joel Grey. Back in the role of the sleazy emcee in the musical ''Cabaret,'' the actor is made up just as he was in 1966 - with patent-leather hair, rouged cheeks, purple lips and drag-queen eyelashes. He darts about like an overwound wind-up doll, twirling his cane with a spastic jerkiness. As his eyes bulge, so his tongue has a most appalling way of flopping out of his mouth. And when Mr. Grey sings, his voice is a piercing siren that doesn't so much welcome revelers to his cabaret, the Kit Kat Klub, as lure them into the hell lurking just out of view - Berlin, 1929.

LEAD: A Staten Island man was stabbed to death in his apartment early yesterday, and his 22-year-old daughter was arrested after telling the authorities she had killed him because he had sexually abused her for years and had tried to assault her sexually again.

LEAD: Call the National City Bancorporation in Minneapolis and chances are that David L. Andreas will answer the phone. At least he did yesterday, while his secretary was out getting lunch. The informal Mr. Andreas is the new chairman and chief executive of the bank holding company.

LEAD: The Nets, who were hobbled by injuries last season, have lost their leading scorer for up to four weeks, two weeks before this season is scheduled to open. LEAD: DANCE, like life, has a way of swinging between extremes. In modern dance, for instance, the socially involved choreography of the 1930's was very much a thing of the past by the early 60's, when minimalism and abstract formalism came into fashion. This weekend's varied dance offerings suggest there is a renewed emphasis on work that looks to social issues, although there are performances that range along the spectrum.

Though set in Los Angeles, the film has a familiar, television look and feel - two handsome partners, cops, criminals, fast cars and a marginal romance.

LEAD: The sign on the wall in the blue-and-white corridor in Yankee Stadium yesterday morning read ''Press Conf.'' The arrow below pointed to the left.
LEAD: Doctors who refuse to care for AIDS patients are raising grave questions about the integrity of the medical profession.

LEAD: The President and Congress have four weeks to put the budget together. If, despite Wall Street's warning, they still can't come to terms, the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law takes effect on Nov. 20. Nominally, this meat-ax approach to deficit reduction will cut ''across the board'' - $11.5 billion from non-defense spending and the same from defense.

LEAD: Christopher Castleman, the former chief executive of the merchant bank Hill Samuel Group P.L.C., has been appointed managing director and chief executive of Blue Arrow P.L.C., Britain's largest employment agency.

LEAD: Alexander M. Haig Jr., Republican Presidential candidate, and his wife, Wendy, greeting a supporter after his speech yesterday before the National Press Club. In his speech, Mr. Haig, the former Secretary of State, urged President Reagan and Congress to resist pressure to raise taxes and adopt protectionist trade laws.

LEAD: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center will present a concert of works by Pergolesi, Mrs. H. H. A. Beach, Shulamit Ran and Ravel Sunday at 5 P.M. in Alice Tully Hall. Guest performers include the pianist Peter Serkin. Tickets are $18. Information: 874-6770.

LEAD: Older buyers who have spent 20 years or more in a detached house on an acre or two of land often have difficulty coming to terms with the idea of moving into the densely populated setting of an apartment building or town house complex. They want to be rid of the problems of caring for the large house and yard, yet yearn for the space and privacy.
LEAD: After the crash I did exactly what most people with a telephone were doing. I called some friends I respect to try to find out what in Heaven's name was going on.
LEAD: When the recent stock market upheavals began, Representative Claude Pepper, the oldest member of Congress, recalled vivid memories of the only comparable event, the crash of 1929.

LEAD: For trout fishermen like David S. Taylor, there are not enough superlatives to describe the South Platte River as it tumbles through Cheesman Canyon in the foothills of the Rocky Mountains southwest of here.

LEAD: Key House and Senate conferees on the trade bill, eager to send reassuring signals to Wall Street, met officially today for the first time and quickly agreed to a compromise on granting the President new trade-negotiating authority.

LEAD: The New York and American stock exchanges, responding to the frenzied pace of trading, announced yesterday that they would shorten their hours today, Monday and Tuesday, halting at 2 P.M. instead of 4 P.M.
LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday that, on the basis of information from the nation's stock exchanges, none of the major brokerage firms was in financial difficulty.

LEAD: THOUGH it's a separate novel, Mario Puzo's ''Sicilian'' functions as an extended insert within his ''Godfather'' epic, being an elaboration on what happened during the two years that the young Mafioso heir Michael Corleone was hiding out in Sicily after his brush with the New York law.

LEAD: Ivan Edeshko will probably never be suitably recognized for his contributions to the development of basketball as a global sport. As a youngster in the Soviet Union he was never his team's most dominating player. And as a coach he is only beginning to emerge in his country as an influential and respected teacher of the game.

LEAD: Alan E. Clore, chairman of Kaisertech Ltd., said he had held discussions with unidentified parties interested in buying all or part of his 31 percent stake in the company based in Oakland, Calif. In a Securities and Exchange

LEAD: Senator John Stennis, the 86-year-old Mississippi Democrat, was released from Walter Reed Army Medical Center today, three days after he underwent surgery to correct a prostate gland problem. The hospital said tests following the Monday operation revealed no evidence of cancer.

LEAD: Insisting that he is not a candidate for President, Donald J. Trump flew to New Hampshire, the state with the earliest Presidential primary, and today delivered what sounded like an impassioned campaign speech to an enthusiastic audience.

LEAD: Members of a Brownie troop from Pleasant Valley picking out pumpkins yesterday in a field outside Poughkeepsie, N.Y. Pickers have until next Friday to select pumpkins in time for Halloween. (AP)
