LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Labor Department imposed a record $5.11 million in fines today against companies it charged with responsibilty for the collapse last April of a high-rise apartment complex under construction in Bridgeport, Conn.
LEAD: The Home Group Inc., a New York-based insurance company, and the Carteret Bancorp have held talks about their proposed merger.

LEAD: After watching, on a screen, Federal officials in Washington announcing today the results of a six-month inquiry into the collapse of L'Ambiance Plaza, some lawyers, city officials and construction workers still differed on who had been at fault and whether the probable cause of the disaster had been found.

LEAD: A Supreme Court Justice today turned down an emergency request from fundamentalist Christians attempting to ban from Alabama public schools 44 textbooks that they say promote a godless religion.

LEAD: The case before the appeals court illustrates the pitfalls lying in the path of those who might be considered for nomination to fill the Supreme Court vacancy after Judge Robert H. Bork's expected defeat in the Senate: The views most valuable in winning nomination could cause problems winning Senate confirmation.

LEAD: Workers at the Government plants that make plutonium for nuclear bombs are being endangered and sometimes injured because managers are ignoring safety requirements, safety auditors told a House subcommittee today.
LEAD: A report in the Advertising column of Business Day on Wednesday mis-stated the location of McCaffrey & McCall's Rumrill-Hoyt unit. It is in New York.

LEAD: There was no gloom tonight. The Minnesota Twins did not allow themselves to consider the difficulty of their situation in the 84th World Series. They simply talked of the dome. They were going home now, they said, back to the Metrodome, their security blanket for an entire season. They are facing a one-game deficit in the Series after losing to the St.

LEAD: JAMES M. CAIN casts a shadow over ''The Killing Time,'' which opens today at the Embassy 1 and other theaters. Unfortunately, it isn't a very long one. In a quiet little seacoast town, the kind of place where one of the two sheriffs (Beau Bridges) calls everyone but his colleague (Joe Don Baker) ''Ma'am,'' we are asked to believe that two of the film's four male principals can be contemplating deceit, frame-ups and cold-blooded murder.

LEAD: In a bid to calm the frenzy in the world's financial markets, President Reagan announced today that he would meet with Congressional leaders to negotiate ways to reduce the budget deficit, with ''everything on the table,'' including possible tax increases.

LEAD: As autumn colors reach their peak along the wooded trails of the New York Botanical Garden, some 1,500 chrysanthemums are blooming indoors for a three-week Japanese Chrysanthemum Exhibition, beginning tomorrow in the garden's Enid A. Haupt Conservatory. The flower show continues through Nov. 15. It will be accompanied by demonstrations of ikebana (Japanese flower arranging) and origami tomorrow between 11 A.M.
LEAD: Are there too many rich, so-called international stakes races for grass horses each fall? The field for the $500,000 Man o' War at Aqueduct tomorrow suggests that the answer is yes.

LEAD: The Washington legal-political grapevine is heavy laden with talk that a Federal appellate panel may soon pass judgment on the law under which at least six special prosecutors are now conducting investigations or prosecutions.
LEAD: The widow of a street vendor who was shot and killed by New York City police officers this year in Harlem filed a $40 million lawsuit against the city and the Police Department yesterday.
LEAD: * Andal Corp., a subsidiary of Olsher Metals Corp., appointed Michael S. Huber senior vice president and chief financial officer.

LEAD: Norwegian authorities disclosed today that Norway's state-owned arms company, Kongsberg Vaapenfabrikk, had shipped to the Soviet Union more than 140 computers capable of running sophisticated machine tools and had cooperated with nearly a half-dozen NATO countries in shipping other high-technology equipment to the
LEAD: Friday BERLIN ANNIVERSARY

LEAD: When the United States Olympic Committee executive board meets this weekend in Oklahoma City, its most important order of business will be to name an executive director to succeed George Miller, who resigned under pressure two months ago. A likely selection, according to committee officials, is Harvey Schiller, the commissioner of the Southeastern Conference, who was among the finalists for the job two and a half years ago when Miller was named.

LEAD: WITH theme restaurants all the rage -from dreamy Provencal to daffy tropical - Anabelle's is distinctive for its lack of a conspicuous label. It is simply a comfortable and welcoming place where the food takes center stage - and what a splendid show it can be.

LEAD: THE Little Orchestra Society under its founder, the late Thomas K. Scherman, hewed out a place for itself in New York musical history largely through its pathbreaking programs of neglected older works such as Berlioz's ''Enfance du Christ.'' However, one might easily forget that the organization also has 50 world premieres and countless other contemporary firsts to its credit.

LEAD: The majority leader of the New York State Senate, Warren M. Anderson, yesterday warned the State Commission on Integrity in Government that public financing of election campaigns might create more problems than it solves.

LEAD: After one of the nation's longest jury trials, the Monsanto Company was found liable today for failing to warn a Missouri town about the risks of a 1979 chemical spill. The jury awarded plaintiffs $16.2 million in punitive damages.

LEAD: Greg Meyer, the last American to run a marathon in 2 hours 9 minutes, has entered the New York City Marathon on Nov. 1. Meyer, 32 years old, is coming back from a series of injuries that sidelined him in 1984 and 1985. . . . The season-ending statistics are in on Bob Horner, the former Atlanta Braves slugger who played in Japan this season, and the numbers pretty much match Horner's major-league performance here: 31 home runs (fifth in the league), 73 runs batted in and a .327 bating average for the Yakult Swallows.
LEAD: AMONG the things that Wall Street has today that it did not have in 1929 is the backing of a highly sophisticated advertising industry. It could make a difference.
LEAD: The Vatican announced today that its budget deficit this year would be about $3.6 million less than expected because of improved fund raising and cost-cutting measures.

LEAD: Every day when he gets home from school, Gerardo Urteaga turns on his television set. Sometimes he checks to see if there is a baseball game on the Atlanta or Chicago stations, but usually he flips the dial straight to MTV.
LEAD: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration today issued the most detailed schedule of shuttle flights and unmanned space missions since the Challenger exploded in January 1986.

LEAD: Two days after undergoing a procedure to clear two blocked arteries near his heart, Vince Dooley was released from Emory University Hospital in Atlanta yesterday morning. ''I've never felt better,'' said Dooley, the University of Georgia football coach, as he headed for an afternoon football practice.
LEAD: A senior State Department official asked Congress today to renew aid to Pakistan, despite concerns that Pakistan may be trying to develop nuclear weapons.
LEAD: A man who contended that his actions were justified under Colorado's self-defense law was acquitted today of charges of murdering a neighbor and assaulting two others.
LEAD: Danny Cox does not mind admitting that he and his teammates from the 1985 World Series still think about the unfinished business.

LEAD: A 15-year-old girl was pushed onto subway tracks in Manhattan as a train approached and rescued by a stranger yesterday as two other bystanders chased and held the assailant until the police arrived, the authorities said.
LEAD: Six executives of Agrokomerc, the food company at the center of a major financial scandal, have been sentenced to prison terms, a Belgrade newspaper reported today.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The nation's leading commercial banks lowered their prime lending rate yesterday by a quarter of a percentage point, to 9 percent, a move that reflected the Federal Reserve System's determination to avert a widespread financial panic.
LEAD: The finals of the world team championships began here this afternoon, with the United States involved in both the open series and the women's series.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Marvin L. Warner, who was convicted this year on felony criminal charges related to the 1985 collapse of the Cincinnati-based Home State Savings Bank, which he owned, filed for protection from creditors today in United States Bankruptcy Court in Jacksonville, Fla.

LEAD: In the wake of this week's plunge in stock prices and its implications for slower economic growth in 1988, some Wall Street firms are telling clients to cut back on stocks and - if they stick with equities - to go with safer, high-yielding investments such as electric and telephone utilities.

LEAD: If the Yankees plan on sending Dave Righetti back to the starting pitching rotation next season, they face two substantial obstacles: Righetti's intention to file for free agency Monday, plus his determination to remain in the bullpen, where he has spent the last four seasons.

LEAD: In awarding Robert Solow its prize in economics, the Nobel committee cited the M.I.T. professor's pioneering research in growth theory. The committee could have added that Mr. Solow is the economist's economist, a delightful exception in an academy that usually saves its highest honors for the narrowest of specialists.

LEAD: THE new exhibition at the Center for African Art provides an excellent introduction to African sculpture - especially to the stylistic diversity of its carved figures and masks - but this is only the beginning. What makes ''Perspectives: Angles on African Art'' so unusual is that it also represents the multiple viewpoints from which African art is studied, interpreted, appreciated and debated.
LEAD: Oliver Stone's ESP

LEAD: The St. Louis Cardinals, scrapping desperately to win tonight so they wouldn't be faced with winning two at Minnesota's Noisedome, did not see any good omens in developments in the third and fifth innings of the fifth game of the World Series.
LEAD: Stock Market's Effect

LEAD: The Enron Corporation said today that it would permanently close its Enron Oil Corporation subsidiary after learning that the unit had lost $85 million because of unauthorized trading in the petroleum futures markets.

LEAD: Holly Farms, a marketer of brand-name poultry based in Wilkesboro, N.C., has switched its agency to Long, Haymes & Carr, down home in Winston-Salem. Left behind in New York is a ''stunned'' Grey Advertising, the agency for the last five years, which saw the client move into chicken-marketing eminence.

LEAD: THERE have been entertaining film versions of Tennessee Williams's works (''Cat on a Hot Tin Roof''), and there have been important ones (''A Streetcar Named Desire''). But by and large, Williams's work has never traveled easily to the screen. The playwright himself claimed to favor only ''The Roman Spring of Mrs.

LEAD: Gymnastics Russians Retain Title: Led by Dmitri Bilozerchev, gymnasts from the Soviet Union won the men's team title at the world championships last night in Rotterdam, the Netherlands. The Soviet team dominated the competition as it scored 589.75 points as it easily defended its title.
LEAD: An article on Oct. 7 about New York City's Chief Medical Examiner, Dr. Elliot M. Gross, misidentified a former Chief Medical Examiner. He is Dr. Milton Helpern.

LEAD: SUSAN ROTHENBERG'S eagerly awaited exhibition defines the direction in which she has been moving since she exhausted the emblematic images of horses and heads that established her reputation. It is her first show at the Sperone Westwater Gallery, a larger and more neutral space than the Willard Gallery, which closed last summer and with which she, more than any other artist, was identified.
LEAD: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's news conference yesterday in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times:

LEAD: The Hungarian leadership deserves the Nobel Prize for chemistry this year, goes a current joke in this capital, which has long sublimated anger and anguish in bitter quips. The leadership has created a compound of Ethiopian wages and Swedish taxes.
LEAD: Trading was light today in Chicago's stock index futures pits, but the violent price swings of the last few days intensified.

LEAD: Democratic Presidential candidates, responding to the crisis in the stock market, have been long on calls for bipartisanship, short on specific remedies and cautious lest any misstatement be seen as an effort to take partisan advantage of the upheaval.

LEAD: Short- and long-term interest rates declined sharply for the fourth consecutive day, spurred by speculation that the Federal Reserve would adopt a more generous monetary policy as the stock market's gyrations cause the economy to weaken.
LEAD: Kuwait's main offshore oil terminal was seriously damaged in a missile attack today, and Kuwaiti and American officials said Iran was responsibile.

LEAD: THE STOCK MARKET TURMOIL The stock market bent but did not break. The Dow Jones industrial average closed down 77.42 points, at 1,950.43, but even this was an improvement over an earlier 140-point deficit. Trading opened with a blizzard of sell orders that caused many participants to expect a rout as complete as Monday's, but a number of factors helped the market to weather the storm.
LEAD: BASEBALL

LEAD: Roy Plaut, a founding partner of the Manhattan law firm of Lipkowitz & Plaut, died Wednesday at his home in Chapel Hill, N.C. Mr. Plaut, who had retired to Chapel Hill so he could attend courses at the University of North Carolina, was 85 years old.
LEAD: At a time when more and more local politicians are in trouble with the law, most former politicians who have served time have found that they can re-establish their professional lives.

LEAD: HE forbidding Black Rock, as the CBS building on Avenue of the Americas at 53d Street is dubbed, has sprouted an exotic flower called China Grill, an offshoot of Chinoise on Main in Santa Monica, Calif.

LEAD: On Monday the New York Telephone Company reported that telephone traffic in the Wall Street area remained the same as for any normal business day. But Monday was anything but a normal business day with the stock market taking a record-breaking plunge.

LEAD: Assets of the nation's 408 money market mutual funds increased $9.64 billion, to $256.84 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 108 institutional funds were up $4.29 billion, to $69.36 billion. Assets of the 207 general purpose funds were up $4.12 billion, to $78.14 billion.

LEAD: NOW the World Series is returning to the Decibeldome in Minnesota, where Whitey Herzog couldn't even hear himself think last weekend. Maybe that's why the Twins won the first two games, 10-1 and 8-4.

LEAD: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. ARGENTEUIL, #253 East 52d Street (753-9273) - *(July 3, 1987) Named for a town northwest of Paris, this new midtown restaurant - on the site of the old Cafe Argenteuil - is set in a cozy and tranquil room decorated in flowery fabrics.

LEAD: The decision by the New York Stock Exchange to curtail trading for the next three days was made during a day of intense consultations with the Securities and Exchange Commission as the two parties set up a new ''open'' telephone line between them, a commission spokeswoman said today.
LEAD: A draft committee to convince Governor Cuomo to run for President filed a statement of organization today with the Federal Election Commission.

LEAD: Victoire de Castellane, Karl Lagerfeld's assistant for jewelry at the Chanel fashion house, is just 24 years old. She proves that youth is no barrier to success. Already, she has helped to change the face of fashion.

LEAD: Congressional leaders today welcomed President Reagan's statement that he was willing to discuss tax increases and would meet ''as soon as possible'' with the leaders to set up negotiations on a deficit-reducing package.

LEAD: Richard Roud, the longtime director of the New York Film Festival, was removed from his position yesterday when the board of the Film Society of Lincoln Center voted unanimously to accept his resignation, which was requested last week. Mr. Roud has been with the film festival, a project of the Film Society, for its entire 25 years.

LEAD: Soviet and American spokesman struck a positive tone today as they reported progress in the opening round of talks between Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze and Secretary of State George P. Shultz.

LEAD: Four days after a demonstration to protest two huge office towers planned for Columbus Circle, more than 7,000 trade union members rallied yesterday to express their support for the construction project.

LEAD: Steve Dunnington, in background, delivering a body kick to a student as he taught the art of fighting without lethal contact yesterday at a former fountain near the 79th Street Boat Basin. Others practiced fencing in the course, which is for actors and stunt men. (NYT/Jim Wilson)

LEAD: Last Monday at 5 P.M. was perhaps the most tense point in the business career of Peter Haas. A senior partner with the New York Stock Exchange specialist firm A.B. Tompane & Company, Mr. Haas had no idea how large his firm's losses had been during the day when the stock market took its historic plunge.
LEAD: Progress in Shultz Talks

LEAD: By 9:15 A.M. yesterday, the tension was building inside the trading room at Wertheim Schroder & Company, a medium-sized brokerage firm that caters to institutional customers and wealthy individuals. Clients were flooding the firm with orders to sell stock. ''There hasn't been a single buy order so far today,'' said Robert J.

LEAD: The Soviet magazine Novy Mir is negotating to publish the works of Joseph Brodsky, who was imprisoned and then banished from his native country for his poetry and who won the Nobel Prize in Literature today, a Government spokesman said today.

LEAD: A picture caption yesterday about the funeral of the cellist Jacqueline du Pre described the end of her career incorrectly. She was stricken with multiple sclerosis in 1971, but her final concerts were in 1973.

LEAD: At the start of yesterday's session in the Howard Beach case, the light in the courtroom was bad. Some bulbs in the high ceiling had burned out. And the judge said he was putting a lamp at the edge of the bench to shine down on the witness so the jury could see him clearly.

LEAD: A Miami dispatch about a psychiatrist's testimony on the suicide of a 17-year-old Florida girl was inadvertently omitted from some editions yesterday; a duplicate of an unrelated article appeared under its headline.
LEAD: Reagan Administration officials said today that the United States was not committed to any action against Iran in response to the latest missile attack on Kuwait's oil installations.
LEAD: ''I don't know how much longer I can do it,'' said Stanley Silverberg, a specialist on the American Stock Exchange, as he stood off the trading floor taking long drags on his cigarette.

LEAD: A Federal judge has dismissed the Bonneville Power Administration as a defendant in the litigation surrounding the $2.25 billion bond default of the Washington Public Power Supply System in 1983.

LEAD: A quartet - Stephen Brown, pianist; Dinos Constantinides, violinist; Karen Hunt, soprano; Harry Sagous, oboist - will perform works by Ives, Robert Helps, Henry Cowell, Antal Dorati and Mr. Constantinides Sunday at 2 P.M. in Weill Recital Hall. Tickets are $7. Information: 247-7800.

LEAD: Danny Cox, the big-game pitcher for the St. Louis Cardinals, pitched an absolutely big game tonight as the Cardinals swept their third straight from the Minnesota Twins and moved to within one victory from winning the 84th World Series.

LEAD: Expressions '87, a Celebration of Africa in the Americas, Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street (307-7420). The Caribbean Cultural Center's Expressions Festival is presenting the United States debuts of two intriguing bands this weekend. Fundo de Quintal plays Brazilian samba - not the dressed-up, jazzed-up samba, but the percussive, heavily African variety.

LEAD: As the number of senators opposed to Judge Robert H. Bork grew to 55, Senate Republicans agreed early this evening to permit a vote Friday on the doomed Supreme Court nomination. Senate leaders said the vote would be no later than 2 P.M.

LEAD: Tentative optimism gave way to nervous caution among small investors yesterday. After a wave of bargain hunting on Tuesday and Wednesday, small investors seemed more willing to watch and wait as the market took another dive, brokerage officials around the country said.

LEAD: Rarely have the Swedes displayed as much wit and sense as in bestowing the Nobel Prize in Literature on Joseph Brodsky, whose writing shimmers, just as their citation says, with raillery, parody and an amazing mastery of English idiom. What a wonderful twist in the life of a poet who was once denounced in his native Leningrad as a ''militant parasite.

LEAD: Rodney McCray, the 6-foot-8-inch forward for the Houston Rockets who is a holdout, has dismissed his agent, Howard Slusher, in the hope of speeding negotiations toward a contract. ''I have nothing personal against Howard,'' said McCray, 30 years old, who has played four seasons with Houston. ''I just felt that maybe he had some other things going on that required his attention.

LEAD: They are the representatives of the American people elected to share the joys and tribulations of the nation, and this week many members of Congress discovered they were sharing the plight of constituents who suffered heavy losses on the plunging stock markets.
LEAD: Changing conditions may require the Government to reconsider some of the mergers it has allowed in recent years, a member of the Federal Trade Commission said today.

LEAD: Home-field advantage? To the Minnesota Twins, it's the Metrodome, known to visiting teams as the Metrodoom. To the San Francisco Giants, it's Candlestick Park, a house of horrors to visiting teams with its gale winds and wintry temperatures. To the St. Louis Cardinals, it's Busch Stadium, mostly because it's big.
LEAD: President Reagan defended his troubled AIDS commission tonight and said he still hoped it would help find the best way to combat ''this terrible plague.''

LEAD: For the last eight years, Robert S. Prechter has worked as a shepherd in the field of investment counseling, offering to lead an ever-growing flock toward the greenest of pastures, a Dow Jones industrial average of 3,686. To get there would take some zigging and zagging through the wilderness, he has told his 16,000 followers and anyone else who would listen, but they would arrive in the promised land in 1988.

LEAD: New York City is a capital of world finance, and this week it's become a capital of financial trauma. How will the fallout affect New York and other cities where financial services play a big role in local spending and taxing? Common sense dictates serious local planning for the worst, even as Federal officials wrestle with the budget and international trade issues.
LEAD: The state's highest court today ordered the ouster of a Montgomery County town court justice who fixed two speeding tickets and then lied to a state judicial panel investigating his conduct.

LEAD: A whimpering 2-year-old girl was found buckled in her seat, shielded by a body, in the wreckage of small plane that crashed in heavy fog, killing her father, grandmother and another adult, officials said. The girl, Aubrey Holst, was in serious condition at Sacred Heart Hospital in Eugene.

LEAD: An Indian official said today that Indian troops had ''more or less'' seized control of a Tamil rebel stronghold in Sri Lanka, but that the top rebel commander had escaped, perhaps with most of his associates.

In addition to individual studios, stops are included at the Cork Gallery at Lincoln Center and the West Side Y.M.C.A., at West 63d Street and Broadway.

LEAD: EVERY FILM REQUIRES ITS audience to make a leap of faith, but some leaps are longer than others. A lot longer. It isn't even a question of whether what we're seeing can literally be believed. One film may make its viewers accept the idea that a nobody from Palookaville can slug his way to the top of the boxing world, or that a schoolboy can travel backward in time to meet his parents as teen-agers; another may strain credulity with the sight of a simple soul making a visit to his neighborhood store.

LEAD: FOR the first of his three New York Philharmonic subscription programs this season - the final repeat is scheduled for Tuesday evening at Avery Fisher Hall - Erich Leinsdorf has surrounded the Grieg Piano Concerto with two symphonies that, while not unknown, still count as slightly off the beaten track.

LEAD: To the Editor: On Aug. 24 you carried a Travel Advisory item on Highland Express, and for some time the Travel section has been carrying advertisements for this airline. I bought seats on it because of the advertisements, and I feel it is my duty to warn others about the airline.

LEAD: A Federal judge yesterday sentenced Meade H. Esposito, the 80-year-old former Brooklyn Democratic leader, to a suspended two-year prison term with two years probation and fined him $500,000 for unlawfully paying the vacation expenses of Representative Mario Biaggi of the Bronx.

LEAD: A study of nearly 450 public high schools in metropolitan Los Angeles has found black and Hispanic students lagging further behind white high school students in reading, writing and mathematics.

LEAD: Dolores Barrett, the senior vice president of the public-relations firm of R. C. Auletta & Company in New York, and Edward Klein, former editor of The New York Times Magazine, were married yesterday. Justice Milton Mollen, the presiding justice of the Second Judicial Department of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court, performed the ceremony at the Manhattan home of Kitty Carlisle Hart.

LEAD: AFTER assessing the National Football League strike, the heads of the unions representing professional baseball and basketball players have concluded that lack of unity among the football players had doomed their effort to win concessions on free agency and other issues from the owners.
LEAD: The first prenatal clinic at a New Jersey high school has been established at the Chestnut Street School, an alternative high school here for about 125 pregnant teen-agers.

LEAD: IN Connecticut last week, two brokerage houses that planned expansions in Stamford pulled out of deals. In Los Angeles, about 25 homeowners, including some with deeds to multimillion-dollar mansions, were putting their homes on the block or trying to back out of deals. And in Manhattan, the traffic among would-be apartment owners and renters virtually came to a halt.

LEAD: THE Metropolitan Opera's new production of Wagner's ''Rheingold'' - solidly stage-directed, somewhat tackily designed, persuasively cast and surely conducted - offered a company debut Thursday night, along with several singers appearing in their roles for the first time or the first time this season.

LEAD: Q. My toilet does not always flush properly. When it doesn't, the water swirls around without going down and the toilet makes a gurgling sound. A second flushing usually does it, but in rare cases I even have to use a plunger. Originally the plumbing system lacked a vent stack, but I retrofitted one by installing a tee fitting that I cut into the main waste line in my basement.

LEAD: AFTER three weeks of hearings that changed some minds and two days of fierce debate that did not, the Senate last week voted down President Reagan's nomination of Judge Robert H. Bork to the Supreme Court last week.

LEAD: This is the time of year when teams start planning for their appearance in next year's World Series. Whichever two teams make the most successful plans figure to provide a stronger matchup than the one created by the Minnesota Twins and the St. Louis Cardinals. No other two teams could have made it this far and presented such a weak World

LEAD: NOV. 18, 1936. Although President Franklin D. Roosevelt had just carried 46 of the 48 states to re-election, a bleeding nation was still in the grip of the Depression and the time hardly seemed propitious for a new musical organization.
LEAD: THE pace of residential building and sales on Cape Cod may have slowed this year, but the same cannot be said of retail and office construction.

LEAD: I returned from Florida in time to read an article by Thomas Allen Stock, ''Crossing the Sound to Bike a Shrouded Shore - A Race With Myself to Test My Limits'' [ Opinion Page, Sept. 20 ] . I competed in a tennis tournament sponsored by the Du Pont Company, where I, too, had to utilize my capabilities to the fullest.

LEAD: The marriage of Wendy Susan Frumkes, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert M. Frumkes of New York, to David Robert Meller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Percival Meller of London, took place last evening at the Metropolitan Club in New York. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel officiated.

LEAD: THE Wayside Cottage is a Scarsdale landmark that has occupied its present site on the corner of Post Road (Route 22) and Wayside Lane since the early 18th century. Listed in the National Register of Historic Places, the cottage not only served as home to early Westchester families but also was used, at various times, as an inn and tavern (becoming for a while the hub of the area's social and cultural life), a church school, the headquarters of the Scarsdale Equal Suffrage Club, a community garden during World War

LEAD: Julie Ann Epstein, a daughter of Mrs. Lannie Goodman of New York and Myron Epstein of Springfield, N.J., was married last evening to Steven Dennis Rubin, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert S. Rubin of Fall River, Mass. Rabbi Harlan J. Wechsler officiated at the St. Regis-Sheraton.

LEAD: Jennifer Sage, an architect, and Nicolas Grabar, a lawyer, were married yesterday at the National Arts Club in New York by Judge Pierre N. Leval of Federal District Court.

LEAD: MAYOR WILLIAM J. HATTRICK JR. of Southampton has thrown his support behind a bill that would allow village residents to rent accessory apartments in their single-family homes.

LEAD: NO personal computer could have prepared an investor for the wild ride the markets took last week. Even the Big Boys, using their Big Computers, were stunned by the magnitude of the tremors that shook Wall Street.
LEAD: THE CONSTRAINTS OF CORPORATE TRADITION Doing the Correct Thing, Not Just What the Past Dictates. By Alan M. Kantrow. 216 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $19.95.

LEAD: THE LILTING SOUND OF Mbaqanga, South Africa's distinctive black pop music, filled Lincoln Center's Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater on a recent afternoon. Six musicians, looking sharp in pressed khaki uniforms, were churning out the music's joyous rhythms, while a seventh player, Douglas Mnisi, swayed back and forth, embroidering the beat with lightning-fast runs on his electric guitar.
LEAD: Poland's leadership sought to tighten control over planned economic changes today with a Government shake-up that included the appointment of a powerful Minister of Industry.
LEAD: Fair Lawn High got all of its points in the first half and then held off a Bergenfield rally to win, 21-14, yesterday in a games that matched perfect records at Fair Lawn.
LEAD: The Soviet Union today criticized what it called efforts to draw Kuwait into the Iran-Iraq war and said continued attacks on the emirate would only aggravate problems in the Persian Gulf.
LEAD: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, former chief United States delegate to the United Nations, planned to disclose Monday whether she will enter the race for the 1988 Republican Presidential nomination.

LEAD: There were those on the Michigan side of the field who were prepared to call a halt to the Big Ten season, declare Indiana the conference champion and send the Hoosiers on their way to the Rose Bowl, even if they arrive early. After only seven games, Indiana has already had one of its most memorable seasons, and asking the Hoosiers to play on just doesn't seem fair.
LEAD: The day the world nearly crashed down on Lenore Waxman is stamped indelibly on her mind.
LEAD: The town crier here stands to lose his job over accusations that he told a tourist that homosexuals and the devil had taken over a local church.

LEAD: I am most appreciative of Michael E. Ross's review of my book ''Music Talks: Conversations With Musicians'' (Oct. 4) but would like to correct three inadvertent inaccuracies. The book includes material written between 1971 and 1986 - not 1974 and 1981. About one-third, including the profiles of the bassoonist Hugo Burghauser and the master teacher Dorothy DeLay, is previously unpublished work.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH the Government managed to resist the impulse for dramatic action, such as closing the exchanges, it was forced by last week's stock market plunge to make some abrupt and important policy changes. One result could be a breakthrough in the long political impasse over the Federal budget deficit - one of the main causes, economists say, of the market's instability.
LEAD: Kevin Minicus, a halfback, scored on a 3-yard run just 1 minute 43 seconds into the game today as Amherst rolled to a 21-12 victory over Wesleyan.

LEAD: As a dentist, I know that when the Hunts forced up the price of silver artificially, it greatly inflated the price of silver-amalgam filling material. Silver is the most widely used filling material for teeth. The Hunt brothers' ''game'' cost consumers untold millions in added costs for dental care.
LEAD: The N.F.L. strike is not over. Management will find that the negotiation of a labor contract requires give and take.

LEAD: BRAD BENSON had decided before the National Football League players' strike that, no matter what anyone else did, he would follow a certain moral code. This meant he would not cross the Giants' picket line and would not hold a grudge against those who did. Or try not to, at any rate.
LEAD: THE FIRST WAVE Women Poets in America 1915-1945. By William Drake. Illustrated. 314 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $19.95.

LEAD: The American public sides with the owners in the National Football League strike, and football fans overwhelmingly support the decision to count the games played during the strike in the standings, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

LEAD: Alexandra Auchincloss and Paul Karel Herzan were married yesterday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. The Very Rev. James P. Morton, Dean of the Cathedral, performed the ceremony, assisted by Bishop Paul Moore Jr. and the Rev. Daniel W. Morrissey, a Roman Catholic priest.

LEAD: At the Fenway Golf Club in Scarsdale, N.Y., last evening Marcy Robin Salzman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan H. Salzman of Rye Brook, N.Y., was married to Paul H. Nathan, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Conrado Nathan of Orinda, Calif. Rabbi Daniel Wolk performed the ceremony.
LEAD: A report in Travel Advisory on Sept. 6 described the Carte pass incorrectly. It provides entry to Paris museums and attractions at reduced admission, but not free.

LEAD: IT is the boxing match with the distinct premise as its axis that is likely to be the most profound, and in our time the boxer whose matches are most consistently fueled by such interior (if rarely articulated) logic is Mike Tyson, the youngest ''undisputed'' world heavyweight champion in history.

LEAD: SPIRALS - CAST, COILED, twisted, engraved and hammered - dominate among the forms and embellishments of the antiquities on view in ''Origins of Design: Bronze Age and Celtic Masterworks,'' at the Michael Ward gallery, 9 East 93d Street, through Dec. 15.

LEAD: At a moment that has seen baseball bats theatrically slammed to the ground and fists triumphantly shot toward the sky, Don Baylor just went about his business. ''I don't hit it and stop and throw my bat,'' Baylor said. ''I've always done it: you hit it and you run around the bases.''
LEAD: In the aftermath of Black Monday, almost everybody is knocking the deficit. And so it has always been, usually in the face of all reason and logic.

LEAD: Manager Tom Kelly of Minnesota, a man who admittedly is not fond of the media attention he is receiving during the World Series, became involved in a heated argument with a reporter for The Minneapolis Star Tribune just an hour and a half before the game today.

LEAD: The marriage of Constance Mary Stewart, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Dalzell Stewart of Pittsburgh, to M. George Stevenson, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Gerald Platt Stevenson of Salt Lake City, took place yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in Pittsburgh. The Rev. Dr. Bruce Wheeler Thielemann performed the ceremony.

LEAD: The Hunt brothers wanted to dance to the tune of high-risk/ high-profit business ventures, and now it is only fair that they pay the fiddler his due. After all, no quarter was given to the thousands of American farmers whose land was repossessed after the banks had overextended loans to them. Should the Hunts be treated differently, just because they can afford the legal guns to keep the banks at bay and their creditors satisfied?
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: IN ITS continuing quest to provide disadvantaged children with a quality education, the Fund for Educational Advancement of the Archdiocese of Newark is mailing solicitations to 2,800 businesses and 3,000 individuals in Bergen, Essex, Hudson and Union Counties.
LEAD: A man was killed by the police yesterday when he reached for a toy gun from a shoulder holster during an undercover drug raid on a peep show near Times Square.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Anne Dean Truitt of Washington of the engagement of her daughter Mary McConnell Truitt to John Lyster Hill, the son of Mrs. Cornelius F. Froeb of Chestertown, Md., and the late John R. Hill. The couple plan a December wedding.
LEAD: A deep rift in the American labor movement ended today when the International Brotherhood of Teamsters was readmitted to the A.F.L.-C.I.O.
LEAD: ONE of the newest productions of the Vivian Beaumont Theater appears on paper rather than on stage.

LEAD: DANCE lovers applauding an enjoyable program may occasionally feel like rushing down the aisles to cheer the performers or even like jumping on stage to dance along with them. Such impulses are usually resisted.

LEAD: Q. My toilet does not always flush properly. When it doesn't, the water swirls around without going down and the toilet makes a gurgling sound. A second flushing usually does it, but in rare cases I even have to use a plunger. Originally the plumbing system lacked a vent stack, but I retrofitted one by installing a tee fitting that I cut into the main waste line in my basement.
LEAD: AFTER noticing an unusual drop in collection-plate receipts, the Roman Catholic Diocese of Cleveland called in the sheriff.
LEAD: Ellen Elizabeth Martin and Kenneth Stanley Taratus Jr. were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in Manhattan. The Rev. Daniel G. O'Hare performed the ceremony.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, a dispatch from Burlington, Vt., last Sunday about a tax dispute referred incorrectly to Nicola Marro, public relations director at the University of Vermont. He is a man.

LEAD: IT seldom happens that a single slam deal presents major problems in bidding and play that world-class players have trouble solving, even in the post-mortem. One such deal, shown in the diagram, occurred at the start of the World Team Championships, which ended yesterday in Jamaica, and generated argument for several days.

LEAD: Tom Yohe, the junior quarterback, threw for two touchdowns on plays covering 49 and 40 yards and the Harvard defense stopped a Princeton scoring threat with two minutes remaining today as the Crimson moved into a tie for the Ivy League football lead with a 24-19 victory.

LEAD: To the Editor: I was recently on an Iberia Airlines flight fron Nice to Madrid and had requested a seat in the no-smoking section. I was seated near the front of the plane on the lefthand side. A man in the row in front of me on the righthand side began to smoke, and when I asked him to stop, he said that he was seated in a smoking section.
LEAD: A picture caption on Oct. 4 about a town square in southwestern Poland misidentified the town. The town is Jelenia Gora.

LEAD: Some scary staples are back on TV this witch-and-goblin week - ''Fright Night,'' ''Psycho,'' ''Invasion of the Body Snatchers'' and of course ''Halloween.'' There's also the premiere of a solid thriller and an array of less familiar suspense treats.

LEAD: AS BERNARD HAMMERMAN tells it, his work is art in the service of business. Co-founder, in 1946, with his two brothers, of Hammerman Bros. Inc., in New York City, and now the firm's president, he oversees the design and manufacture of some of the world's finest and priciest jewelery. ''I get these ideas in my head,'' he says, ''as to what I'd like to fit into our inventory, what I believe will sell.

LEAD: The world bridge championships drew to a close here today with the United States claiming a double victory. The Americans won the Venice Trophy for women's teams Friday, and their open team defeated Britain in the final of the Bermuda Bowl by 64 international match points.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: MONTEVERDI'S ''Orfeo'' is not the first opera, but it is the first by a truly gripping composer. Appearing in 1607, it was actually the sixth attempt at this new art - one intended to prod dramatic poetry with a new energy by coloring it with the melodies and rhythms of music. It was an evolution that the Italian language with its broad vowels and elastic stresses made almost inevitable.

LEAD: Gymnastics Soviet in 1-2-3 Sweep: Dmitri Bilozerchev led a 1-2-3 Soviet Union finish in winning the men's all-round title yesterday at the world championships in Rotterdam, the Netherlands. He won the crown for six routines with 118.375 points. Yuri Korolev finished second with 118.350 points and Vladimir Artemov was third with 118.125 points.

LEAD: IF there is one quality that sets Americans apart from most peoples, it is our optimism. But the nation's inherent belief that every problem has a solution and that things will turn out for the best was sorely tested last week by a rat-tat-tat of events that suggested even to the sunniest among us that things might be sliding out of control.

LEAD: Celebrating the Theater Halloween Preview Oct. 25 - Costumes are optional but merriment is mandatory at a Caribbean Halloween party featuring Chinese-Hispanic food, a cash bar, dancing and a raffle at Bayamo, 704 Broadway (just north of Fourth Street). The event, from 7 to 11 P.M., will benefit the Jewish Guild for the Blind, which has provided services for visually impaired people of all religions and races since 1914.
LEAD: FOR most collectors, philatelic literature, if it exists at all, centers around a few mass-distribution catalogues. But times are changing.

LEAD: A new draft of the joint Congressional report on the Iran-contra affair is more critical of President Reagan than earlier versions and concludes that he supported an ''environment of inverted values'' and ''upside-down logic,'' according to Congressional officials.

LEAD: St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Janet Eileen O'Connor and George V. Cornell 3d. Msgr. Peter G. Finn officiated. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John R. O'Connor of Fairfield, Conn. Her husband is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Cornell Jr.
LEAD: Top-ranked Roosevelt (5-0) just kept rolling along yesterday, crushing Suffern, 35-17.

LEAD: IT'S not a common occurrence, but it sometimes happens that a boxer is declared the winner of a bout after being knocked out in the final seconds of the last round. That is because a fighter who hits the canvas in the last 10 seconds of a bout can be saved by the bell, which, by long tradition, ends not only the round and the bout, but the referee's count as well.

LEAD: People waiting in line outside Bronx-Lebanon Hospital Center as about 15,000 pounds of cheese, rice, honey, powdered milk and butter were given to the needy. Distribution is scheduled to continue through today. (NYT/Keith Meyers)

LEAD: The streets of the South Bronx are still dark and deserted at 6 A.M., and the same hush pervades the hallways of South Bronx High School, a drab building in the heart of the bleak Melrose neighborhood. But the faint sounds of pop music can be heard coming from the school's gymnasium, where students are stretching their muscles to the beat.
LEAD: A JAPANESE political scientist, Keiichi Matsushita, wrote a few years ago that Japan should be considered a ''half democracy.''

LEAD: WALL STREET had already begun to take a long, hard look at itself; last week's market plunge shook it to its very core. It came just as many firms were realizing that the days of quick profits were ending and, in a traumatic way, it highlighted the inherent riskiness of the securities business. Now, firms already planning to retrench may become more determined to shrink their businesses and to cut jobs.

LEAD: An official of the Christian Broadcasting Network has been chosen by officials of a Federal bankruptcy court to head daily operations of the PTL ministry.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: READING THE MEMOIRS of Joan Baez and Judy Collins, folk-music pioneers who are both now in their late 40's, one is tempted to mourn the vanishing tradition of the folk-music heroine. Through the 60's and 70's, the image of the long-haired, guitar-toting folkie with flowers in her hair, burning with noble ideals, was a cliche that, while often ridiculed, bespoke a artistic seriousness that in the age of music video is disappearing from the pop mainstream.
LEAD: The union movement, which united behind Walter F. Mondale's Presidential candidacy in 1984, is struggling to define a new role for itself in the 1988 Democratic Presidential campaign.

LEAD: FIRST off, let me apologize. My last column, regarding what is right and what is wrong with today's automobile, touched a nerve, but the response needs to be truncated if it is to be here at all.
LEAD: The executive board of the United States Olympic Committee elected two executive directors today, one to hold the job until the other succeeds him in January.
LEAD: The Commission on Fine Arts has rejected a plan to add a statue of a woman to the Vietnam Veterans Memorial in honor of nurses and other women who served in that war.

LEAD: Your article on pollution in Long Island Sound [ ''Two Groups Forming on Sound Pollution,'' Sept. 27 ] was timely. A friend and I recently took an 11-day sailing cruise to Block Island and back and were shocked to learn that marinas don't provide facilities for dumping sewage from boat holding tanks or portable toilets.

LEAD: At St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church in Avon, N.Y., Barbara Ellen Burke, a legal assistant in the New York office of the law firm of Latham & Watkins, was married yesterday to David George Whalen, a senior associate at Booz, Allen & Hamilton in New York. The Rev. Charles Bennett performed the ceremony.

LEAD: An article about Yiddish in The Week in Review Oct. 11 incorrectly described the publication of ''The Great Yiddish Dictionary.'' The four volumes that have been published were prepared under the supervision of lexicographers at the City College of the City University of New York and the Hebrew University.
LEAD: BEGINNING tomorrow, Montclair State College and New Jersey Network will be training students in on-air television production.
LEAD: Not many people head for a beach resort to sit in the shade.

LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the United States and the Soviet Union could conclude an accord banning medium- and shorter-range missiles without a summit meeting between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
LEAD: ECONOMICS IN PERSPECTIVE A Critical History. By John Kenneth Galbraith. 324 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $19.95.

LEAD: THE PIANOPLAYERS, by Anthony Burgess. (Washington Square/Pocket Books, $4.95.) Anthony Burgess's 29th novel is about a man, much like the author's own father, whose piano playing provides the real-time soundtrack for silent pictures; his career falls apart with the advent of a new technology called talkies.

LEAD: Law enforcement officials in New York City, armed with one of the toughest gun statutes in the country, have seen a rapid increase in gun crimes this year and are seizing sophisticated automatic weaponry that was rarely seen in criminal hands as recently as 1985.

LEAD: Apple aficionados gathered at Muscoot Farm Park in Somers recently for the Fourth Annual Apple Day, sponsored by the county's Department of Parks, Recreation and Conservation. LEAD: Across Eastern Europe, a crisis of the environment is eroding the natural and cultural heritage, confronting Communist governments with major pollution problems at a time when economic difficulties are diminishing the financial resources to deal with them.

LEAD: FOR more than 200 years, what are now Ansonia and Derby, at the confluence of the Naugatuck and Housatonic Rivers in Connecticut, were a single unincorporated community. It was a thriving shipping and shipbuilding center from which sloops carried livestock and fish to the West Indies.

LEAD: Don McPherson threw four touchdown passes to Tommy Kane, caught a touchdown pass and set two Syracuse records all in the first half today. This made it very easy for the undefeated Orangemen to roll over Colgate, 52-6, before 48,097 fans in the Carrier Dome.

LEAD: The year 1970 was a crucial one for Philip Guston, an American painter who had long been accepted and admired as an abstract expressionist. His way of playing pink against red with fat and juicy little touches was unmistakable and amounted almost to what is now called ''a signature style.''

LEAD: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan today accused his American critics of double standards on the question of nuclear nonproliferation, and reiterated that Pakistan is opposed to the production or acquisition of nuclear arms.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Van C. Campbell of Corning, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Sara Blythe Campbell to John Joseph Kelemen 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kelemen Jr. of Rockville, Md.

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: LAST Monday's stock market collapse left everyone from taxi drivers to professional analysts confused and groping for explanations. What follows are preliminary answers to some basic questions about what happened. Q. Why did the market plunge? A. The theories vary widely - from investor concern about America's huge budget and trade deficits to growing evidence that President Reagan has entered the lame duck period of his Administration.

A brutal murder creates a crisis among a big city's politicians and lawyers.

LEAD: WHILE Westchester County waits expectantly for what it hopes will be a breakthrough in its efforts to ease the problem of housing the homeless, it is finding a partial solution in an unexpected asset: its run-down and burned-out buildings.

LEAD: MOST regional theaters, if they do new plays at all, bury them in the middle of a season weighted down by Broadway comedies, familiar musicals and classic revivals. LEAD: A panel of Federal health experts is recommending a wide range of new steps to combat the AIDS epidemic and to provide health care for its victims.

LEAD: JUDGING by the response to a recent magazine article, Senator Bill Bradley has found overwhelming national support for his plan to spend more Government money on prenatal care.

LEAD: When the foundation was dug and steel structure erected on a 4.2-acre site at the intersection of Merrick and Brookville Boulevards in Rosedale, Queens, more than a decade ago, the plan was to construct a public junior high school.

LEAD: While politicians and the news media seem to be concerned with corporate raiders and wheeler-dealers, at one extreme, or with illegal immigrants and welfare recipients, at the other, it is ironic that only entertainers such as John Cougar Mellencamp, Willie Nelson and Bruce Springsteen seem to care about farmers and blue-collar workers who are caught in the middle.

LEAD: THINK OF JAMES STEWART AND W. C. Fields. That's one way of approaching the hour between 9 and 10 on Wednesday evenings on ABC, the hour that stars the enormously likable John Ritter as ''Hooperman'' and then switches to Dabney Coleman doing the misanthropic title character in ''The 'Slap' Maxwell Story.
LEAD: OFTEN agreeing on the problems but not the solutions, the Republican and Democratic candidates for Nassau County Executive clashed last week over a wide variety of issues.

LEAD: Sometimes within the brain's old ghostly house, I hear, far off, at some forgotten door, A music and an eerie faint carouse And stir of echoes down the creeking floor. - Archibald MacLeish ''Chambers of Imagery''

LEAD: GORO YAMAGUCHI'S 1968 Nonesuch album ''A Bell Ringing in the Empty Sky'' introduced the sound of the shakuhachi, a Japanese bamboo flute, to many Western listeners. On that album, Mr. Yamaguchi's command of the instrument's varied textural resources conspired with a vivid, intimate recording to give the music a big, almost cinematic sound.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Serious poets engage in the riskiest of literary business, seldom achieving anything appoaching unanimous acclaim, let alone big paychecks. So there seemed a bit of justice done last week when Joseph Brodsky, the exiled Russian poet, won the Nobel Prize in Literature. The 47-year-old Mr. Brodsky, who was deported from the Soviet Union in 1972 after serving 18 months in a labor camp for ''parasitism,'' is widely regarded as the best living Russian poet.

LEAD: The Hotel Pierre was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Evie Marie Ramos, a daughter of Laura N. Rey of Secaucus, N.J., and Edward Ramos of Gainesville, Fla., to William C. Monroe, a son of Anna H. Meyers of Fort Meyers, Fla., and the late Charles Henry Monroe of Manhattan. Judge Robert L. Nahman of City Civil Court officiated.
LEAD: THE JOFFREY BALLET has often been ambitious.

LEAD: Efforts by the Mexican left to run a single candidate in the presidential election next year have been thrown into disarray by the leading contender's decision to spurn, at least for the moment, a ''united front'' to challenge the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party.

LEAD: The wedding of Margaret LaiPing Chan, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Chan Charn of Hong Kong, to Daniel Gene Murphy, a son of William Joseph Murphy and June Marie Serio, both of Chicago, took place yesterday at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York.

LEAD: WHEN Donald J. Zinn was 24 years old, his salary was $55,000 a year. The next year, his earnings dropped to $18,000. Richard Benedetti fared even worse; he was 32, married with three children, making $60,000 one year and $18,000 the next.

LEAD: ON Tuesday night, Sung Kwak, dressed in tails, will raise his baton in Woolsey Hall on the Yale University campus and hope that the New Haven Symphony will play along with him. After all, this will be more than a concert: it is an audition, with more than 2,000 critical listeners - the audience and the orchestra itself.
LEAD: Connecticut law does not allow a relative to seek damages from medical professionals for emotional distress caused by watching a loved one become ill and die, a Superior Court judge has ruled.
LEAD: I am disgusted at the legal tactics the Hunt brothers are using to avoid paying the $2.43 billion they owe their creditors (''Battling a Billion-Dollar Debt,'' by John A. Jenkins, Sept. 27).
LEAD: Tables on page 25 of the Business section today, showing the week's market averages, give the net change incorrectly. A corrected table appears in this section, on page 24.

LEAD: BETWEEN MID-SEPTEMBER AND early November, segments of rural France take on an air of anticipation, anxiety and celebration. It is vendange, the grape harvest, when the status of the grapes tells much about the wine for the year. But regardless of the grapes' condition, vendange is a time for a fete, which translates, quite naturally, into good food and good times.

LEAD: UNTIL RECENTLY, MICHAEL Haydn languished in almost total obscurity, remembered - when at all - in footnotes to the lives of either his elder brother, Joseph, or his Salzburg colleague and neighbor, Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart.

LEAD: Craig Heyward had the game's only touchdown, ran for more than 100 yards for the seventh consecutive game and moved into third place on Pitt's career-rushing list as the Panthers defeated Navy, 10-6, today.

LEAD: Vermont's marijuana growers, stung by police raids and irked by hikers and hunters who pick their buds, are increasingly cultivating the illegal weed indoors or resorting to guerrilla farming tactics, according to the police and other experts.

LEAD: East End Temple, now 40 years old, has always wanted a new home, but at its current location, the southeast corner of Second Avenue at 23d Street. The only way the tiny temple could achieve this, it has argued, was to sell its air rights to a developer who would demolish the one-story structure, along with three adjacent tenements owned by the temple, and build an apartment tower above with a new, larger temple at street level.

LEAD: Helene Abby Resnick, a daughter of Mrs. Louis B. Resnick of Manhasset, L.I., and the late Mr. Resnick, was married last evening to Parker Waite Silzer 3d, the son of Joan Windatt Silzer of Westport, Conn., and Mr. Silzer Jr. of Pound Ridge, N.Y. LEAD: It was, to use a phrase coined by Yogi Berra, deja vu all over again. Last week, for the fifth time since 1975, Billy Martin was named manager of the New York Yankees. It was the 15th managerial change in the 14 years that fiery George Steinbrenner has owned the club. Martin will replace Lou Piniella, who managed the Yanks to a fourth place finish in their division this year.

LEAD: NBC Strike Ends Two holdout union locals voted to accept the network's contract offer and the 2,800-member broadcast employees' union stopped picketing. Page 21. Football Poll Backs Owners Forty-six percent of people surveyed on the football strike backed the owners, 26 percent the players.

LEAD: Most Friday evenings, members of a local Pentecostal church gather near the water's edge on Copacabana Beach for intense and emotional prayer sessions at which they try to exorcise ''diabolical'' African spirits from prospective converts.

LEAD: SINCE it is the most international of all sports, it has been said that soccer knows no language barrier. But don't try telling that to Steve Kassoy, the coach of the boys' soccer team at Hartford Public High School.

Grunewald, Democrat; Jack Olchin, Liberal, and Dr. Raymond J. Vuolo, Right-to-Life Party. The candidates were questioned by reporters and editors at The New York Times.

LEAD: IT IS LITERALLY A DECADENT building, a place where crumbling plaster, broken column capitals and cracked archways have been carefully preserved, and in more than a few cases, artfully stage-managed. The Majestic Theater, two blocks from the Brooklyn Academy of Music, was built in 1903 for the live stage and became a movie house before being abandoned in 1968.

LEAD: Mike O'Hara is a consumer, one of the little guys, and he likes the idea of the little guys getting together to fight rate increases by the electric company, the phone company and the gas company.

LEAD: THE story about, as the narrator introduces it, ''a boy, a girl, two fathers and a wall'' - otherwise known as ''The Fantasticks'' - is at the Downtown Cabaret Theater in Bridgeport for a spell. What else is new?
LEAD: Jamelle Holieway, a quarterback, rushed for 146 yards tonight to help Oklahoma overcome a sluggish performance and beat Colorado, 24-6, in a Big Eight Conference game.
LEAD: I read with interest the excellent article about the state's proposal for baby-naming regulations [ Page 1, Oct. 11 ] .

LEAD: PEOPLE in Lake Forest, Ill., take trees seriously. For eight consective years, the National Arbor Day Foundation has designated the community ''Tree City, U.S.A.'' because of the profuse planting and nurturing of trees by its 17,000 residents.

LEAD: A week after the Houston Oilers' top draft choicew, Alonzo Highsmith, won a temporary court injunction declaring him a free agent, the running back from the University of Miami and the Oilers have reached an agreement in principle, according to lawyers representing the club.
LEAD: To the Editor: Often when things on a trip go wrong passengers feel a need to blame someone and that someone is usually the airline. Sometimes it's a bum rap.

LEAD: NOT JUST A MOVIE, HERBERT Ross's film ''Dancers'' - starring Mikhail Baryshnikov - is a fable for our time. Critics across the board have hated it. Thirteen-year-old girls, especially the thousands who hang Baryshnikov posters on their bedroom walls, will love it. As they say in the business, the camera likes him.
LEAD: Rancor and hostility toward this city's newest group of immigrants has surfaced amid an angry debate over a school desegregation plan.

LEAD: People who crowded into a forum at the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem last week agreed on one point: the planned revision of the New York City charter is the ''single most important political issue'' for the city's minority groups.
LEAD: THRIVING ON CHAOS Handbook for a Management Revolution. By Tom Peters. 561 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

LEAD: OUT OF DONNA KARAN'S inner sanctum comes the designer's favorite fitting model, the willowy Doreen Erickson. She is wearing a sort of 1930's lacy straw hat, its brim casting seductive shadows on the sweetheart-necked stretch lace top. Her waist is sashed in folded satin, culminating in a rosette bow.
LEAD: Jerry O'Riordan's 28-yard field goal with four seconds left gave Wagner a 16-14 victory over Merchant Marine Academy yesterday at Kings Point, L.I.

LEAD: Most people share much more in common than they realize. Our aspirations for ourselves, our families, our associates and our countries are usually not too different. It is only natural, therefore, to have common ways of expressing these aspirations.

LEAD: WE went to South Jamesport on the North Fork seeking an uneventful holiday, a departure from normal rigors, a chance to gaze out at the bay and swim and read on the beach and nod off. We were not disappointed, but the visit revealed a large surprise nonetheless.

Rabbi Arthur Schneier officiated at the St. Regis-Sheraton Roof in New York.

LEAD: WE Americans tried hard to remove ourselves from the reality of what was going on in Europe in 1939. After all, there was a large ocean between us, The War had saved the world for Democracy and the idea that anyone would even consider another was ridiculous. Anyway, even if they did, it was not our business.

LEAD: The Miami Herald, the leading newspaper of South Florida, and the Cuban-American National Foundation, an influential lobbying group made up of wealthy Cuban-born businessmen, appeared, until last week, to be the best of friends.

LEAD: The activities of Unicef, as well as those of other United Nations agencies in Lebanon, have been severely hampered by the depressed economy, deteriorating public services and terrorism, agency officials say.
LEAD: Wall Street is rediscovering the importance of the denizens of the back office, who process and clear the endless stream of stock transactions, allowing the stock markets to function.

LEAD: ''Summits tend to get associated with positive substance, so I'm for them. But the point is to get substantive things done, not just to have a summit. We're not trying to achieve a summit for its own sake.'' - Secretary of State George P. Shultz. [ 12:4. ]

LEAD: EARLY LAST MONTH, AS ONE million pupils were returning to New York City's public schools, a rather eye-catching advertisement turned up on subway platforms and across full pages in newspapers. It showed two men standing inside a shattered window, one of them wearing a football jersey and black weight-lifting gloves, the other brandishing a baseball bat.

LEAD: SIX years ago, when the Village of Morton Grove, Ill., passed the nation's first ordinance banning both the sale and the possession of handguns, it provoked sharp controversy. Such critics as the National Rifle Association warned that Morton Grove's action could be the beginning of a nationwide campaign by local communities to take away the public's constitutional right to keep and bear arms.
LEAD: IN a remote corner of Maine, where farming means potatoes and lobster is king, a group of coastal residents is harvesting a different sort of crop: seaweed.
LEAD: NEW HOUSE By Joyce Maynard. Illustrated by Steve Bethel. Unpaged. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $12.95. (Ages 5 to 9)
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: I, too, come from a family who loved ''firsts'' (''A Family of Firsts,'' by Patricia Volk, Oct. 4). My husband thought it was an affliction. My children even loved being first to use the peanut butter. In my family, the first to tell the good news was the ultimate. My dilemma now: should I be first to tell them that you published my letter, or should I let them read it and think they are the first to know?

LEAD: SYLVIA PLATH A Biography. By Linda Wagner-Martin. Illustrated. 282 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

LEAD: AS the ''new town'' named Newport takes shape at the Hudson River waterfront in Jersey City, across the river from Canal Street in Manhattan, a picture is emerging of the residential market that the Lefrak Organization will be tapping over the next few years. So far only rentals have been offered.

LEAD: In the churches of Grenada on Sunday they will be saying prayers of thanksgiving to mark the day four years ago when American troops swept ashore to quell a spasm of violence that threatened to consume this beautiful Caribbean island.

LEAD: Despite their failure to set a date for a summit meeting, the United States and the Soviet Union bridged important differences on the emerging agreement to ban medium-range and shorter-range missiles, Administration officials said today.

LEAD: Eugene Hasenfus, the American whose airplane was shot down over Nicaragua last year on a run to deliver weapons to the contras, has filed a civil lawsuit against the company that employed him for the mission.

LEAD: The exit of Amadou-Mahtar M'Bow as Director General of Unesco is welcome in itself and for the signal it sends to entrenched bureaucrats in other international organizations. After 13 years, Mr. M'Bow had come to regard his $170,000-a-year post as impregnably tenured. But his candidacy for a third, six-year term proved so divisive that his own Government in Senegal urged him to withdraw.

LEAD: A judge who ordered a cocaine defendant to abstain from alcoholic beverages for three years was within his legal bounds, an appeals court has ruled.
LEAD: A curious thing about Elvis Patterson is that he answers your questions before you ask them.
LEAD: The ramifications of the strike of 1987 parallel last week's stock-market crash. Everyone involved got hurt: fans, owners, players, TV and vendors. But most of all the fans.

LEAD: CHRISTOPHER COLLIER, a history professor at the University of Connecticut, has been the Connecticut State Historian for three years. He is the author of several books, among them ''Roger Sherman's Connecticut,'' and ''Decision in Philadelphia,'' his most recent, about the Constitutional Convention, which he wrote with his brother, James Lincoln Collier.

LEAD: The six and a half million Armenians in the world have been a dispersed and tormented people without their own independent land. But their banner of unity has always been their church -the Armenian Apostolic.
LEAD: The Rockefeller family is expanding its activities in the Hudson Valley in an effort to preserve the rapidly growing region's famous vistas, historic sites and rural quality of life.
LEAD: The New York City Police Department will assign special liaison officers to five city hospitals beginning Monday to resolve conficts between other officers and medical personnel.
LEAD: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger has ordered the armed services to adopt a policy statement stressing the right of military spouses to take private jobs.

LEAD: The Defense Department is planning extensive layoffs of civilian employees and deep cuts in the work of small contractors in an effort to generate a political backlash against Congress for budget cuts, according to Pentagon officials.

LEAD: In the early morning light, as you drive west from Pecos, the mountains in the distance look like either a densely textured, low-lying bank of clouds or a mirage. The West Texas terrain has been so hard and so flat for so long that the mountains in the distance seem as improbable as an ocean. But the mountains are real, and their cold, lonely beauty gives identity to the one part of the state where the mythic

LEAD: GOOD EGGS Never mind the birds and the bees; consider the fish. The naturalists at the Cold Spring Harbor Fish Hatchery do, and, since this is fall, a traditional ritual, dating back to 1883, has begun: the autumn egg-taking. That's a demonstration twice a day, Saturdays and Sundays at 1 and 3 P.M., that shows visitors how eggs are extruded from the female trout and then mixed with similarly extruded milt from the male to create fertilized eggs.

LEAD: THE historic drop in the stock market was the result of the bearing down of a series of fundamental forces, the coming to the fore of a variety of structural vulnerabilities and the failure of market participants either to learn from or remember the lessons of history.
LEAD: VARIETY is the watchword on the concert scene this week, with large and small ensembles, new and old music, and ballads and ballet performed by Connecticut artists as well as visitors.

LEAD: Eight families from Woburn, Mass., who say chemicals in their water have caused six deaths from leukemia have accused one of the companies they hold responsible of suppressing key evidence during litigation last year. The families are asking for a new trial.

Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony.

LEAD: The ruling assembly of China's 46 million-member Communist Party meets Sunday for the first time in five years to grapple with a sweeping array of problems, including who will lead China, where they will lead it and how.

LEAD: A CREDULOUS viewer of Soviet television might think that ordinary Americans fall into two categories. Some live in cardboard boxes on the mean streets of New York. The rest spend their days marching vainly before the White House to protest the bellicose policies of the Reagan Administration.

LEAD: I've just had the opportunity to read the article titled ''State Nears Decision on Future of Congested Expressway'' [ Sept. 20 ] . Frankly, I feel that widening I-287 is a Band-Aid approach, as this is not a far-sighted solution, only an accommodation to the problem.

LEAD: BARRY WEINER is spending nearly $25,000 to search for tainted soil, toxic chemicals and asbestos in and around an industrial building he hopes to buy near New Haven.

LEAD: Nearly 200 years after a Philadelphia physician first advanced the theory of alcoholism as a disease rather than merely a character weakness, the issue may be faced squarely by the Supreme Court.

LEAD: ELEANOR PORTER'S ''Pollyanna'' seems in our time to be a book few people have read but everyone dislikes because of its reputation. The American Heritage Dictionary defines a Pollyanna as ''a foolishly or blindly optimistic person.'' One postwar reference book describes Pollyanna Whittier as ''possibly the most exasperating heroine in fiction.

LEAD: THE buyer of a single-family house is discovering that a lender may require homeowner insurance that exceeds the replacement value of the house. The reason is that market values have started to substantially exceed building costs.

LEAD: ABOUT two months ago, Dr. Leonard Davis, a radiologist in private practice in West Los Angeles, offered to do mammograms at the cut-rate price of $50 for women working at a Rockwell International plant in the San Fernando Valley. Dr. Davis, a strong advocate of mammography, the diagnostic technique that detected Nancy Reagan's breast cancer, reasoned that the price would be a strong incentive, since the test normally costs $100 to $150.
