He was an adviser to presidents, including Roosevelt, Truman and Johnson. Remembering the crash of '29, he said, ''We were confused, befuddled and lost.

LEAD: Police Commissioner Kevin M. Tucker has barred officers here from compiling ''any list related to a communicable-disease patient'' after a precinct posted the names and addresses of people believed to have AIDS. Officers said the list had been posted so they could put on protective gloves and take other precautions when responding to calls involving someone with acquired immune deficiency syndrome.

LEAD: A FRIEND familiar with my feelings about unedited vacation pictures had the temerity last week to ask to see my vacation snapshots. I blushed, shuffled my feet, and allowed as how I had used black-and-white film. Since I do the processing on my own, I explained, there were as yet no prints to look at.

LEAD: Queene Ferry Hooper, a daughter of Mrs. Arthur Upshur Hooper of Baltimore and the late Mr. Hooper, was married yesterday to Jonathan Sherill Foster, the son of N. Sherill Foster of East Hampton, L.I., and the late John R. Foster. The Rev. Frederick Hann, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the home of the bride's mother.

LEAD: INSIDE BUNGALOW I, AT HIS NEW headquarters in Culver City, Calif., Grant Tinker is taking a meeting. Right on the stroke of 10:30 A.M., an anxious writer, his agent at his heels, arrives to pitch a half-hour comedy series.

LEAD: WHAT is it about Arthur Miller's masterful play ''The Price'' that brings out the best in some regional theaters? Two outstanding productions have been seen in the state's professional playhouses in as many years.

LEAD: TEN months ago, on a Wednesday evening after work, Beverly Scott, a local resident and an employee of a New York City bank, went downtown to the United Community Corporation with an altruistic purpose and a briefcase full of instructional reading material.

LEAD: THE turmoil in stock prices hassent a clear warning to Washington: United States economic stategies need to be overhauled fundamentally and quickly. We have lost control over our fiscal and monetary policies, which threatens to destabilize the economy and deprive us of the traditional tools for dealing with inflation and recession.

LEAD: When William Penn offered haven to the persecuted of Europe, groups of Germanic Protestants accepted his offer and settled in the gently rolling countryside of Lancaster County in southeastern Pennsylvania. Though the people became known as the Pennsylvania Dutch, Dutch is a misnomer, a corruption of the word Deutsch, or German, the language that was spoken by Mennonites, followers of Menno Simons, and the Amish, followers of a Swiss Mennonite bishop, Jacob

LEAD: Believing that fundamental conditions of the country are sound and that there is nothing in the business situation to warrant the destruction of values that has taken place on the exchanges during the past week, my son and I have for some days been purchasing sound common stocks. We are continuing and will continue our purchases in substantial amounts at levels which we believe represent sound investment values.
LEAD: HER MOTHER'S DAUGHTER By Marilyn French. Illustrated. 686 pp. New York: Summit Books. $21.95.

LEAD: THE other day, my son told me that I was to become a grandfather. My first reaction was one of utter joy, for him and also for me, perhaps primarily for me. Certainly the birth would be a major milestone, a ''marker event'' in both our lives.
LEAD: Gary Kasparov's macho approach to chess is glorious when it succeeds, but it can look juvenile in failure.
LEAD: Jocelyn Pascal Koskinas and W. Scott Simon were married yesterday at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Osterville, Mass. The Rev. Raymond Webster performed the ceremony.

LEAD: To me, some of the big losers in the football strike were the networks' TV announcers. These people in their attempts to disparage the play of the replacement players gave me the impression that they believe the N.F.L. regulars never drop a well-thrown pass, never jump offside, never miss a block, never throw an interception, etc.

LEAD: Weeks On Fiction List 1 THE GOLDEN CUP, by Belva Plain. (Dell, $4.95.) 3 Continuing the saga of a turn-of-the-century New York family begun in "Evergreen." 2 A TASTE FOR DEATH, by P. D. James. (Warner, 4 $4.95.) Comdr. Adam Dalgliesh investigates a brutal double murder.

LEAD: Throughout Polynesia, islanders have traditionally used tapa, richly patterned bark cloth, as a gift for weddings, the installation of chiefs and other special occasions. In the Kingdom of Tonga, which produces more than any other South Pacific country, tapa continues to be used in these traditional ways and has become popular with tourists as well.

LEAD: Pat Robertson, seeking to portray himself as the Republican Presidential field's champion of conservatives, told a crowd of staunch supporters here Friday night that if elected he would put conservatives in appointive positions from top to bottom and purge the bureaucracy of what he said were thousands of holdovers from the Carter
LEAD: THE first building of South Pointe Towers began receiving occupants here last week, ending a long struggle with financial difficulties.
LEAD: The use of speechwriters by public figures is deceptive to begin with. Is it any wonder that the additional dishonesty of stealing the script from others arouses genuine outrage?

LEAD: CHALLENGING the procedures used by international track officials in banning her from competition for using steroids, Sandra Gasser, the Swiss middle distance runner who received a two-year ban after traces of steroids were found in her system at the world track and field championships in Rome, has filed suit in Bern seeking immediate reinstatement.

LEAD: WHEN BILL MOYERS RE-turned to public television a year ago, he arrived with a slate of ambitious projects, a potful of foundation money and high expectations. However, it was not long before Mr. Moyers, who had been away for five years, was reminded of the frustrations of working in a system that is maddingly democratic, with as many bosses -317 - as it has stations.

LEAD: NOT a day passes in which we are not exposed to a news story that in some way deals with the deterioration of our environment. The pictures vary, but usually we see a crowd of demonstrators who are announcing their opposition to changes in their community or protesting the closing of their polluted-beyond-use beaches, the conversion of single-house properties with trees to two-house wastelands, nuclear plants, nuclear waste sites, multifamily housing, down-zoning for more industries and a score of other problems too numerous to mention.
LEAD: The first moment that Secretary of State George P. Shultz realized that things were going wrong came just after he woke up in Moscow Friday morning.
LEAD: SHORTLY after his 26th birthday last June, Ken Rose decided that 1987 would be the denouement of his football career. Either he would make it or he wouldn't.

LEAD: ''Urban VIsions,'' an Adelphi University exhibition dealing with images of the contemporary city, will reinforce convictions about realism as a technique, but its true value rests with its psychological concerns and with its insights into the artist's own attitude toward the theme. An artist's approach is usually revealing about the way we see our world.

LEAD: First Options of Chicago Inc., the nation's largest options clearinghouse, last week needed a major infusion of capital from the Continental Illinois Corporation to meet its regulatory obligations.

LEAD: The team was already hampered by the absence of its best player, Arvidas Sabonis, the 7-foot-2-inch center who is recovering from surgery on his Achilles' tendon one month ago. Then there was an arduous 26-hour wait in the Soviet Union for heavy fog to lift before traveling.
LEAD: THE notable Georgiaville mill complex on the banks of the Woonasquatucket River here is in line for conversion into 125 condominium units.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Sir Arthur Conan Doyle once called London ''that great cesspool into which all the loungers of the Empire are irresistibly drained.'' London is no place for loungers these days. More than anywhere else in Britain, London today shows the transforming hallmarks of Margaret Thatcher's ''spirit of enterprise.
LEAD: ''In this business,'' said Ken Dayley, who came out of the bullpen today and threw one pitch that cost four runs in the World Series, ''you're either a hero or a zero.''
LEAD: NOW in the throes of its ''Second Emerging Expression Biannual,'' the Bronx Museum of the Arts seems about to become a headquarters for artists working with computers.

LEAD: The wedding of Linda Sue Schwartzman, the daughter of Allan Schwartzman and Dr. Lois Schwartzman of Westport, Conn., to Charles D. F. Cohn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. Cohn of Riverdale, the Bronx, took place last evening at the Rye Town Hilton in Rye Brook, N.Y. Rabbi Amiel Wohl officiated.

LEAD: Las Vegas Question:I want to realize an old ambition to visit Las Vegas. Who runs short trips there and what do they cost? - G. R., New York Answer:Among tour companies travel agents turn to when they arrange trips to Las Vegas are Freedom Express Tours (155 East 55th Street, New York, N.Y.

LEAD: INTRODUCING ''THE CHINESE Scholar's Studio: Artistic Life in the Late Ming Period,'' at the Asia Society, is a hanging scroll called ''Venerable Friends.'' Painted by Xiang Shengmo and Zhang Qi, it is an imaginary group portrait of six influential literati of the Ming Dynasty. All were from Jiaxing or Songjiang in the Yangtze River delta.

LEAD: SOMETIME AROUND MIDSUM-mer, about as far away psychologically from Christmas as one could possibly imagine, commercials appear for the annual Crazy Eddie Christmas sale. Readers may feel a similar sense of inappropriateness at the October appearance of a Christmas album. But marketing timetables being what they are, this seems to be the time to release such ventures, to judge from the host of

LEAD: EVEN before stock prices tumbled on Wall Street last week, developers, investors and house buyers tried to assess just how closely the real estate market and the stock market were linked. Now they want to know if one can prosper without the other.
LEAD: IRAN, an old hand at byzantine maneuvers, is resorting to an ancient tactic to deal with its many enemies: divide and rule, or at least create confusion and hesitation.
LEAD: Joel Ratner, the alderman from New Haven's first ward, does not get many telephone calls from angry constituents complaining about municipal concerns like garbage collection and leaf pickup.

LEAD: Fed up with what it considers overregulation, the Massachusetts Medical Society has sent letters to medical societies elsewhere asserting that the state is ''an undesirable location in which to practice.''

LEAD: The Bryn Mawr (Pa.) Presbyterian Church was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Sherri Lynne Carroll, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew David Carroll of Bryn Mawr, to Curtis Paul Oberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lambert Oberg of West Hartford, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Eugene Bay performed the ceremony.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: THE CURTAINS ARE DRAWN, AS THEY must always be. ''Security,'' explains Lawrence E. Walsh, the special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair; the Federal Bureau of Investigation worries that someone might spy through the windows.
LEAD: FORTY STORIES By Donald Barthelme. Illustrated. 256 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $17.95.

LEAD: ABOUT HALFWAY INTO THE first scene of the Metropolitan Opera's new ''Rheingold'' on opening night, I became aware that surprisingly little of the staging was distracting my attention from Wagner's own shrewd way of telling his tale of moral decay and betrayal. So hardened have we become to seeing directors and designers intrude their daring little persons into opera productions that the absence of conceptual handstands and theatrical back flips can now be startling.

LEAD: THE old Syms Operating Theater, at the southwest corner of 59th Street and Columbus Avenue, is the oldest extant Roosevelt Hospital building. As Community Board 4 begins reviewing plans for two 45-story apartment towers on an adjacent hospital site scheduled for clearance, the squat, red-brick structure may become a bargaining chip.

LEAD: In his favorable review of behavioral medicine, Daniel Goleman neglects to mention two of its most serious shortcomings: first, its obvious bias toward affluent and highly verbal patients, and, more important, the very real danger it presents to patients who do not respond positively to behavioral treatment.

LEAD: The Bio-Bio, a 238-mile-long river in Chile, is named for the sweet ''feeo-feeo'' call of the Chilean elaenia, a local bird, but its nature is much less benign. Since the first descent in 1978 by a team of California adventurers, white water rafting enthusiasts from around the globe have responded to its call.

LEAD: The seasonal rituals of production and the quiet self-confidence of many farmers have been shaken here in California's Central Valley, where straight roads and deep creeks run past miles of walnut groves and peach orchards.
LEAD: After more than a year of negotiation, New Jersey has become the first state to obtain Federal waivers so that it can begin one of the most sweeping welfare overhauls in the country.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: FOR a time it looked as if Las Colinas, a 12,000-acre new town of apartments, offices and stores here in the middle of the Dallas-Fort Worth Metroplex, might succumb to the Texas oil bust and the region's 30 percent-plus office vacancy rate.

LEAD: The Minnesota Twins tied the World Series at three games each yesterday when they ended a three-game losing streak and overwhelmed the St. Louis Cardinals, 11-5, in Minneapolis. The deciding game will be played in Minneapolis tonight at 8:25, Eastern Standard Time.
LEAD: THE TENTH JUSTICE The Solicitor General and the Rule of Law. By Lincoln Caplan. 352 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

LEAD: October's reputation for cruelty to investors is more firmly established than ever. The late 1970's saw the back-to-back October massacres of 1978 and 1979, with the Dow posting double-digit percentage losses in each of those months. Of course there was 1929 with its Black Monday on Oct. 28. Then there was October 1987.
LEAD: PINXTER FLOWER, pink shell, and honeysuckle are some of the best landscaping shrubs available, each of them carrying clusters of fragrant, delicate flowers.

LEAD: FOREIGN investors, once high rollers on Wall Street, are taking their new investment money elsewhere and are unlikely to return en masse until stability prevails, economists and international market specialists say. Some picked up blue-chip bargains after the market plunged, but most remain on the sidelines.

LEAD: This is a good week for vocal fans. Sunday, Carnegie Hall devotes itself entirely to singing. At 3 P.M. Leontyne Price will sing a varied program to benefit the United Negro College Fund, and at 8,the Richard Tucker Music Foundation, which has for 12 years supported upcoming singers, will stage a gala concert conducted by Richard Bonynge and Daniel Oren, with members of the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra.

LEAD: Leonor F. Loree 2d, a retired vice chairman and director of the Chase Manhattan Bank, died Thursday at the Morristown (N.J.) Memorial Hospital from complications of pneumonia. He was 73 years old and lived in Millington, N.J.
LEAD: ''THE Song of the Loom,'' a major exhibition at the Montclair Art Museum, focuses on a little-known style of contemporary Navajo weaving.
LEAD: Rutgers stirred visions of its first trip to a bowl game outside the state of New Jersey by winning, 27-14, today from an Army team depleted by injuries to its quarterbacks.

LEAD: Since nobody I know recommends a mother-son trip as a child-raising device, the vacation I took with my 10-year-old to Hawaii earlier this year was an experiment in more ways than one. We were two generations with different interests going nearly 5,000 miles to a place we had never been before, trying to see and absorb as much as possible in 10 days' time.

LEAD: THE county has traditionally supported fine orchestras, excellent choirs, top-notch chamber ensembles and all manner of innovative concert series, but all previous efforts to establish a base for professional opera in the county have been, at best, of short duration. Undaunted by this precedent, a group of opera buffs have come together to form The Westchester Opera, with performing headquarters at the Tarrytown Music

LEAD: EACH fall, scores of women, many of them recent graduates of the best schools in the country, descend on Manhattan to make their marks in book publishing. Those who succeed can look forward to jobs that not only offer low salaries and infrequent promotions but also assign homework: boxes of manuscripts that must be lugged home on the subway to be evaluated and edited in what normal people would consider their spare time.

LEAD: A BLACK-AND-WHITE drawing by a 9-year-old boy from a divorced family shows a line drawn down the middle separating ''Dad's'' side from ''Mom's'' side. ''Dad'' is riding on top of an army tank shooting a machine gun at ''Mom.'' ''Mom'' shoots back, and the boy drew himself in the middle of the page yelling, ''Help!

LEAD: The players should have gone on strike between the sixth and the eighth games. They would not be hurt as much financially, the owners would not have time to assemble ''scabs'' and the players would have been able to stay out for the season. The owners without eight more television games would have caved in.
LEAD: THE SELECTED LETTERS OF LOUISA MAY ALCOTT Edited by Joel Myerson and Daniel Shealy with Madeleine B. Stern. Illustrated. 352 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $24.95.

LEAD: Notre Dame rolled up 351 rushing yards today and Tony Rice, a sophomore quarterback, directed first-half scoring drives of 88 and 90 yards in a 26-15 victory over archrival Southern California.

LEAD: THE JAZZ AGE Popular Music in the 1920's. By Arnold Shaw. 350 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $19.95. ALL IN GOOD TIME By Marian McPartland. Illustrated. 174 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $14.95.

Not only does it include the original manuscripts of some of the most famous poems in the English language, but also a large group of masterpieces by Constable,

Saturday. Carl Picha, historian and engineer with the New York City Water Department will start the program with a slide-talk at the Southeast Museum in

LEAD: President J. R. Jayewardene said today that India's two-week-old campaign against a Tamil rebel stronghold in Jaffna had succeeded in breaking the ''military hold'' of Tamil guerrillas in northern and eastern Sri Lanka.
LEAD: Scott Davis, an Illinois defensive end, blocked a last-second 28-yard field-goal attempt by Michigan State's John Langeloh to preserve a 14-14 tie in the Big Ten Conference game today.

LEAD: EVEN retrospectively, the course of AIDS is not necessarily knowable. For one thing, although the findings are so stark and so hard to explain that researchers hesitate to say much, AIDS evidently kills women more rapidly than it kills men. And in New York, city health officials announced last week, it has killed more drug users than anyone had thought.
LEAD: Harlem is unfamiliar terrain to most urban explorers, but it is one of the city's more vibrant areas and one that is experiencing considerable development activity.

LEAD: IN a reflective moment toward the end of his life, William Carlos Williams brushed aside yet another question about himself and his poems, stories and novels: ''The last few years, just when I'm getting ready to kick off, people keep coming at me. They want to know who I am, and what do I mean here and there and everywhere in my writing.
LEAD: CONNECTICUT, like all of New England, is steeped in history. If a new state law is put to its full use, this history will have many more people looking after it.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH New Jersey's legislative races do not appear to be generating much interest and both Democratic and Republican leaders expect a light voter turnout on Nov. 3, there has been no stinting when it comes to spending money on the campaigns.

LEAD: THE MARTHA GRAHAM dance company season that ends tonight opened on Oct. 6 with a celebrity-studded gala benefit performance that looked both backward to the hard-won glory of its past and forward to its future. That future is dependent, Graham company sources say, on greatly increased funding, much of which the company is attempting to secure by bypassing the National Endowment for the Arts and appealing directly to Congress.

LEAD: ''THE CREATION'' AND ''THE Seasons'' have so dominated Haydn's reputation as an oratorio composer that little room has been left over for such earlier beauties as ''Il Ritorno di Tobias.'' ''Tobias,'' however, returns to us on a three-compact-disk release by Hungaroton (HCD 11669-62-2). It reminds us of the rich, if perhaps simpler, qualities of a younger

LEAD: LEAFLETS circulating in some Nicaraguan war zones show a photograph of President Daniel Ortega Saavedra shaking hands with the Roman Catholic primate, Miguel Cardinal Obando y Bravo. Behind the two men, who have been vigorous adversaries for years, is a Nicaraguan flag. The message is simple: ''Come home.
LEAD: The last six weeks have been like a roller-coaster ride for Coach Joe Walton.

LEAD: WITH the approach of the New York City Marathon next Sunday, I realized that for more than half of my life I have had distance running as my companion. Much has changed both in my own life and in the perceptions of road running.

LEAD: ANGELS WITHOUT WINGS A Courageous Family's Triumph Over Tragedy. By Jane Vonnegut Yarmolinsky. 174 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $15.95.

LEAD: It all seems familiar: the Giants 10-point favorites over the Cardinals today, another late-afternoon game at the Meadowlands, Phil Simms throwing against Neil Lomax, players named Morris, Benson, Carson and Bavaro.

LEAD: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, the Democratic Presidential contender, has released a listing of his personal finances that puts his earnings from last year to this month at $192,090, mostly from honoraria, and his assets at $347,000.

LEAD: Bestial Crimes Animals used to be taken much more seriously and less sentimentally by society - at one time they could be tried and sentenced for criminal acts. This is from ''The Animal Estate: The English and Other Creatures in the Victorian Age'' by Harriet Ritvo (Harvard University).

LEAD: AFTER EXPOUNDING FOR a couple of Sundays on the general principles of picking stereo equipment, we are about to dispel lingering patches of fog and get down to particulars. Besides, an itemized shopping list, however prosaic, might be useful to audiophiles heading for the store in a timely attempt to beat the Christmas rush.

LEAD: Bridgewater, Conn. 450,000 Skyline Ridge 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 41-year-old ranch; inground pool, 3-car garage, 8.9 acres; taxes $2,696. New Preston, Conn. $160,000 Route 202 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 53-year-old farmhouse; barn, brook, 2.3 acres; taxes $1,034.

LEAD: Doctors believe a St. Louis teen-ager who died in 1969 was infected with the virus that causes AIDS, according to a newspaper report. A finding of AIDS in 1969, if confirmed, would be far earlier than the earliest known cases, identified in the late 1970's in New York City and California.

LEAD: FISH AND FLIES Bing Crosby was one. Ernest Hemingway was another. Like Zane Grey, Daniel Webster and millions of others, they were enthusiasts of the ancient sport of fly fishing, the subject of an exhibit that opened yesterday at the Academy of Natural Sciences Museum in Philadelphia.

LEAD: THE BLOCKS AROUND TIMES Square look different right now from the way they have for the last 50 years, and the change is both exhilarating and depressing. The wave of high-rise construction just north of Times Square that the city's planners have long predicted has now begun to break on these concrete shores, and it is an extraordinary moment in the history of these blocks.

LEAD: WHISTLES blew. Officials in black-and-white striped shirts waved their arms. The football players wearing Jets and Dolphins uniforms peered out from behind their facemasks as if they were impostors whose real identities had been discovered. Which they were. In the fourth quarter at Giants Stadium last Sunday, all those imposters suddenly stood still.
LEAD: TO reduce insurance costs, 10 Connecticut fire and police departments are now hiring only nonsmokers. But they are allowing those already hired to continue smoking.
LEAD: The Navy has quietly created a new mission for submarines - firing cruise missiles with high-explosive, nonnuclear warheads at military targets ashore, according to Pentagon officials.
LEAD: A small bomb went off in the seafront offices of Pan American World Airways today, as Kuwait remained tense after a missile damaged its main offshore oil terminal on Thursday.

LEAD: Ann Stuart Reed, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Reed of Winter Park, Fla., was married there yesterday at All Saints Episcopal Church to Gregory Scott Scileppi, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Scileppi of Floral Park, L.I. The Rev. Paul L. Crowell officiated. The bride is an administrative assistant in the commodities department at Interstate Securities Inc.
LEAD: BENEFIT FOR THE HUNGRY Sixty professional entertainers who live or have lived in Monmouth County will donate their services this evening in a concert to raise money to feed the county's hungry.

LEAD: WHEN we last left them, a few minutes ago, hemlines seemed to be going in two directions: up and down. Except, of course, the ones that weren't going anywhere. If you are confused by all this, don't worry about it. Just put on your best evening duds and get yourself to a fancy party. There you'll find that hemlines know exactly where they're headed, and that's north.

LEAD: THE patient, plodding tempo of Secretary of State George P. Shultz's diplomacy has just carried him gamely through the Middle East and the Soviet Union in nine frustrating days, yielding only subtle accomplishments amid the overwhelming impression of defeat. He reported no progress in his efforts to revive the Middle East peace process.

LEAD: KEEP up with bulb planting; if small bulbs such as those of anemone and puschkinia appear dried out, soak them in warm water for an hour or so before planting; drain to dry on paper towels first. Plant grape hyacinth bulbs where their recurrent foliage does not hamper other garden plants. Finish dividing and replanting thick clumps of ferns; be sure the soil is enriched with peat moss and/or compost.

LEAD: One day in the first week of June, we students at the Alliance Francaise set out like a band of Parisian Huck Finns to see, not the world, but the movies. What freedom we had! As debutants Francophones, it didn't make much difference to us which movie - we were bound to miss most of the dialogue anyway.

LEAD: THE church has stood on the same grassy knoll for 302 years, surrounded by the locust trees and ''lofty elms,'' through which, as Washington Irving wrote, ''peeks may be caught at the blue hills of the Hudson.''

LEAD: The Peace Corps, as part of a drive to double its force of volunteers to 10,000 by 1992, has announced that it will arrange with universities to allow dental and public health students to perform much of their work toward a degree while serving with the agency.

LEAD: PAULA ROBISON and Eliot Fisk gave another of their appealing flute and guitar programs Friday evening at Weill Recital Hall. The two players are expert, sensitive and affable; they know how to give the audience a good time, and they make a bit of modern music go down easy, even if they do not entirely evade a certain blandness in the process.

LEAD: LIKE a good detective novel, the campaign for the French presidency has opened briskly and with little indication of how it will end. Although the winner will probably not be evident until a runoff ballot between the two leading contenders in May, many French politicians and commentators have already concluded that the election will be an institutional watershed.

LEAD: FACED with a backlog of 1,200 requests to outline the boundaries of wetlands in the tri-state area of South Jersey, Pennsylvania and Delaware, the Army Corps of Engineers is encouraging property owners to have their land privately inspected.

Gordon Jr., a senior vice president of the GECC Capital Markets Group Inc., a subsidiary of the General Electric Credit Corporation.

The next generation of corporate officers must be able to cope with paradox.

LEAD: AIDS is proving elusive as well as deadly. Medical experts, unable to find a vaccine or a cure, cannot even agree on how to track and forecast the epidemic's devastating path.

Some were decorated with brilliant appliques, others were made of black, hairy material like a bear's skin, and still others had upturned shoulders like wings.

LEAD: Wall Street went to work yesterday, hoping no hidden financial bombshells would be uncovered in the sorting of mounds of computer records that tracked last week's frantic stock market.
LEAD: Protesters hurling firebombs today attacked the motorcade of Roh Tae Woo, the governing party's presidential candidate, as he drove in an open jeep to a campaign rally in this central city.
LEAD: When Joseph L. Opala reads folk tales written in the Gullah language of American blacks, audiences here ''just go crazy,'' the American anthropologist says.

LEAD: MARKET analysis provides the single most reliable tool for anticipating major changes in economic trends, and to some degree, accompanying social trends as well. A particularly dramatic shift in the trend of a major market virtually always constitutes a signal that a fundamental change in the associated environment has occurred or will soon occur.

LEAD: NEW YORK CITY is big. It's big in size; more than 300 square miles. It's big in people; more than seven million. It's big in buildings; more than 800,000. And it's big in apartments; more than two million.

LEAD: NOT LONG AGO, I had the chance to work for several months on an archeological salvage ship looking for a sunken Spanish galleon. I had never even snorkeled before, but I soon became, at the age of 53, one of the ship's regular divers. My wife and daughter had encouraged me to try it. ''Chance of a lifetime,'' they said.

A second flushing usually does it, but in rare cases I even have to use a plunger. Originally the plumbing system lacked a vent stack, but I retrofitted one by installing a tee fitting that I cut into the main waste line in my basement.

LEAD: OFFICIALS of the Seattle SuperSonics said that Dale Ellis, the guard who had been seeking a better-paying contract, had decided to abandon the effort for the time being and to play out the option year of his old contract before resuming his quest as a free agent. . . Jim Peterson, a forward for the Houston Rockets, underwent surgery to remove bone spurs from his left ankle and will be out for up to six weeks.

LEAD: We feel strongly that it is time for Pete Rozelle and the National Football League management to intervene and amend the playoff format to include more teams. In this way, the N.F.L. compensates for unrepresentative replacement teams unfairly influencing the crowning of the champion. By proportionally increasing the importance of an expanded postseason and reducing the importance of -while not canceling - the replacement games, the league can still salvage this woebegone season.

LEAD: THE House voted last week to extend the independent prosecutor law, a prospect that galls the Reagan Administration, which sees the law as unconstitutional and which also has present and former aides under investigation by at least six special prosecutors. A veto has been mentioned.
LEAD: THE notable Georgiaville mill complex on the banks of the Woonasquatucket River here is in line for conversion into 125 condominium units.

LEAD: AROUND the turn of the century, a 647-pound fire chief named Barney ran a bar-hotel in Locust Valley. Today, that bar-hotel building is a fashionable restaurant that keeps alive Barney's legend as the largest fire chief in Nassau County's history.

LEAD: THE announcement of the closing of a branch of the Chemical Bank in Wyandanch has drawn a reaction of frustration and anger from customers, many of whom are welfare recipients who depend on the services of the bank to pick up food stamps and cash their checks.

LEAD: The naturalists missed one beast [ ''Naturalists List the Beasts Among Us,'' Sept. 6 ] - the goundhog, also known as the woodchuck, or Marmota monax, whichever you prefer. I don't prefer them in my yard under any name.

LEAD: John Cougar Mellencamp's sobriquet ''Little Bastard'' might very well be attributable to his fiery demeanor (''Rebel With a Cause,'' by Timothy White, Sept. 27). LEAD: United Press International may be moving toward yet another crisis in its long and troubled struggle to survive.

Rudolf Jansen will be her accompanist. Tickets, at $18, $16 and $12.50, are available at the box office or through Carnegie Charge, 247-7800.

LEAD: At a party that he had hoped would be his victory celebration, Louisiana's populist Governor, Edwin Edwards, withdrew from his campaign for re-election today after a second-place finish in Saturday's primary.

LEAD: High school athletes have been turning away from individual sports in favor of team sports over the last 10 years, but at the same time they have been demonstrating heightened individualistic tendencies that have made it harder for their coaches to mold them into teams.
LEAD: An earthquake centered offshore was felt in Southern California on Saturday, the authorities reported.

LEAD: In an experimental program, 10 elementary schools in poor neighborhoods of New York State plan to operate year-round, seven days a week, and to provide an array of special services, top state education officials say.
LEAD: Moment of Hope completed a weekend of short-priced stakes winners at Aqueduct by taking the $181,800 Stuyvesant Handicap yesterday by 1 1/2 lengths over Wind Chill.

LEAD: A convicted drug smuggler who escaped from prison in Kentucky five years ago was arrested Saturday as he walked from a truck stop in Oregon with $1,500 stuffed in his artificial leg, the United States Marshals Service said.

LEAD: Susan Hollis Goldstein, a designer for WBTL Architects in New York, and Geoffrey Robert Doban, a designer for Gruzen Samton Steinglass, New York architects, were married yesterday at the Ritz-Carlton in Boston. Rabbi Burton Padoll performed the nonsectarian service.

LEAD: In what seemed an impossible feat, a soaring acrobat whirled over a line of obstacles, in this case volunteers from the audience, during a performance by a group of street acrobats in Washington Square Park. The acrobats, called the Calypso Tumblers, thrilled a large crowd of spectators, whose applause, as well as their contributions, were welcomed.

LEAD: David Sinclair, a retired research physicist and a son of Upton Sinclair, the American writer and journalist, died Saturday of lung cancer at Cabrini Hospital in Manhattan. He was 85 years old and lived in Martinsville, N.J., and Manhattan.

LEAD: In the 12 years since the fall of Saigon, Bui Diem, South Vietnam's last Ambassador to Washington, has been a bit of a jack-of-all-trades: professor, writer, lecturer and, for one two-year period, a dispenser of pastrami and corn beef at Goldberg's Deli in northwest Washington.

LEAD: THE shares of publicly held advertising agencies did about the same as the rest of the stock market last week, or slightly worse, according to Wall Street analysts. But nothing has happened to disturb the traditionally optimistic precincts of Madison Avenue.

LEAD: Julie Agoos and Sharon Bryan will read from their poems on Nov. 4 at 6:30 P.M. at the Poetry Society of America, 15 Gramercy Park, near 20th Street between Park Avenue South and Third Avenue. The free reading begins a new series devoted to emerging writers. Information: 254-9628.

LEAD: The middle-aged man in the blue suit, red tie and blue shirt looks directly into the television camera and says this about the Social Security system: ''The present system gives young people a false sense of security. I'm Pete du Pont. There is a solution.''

LEAD: When Nicaraguan rebel leaders met with Republican senators this month, they asked whether some legislators would accompany them in their attempt to return to Managua to negotiate a cease-fire with the Sandinista Government.

LEAD: Three robbers invaded a jewelry store on a crowded thoroughfare in Chinatown yesterday and, as they fled with gold chains and other loot, shot a young woman employee and a male clerk who ran to her aid from a shop next door.

LEAD: A Silicon Valley computer networking company said today that it had received an unsolicited takeover offer. Analysts have predicted that last week's drop in stock prices might produce a number of such offers.

His father, a tailor, is not amused, especially when Fearnot botches an expedition to fetch a shipment of buttons. The old man kicks his son out of the house, giving him 40 shillings and an order to learn something responsible.

LEAD: Doctors believe a St. Louis teen-ager who died in 1969 was infected with the virus that causes AIDS, according to a newspaper report. A finding of AIDS in 1969, if confirmed, would be far earlier than the earliest known cases, identified in the late 1970's in New York City and California.

LEAD: From the President down, Reagan Administration officials seem determined to be reassuring about the stock market crash and the underlying state of the economy. This is an inadequate response to emergency, even if the official facts seem to bear them out.

LEAD: Prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange plummeted today, but then recovered some of their losses late in the session in roller-coaster trading that apparently reflected worries here about Wall Street's health.
LEAD: Vladimir Slepak, a Jew who had been refused permission to leave the Soviet Union, arrived in Vienna today, ending a 17-year struggle to emigrate. ''It's like a dream,'' he said.

LEAD: George M.D. Lewis, a Pennsylvania architect who served as a bomber pilot under Fiorello H. La Guardia in northern Italy in World War I, died Friday at the Community Medical Center in Scranton, Pa. He was 96 years old and lived in Waverly, Pa.

LEAD: Tennis Edberg Upsets Lendl: In a showdown between the world's top two tennis players, second-ranked Stefan Edberg of Sweden upset top-ranked Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia, 6-7, 6-4, 6-4, yesterday for the $60,000 first prize in the $375,000 Seiko Super Classic in Tokyo. Edberg played his usual serve-and-volley game before a crowd of 11,000 on the Supreme Court of the Yoyogi National Stadium, while Lendl played mostly from the baseline.

LEAD: The Nutrasweet Company said Friday that it had asked the Food and Drug Administration to approve the use of the artificial sweetener aspartame in baked goods and baking mixes. In the past, the F.D.A. had said that aspartame, sold under the trade name Nutrasweet, was unacceptable for baking because the sweetener would break down at high temperatures.

LEAD: James S. Berrien of the American Express Publishing Corporation is stepping into his second job as a magazine publisher at age 35. His new responsibility is Travel & Leisure, circulation 1.1 million, a bit of a step up from Food & Wine, circulation 750,000.

LEAD: Behind the start of official Ivy League round-robin competition 31 years ago was the concept that the eight conference members, similar institutions playing under the same strict academic rules, would share the laurels.

LEAD: Wilbur Darby Curtis, the inventor of the glass coffee pot and a fiber glass-bodied automobile, the Shamrock, died Saturday of a heart attack. He was 82 years old. He had been ill since August, when he suffered a stroke at his home here, according to his son-in-law, A. James Liska of Agoura.

LEAD: Some strategic fiscal footwork by the Martha Graham Dance Company has not drawn bravos from the National Endowment for the Arts. Bypassing the endowment, which has helped support the company since 1966, the Graham company has gone directly to Congress to seek a $7 million appropriation.

LEAD: Charitable giving, traditionally high in the holiday season, could drop alarmingly because of the stock market downturn, according to leading authorities on philanthropy. A number of fund-raisers also warned that the market's fluctuations could put a long-term chill on giving.

LEAD: THE MASK OF COMMAND. By John Keegan. 368 pages. Illustrated. Elisabeth Sifton Books/Viking. $18.95. ''THE MASK OF COMMAND'' is a book about what it means to be a general that starts off from the premise that it can mean many different things. Over the centuries kings and demagogues have doubled as generals, and generals have doubled as diplomats and priests; a commanding officer, like the army that serves under him, is always the product of a particular society, and the qualities that his position calls for vary from age to age and place to place.

LEAD: Tourists from the Soviet Union had a unique opportunity to watch capitalism at work yesterday at the New York Stock Exchange. Observing from the administrative platform, they photographed the frenzied activity as traders raced to complete their business before the 2 P.M. closing. Their visit had been arranged before the volatile events of the past week, although they could not have picked a better day to witness the drama of buying and selling.

LEAD: TWENTY years after its first staging here, John Herbert's ''Fortune and Men's Eyes'' has been revived at the Actors' Playhouse, where it had its first run. We have seen many plays, films and television programs about sexual power struggles in prisons since then, so the shock value of this story about a Canadian boys' reformatory has virtually disappeared - and that works to the benefit of the play.

LEAD: THERE are three reasons why Prof. Orley Ashenfelter is watching with interest as capital flees the stock market and moves into liquid assets. First, he teaches economics at Princeton University. Second, he is managing editor of The American Economic Review, the scholarly journal of the American Economic Association.

LEAD: On the eve of a Koch administration effort to hospitalize homeless people who are severely mentally ill, an advocacy group charged yesterday that the city and state were improperly sending psychiatric patients back to the streets.

LEAD: WHEN we first meet the title characters of Terrence McNally's provocative new play, ''Frankie and Johnny in the Clair de Lune,'' they are grunting through an orgasm on a Murphy bed in a dreary Hell's Kitchen walk-up. But Frankie (Kathy Bates) and Johnny (Kenneth Welsh) are hardly sweethearts. They are fellow employees of a greasy spoon -she a waitress, he a recently hired short-order cook - and this is their first and quite possibly their last date.

LEAD: EVER since the first umpire missed a call, baseball's cop-out has been that bad calls even up, that each team will get its share. LEAD: AS the ranks of working mothers - particularly those with young children - continue to swell, many of them agree that one of the prerequisites for their success is not an M.B.A. or an undergraduate degree from a prestigious school, but rather a reliable, efficient nanny or housekeeper. Knowing that there is someone at home they can count on to take good care of their youngsters, and sometimes of their home as well, allows them to concentrate on business while they are in the office.

It was the first public outing for the 18-month-old since she was rescued from the abondoned well she had fallen into. It took volunteers more than 58 hours to free her. The rescuers, who numbered more than 400, were honored with a parade yesterday and Jessica was able to watch it from her window.
LEAD: There are 118 Grade I races on the American racing calendar this year, and 95 have been run so far. The leaders in winning these top events look nearly impossible to overtake.

LEAD: The British Government's decision yesterday to soften the immediate impact of its sale of British Petroleum shares by providing market support through the Bank of England should encourage international markets today, investment fund managers and economists said.

LEAD: Can anyone here play quarterback? That might be the theme for Army's game against Temple at West Point tomorrow. The Cadets have lost three quarterbacks and have two left, Morrell Savoy and Bryan McWilliams; whoever plays for the Owls will be starting for the first time.

LEAD: The Thompson Medical Company said its board had received a proposal for a management-led buyout of the company from a group headed by S. Daniel Abraham, its chairman and chief executive. LEAD: In announcing his second choice for the Lewis Powell vacancy on the Supreme Court, President Reagan combatively showed himself unchastened by the Senate's embarrassing rejection of his first choice. LEAD: An article in The Home Section yesterday about handicapped students competing in the New York City Marathon misidentified the organization that donated a sports wheelchair to Keith Givens. It is the Eastern Wheelchair Tennis Association.

LEAD: A bidding concept that has been popular in Europe for half a century but neglected on this side of the Atlantic is ''canape'': bid a short suit first, and keep a long suit in reserve. Many Italian and French experts have employed it in winning world titles.

LEAD: Jean Helion, an influential abstract artist who later turned to representational painting, died of pneumonia in a Paris hospital Tuesday night. He was 83 years old. His canvases, both abstract and representational, hang in major institutions throughout the world, including the Metropolitan Museum and the Museum of Modern Art in New York.

LEAD: Architects are a different breed from most New Yorkers. They are forever perusing the city, soaking up views we often overlook. Some are preoccupied with details - a ferocious-looking gargoyle, a graceful window or a wide front stoop. Others examine entire streets or neighborhoods that have a character all their own.

LEAD: One report for the Department of Labor on what the American work force would look like at the end of the century runs 117 pages. Another report runs 63 pages. They are nearly identical except that the 117-page study cost $1.3 million, the other nothing.

LEAD: Hundreds of Queens residents came to City Hall yesterday to protest a city law that, they said, encourages developers to raze habitable single-family homes and build higher density housing, thereby threatening the ''villagelike'' atmosphere of many Queens neighborhoods.

LEAD: Sparky Anderson, who led the Detroit Tigers to a 98-64 record, the best in the game this season, was named the American League Manager of the Year yesterday by the Baseball Writers' Association of America. Anderson, who also earned the honor in 1984 when the Tigers won 104 games and the World Series, received 11 first-place votes and a total of 90 points in balloting by a panel of two members of the association from each American League city.

LEAD: Last year it was the most lopsided division in the American Conference: two playoff teams at the top, two teams with a total of seven victories at the bottom. But who's in first in the Eastern Division now? Almost everybody.

LEAD: The stock market collapse has reshuffled yet again the complicated politics of trade legislation, raising questions about what kind of bill will emerge from a Congressional conference committee or whether there will be a trade bill at all this year.

LEAD: L. F. Rothschild Holdings Inc. confirmed a report yesterday that the company is seeking a substantial capital infusion to restore it to financial health after large losses from the recent market plunge. LEAD: IN the retrospective of his drawings at the New Museum, the sculptor Bruce Nauman comes across as the complete Post-Minimalist artist, an exemplary representative of the almost frenzied experimentation that took hold of art, and especially sculpture, in the late 1960's and early 70's. During those years, younger artists built on and broke through the limitations of Minimalism, branching out into areas soon designated as Conceptual, Performance, Installation and Process art.

LEAD: The stock market's plunge and subsequent gyrations could mean somewhat reduced Christmas sales for the nation's retail stores. Although sales have not yet been hurt significantly, analysts are shaving their earnings estimates for retailers.

LEAD: LEE MacPHAIL could sit with his son at the moment of ultimate triumph while Frank and Helen Viola had to watch their son celebrate from a distance. But all three parents shared the joy of seeing somebody who used to be a child now handle the details and the pressures of being an adult.

LEAD: EVERY serious depression in business, and virtually every recession in American economic history, has been accompanied by a serious decline of stock prices. LEAD: Troy Aikman passed for two touchdowns to Paco Craig during a 17-point third-quarter surge as U.C.L.A. overcame Arizona State, 31-23, in a Pacific-10 Conference game today.

LEAD: The engagement of Dr. Elizabeth Lathrop Finch to Peter Goodwin Coe, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm D. Coe of Bassett, Va., has been announced by her parents, Elizabeth J. Finch of New York and Quogue, L.I., and Edward R. Finch Jr. of New York and Westhampton Beach, L.I. A May wedding is planned.

LEAD: CITY SLICKERS. By William E. Geist. (Times Books, $16.95.) He came from the Midwest to a city he suspects is ''as different from mainland America as Botswana.'' William E. Geist's impressions filled the About New York column of The New York Times as he explored a city he found ''exciting, yes, but in a terrifying kind of way.
LEAD: POLITICAL observers expect a low turnout Tuesday when Westchester voters go to the polls to select county legislators, supervisors, mayors, judges and city and town councils.

LEAD: IN LINE with what experts say is a trend, the final remnants of old-time carrousels - the ones with artfully carved wooden horses and menagerie figures that made children merry as they went 'round and 'round - were sold here 'round and 'round - were sold here recently.

LEAD: AT first glance, there are many similarities between the extraordinary collapses of stock prices that occurred in October 1929 and the declines we have recently experienced. Both hit after extended bull markets and amid general prosperity that tempted investors to ignore underlying weak spots in the economy: agriculture, coal mining and textiles in the 1920's, agriculture again and the smokestack industries today.

LEAD: AN arcane, theoretically fail-safe procedure called ''program trading,'' in which investment decisions involving hundreds of millions of dollars can be taken and implemented without human intervention, has been indentified as a factor in the stock market collapse. Computer-driven program trading raised the peaks, deepened the valleys and compressed market cycles.

LEAD: NOBODY in the Italian Government wants to straighten the Leaning Tower of Pisa; its tilt keeps the tourist lire flowing. But in January, the Government approved a $25 million project to keep the 800-year-old tower from tipping farther.

LEAD: A TORRENTIAL rain did not deter Dan Weaver and Mark Covello from going out for a nine-mile bike ride one recent Sunday. ''When you're hooked on riding like we are, the rain doesn't bother you,'' said Mr. Weaver.
LEAD: Three nights a week, the President of this Spanish-speaking country retires to a quiet room in the palace, flicks on his tape recorder, and practices his French.

LEAD: THEY have their fans, but there are those who resent the likes of pampered professional tennis players who earn huge sums while public servants struggle. There those who think that professional tennis has lost its dignity as a sport and has generated into a crass business enterprise.
LEAD: DESPITE some staggering losses, the nation's pension funds, and their beneficiaries, have come through the great market collapse of 1987 in relatively good shape - so far.

LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Despite the objections of some judges and lawyers, a new and, some say, stricter uniform system of sentencing will go into effect Sunday in Federal district courts.
LEAD: The 34-game unbeaten streak of the powerful Hempstead Tigers (5-1) ended yesterday as the Tigers lost to Uniondale, 13-12.
LEAD: For 17 years, as president of Wesleyan University in Middletown, Conn., Colin G. Campbell has had all the college administrator's usual concerns about fundraising.

LEAD: As a suburban homeowner with a ''mole problem,'' I found Richard B. Elsberry's ''A Farewell to Arms'' right on the mark (About Men, Sept. 27). As the movie ''Caddie Shack'' demonstrated as well, there is no way to win the battle when trying to eliminate the mole. A good sense of humor will go a long way.
LEAD: AMERICANS have always been on the move, but never have so many moved so far so fast.
LEAD: WHEN Elizabeth Bell was in college in 1950, she was told that women couldn't be composers. ''Women don't have the strength,'' a teacher said.

LEAD: HOLIDAY FARE IS GENERALLY laden with richness - and calories. With a microwave oven, however, you can create a low-calorie meal so festive and delicious that no one will miss the usual indulgences. Because microwave cooking requires no fat, and allows vegetables and herbs to retain their flavor, and fruits their sweetness, you won't be tempted to add extra butter, salt or sugar.

LEAD: THERE I was, sitting at my desk, when the phone rang. The better to exercise, I stood up to answer it. ''Are you sitting down?'' my friend asked. ''You'd better sit down.'' I sat, fearing the worst. ''The Dow is down 500 points.''
LEAD: The South African Government made an unexpected move this week in an attempt to improve its icy political relations with Zimbabwe, its black-ruled neighbor.
LEAD: Princeton, controlling the game on offense and defense, beat Penn today, 17-7, the Tigers' first victory over the Quakers since 1982.
LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Miller of Manhasset, L.I., have announced the engagements of their daughters Lori Beth Miller and Debra Sue Miller to Daniel Jay Kase and Alan Jay Schefer, respectively.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: IN the past 20 years, J. D. Salinger has undoubtedly become the most famous - as well as the most read - recluse in the world. He has rarely been sighted in public, has not given an interview since 1953 and, although he continues to write fiction, hasn't published any of it since a short story appeared in The New Yorker in 1965.
LEAD: THE world team championships that ended in Ocho Rios, Jamaica, eight days ago were, perhaps, the most completely satisfactory ever staged.

LEAD: Patricia Claire Turner and Reginald Edward Kavanaugh, newspaper reporters in New Jersey, were married yesterday at Three Mile Run Church at East Jersey Olde Towne in Piscataway, N.J., by Judge Richard S. Cohen of the Appellate Division of Superior Court in New Brunswick, N.J.

LEAD: The engagement of Ann Morris Colin to Peter Herbst, a son of Eugenia V. Herbst of New York and the late Frank F. Herbst, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Cynthia Green Colin and Justin Colin, both of New York. A March wedding is planned.

LEAD: AN OPEN HOUSE IS NOT YOUR everyday kind of affair,'' said Roulhac Toledano, as she rushed around her family's 10-room apartment, trying to tie up loose ends before her 60 guests arrived. ''But it's good for lots of different people who may not know each other.'' She might have added that it is also good for hosts: Because people tend to arrive at different times, it's possible to entertain large numbers in the space of a day or an evening.

LEAD: 'DISTINGUISHED ARTISTS' Just in case anyone has any doubt about what Oyster Bay thinks of the performers it books for its music series, the town provides a lavish hint. The programs come under the umbrella of Distinguished Artists Concerts, and today, when the current series opens, that distinction falls upon Mike Carubia and the Great South Dixeland Jazz Band.

LEAD: Larry Davis, who is charged in the murders of four suspected drug dealers, discussed a plot to kill a man who resembled him in order to trick the police and elude one of the biggest manhunts in New York City history.

LEAD: For seven days or so, until he seemed too tired to do so, Newi Celali told his story to anyone who would listen as he protested his plight by staging a solitary and largely unnoticed hunger strike outside the United Nations refugee office here.
LEAD: Start with the French theologian Georges Bernanos: ''The worst, the most corrupting lies are problems poorly stated.''

LEAD: Q. The brick fireplace in our home had been painted by previous owners. We want to remove the paint and restore the natural brick. What is the best way to do this?

LEAD: Sarah Marie Keenan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Willis J. Keenan of Port Washington, L.I., was married there yesterday to Joseph Sferrazza, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Sferrazza of Manhasset, L.I. Msgr. Walter Simmons performed the ceremony at St. Peter of Alcantara Roman Catholic Church. Mrs. Sferrazza, known as Sally, and her husband are associates at the law firm of Shaw, Licitra, Eisenberg, Esernio & Schwartz in Garden City, L.I.

LEAD: At a luncheon some months ago, the leader of one of Chile's small center-right parties turned to a Socialist leader and raised an issue that has plagued Chilean public life for more than two decades.

LEAD: A PROTECTIVE DISCRETION SUR-rounds what is in effect, though not in name, the Marcel Duchamp museum within the Philadelphia Museum of Art. Though known to enthusiasts the world over as the largest single repository of Duchamp's work, the galleries in question occupy a distant and almost a secret place in the huge congeries of the Philadelphia Museum.

LEAD: THE bicycle once seemed the environmentalist's dream machine, a solution to air pollution, traffic jams and flabby muscles. But that was before bicycle makers here in Marin County added gears to some old fat-tire Schwinns and launched the latest rage to roll out of California: the mountain bike, a machine capable of climbing trails and scaring hikers as it roars like a roller coaster in a cloud of dust.

LEAD: CREON'S queen descends upon Corinth in a helicopter. His daughter has a jeep, operated by remote control. Jason bears gifts of BB guns and toy aircraft carriers for his sons. And the Chorus lunges into a rap number.

LEAD: After weeks of debating such serious state issues as a lottery, a budget deficit and taxes, the most expensive gubernatorial campaign in Kentucky history has got back to the sort of personal attacks that have been traditional in the state's politics.

LEAD: SCAB BALL'' WAS THE label pinned on the professional football played by replacements or substitutes by such sportswriters as Tony Kornheiser of The Washington Post. The owners' use of scab labor -usually a union member's derogation of an employee who works during a strike -prevailed, and the players' strike was broken.

LEAD: What will the Yankee changes mean? Answer: More changes. JAY KREISBERG New Rochelle, N.Y.

LEAD: AS I SAT AT ''AIDA'' IN HOUSTON the other evening watching a throng of dangerously inept spear carriers trying to persuade me that they were ferocious Egyptian warriors celebrating a victory over the Ethiopians, I was struck by how much energy and money opera houses regularly expend nowadays to dispel illusion.
LEAD: IF not capitalism, at least a capitalist ethic is seeping into the marrow of China.

LEAD: A Caveat on Co-ops Question: I read recently about an improperly managed cooperative apartment house where the owners lost their equity to a bank and became renters of their apartments instead of owners. I am considering buying a co-op apartment and want to know if there is any type of insurance I can buy to cover this contingency.

LEAD: For many black Americans, the anniversary of the day their ancestors were freed from slavery is an independence day meriting at least as much to-do as the Fourth of July. In O FREEDOM! Afro-American Emancipation Celebrations (University of Tennessee, $24.95), William H. Wiggins Jr., a fellow of the Folklore Institute at Indiana University, brings much-deserved scholarly attention to the longstanding black American tradition of emancipation celebrations.

His career certainly illustrates the theory.

LEAD: To the Editor: When my wife and I returned from England in July, the next issue of the Travel section (Aug. 2) carried an Advisory item regarding the bankruptcy of Reject China Company in London. We were aghast, having just placed a rather large order for Coalport china. I wrote to Reject China Shops, 33-35 and 56-57 Beauchamp Place, in London, to cancel our order.

LEAD: WITH A LOG FIRE CRACKLING in the fireplace and delicious aromas emanating from the pear tarte tatin in the oven and the saddle of venison just roasted, Hugh and Tiziana Hardy's Greenwich Village town house was a welcoming place.

LEAD: VOTERS will go to the polls Tuesday to elect all 120 members of the State Legislature and scores of county and local officials, and to decide six statewide public questions, including three new spending proposals that could be affected by the stock market decline. The polls will be open from 7 A.M.

LEAD: THE 13-piece band that Buck Clayton is leading at Fat Tuesday's, Third Avenue at 17th Street, through today reflects his years of experience as one of the major stars of Count Basie's orchestra during its rise to fame in the late 1930's and early 40's and his work as a composer and arranger that began in his Basie days and has continued ever since.

Hallock of Los Angeles, was married yesterday to Bayly Philip Winder, a son of Mr. and Mrs. R. Bayly Winder of Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Walter Taylor performed the ceremony.

LEAD: A HISTORIC deadline arrives in Nicaragua this week. The deadline on Thursday closes the first phase of the ambitious Arias plan designed to bring peace to Central America generally and particularly to end the guerrilla erally and particularly to end the guerrilla war that has killed 40,000 Nicaraguans since the Sandinistas took power in 1979.
LEAD: PRINTERS AND PRESS FREEDOM The Ideology of Early American Journalism. By Jeffery A. Smith. 233 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $24.95.
LEAD: Think of the Giants' locker room as shaped like a human, and the first thing you see - the head, so to speak - is Harry Carson's locker. And one stall away is Lawrence Taylor's locker.
LEAD: Columbia University's undergraduate art center is taking shape on the lower two floors of a new 17-story dormitory under construction on campus.
LEAD: Willie Hislop and Tim Frager ran for touchdowns in the first nine minutes of the second half as Boston College upset Tennessee, 20-18, today.

LEAD: WILLIAM WOLFRAM seems to have survived the competition process with most of his sensibilities intact. He is a busy warrior in the field, and fresh from his victory in the William Kapell piano contest at the University of Maryland, Mr. Wolfram gave a piano recital at Alice Tully Hall on Friday night.

LEAD: IN placing their money, modern investors leapfrog national frontiers. From Tokyo to London to New York, bankers shift billions daily at the shiver of a Eurodollar rate or the flick of an arbitrager's computer keys. Today the sun may set on the British Empire, but never on the pulsing financial markets.

LEAD: An outbreak of vandalism against synagogues and Jewish-owned businesses in Providence, R.I., last month raised concern there about anti-Semitism but also brought support from other religious, ethic and racial groups for those who were the objects of the acts. .
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: AN a rare electoral coincidence, Long Island voters will elect chief executives of both Nassau and Suffolk Counties on Tuesday.

LEAD: PRESIDENT Reagan's last-minute selection of Judge Douglas H. Ginsburg for the United States Supreme Court left combatants in the long battle over Judge Robert H. Bork scrambling to learn new lines.

LEAD: RAKE, rake, rake, blow, sweep or whatever to get the leaves off the lawn; if not kept off the grass, they will smother it and mat; what is more they will be extremely difficult to remove in spring and may even kill a lawn. If finished using hand tools, wipe them and clean blades by rotating them in a box of sand; rub metal parts with oil or rust preventive.

LEAD: Now that Mikhail S. Gorbachev has finally set a date for visiting the United States, the next question is what kind of summit meeting it will be.

LEAD: LAST week was a busy one for the first Chief Justice of the United States, John Jay. His constitutional contributions were discussed by Justice Harry A. Blackmun of the United States Supreme Court in a speech in Justice Jay's home town of Rye, while the debate over the future of Jay's boyhood home continued in Albany.

LEAD: A ballot initiative to require deposits on beverage containers sold in the District of Columbia could spur action in other states because of the high profile of the nation's capital, proponents say.

LEAD: PUBLIC TELEVISION IS SUP-posed to be in crisis: Where is its soul, its reason, its purpose, the spirit that would make it, as E. B. White once wrote, ''our Lyceum, our Chautauqua, our Minsky's and our Camelot''? It is hard to say, although for some time now the crisis has been cast in terms of God overcome by mammon.
LEAD: Begun in the smoldering ruins of the riots here 20 years ago, the New Community Corporation has developed into a veritable city-within-the-city on 45 acres of the Central Ward.
LEAD: The House Appropriations Committee has voted to block the Bureau of Reclamation's plans to move its headquarters from Washington to Denver as part of a major reorientation of the bureau.

LEAD: Arthur Davis ran for two touchdowns as South Shore beat Sheepshead Bay, 15-6, yesterday at South Shore's home field in Brooklyn. The victory was South Shore's third without a defeat in the Public Schools Athletic League Brooklyn A Division I, and it makes next week's game against Midwood, also 3-0, a pivotal one.

LEAD: The return of Billy Martin brings new excitement and anticipation to New York baseball. We can all sit on the edge of our seats waiting for Billy to make his inevitable indiscretion. Will he punch out a fan, another of his players, an opposing player or perhaps even an umpire? Or will 1988 see Billy make the ultimate move?
LEAD: A 22-YEAR-OLD white man and two white women are walking down a street in Brooklyn. Five black youths approach.

LEAD: World Without Walls: Beryl Markham's African Memoir Narrated by Diana Quick and Lyle Talbot. Wild Wing Productions. 60 minutes. $29.95. Beryl Markham, who in her youth looked as striking as Vanessa Redgrave, died last year in Nairobi. Suddenly, she is more acclaimed in death than in life. Her memoir, ''West With the Night,'' rediscovered and reprinted after 40 years, has been on the best-seller charts all during 1987, with a half-million copies in print from North Point Press of Berkeley, Calif.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Louisiana's gambling Governor, Edwin Edwards, decided early last Sunday morning that a fourth term was not in the cards. Mr. Edwards, known for scandal-scarred administrations and a love of high-stakes recreation in Las Vegas, dropped his bid for re-election after finishing second in the Democratic gubernatorial primary.

LEAD: Entertaining/Magazine Part 2 The Party Season: How to Make It a Success, includes these special reports: A host's guide to the well-planned cocktail party. When and how to include the children. An unusual idea that makes dinner for 30 workable. Tips from floral designers on how to make inexpensive arrangements.

LEAD: IF YOU'VE FORGOTTEN WHAT it's like to leave a theater walking on air, a remedy lies ready to hand. The revival of ''Anything Goes'' at the Lincoln Center's Vivian Beaumont Theater is wonderfully exhilarating and euphoria-inducing; Patty LuPone's Reno Sweeney is only one - though the most memorable - of an array of fine performances, and whatever minor imperfections the production may have are soon lost sight of in the glow cast by its energy and joie de vivre.

LEAD: WOMEN smoothed their fingernails for three-quarters of a century with emery, a substance almost as hard as diamonds, that came from the mines of Cortlandt, once among the largest producers of emery in the world.
LEAD: THE recent turbulence in the stock market is causing many concerns for buyers who are poised to close on a home or an investment property.

LEAD: THERE is always a danger of provincialism on the new-music scene. New York performing groups naturally tend to favor local or at least American composers, with only occasional representation from abroad. And since new music doesn't ''sell,'' visits by entire foreign ensembles devoted to the new are rare.

LEAD: I would like to respond to ''Curing Those Who Sue Their Doctors'' [ Opinion page, Sept. 27 ] . Dr. K. J. Lee suggests that plaintiffs' lawyers are bringing too many groundless medical malpractice cases and are being unjustly enriched in the process. I disagree.

LEAD: Pleasantville - undefeated and ranked first in the C Division - faced what seemed to be an inferior opponent but found its stiffest challenge of the season yesterday, managing to hold off Valhalla in the closing minutes by a score of 13-12.

LEAD: Five years ago, when tourism to Australia was just beginning to take off, the Australian writer Germaine Greer observed that ''what most people mean when they say they'd like to go to Australia is that they'd like to go to Sydney and its suburb, Ayers Rock.''

LEAD: Led by Jeff Wiley's 438 yards passing, including four touchdown tosses, Holy Cross rolled over the University of Massachusetts, 54-10, today to remain the only undefeated football team in Division I-AA, at 8-0.

LEAD: If the Occupational Safety and Health Administration is correct, the building collapse that killed 28 workers in Bridgeport, Conn., last April could have been prevented for far less than $5.11 million. Now it will cost the companies involved that much just to pay OSHA's fines.

LEAD: Just after daybreak each morning, Weyman Billings sits before his living room window to watch a solitary loon swimming in the clear waters of Donnell Pond. He wonders how long the loon will be there.

LEAD: MONEY managers who had built substantial cash positions as a defensive strategy before the stock market's collapse were in no hurry last week to return to buying common stocks. Even in the face of prices that would have appeared irresistible a month ago, the prevailing feeling among some of the country's more conservative investors, some of whom had as much as 50 percent of their portfolios in cash, was that the risk of a further decline outweighed any opportunity.

LEAD: The result had been decided long ago, but at last the rout was complete. In the locker room, there was talk of redemption and enthusiastic conversation of a renewed commitment. Brent Sutter moved through the motivational mayhem, patched up a cut and left quietly.

LEAD: A senior Soviet envoy on a peace mission in the Persian Gulf criticized the United States Navy's presence here today, saying that one nation acting alone cannot bring about a cease-fire between Iran and Iraq.

LEAD: I TEACH FIRST GRADERS. I LIVE in a world of skinned knees, double-knotted shoelaces, riddles that I've heard a dozen times, stale birthday cakes, hurt feelings, wandering stories and one lost shoe (''and if you don't find it my mother'll kill me''). My work is dominated by 6-year-olds. It's 10:45, the middle of snack, and I'm helping Emily open her milk carton.

LEAD: Dozens of policemen swept through the capital's movie theaters last week, pulling down movie posters showing semi-nude women and sexually explicit scenes, to show the authorities' determination to enforce a new law on obscenity.

LEAD: LINDA MUSSMANN'S ''Blue Scene Grey,'' performed by her Time and Space Limited company on Friday at the Marymount Manhattan Theater, operates on a number of levels. The first part of a four-part piece called ''Civil War Chronicles,'' the cantata jogs through 80 years of American history, from 1781 to 1861, in a manner that often makes schoolroom history come alive.

LEAD: Congratulations on Robert Sherman's ''How an Orchestra Fell Silent: Postlude'' [ Oct. 11 ] . Mr. Sherman goes beyond fund-raising to highlight critical, common problems of nonprofit management.

LEAD: THE outrageous cocktail hat - the kind that leads to conversation betwen strangers and breaks the ice at parties - bobbed about last week at the opening of an exhibition called Surrealism that will run through Jan. 23 at the Fashion Institute of Technology Galleries, 27th Street and Seventh Avenue.

LEAD: IN HER DREAM, THERE was a steel-gray casket in her living room. Who was the dead man laid out in a gray suit? She couldn't tell. And every time she moved closer to the coffin, someone she didn't know said, ''You don't need to see this.'' But Beulah Mae Donald knew that she did, and so she woke from her dream at two in the morning in Mobile, Ala., on March 21, 1981.

LEAD: THOSE IN SEARCH OF sound equipment at this season will, as always, find optimal dollar values in the midprice range rather than among the least expensive models, which were discussed in this space last week.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Lee Harris Pomeroy of New York and Garrison, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Jordana Pomeroy to Tyler Anbinder, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen B. Anbinder of New York and Washington, Conn. The couple plan to wed May 22.
LEAD: Parents of 21 elementary pupils who were ordered to disrobe partially during a search for a missing watch have sued a school district.
LEAD: Bergen Catholic's strong team kept two impressive streaks alive yesterday as it turned back St. Joseph of Montvale, 17-0, at Oradell.

LEAD: THE COMPACT DISK IS about four and a half inches in diameter - or it was until now. Two record companies, Delos and Rykodisc, have issued a three-inch compact disk, but it is designed to be an adjunct, rather than a replacement, for the four-inch version.

LEAD: It takes no graduate student of body language to see how awkward many people feel about tipping. They go through pockets and purse, pulling out handkerchiefs, house keys and credit cards, but never come up with a bill of a suitable denomination for the bellman poised by the door. Eventually, they find a crumpled bill, or mumble something about catching the employee later, and retreat in embarrassment.

LEAD: Indian Army losses to Tamil rebels in Sri Lanka this month have shaken the Indian military establishment and raised questions among many experts about the quality of New Delhi's military intelligence and planning.

LEAD: President Reagan insisted anew today that the Senate should act quickly on his nomination of Judge Douglas H. Ginsburg to the Supreme Court, saying he wanted ''no delays to gear up opposition or support for this nomination.''

LEAD: President Corazon C. Aquino flew to Clark Air Base today to demonstrate her concern over the killing of three Americans on Wednesday, as Americans in the Philippines faced heightened security restrictions.

LEAD: NEW York City has experienced a widely perceived increase in racial tensions this year - notably in connection with the Howard Beach trial, in which four white youths are charged with murder in connection with an allegedly racially motivated attack on three blacks - and tensions within the police department have to some extent reflected those of the city.
LEAD: IF DOUBTS remain about the symbiotic relationship between art and politics, ''Puerto Rican Painting: Between Past and Present'' should put them to rest once and for all.

LEAD: The suggestion that an explosion played a critical role in the sinking of the Titanic 75 years ago is incompatible with accounts by survivors, according to Dr. Robert Ballard, leader of the expedition that found the wreckage of the giant ocean liner in 1985.

LEAD: Mary Beth Whitehead, the New Jersey surrogate mother who lost custody of Baby M after a bitter court fight, has become pregnant by a man other than her estranged husband, the court-appointed lawyer for Baby M said today.

LEAD: Good news for the Yankees! Billy Martin is a skilled and demanding manager. He will unify this team and push each talented player to his limit. Piniella is a quick study and will learn the general-manager business faster than most. Lou is the perfect buffer between the ''Boss'' and the volatile Martin.

LEAD: ''WE'RE HERErrxh to get the flavor of six candidates,'' said William F. Buckley Jr. last week, and at times the flavor was peppery in the first debate of the contenders for the Republican Presidential nomination. Vice President Bush slipped several verbal punches and hit back strongly, protecting his front-runner status, according to polls and politicians.

LEAD: THIS is the time of year when many high school juniors start devoting a good deal of thought to their future and the college application process, part of which consists of becoming familiar with the colleges you think you are interested in and that - joy of joys -might return the interest.

LEAD: THE AUTOMOTIVE HISTORY OF LUCKY KELLERMAN. By Steve Heller. (Chelsea Green, Paper, $9.95.) ''On his sixty-fifth birthday Frank Kellerman locked himself inside an old stone schoolhouse filled with honey bees,'' begins Steve Heller's subtle first novel. For the next seven days, Frank (or Lucky, as he was called before old age, diabetes, injury and loneliness took their toll), tells his life story to his only friends, the bees.

LEAD: As he campaigns tirelessly across the country, the Rev. Jesse Jackson is presenting a dual message, as a mainstream politician reaching for the support of a broad spectrum of voters and as a candidate whose positions are well to left of the others seeking the Democratic Presidential nomination.

''I was a registered Democrat when I lived in Flushing,'' he said in a recent interview, ''and I was still a registered Democrat when I moved to Hauppauge.
LEAD: The Edmonton Oilers, the defending Stanley Cup champions, are the latest team to find out how much the Devils have improved.

LEAD: Throughout the 180-mile boat trip from Helsinki to Leningrad I kept thinking that there would be some foul-up at the Soviet end, some piece of red tape that would prevent us from setting foot in Leningrad without visas.
