LEAD: Jeff Burger, who regained his eligibility last Thursday, passed for 218 yards and a touchdown to lead Auburn to a 29-6 rout of Florida in a Southeastern Conference game tonight.
LEAD: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 14 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

LEAD: BECAUSE the members of Ballet Hispanico of New York simultaneously took pleasure and gave pleasure by dancing on Friday night, it was appropriate that three of the five works they presented at Davis Hall of City College celebrated the act of dancing itself.

LEAD: FOR those seeking signs of stability on Wall Street, there is some good news. Despite the heavy volume in recent trading that has turned the Dow Jones into a roller coaster, skirt lengths in the financial district have held steady, closer to the ankle than the knee.

LEAD: A slow-moving freight train struck a tanker truck filled with 8,000 gallons of gasoline Friday, killing a train crewman and injuring four other men, officials said. The crash ignited an explosion and fire that shot flames 100 feet into the air; smoke could be seen 16 miles away, witnesses said. The truck was straddling the railroad tracks, waiting to turn onto a highway, when the train hit it, splitting the vehicle in two, the authorities said.
LEAD: T. Hunter Wilson lives on the land that his ancestor, Boomer Jenckes, farmed after the American Revolution.

LEAD: America's stubborn budget deficits - roughly $150 billion in the last fiscal year - are widely blamed for contributing to the Crash of '87. New York Times reporter Lawrence M. Fisher asked three former members of the Council on Economic Advisers for their views on what should be done about it.

LEAD: IT is not very difficult for most of us to agree that overdevelopment has a negative impact on our lives and tranquillity, but have we considered properly what benefits could be derived from continued expansion?

LEAD: Juveniles accounted for 40 percent of arson arrests last year, with 6.6 percent of those arrests involving children under 10 years old, according to a report by the National Fire Protection Association.

LEAD: Bernard and Marc Nevas are taking advantage of a special zoning district in Westport, Conn., in which developers may combine clusters of apartments and offices on a single plot as long as they limit building size and height.

LEAD: IT was a long time coming, and they wanted it so much they could taste it. LEAD: HERE IS DANIEL AUTEUIL, arguably France's hottest young actor these days - or, at least, the one who got the best actor award at the French version of the Oscar ceremonies in Paris this year -and he doesn't look it.

LEAD: A Miscellany of Anxieties What are the ingredients of a contemporary short story? Ann Beattie offers her answer to this question in her introduction to ''The Best American Short Stories 1987'' (Houghton Mifflin), edited by Ms. Beattie and Shannon Ravenel.

LEAD: A financial world fearful of incompetence in the American Government is looking desperately for reassuring symbols. LEAD: The embarrassment of law-enforcement officers over a police captain who robbed a bank and stole Civil Service examinations has scarcely faded before the former officer has infuriated Massachusetts lawmakers by turning a profit on the robbery.

LEAD: ''WE FIGURED 250 COSTUMES, give or take a few,'' says Patricia Zipprodt. A celebrated costume designer whose achievements include three Tony Awards, she's referring to the mammoth production of ''The Sleeping Beauty'' that the New York City Ballet is planning for an unspecified future season. Lincoln Kirstein and George Balanchine, co-founders of the City Ballet, conceived of the project more than a decade ago.

LEAD: With a minimum of fanfare, Prague let one of the great anniversaries of operatic history slip by on Thursday night. Two hundred years ago, in this city, Mozart conducted the first performance of ''Don Giovanni.''

LEAD: For movie fans who nourish their habit via cable, this is the week that justifies the subscription - three of last year's most talked-about films served up for the first time: ''Hannah and Her Sisters,'' ''Peggy Sue Got Married'' and ''Top Gun.''

LEAD: THERE is more than one way to win a driving championship, and Nelson Piquet of Brazil, who won his third Formula One title yesterday, was lamenting that he could not have found a better way to his. Piquet, who came to the Grand Prix of Japan with 73 points, 12 more than his teammate and closest rival, Nigel Mansell of Britain, captured the title by default when Mansell, who could have taken the championship by winning the Japan and Australian races, was injured and forced to withdraw from the Japanese race.

LEAD: FRANCO ZEFFIRELLI'S ''Boheme'' returned to the Metropolitan Opera Friday evening for its first performance of the season. The director's six-year-old staging of the Puccini opera remained the most striking characteristic of the production. Rodolfo's garret continued to pose a challenge for the singers, who had to project their voices from far back on the stage as well as engage in some uncomfortable swordplay on some uncomfortable swordplay on the rooftops of Paris.

LEAD: ON Wednesday, when car makers report their sales for the last 10 days of October, those seeking to divine the course of the economy will pore over the figures as never before. As the first solid piece of statistical evidence of consumer behavior since the stock market collapse, the numbers, depending on their strength or weakness, are sure to be seen as harbingers of continued moderate economic expansion or impending malaise.

LEAD: OFTEN A SONG CAN BE THE KEY TO THE evolution of a musical. With ''Into the Woods,'' the new Stephen Sondheim-James Lapine show opening Thursday at the Martin Beck Theater, the turning point came when the composer wrote the second-act ballad, ''No One Is Alone.'' The song is sung by Cinderella after her prince has disappeared, to Little Red Ridinghood, as they huddle together in the wake of a cataclysm.

LEAD: By now Jonathan Valin's series about Harry Stoner, the Cincinnati private eye, is well established. It started in 1980 with ''The Lime Pit,'' and the new FIRE LAKE (Delacorte, $14.95) is the seventh Stoner case. Stoner is in the classic tradition of the American private eye. He is a big, tough man who does not throw his strength around but nevertheless is not one to be trifled with.

LEAD: WHEN my mother needed to escape from the noise and confusion generated by five children, she would go out and work in the yard. She couldn't have picked a better refuge. We children considered trimming, raking and mowing akin to torture. We always offered to help, though, knowing full well that Mom would decline the offer.

LEAD: Dancing tends to be a youthful art, but maturity does out. LEAD: Mr. LeMoyne discounts the possibility of the contra leaders' returning to Managua, saying, ''The fight for popular support inside Nicaragua promises to be extremely risky, testing the rebels where they have been weakest.'' In other words, the contras have little support inside Nicaragua. Mr. LeMoyne forgets that guerrillas with popular support inside their own country do survive on scant funds.

But in the somber, wood-paneled office of the Prime Minister, Balthazar Johannes Vorster, it was the onset of another, more bitter kind of season.

LEAD: SOMETIMES after the theater or movies, it is more fun to eat at home than in a restaurant. The menu given below is perfect for a late-night meal, not too heavy and easy to prepare ahead of time. It also makes a pleasant weekend lunch. Ducks are roasted with thyme, ginger, garlic and soy sauce and served at room temperature with a salad made from yellow split peas and collard greens.

LEAD: Every year, on the last Sunday of October, hikers from New Jersey join those of neighboring states to memorialize Raymond H. Torrey, co-founder of the New York-New Jersey Trail Conference and one of the area's legendary outdoorsmen.

LEAD: THE parallels between the crash of the stock market in 1929 and 1987 are too strong to ignore. Nevertheless, the recent collapse does not necessarily portend a new Great Depression. The 1929 crash shook the economy, but it was other problems - some similar to today's dilemmas - that caused the collapse.

LEAD: The West German twins who were joined at the head at birth have been taken off the critical list and have gained weight steadily since they were separated in a 22-hour operation Sept. 6, officials at Johns Hopkins Hospital said Friday.

LEAD: BACK IN THE NEAR-MYTHIC PAST -at least 10 or 15 years ago - the dinner party was a happy ornament of middle-class life. In the modern world, however, with the two-career family becoming the national mode, many couples are finding precious little room in their lives for these kinds of social gatherings, and the prospect of giving a dinner party, let alone two, may well throw them into a panic.

LEAD: JOHN MAZZOLA is convinced that his wife, Sylvia, lives by the maxim ''Don't get into any vehicle that's not moving.'' If this maxim is not a familiar one, it is not surprising because, he said, his wife made it up.

They try to share her, but jealousy begins to fester between them. They try to get rid of her, selling her to a whorehouse - but each sneaks off to visit her in secret, so the brothers finally buy her back, the trust between them now tainted by mutual deception.

T.Barnum, the founder of the P. T. Barnum Museum in Bridgeport, and O. C. Marsh, a paleontologist and the nephew of George Peabody, the founder of the Peabody museum Disparate as their occupations and aims were, the two men frequently found themselves competing to acquire the same objects - Barnum seeking oddities for exploitation in his circus, Marsh coveting them in the name of scientific research.

LEAD: WHITES, by Norman Rush. (Collier/Macmillan, $6.95.) From 1978 to 1983, Norman Rush was co-director of the Peace Corps in Botswana, an experience that led him to write short stories about the invisible barriers separating black Africa from its would-be saviors. This ''admirable collection'' is about ''disillusionment and loss of conviction,'' Leslie Marmon Silko wrote in The Book Review last year.

LEAD: I'M HOPELESS WHEN IT comes to books. I can't go past a bookshop without slipping in to buy some classic I've never read before -one of those handsome Penguin editions of Dickens or Jane Austen, a volume of Henry James's correspondence or the poems of Wordsworth. The old-fashioned illustrations on the cover, the crisp pages, the unbroken spine: they give off powerful emanations of culture, promise self-improvement, a subtle deepening of the mind.

LEAD: THE National Assembly of El Salvador last week approved an amnesty that will free hundreds of leftist guerrillas and prevent the prosecution of any members of rightist death squads. The law was approved the day after the murder of a prominent advocate of human rights, Herbert Anaya Sanabria.

LEAD: Tennis Lendl vs. Mecir: Ivan Lendl struggled past Pat Cash and Miloslav Mecir overwhelmed Mats Wilander yesterday to advance to the final of the $923,000 European Community Championship in Antwerp, Belgium. Lendl relied on stamina to power him past Cash, 6-4, 7-6. Mecir, ranked fifth in the world, used a variety of daring strokes to beat Wilander, 6-1, 6-3.

LEAD: IT took my friend Judy Huttner to open my eyes to what was happening all around me, without my noticing. Judy is an artist, but primarily she is an art-tour guide, conducting trips to museums and galleries and studios for Long Islanders interested in the graphic arts.

LEAD: RENATO BRUSON, the Italian baritone who had previously withdrawn from three scheduled appearances as Iago in the Metropolitan Opera's production of ''Otello'' in September, has canceled all his dates with the company this season.

LEAD: When Herman Melville, in ''Moby Dick,'' attributed the line ''I only am escaped alone to tell thee'' to Job, he was referring to the Book of Job, and not to the character. Actually this line was uttered in the Bible by four separate messengers to Job. There is quite a difference between having the victim cry that he has escaped alone and having a servant tell the victim of the latter's losses.

LEAD: THE Arizona docked in New York Harbor on the evening of Jan. 2, 1882. It was too late to clear quarantine until the following morning. The press, avid to see Oscar Wilde, could not wait. Enterprising reporters ''came out of the sea,'' as Wilde picturesquely noted, their pens still wet with brine. In fact, they chartered a launch to bring them aboard.

LEAD: Mayor William H. Hudnut has acknowledged that he is seeking the presidency of the University of Tennessee, but he says he will withdraw his application if he is re-elected to a fourth term next week.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: WHEN legislators and lobbyists win a battle on Capitol Hill, they usually exult in triumph.

LEAD: THE NOTION OF CON-servative Barry Goldwater, the most prominent politician in Arizona history, calling for the resignation of an Arizona Republican Governor would once have seemed less likely than a blizzard in Phoenix. Yet when he did so, on Oct. 9, nobody was deeply shocked.

LEAD: Dialing Weather Question:I believe there is a telephone service for travelers who want to know what kind of weather they are going into. How do you get it? -R. H., Mahwah, N.J. Answer:The service called WeatherTrak gives weather information for 190 cities in North America and 60 overseas.

LEAD: Brunswick moved its record to 7-0 with a handy 27-12 win over Salisbury, setting up next week's Fairchester League showdown with Fieldston, who shut out Dalton, 21-0.

LEAD: WHEN THE CD CATALOGUE of a small independent record company features such dissimilar entries as ''Lisztronique: Electronic Performances of Music by Franz Liszt,'' four volumes of Bach preludes and fugues with the organist Anthony Newman, and ''Larry Adler Live at the Ballroom,'' you just know that a lively imagination is at play behind the scenes.

LEAD: WITH last week's announcement that Mikhail S. Gorbachev will be coming to Washington Dec. 7 for a summit meeting with President Reagan, Americans are promised a closer look at one of the world's most provocatve figures.

LEAD: SOME ballets are like gems: their full value comes through when they are completely polished. Certainly that is what has happened during the Joffrey Ballet's opening week in its performances of a 19th-century excerpt, the pas de six from ''La Vivandiere'' by Arthur Saint-Leon.

LEAD: Debi Thomas, who lost her United States and world figure skating championships earlier this year, took a big step toward regaining her former prominence today by winning at Skate Canada, a major pre-Olympic competition.

LEAD: BUTOH IS NOT FOR THE FRAIL. THE AVANT-garde dance form that today is Japan's most startling cultural export does not aim to charm. Instead, it sets out to assault the senses. The hallmarks of this theater of protest include full body paint (white or dark or gold), near or complete nudity, shaved heads, grotesque costumes, clawed hands, rolled-up eyes and mouths opened in silent screams.
LEAD: ''Ouch!''

LEAD: Japan told the United States today that it would not go along with American sanctions on trade with Iran, but suggested that it would at least try to hold imports of Iranian oil at present levels.

LEAD: IN the cascade of comment on the stock market debacle of the last two weeks, it is hard for an economic historian who has written on 1929 and on 18th and 19th century booms and crashes to find something to say that is not entirely banal. Nonetheless I try:

LEAD: The St. Regis-Sheraton in Manhattan was the setting last evening for the marriage of Debra Lynn Feldman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon Feldman of Boca Raton, Fla., and Bruce Richard Kaliner, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Kaliner of Purchase, N.Y., and Boca Raton. Rabbi David Benedict performed the ceremony.

LEAD: EVERY YEAR, I LOOK FORWARD TO the marathon of holiday entertaining with both anticipation and trepidation. The season's social calendar overflows with cocktail parties, concerts, theater, sports events and the like, which often leave few moments for serious cooking. This is also the time, however, when hosts are expected to show off their plumage with dazzling dishes.

LEAD: JOSEPH K. sleeps on a narrow plank, the size of a coffin, between two high walls; he works in an equally confined space. That is basic to the Jean Cocteau Repertory's intelligent new production of ''The Trial,'' Franz Kafka's novel, dramatized by Andre Gide and Jean-Louis Barrault.

LEAD: MOST of the unicorns, griffins, sea serpents and other fabulous creatures that once tinged the everyday world with romantic mystery have succumbed to the withering touch of rational inquiry. LEAD: Saudi Arabia announced today that King Fahd would not attend an Arab League summit meeting opening Sunday in Amman, Jordan.

LEAD: A stroller walking in the cloudy but mild weather yesterday along a group of trees in Riverside Park that had partly shed their leaves. Temperatures today should seem more like summer, with the high expected to reach into the upper 70's under sunny skies. (NYT/Chester Higgins Jr.)

LEAD: A Federal appeals court refused to delay the merger of USAir Group Inc. and Piedmont Aviation Inc. while it considers a competitor's challenge to the Transportation Department's approval of the deal. The Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia rejected the petition, filed by America West Inc.
LEAD: It's been quite a season at the Bronx Zoo. New York City's two most distinguished - and cuddly - visitors downed 6,800 pounds of bamboo, 736 eggs and 2,208 apples and carrots.
LEAD: A day after Mikhail S. Gorbachev's speech on the Bolshevik Revolution, American scholars drew sharply differing lessons about its meaning.

LEAD: Police officers examining the site where a bomb exploded next to a police van about 50 feet from the Interior Ministry complex. Officials said no one was hurt. (AP)
LEAD: Democrats won governorships last night in Kentucky and Mississippi, completing a shutout of the Republicans in this year's gubernatorial elections.

LEAD: THE stock market had a worrisome day yesterday, and analysts rounded up the usual suspects: Some feared that the dollar might plummet if the central banks were unwilling to support it. Others worried that, in Washington, cutting the budget deficit was stalled. Still others feared the budget cuts might be too little (to rally the markets) or too much (for the economy to sustain).
LEAD: MOVIES today boast spectacular special effects, the latest in sound systems and ever-improving color and clarity. But Douglas Trumbull is not impressed.
LEAD: The dollar rallied on world currency markets yesterday after traders pushed it to new lows against the West German mark and the Japanese yen.

LEAD: Nathan's Famous Inc. and two New York restaurateurs, Irving and Murray Riese, said they had signed an agreement to open 23 franchised Nathan's fast-food restaurants in Manhattan in the next five years. The new units would more than double the number of Nathan's restaurants.

LEAD: BASKETBALL CHICAGO (NBA) - Waived Doug Altenberger, guard-forward, and Pete Myers, guard. CLEVELAND (NBA) - Placed Kent Benson, center, on injured list. HOUSTON (NBA) - Waived Michael Kennedy, forward. Placed Robert Reid, forward, on injured list. KNICKS (NBA) - Waived Geoff Huston, guard, and Leo Rautins, forward.

LEAD: Thirteen monuments that New York City put up for private adoption last spring have found benefactors, but six orphans remain - on Staten Island, in the Bronx and Queens, and in the heart of Manhattan.

LEAD: The Reagan Administration has decided against pushing for new real estate and insurance powers for banks, focusing instead on persuading Congress to grant banks permission to underwrite securities, a top Treasury Department official said today.
LEAD: The mind of a fighter is a fragile item, especially when forced to come to terms with defeat. A case in point is Marvin Hagler.
LEAD: Guy Polhemus had an idea of how to help the poor that was almost too good. It is helping them, but for a period it nearly left him bankrupt.
LEAD: The beleaguered nuclear power industry won a victory in Maine yesterday, where voters rejected an effort to shut down the state's only nuclear power plant.

LEAD: The resignation of Caspar W. Weinberger as Secretary of Defense, which is expected to be announced later this week, seems likely to change the chemistry of policy making during the final 14 months of President Reagan's term.

LEAD: CHANGES in American society are drawing new attention to the form of sexual expression most widely practiced, yet least talked about: masturbation. Compared with the 1940's and 50's, when Alfred Kinsey did his studies, many more people today say they approve of sexual self-stimulation and perform it fairly often.

LEAD: The Rev. Jerry Falwell, founder and leader of the fundamentalist Christian political group Moral Majority, announced today that he was giving up politics and returning full time to his church and television ministry.
LEAD: Earl Monroe, who spent almost nine seasons with the Knicks, was one of four players and five coaches nominated today for election to the Basketball Association Hall of Fame.

LEAD: The first performance of ''Elena's Aria'' by Anne Teresa de Keersmaeker, an experimental Belgian choreographer, in the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Next Wave Festival was canceled last night. The New York premiere of the work was rescheduled for 8 o'clock tonight.

LEAD: The Supreme Court heard arguments today on the emotionally charged issue of how far states may restrict minors' access to abortions so as to promote consultation with their parents.

LEAD: Democrats scored major victories across New York State yesterday, ousting Republican county executives in Suffolk, Erie and Monroe Counties and the longtime Republican Mayor of Yonkers.

LEAD: Relaxing one of its key bans on program trading since the stock market plunge two and a half weeks ago, the New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that it would now allow major brokerage houses to execute program trades for their own accounts.

LEAD: The Charles Schwab Corporation said today that it had been forced to obtain a waiver of a provision of its bank loan agreement because the stock market downturn had put it in danger of violating the minimum-capital requirement.

LEAD: ''If all internal party matters are discussed by one and all, then there will be no sense in having a party. This, I think, is understood.'' - Aleksandr N. Yakovlev, a member of the Soviet Politburo. [ A12:5. ]
LEAD: To The Living Section:
LEAD: The headline of a brief music review yesterday about Margaret Price's song recital on Sunday afternoon misstated the site. It was the Metropolitan Opera House.
LEAD: BRUCE WEBER, known for his photographs of athletic looking fellows posed sexily in underwear advertisements, demonstrates in ''Broken Noses'' that shorts do not make the man.

LEAD: An American lawyer in Moscow in 1965 asked his Intourist guide-guards the way to the men's room, slipped out the back of a restaurant and took a taxi to an address he had been given by a Canadian newsman. The politically defunct lawyer was seeking a rendezvous with a former Soviet leader he had spoken with in a kitchen six years before.

LEAD: Some voters on the Upper West Side and in Greenwich Village got a look yesterday at the latest solution to the problems of voting the old-fashioned way: state-of-the-art electronic voting machines.

LEAD: Seven Manhattan artists or arts organizations were honored Monday for their contributions to the cultural world of the borough at an awards ceremony sponsored by Borough President David Dinkins of Manhattan, at Davis Hall at the City College of the City University of New York.

LEAD: In hockey they call it a cross-check, but if Dave Brown had done what he did to Tomas Sandstrom anywhere except on the ice, it would be called assault. Mr. Brown has been given a 15-game suspension without pay, while his team, the Philadelphia Flyers, may sign another player to replace him. Both player and team got off too lightly.
LEAD: When Mikhail S. Gorbachev's speech ended Monday, Aleksei I. Adzhubei got an excited phone call from his youngest son, a biochemist.

LEAD: THE Equity Library Theater's ''Kismet'' is always exuberant and often hilarious, but at times the pedestrian direction of Russell Treyz reduces its whimsies to mere absurdities. People who like this musical, dreadful rhymes and all, will believe anything, and the higher a director lets his imagination fly, the better.
LEAD: George R. Albino, the chairman and chief executive of Rio Algom Ltd., a large Canadian mining company, has been ousted by the company's board.

LEAD: The Utah Jazz cut Billy Donovan, the rookie guard from Providence. . . . The Portland Trail Blazers cut Ron Rowan, the former St. John's guard. . . . The Cleveland Cavaliers placed Kent Benson, the center, on the injured list because of a hyperextended elbow. . . . The Houston Rockets placed the forward Robert Reid on the injured list for 30 days to rehabilitate his right knee.
LEAD: There were booths with bottles, glasses, ice buckets and corkscrews in all directions.

LEAD: GARY FUMICELLO was cheered to victory as he ran in an event here in 1986, holding a pan of eggs in one hand and waving aloft his other hand, which was swathed in bandages after an encounter with a kitchen knife. The injury was work related. Mr. Fumicello is a student at the New England Culinary Institute.
LEAD: Treasury bond prices rose nearly a point yesterday, cutting the yield of the 30-year issue to slightly above 9 percent.

Ginsburg's nomination to the Supreme Court could be imperiled by charges of conflict of interest, and the Senate Republican leader summoned the nominee to the Capitol to explain his involvement in decisions affecting regulation of the cable television industry.

LEAD: A mourner passing the open coffin of Rene Levesque yesterday in Montreal. A state funeral for the former Premier and separatist leader, who died Sunday, is to be held tomorrow in Quebec City. (Reuters)

LEAD: Job security for civil servants isn't what it used to be.

LEAD: MALFUNCTIONING floor or desk lamps are dangerous. If a lamp flickers, won't light, has a frayed cord, requires delicate positioning to operate or frequently burns out bulbs, you should repair it immediately or discontinue using it.

LEAD: The stock market crash, President Reagan now says, two weeks after the fact, was a warning ''we can't afford to ignore.'' What counts is what the President now does. And so far, he and his aides have shown little fire in the negotiations with Congress on reducing the budget deficit. They're simply using the meetings as an opportunity to rehearse old arguments over priorities and old nostrums against tax increases.

LEAD: Jeff Rutledge, left, leaving practice yesterday with Raul Allegre, the Giants' place-kicker, at Giants Stadium. Rutledge, who joined the team in 1982, is scheduled to make his second start since 1983 Sunday against the Patriots. Page B14. (NYT/Ruby Washington)

LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said today that it would close indefinitely its 3,700-worker assembly plant in Framingham, Mass., because of slow sales of the Chevrolet Celebrity and the Oldsmobile Cutlass Ciera.

LEAD: An overwhelming majority of Pan American World Airways pilots in New York are opposed to having the pilots union pursue a proposal made by Kirk Kerkorian to take over the airline, a union official said yesterday. The New York base accounts for about half of the carrier's pilots, and the official said sentiment was running 20 to 1 against the proposal in a poll of the pilots.
LEAD: The National Endowment for the Humanities said Monday that it would sponsor paid sabbatical leaves for one elementary or high school teacher from each state to study the humanities.

LEAD: President Reagan today announced a further partial lifting of trade sanctions against Japan. They were imposed last April after Japan failed to comply with a 1986 agreement on computer memory chips.

LEAD: The jobless rate for nine member states of the European Community, excluding Spain, Portugal and Greece, rose to 10.9 percent in September, from 10.8 percent in August, the community's statistical office said today. The figures are seasonally unadjusted. The total number of job seekers for the nine countries rose to 12.62 million, from 12.53 million.

LEAD: Raphael Soyer, an artist whose gently rendered portraits of New York artists, dancers and the city's lonely and dispossessed won him fame that lasted from the 1930's to the present, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 87 years old.

LEAD: THE MARKETS The stock market continued to slump in another session marked by wide price swings. Selling by institutions helped drag down share prices, analysts said, but there were indications that some stability may be returning. The Dow Jones industrial average tumbled more than 50 points early in the day, then rose as much as 17 points above Tuesday's close, but ended down 18.24 points, or 0.93 percent, at 1,945.29.

LEAD: Visibility in the shipping lanes of the Persian Gulf was dropping in the amber dusk. Suddenly, a young, twangy American voice came over the marine radio: ''Unidentified dhow one mile off my port bow, this is a U.S. Navy warship. State your intentions.'' The admonition was repeated once, then again, and each time the sailor's voice grew more insistent.

LEAD: Madison Square Garden and the Big East Conference announced a three-year extension of their agreement to hold the conference's postseason basketball tournament at the Garden. The extension assures that the Garden will continue to host the popular four-day tournament through the 1990-91 season.

LEAD: Govan A. Mbeki, the 77-year-old former chairman of the African National Congress, wrote his last book on tissue paper and smuggled it to a publisher. He will not need to be so secretive with future manuscripts, for he was freed yesterday after 23 years in a South African prison.
LEAD: Hopping across the country, the question people keep asking me is, ''Can we trust Gorbachev?''

LEAD: President Reagan's latest Supreme Court nominee, Judge Douglas H. Ginsburg, saidtonight that he smoked marijuana once as a college student in the 1960's and on ''a few occasions'' in the 1970's.

LEAD: Good Housekeeping magazine has selected Hal Riney & Partners, New York, to handle its advertising after a monthlong, four-way competition. The budget is in the $1.5 million to $2 million range. Baron & Zaretsky was the agency for the last three years.

LEAD: THE loan show of ''Fernand Leger'' at the Acquavella Galleries is a remarkable achievement. For the two rooms upstairs, the gallery has been able to borrow no fewer than 28 paintings that are dated between 1905 and 1921. From the beginnings of Leger's Cubism in the ''Compotier'' of 1909, through a great series of ''Contrastes de Formes'' and some incisive allusions to Leger's later preoccupation with the factory, the level crossing, the circus, the machinist and the big city as a whole, the standard is remarkably high.
LEAD: The six Democratic candidates for President all promised increased Federal spending on education tonight and then argued in a sharp debate here over how they would pay the bill.

LEAD: American steelmakers, who have enjoyed higher prices and a return to profitability for much of this year, face a downturn in demand because of the collapse of stock prices, some steel analysts and economists predicted yesterday.

LEAD: With the stability of the stock market still fragile, small investors are acting with caution, choosing to make safe investments or to hold on to what they have, analysts and brokerage officials say.

LEAD: The Polish authorities, apparently concerned over a Solidarity appeal for a boycott of a national referendum, have ordered eight people who signed the appeal, including Lech Walesa, to report for police questioning.

LEAD: This is the time of the year when his former boss, Hubie Brown, would walk to the nearest available chalkboard and scribble the number of victories he was establishing as the team's goal for the season. Brown would then refer to the number for the remainder of the season, or until the team achieved the goal, whichever came first.

LEAD: THE smartest thing that the makers of ''Less Than Zero'' have done is the thing that they didn't do: stick very closely to Bret Easton Ellis's novel, no matter how trendy and best-selling that book may have been. LEAD: THE mantle of greatness does not fall lightly onto the heroes of Sir Richard Attenborough's epic film biographies. It is placed there by a heavy hand. LEAD: A proposal to reduce Social Security cost-of-living increases came up again today in talks on reducing the Federal deficit. Several negotiators said that such a cut, although politically touchy, was the key to reaching a serious agreement.

LEAD: Strong investor demand led New York City to increase the size of its bond sale to $750 million, from $600 million, and allowed securities dealers to reduce interest rates a tenth of a percentage point for some maturities.

LEAD: The annual spec-tacle of hundreds of bald eagles con-verging on Glacier National Park to feast on spawning salmon is proving to be a dud this year, park officials said, with the number of eagles down 80 per-cent and salmon almost nonexistent. Riley McClelland, wildlife biologist for Glacier Park, cited the unusually warm fall.

LEAD: J. Richard Walton, a professional money manager who invests in American stocks, is now beginning his business days with a 6 A.M. telephone call to London from his home in Irvington, N.Y. Yesterday he learned that Japanese institutions were selling American stocks and that the dollar was once again under attack in the currency markets - factors he would have to consider in deciding whether to buy or sell stocks during one of the most turbulent times in financial history.

LEAD: In the first strong sign of international economic cooperation after a month of turbulence in the financial markets, West Germany ordered reductions in interest rates today to speed up its economy. The Reagan Administration and other governments had urged Bonn to lower its rates because they feared the onset of a worldwide recession caused partly by high interest rates.

LEAD: In a dazzling display of the art of dressmaking, Geoffrey Beene made the jump suit the newest fashion look. Immediately after the Beene show at the Pierre, Donna Karan presented an ultra-feminine version of her sexy separates look in her Seventh Avenue showroom. Her plunging neckline jackets, lace skirts and stretch fabric evening dresses give a new slant on provocative dressing.

LEAD: Damaged hull of the Panama-registered tanker Grand Wisdom after an Iranian rocket-grenade attack off Dubai. No casualties were reported and a resulting fire was put out. In an attempt to put new life into his peace mission, Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar of the United Nations has sent messages to Iran and Iraq asking them to send emissaries to New York to begin peace negotiations with him immediately.

LEAD: OCTOBER'S stock market plunge brought gold to center stage once more as individual investors and their advisers argue for and against it as an investment medium. Gold has traditionally been considered a safe haven when there is turmoil in the financial world and expectations of rising inflation - and some advisers therefore believe that this is the time for investors to begin or augment a gold buying program.

LEAD: Is President Corazon Aquino of the Philippines up to her job? That question comes a short year after she was hailed as a political messiah. The Reagan Administration recognizes that one extreme is as invalid as the other. Mrs. Aquino remains one of Asia's more attractive political leaders.

LEAD: A woman was sentenced here today to four years in prison for leaving her 3-month-old twins unattended in a car where they died of heat stroke on a summer day in 1986. The 26-year-old mother, Beverly Jean Ernst, was convicted of child endangerment in April. According to testimony at the trial, Ms. Ernst left Adam and Ashley in her car on the morning of July 20, 1986, when she went into a shop where her boyfriend lived and fell asleep with him.
LEAD: Americans, borrowing heavily to purchase new cars, took out $6.06 billion in credit in September, the biggest increase in a year, the Government said today.
LEAD: In a recent interview, a freelance magazine writer asked a leading member of Chile's political opposition what he thought of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, the President.

LEAD: In the men's room of a small coffee shop, a mannish-looking woman peeks from inside a stall and sees a burly security guard nuzzling a young blond waiter. These three will become central to the action of ''Blind Trust,'' an intelligent thriller by Yves Simoneau, a Canadian director, and the confusions of gender in the men's room give a clue that the story will resonate with tangled relationships and thwarted plans.

LEAD: Arnold Markle, the State's Attorney for New Haven since 1968 and the prosecutor of several members of the Black Panthers in the 1970's, died Thursday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 60 years old and lived in Woodbridge, Conn.

LEAD: A 900-pound sturgeon in Bellevue after it was pulled from Lake Washington. The 11-foot-long fish was found floating Thursday. State officials estimated it was born sometime around the turn of the century and may have died of old age. Tales have persisted of a monster in the lake that sometimes eats ducks.

LEAD: The dollar turned in a mixed performance yesterday in thin trading as world currency markets were buffeted by conflicting rumors about the amounts that Democrats and Republicans expect to slice from the Federal budget deficit.

LEAD: The Exxon Corporation said it planned to increase its drilling activity in West Texas, with 350 new wells over two years. Randall Meyer, the president of the nation's largest oil company, said Exxon was trying to gradually rebuild its drilling program after the 1986 price collapse. While prices have ranged between $18 and $20 per 42-gallon barrel in recent weeks, they dipped below $10 a barrel last year.
