LEAD: CAN students be taught the social skills needed to get along with one another and with adults and, ultimately, to help them find employment?

LEAD: THE land of boiled dinners, baked beans, codfish cakes and brown bread has undergone a metamorphosis so dramatic that gustatory adventurers will be delighted to find themselves in New England at mealtime. Talented chefs in dozens of restaurants are making remarkable meals from local farmstead cheeses, free-range chickens, a variety of meticulously smoked fish and meats, game birds, shiitake mushrooms and, of course, the things for which New

LEAD: THE stock market has been the chief object of investor attention for the last two weeks. But investors in the fixed-income securities market, which is larger than the equity market by at least a trillion dollars, have enjoyed a monthlong rally that propelled bond prices up as much as 12 percent. The rally continued into last week.
LEAD: The World Bank announced today that it was giving drought-related assistance of more than $500 million to India, saying it was seeking to ease this nation's growing balance-of-payments squeeze.
LEAD: An engineering consultant who helped Federal agencies investigating the collapse of L'Ambiance Plaza in Bridgeport says the investigation should be expanded.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: THE election of Patrick G. Halpin and Thomas S. Gulotta as the County Executives of Suffolk and Nassau Counties signals the emergence of a new generation of politicians on Long Island.
LEAD: FEARFUL MAJESTY The Life and Reign of Ivan the Terrible. By Benson Bobrick. Illustrated. 398 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $22.95.

LEAD: THE Campbell Soup Company, like most consumer products companies, has always asked its customers lots of questions. Last year alone, its field researchers contacted close to 110,000 people to talk about food - taste, preparation, nutritional value, the works. On the basis of what they said, Campbell changed the seasonings in five Le Menu dinners and introduced a line of low-salt soups called, appropriately enough, Special Request.
LEAD: PRIME-TIME TELEVISION'S preoccupation with sociopaths is more intense than ever these days.

LEAD: WHEN Frank C. Carlucci succeeds Caspar W. Weinberger as Defense Secretary, his most pressing problem will be to untangle the budgetary gridlock that has practically immobilized the Pentagon's planning, say senior officials in the Administration and Congress.
LEAD: A heady assortment of films awaits buffs this week - from more recent fare such as ''Altered States'' to long-absent classics like ''The Lost Weekend'' and ''La Dolce Vita.''

LEAD: Oklahoma beat Oklahoma State, 29-10, today in a Big Eight Conference game but lost its two most productive backs, Jamelle Holieway and Lydell Carr, for the remainder of the season with knee injuries.
LEAD: To the Editor: I am writing in the hope that what happened to me won't happen to someone else.
LEAD: Nancy Elizabeth Perry and Lieut. Russell Todd Webster, U.S.A., were married last evening at the Unitarian Church in Westport, Conn., by the Rev. Harris Riordon.

LEAD: Although the m.v.p. award usually goes to a member of a division champion, I feel that Andre Dawson was such a dominant force in the National League (almost 50 home runs, more than 130 runs batted in) that he deserves to win it.
LEAD: In East Boston, opposing major public construction projects is an avocation for some and a spectator sport for others.

LEAD: Calling incompetent and impaired physicians ''a potentially lethal minority,'' the State Commission of Investigation has recommended new laws and regulations intended to bring them to the attention of the State Board of Medical Examiners.

LEAD: Should New York City's Board of Education be expanded, replaced or abolished altogether? Such questions are properly raised as the board struggles to find a successor to Chancellor Nathan Quinones, who retires on Jan. 1. The stumbling search exemplifies a crisis of competence for the nation's largest school system, a crisis that begins with the board president, Robert Wagner Jr.
LEAD: Patricia Ann Kriger and Michael Glenn Schaffer were married last evening at the Elmwood Country Club in White Plains by Rabbi Jacob Sodden.
LEAD: THE day dawned dull and chill, summoned to a kind of life by the muezzin's call.

LEAD: COLOR is a sensation caused by the action of light on the retina. It is also definable as an entity that affects its observers physically as well as psychologically, although color choices are generally regarded as reflections of the chooser's mental state.

LEAD: A DECISION by a Federal District Court judge that the North Babylon School District must reschedule its annual date of graduation is being appealed by the district, which wants to maintain the tradition of holding graduation exercises on Saturday morning.

LEAD: ''I'VE come a long way from Cripple Creek,'' Robin Burns said cheerfully, reminiscing about the Colorado mining town where she spent her earliest years. She ticks off favorite memories: riding a horse to school, collecting chunks of turquoise off the dirt streets to sell to tourists.

LEAD: THE QUALITY of library services at the nation's major universities is being threatened by recent steep rises in subscription prices of research journals and periodicals, according to reports by the Association of Research Libraries.
LEAD: An iceberg twice as big as Rhode Island has broken away from Antarctica and is drifting in the Ross Sea, the National Science Foundation says.

LEAD: HE called the other day to check upon the whereabouts of our daughter. As our conversation meandered through the trivialities of which we always speak - my mother, his aunt, the dog, the kids, our recent travels -he casually mentioned that he was giving a party to celebrate the 20th anniversary of the company.
LEAD: Cavalrymen in uniforms of the era parading in Moscow yesterday in celebration of the anniversary of the Bolshevik Revolution. Page 14. (Tass via AP)

LEAD: Gathering here in the names of Thomas Jefferson and Andrew Jackson, Iowa's Democrats today celebrated their party's six Presidential candidates and the happy news that in just 94 days, campaigning for one of democracy's most unusual exercises would be over.

LEAD: ANYONE interested in understanding the importance of Steve Reich's music had only to look around at Thursday night's audience in the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The people were there to hear three of Mr. Reich's newer pieces, played by the guitarist Pat Metheny with a conglomeration of Brooklyn Philharmonic musicians and the composer's own corps of percussion players.

LEAD: THE Village of Great Neck Plaza has filed suit against the Nassau County Rent Guidelines Board, accusing the board of discriminating against renters in a cooperative or condominium building. The board has allowed owners of co-ops and condominiums who lease the apartment units to charge higher rents than landlords of other rental units.

LEAD: Patricia Taylor, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund R. Taylor Jr. of Pocantico Hills, N.Y., was married there yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Mary Magdalene to Antonio Patrick Salazar, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Antonio Salazar of New Britain, Conn. Msgr. Stephen J. Fitzgerald, pastor of the church, officiated, assisted by the Rev.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: THE SIXTIES Years of Hope, Days of Rage. By Todd Gitlin. 513 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $19.95.
LEAD: To the Editor: I go to Spain - and only to Spain - three times a year. And I do so because I love the Spanish people and their culture.

LEAD: A new development of 11 single-family homes, called the Estates at Country Club, has just been opened near Eastchester Bay in the East Bronx by Ruffalo Associates. The homes are along Country Club Road north of the Throgs Neck Bridge.

LEAD: A map of Mystic on Oct. 25 showed incorrect locations for Mystic Seaport and the Mystic Marinelife Aquarium. They are on the east bank of the Mystic River, south of Interstate 95; the aquarium is almost a mile north of the seaport.

LEAD: GREAT AND DESPERATE CURES: The Rise and Decline of Psychosurgery and Other Radical Treatments for Mental Illness, by Elliot S. Valenstein. (Basic Books, $10.95.) In 1949, Egas Moniz, a Portuguese neurology professor, won the Nobel Prize for helping to invent the prefrontal lobotomy, an operation that became so popular as a treament for mental illness that it was sometimes performed as an office procedure, using an ice pick thrust through the bony socket behind the eyeball.

LEAD: GEMS AND SPORTS The Westchester County Center in White Plains, reopened after extensive renovations, will feature two attractions next weekend that in past years have drawn up to 8,000 people, according to Gloria Rothstein, the promoter.

LEAD: THE letters about what is right and wrong with today's automobile continue to flow in. It has been a month since that column ran, and the torrent has slowed to a trickle, two to three letters a day now. But it is obvious that people across the country have some definite ideas about what they are not getting in the way of dandy transportation.

LEAD: I was deeply disappointed by the Oct. 18 article [ ''Democrats Face Loss of 6 More Judgeships'' ] concerning the result of the Republican Party's refusal to grant cross-endorsements to qualified sitting Democratic judicial candidates in this area.

LEAD: Two million times a year, American citizens are subjected to ''lie-detector'' tests. This explosion of the use of machines that measure nervousness (and that fail to catch the cool, practiced liar) is the most blatant intrusion into personal freedom in this country today.

LEAD: LAST call to plant bulbs, especially tulips; use fertilizer at the base of planting holes and water bulbs if the ground seems dry. Continue raking leaves and don't forget to use a bamboo rake or power blower to brush them off groundcovers such as myrtle and pachysandra; shake shrubs and young trees so leaves filter down to the ground; leave them there.
LEAD: Though the Cubs finished in last place, Andre Dawson deserves the National League m.v.p.

LEAD: Judge Douglas H. Ginsburg, who withdrew today as President Reagan's choice for the Supreme Court, sat for two months this spring as a judge on a pension regulation case arising from actions in which he had been directly involved as a Government official two years earlier, according to court documents.
LEAD: Visitors from Moscow, a city that gravitates west toward Europe and the Atlantic, find the eastward inclination of this Pacific port disorienting at first.

LEAD: It was an evening full of alarming scenes. With 10 minutes left in the second period, Bill Smith's ankle gave out, leaving the Islander goaltender in a heap in front of his net. Thirty minutes later, it looked like the entire team had collapsed.

LEAD: THE Joffrey Ballet's treasure house of 20th-century classics is often opened up in ''theme'' programs, and the most popular of these have been the revivals from Serge Diaghilev's Ballets Russes.
LEAD: A PRESERVATION battle may be on the horizon over the Fiss, Doerr & Carroll Auction Mart on East 24th Street that could cast light on state-city sovereignty in landmarks matters.

LEAD: The Left-Handed Gun With Paul Newman, directed by Arthur Penn. 1958. Warner Home Video. 102 minutes. $19.98. If you think a movie starring Paul Newman and directed by Arthur Penn can't be all bad, you don't remember ''The Left-Handed Gun,'' which came and went in 1958 and, like the bad guys in westerns, now returns to put a new generation to sleep.

LEAD: IT would seem that all is law and order in George Rickey's art, with the law that of gravity and the order the way in which the sculptor uses it. Confirming this up to a point is the Neuberger Museum's ''George Rickey: Projects for Public Sculpture,'' a show that examines nine major works by way of models, drawings and photographs.

LEAD: IN 1981, when President Reagan dismissed striking air traffic controllers who had refused to return to work, he noted that he had once led a strike as head of the Screen Actors Guild. But it was his swift, firm response to the controllers' strike, not his background as a Hollywood labor leader, that set the tone for labor relations in his first term.
LEAD: Three weeks after the stock market collapse, most corporate economists are firmly optimistic that consumers will recover their confidence and spend enough to avoid a recession next year.
LEAD: I WANT A DOG By Dayal Kaur Khalsa. Illustrated by the author. Unpaged. New York: Clarkson N. Potter/Crown Publishers. $10.95. (Ages 5 to 9)

LEAD: Lauren Rachel Shapiro, a daughter of Susan B. Braver of New York and Michael D. Shapiro of Northport, L.I., and Steven Paul Beck, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Felix Beck of Livingston, N.J., were married last evening. Rabbi Azriel Fellner and Cantor Henry Butensky officiated at the Pierre in New York.

LEAD: At St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in New York, Caroline Hopping Starr, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herald B. Starr of Orange, N.J., and Thomas William Boylan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Matthew M. Boylan of Westfield, N.J., were married yesterday by the Rev. Robert T. Sheeran, the assistant provost of Seton Hall University.

LEAD: VETERANS DAY marks the culmination of the period preceding Thanksgiving, Christmas and New Year's that I have come to think of as Minor Holiday Season I. Before our older child, Elizabeth, entered public kindergarten five years ago, Columbus Day and Veterans Day had been seen by my husband, Tom, and
LEAD: Who should be the m.v.p.'s in baseball? Tony Gwynn and Dwight Evans. GREG GOLDSTEIN Fresh Meadows

LEAD: ON BLACK MONDAY, crash was the word most frequently used at first to describe the 508-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average that occurred Oct. 19, 1987, a day that many investors think will live in infirmity. Donald T. Regan, former Treasury Secretary, called C-Day ''black and blue Monday,'' a nice play on the battered image of ''black and blue'' with the traditional bad-news sense of ''black [ whatever ] day'' and the don't-want-to-go-back-to-work sense of ''blue Monday.
LEAD: The Byrne Meadowlands Arena is turning out to be a truly sweet home for the Devils this season. Tonight, they beat the Washington Capitals, 4-1, to remain undefeated after eight games here.

LEAD: If push comes to shove, says Treasury Secretary Baker, Washington won't raise interest rates to protect the value of the dollar. Mr. Baker has his priorities right: The risk of high interest rates causing recession exceed the risk of a falling dollar leading to a punishing inflation.

LEAD: EVEN WITH all the funds that New Jersey provides for the arts, something's eating at me. It has to do with how we regard the arts, particularly when it concerns young people. Here in Sussex County, sports - especially high school sports - are a big deal. There is wide coverage in the local newspapers, with feature articles, color photographs, all-county teams, athlete-scholar dinners, ''Athletes of the

LEAD: The Bedroom Window Starring Steve Guttenberg, Elizabeth McGovern, Isabelle Huppert. 1987. Vestron Video. 113 mins. $79.98. You can give ''The Bedroom Window'' points for bravery; here's a romantic-suspense story that plunges into Hitchcock territory, where shrewder, more stylish films fear to go.

LEAD: This man, Mark Lindquist, can write (''Diary of a Lost Weekend,'' Oct. 11). His words, the very phrasing, bring this funny/sad scene to a level of reality I wouldn't have thought possible. Sight, sound and movement are built into the article. SALLY T. PETIT Bronxville, N.Y.

LEAD: BOB DOLE WAS adamant. The budget deficit, he had said since the beginning of the Reagan Presidency, was ''the nation's No. 1 priority.'' Now, standing on the floor of the United States Senate, the tall, crisply tailored Kansan was elaborating on that theme. Health programs, he said, were ''just another instance of how Congress puts spending on automatic pilot.
LEAD: A STATE OF FEAR By Menan du Plessis. 190 pp. New York: Pandora Press/Methuen. Cloth, $25. Paper, $7.95.
LEAD: IT'S easy to say what Karen Monson's ''Blood on the Saddle'' wasn't. Despite its title, it wasn't a Western. But it's harder to determine just what it was.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. John Jay Ferdon of San Francisco of the engagement of their daughter, Maggie Ferdon, to John Withrow Cooley, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel P. Cooley of West Hartford, Conn., and Nantucket, Mass. The couple plan a January wedding.

LEAD: A Federal grand jury has indicted three Lebanese-born Canadians for trying to smuggle a bomb into the United States, the authorities said. The three men, Walid Nicolas Kabbani, 30 years old, Walid Majiv Mourad, 39, and Georges Fouad Nicolas Younan, 44, were arrested Oct. 24, a short time after they crossed the border at Richford.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: An Iran arms scandal that has exploded on the French political scene has thrown President Francois Mitterrand and his Socialist Party on the defensive just as he is deciding on whether to run for a second term.

LEAD: Workers positioning metal plates at the intersection of Park Avenue and 57th Street. The plates were being installed to allow repairs to be made on Metro-North train tunnel below, while still allowing traffic to use the avenue. As each block is completed, repair crews will move one block further north, working their way to 96th Street.

LEAD: RON MOGLIA wants every 5-year-old in America to play the ''birthing game.'' It goes like this: A kindergarten class chooses a girl to be the ''adult mommy'' and a boy to be the ''adult daddy.'' The teacher asks the ''adult mommy'' when she wants to have her baby - before lunch, before recess or before going home.

LEAD: FIRST LOVE IS THE REAL THING, tradition says. But looking at works of art is also a form of love, and we never forget the moment at which we first found out how much can come of it. For this reason, every university museum should be designated as a sacred place - one in which the guards go disguised and can reveal themselves when we least expect them.

LEAD: COMPARED WITH VIOLINISTS, cellists or pianists, players of wind instruments have a paucity of music to choose from when they seek solo materials. Although there are a number of masterly works by great composers, most music for winds has been written by players who regarded themselves primarily as performers and composed only to provide themselves with something to play.

LEAD: AT 60, a man's thoughts turn to what might have been, and he fantasizes about second chances. It is on that premise that Elliott Caplin of Mamaroneck has based his play, ''One Way to Ulan Bator,'' which is being performed on Off Off Broadway (at the Riverwest Theater at 155 Bank Street in Manhattan) through
LEAD: College students across the country are attending forums, signing petitions and staying outside in sleeping bags in an effort to focus college campuses on the plight of the homeless.

LEAD: The engagement of Anne Beals Lewis and J. William Drake 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph W. Drake Jr. of Old Greenwich, Conn., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Stanley P. Lewis of Southport, Conn. An April wedding is planned.

LEAD: Moore P. Huffman, a retired partner of Morgan Stanley & Company, investment bankers, died of a heart attack Oct. 31 at his home in Woody Creek, Colo. A former resident of Bedford Hills, N.Y., and of Aspen, Colo., he was 77 years old.
LEAD: Eugene Rowley

LEAD: To the Editor: According to the letter about Spain on Aug. 30, there is ''nothing'' doing in Madrid, Cordoba, Granada, Seville or the Costa del Sol. The writer compiled a long list of grievances during a short stay. Not only did the Spaniards speak Spanish, they closed a national monument on the flimsy pretext that a national election was being held that day.

LEAD: Bay Shore $152,000 1502 St. Louis Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 32-year-old split level; den, eat-in kitchen, 1-car garage; taxes $2,400. Freeport $110,000 204 East Seaman Avenue 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; finished basement with bar, 1-car garage; taxes $2,300.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: A hockey stick, like a surgeon's scalpel, can provide great satisfaction when used skillfully. Yet for a player the stick also carries with it a tremendous responsibility.

LEAD: N.H.L. Bruins 4, Penguins 1: Rick Middleton scored two goals, one on a short-handed breakaway, as Boston snapped a six-game streak without a victory last night in Boston. The Bruins limited the Penguins to two shots in the first period and 17 in the game. The Penguins were without Mario Lemieux, their top scorer, who had returned to Pittsburgh with a bruised shoulder and back.(AP)

LEAD: DETERMINATION and persistence are qualities that Capt. Robert R. Herb says he has in abundance, and both his critics and backers say he will need them to correct problems in the Bergen County jail system.
LEAD: Following is a statement by Judge Douglas H. Ginsburg yesterday afternoon in Washington as recorded by The New York Times.

LEAD: ONCE the effects of pro football's recent power struggle between the owners and the players subside and a new National Football League champion is crowned, the current season will most likely be remembered for strikeball, as well as the sudden demise of the Giants. But in future years it might also be remembered as the season when pro football showed signs of overcoming its most lingering phobia: apprehension over the use of the black quarterback.

LEAD: By the time large-scale commercial whaling ended in the early part of this century, gray whales had been hunted almost out of existence. ''Twice, the population was thought to be extinct,'' said Don Wilkie, director of the aquarium-museum at the Scripps Institution of Oceanography at La Jolla, Calif.
LEAD: University of California officials have reversed their decision to appoint a Central Intelligence Agency agent as a political science lecturer, ending two weeks of faculty and student protest.

LEAD: IN many older homes, electrical wall receptacles possess only two slots per outlet. Modern three-slot receptacles, which have a semicircular hole centered beneath each pair of slots, are more convenient. And because they provide better grounding for plug-in appliances, they are safer.

LEAD: In percent Tax-Exempt Bonds 7.90 Bond Buyer 20-Bond Index Money Market Funds 6.68 Donoghue's Money Fund 7-Day Compound Yield Bank Money Market Accounts 5.84 Bank Rate Monitor Home Mortgage 9.67 Federal Home Loan Bank, national average Unsecured Personal Loans Minimum fixed rate, 3-year maturity Chase Manhattan, New York 14.50 Continental Illinois, Chicago 14.00 Bank of America, San Francisco 18.25
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Forensic evidence indicates that 6-year-old Elizabeth Steinberg was subjected to several weeks of physical abuse before the battering last weekend in which her fatal injuries were inflicted, a top official in the investigation said yesterday.

LEAD: A man who took control of an Air Canada jetliner here for three and a half hours Friday before surrendering to the authorities is being held at the city jail on charges of attempted hijacking, a spokesman for the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Soviet Union celebrated its 70th anniversary today with a martial parade of the old trappings of the Bolshevik Revolution and the new watchwords of the Revolution's latest leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

LEAD: BRIGHTON BEACH MEMOIRS Written by Neil Simon. Starring Blythe Danner, Bob Dishy, Judith Ivey, Jonathan Silverman (in photo). Produced by Ray Stark. Directed by Gene Saks. 1986. MCA Home Video. 110 minutes. $79.95.

LEAD: It is no doubt a tribute to ''Old Exeter'' that they have chosen an obviously qualified woman to lead them (''A Woman at Old Exeter,'' by Fran R. Schumer, Oct. 11). But what a sad commentary on the process of evaluating and choosing a woman principal that one of the women on the search committee felt compelled to justify the choice by stating that Kendra Stearns O'Donnell was not ''some ditz who was going to throw her hands up and say, 'I don't know 'bout nothing but babies and birds.

LEAD: Ozzie Smith and Alan Trammell should be the m.v.p.'s. Smith hit .303, drove in 75 runs (without a home run) and played his usual brilliant shortstop, saving many runs with his glove. More importantly, he missed only four games and kept the Cardinals together when key players like Jack Clark and John

LEAD: On Oct. 11 you printed an article entitled ''Criticism for Utility Follows Snowfall.'' Year after year, the lives of thousands of Connecticut residents are disrupted when storms result in the loss of electric power. These incidents are not ''acts of God.'' They are exacerbated by the failure of the utility companies to bury power and telephone lines.

LEAD: WHEN THE LUMBERING figures of Maurice Sendak's ''wild things'' stagger to life to the music of the 35-year-old Oliver Knussen at the New York City Opera Thursday night, it will signal a week in which contemporary British music will be unusually prominent in New York. The same night that Mr. Knussen's one-act opera, ''Where the Wild Things Are,'' is receiving its New York stage premiere (it has previously been heard in concert at the New York Philharmonic, conducted by Zubin Mehta), the Philharmonic will be introducing ''Ringed by the Flat Horizon,'' the first orchestral work by George

LEAD: A HANDFUL OF MEN come coasting down the hill on gearless bicycles. They are wearing dark wide-brimmed straw hats, plain blue workshirts and black pants held up by suspenders. They round the corner at the end of the cornfield and pull up to a half-constructed church where 40 or so men, most of them farmers, are already at work.
LEAD: Prime Minister Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali took power in Tunisia today on grounds that Habib Bourguiba, its President for life, was too ill and senile to govern any longer.

LEAD: RECENTLY I was invited to lunch by a new friend, Fran. The invitation was for the same day I planned to visit my best friend, Judy. Judy lives in a fourth-floor walk-up in the Bronx. She had had surgery a few weeks ago, and needed help with shopping. When I declined the invitation, and told Fran why, she stared at me, surprised.

LEAD: Dining and Dancing Back to School Nov. 8 - A dinner with music at 6 P.M. will raise money for an endowment for La Guardia High School, 65th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, which was merged in 1984 with the High School of Music and Art and the School of Performing Arts. Alumni and friends of the schools are sponsoring the dinner by candlelight in La Guardia's marble lobby.
LEAD: To the Editor: I usually take a cab to the airport. However, I recently had extra time and thought I'd try the Carey bus service from Grand Central.

LEAD: The marriage of Julie Jane Shemitz, an assistant district attorney in Brooklyn, to James Brian LeBow, an associate in the New York law firm of Grutman Miller Greenspoon & Hendler, took place last night at the Quinnipiack Club in New Haven. Judge Alan H. W. Shiff of the United States Bankruptcy Court in Bridgeport, Conn., the uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: By surrendering - even for one dark hour - to the powerlessness from which his maleness is likely to protect him, Daniel Voll has shown unusual sensitivity. Willingly descending into his friend's pain, humiliation and vulnerability to understand it from within is an act of profound caring that indeed surpasses 1980's rhetoric.
LEAD: In an area where new homes sell for more than $136,000, a rural housing agency says it will build 200 condominiums costing as little as $22,800 each for Orange County residents.

LEAD: When the four professors from Beijing arrived at Logan Airport in Boston for a flight to New York, they found themselves faced with a travelers' quandary: flight attendants told them that unless they left behind dozens of criminology textbooks, gifts from an American colleague, they would be over the weight allowance.
LEAD: POPCORN is a favorite low-calorie snack - but many people sneak a little butter on for flavor. Soon it may be possible to have buttery tasting popcorn without the calories or the guilt.

LEAD: Washington Monuments Narrated by Robert Prosky. Produced and written by Peter D. Edwards. Atlas Video Library. 30 minutes. $19.95. This is a dull, slow-moving, plodding and superficial attempt at a tourist guide or souvenir that, despite its pretty pictures, captures none of the historical or present-day excitement of our nation's capital.

LEAD: Jenny Angela Engles, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Thomas Engles of Providence and Little Compton, R.I., was married yesterday to Charles William Anderson, a son of Mrs. Randolph Erland Anderson of Peace Dale, R.I., and the late Mr. Anderson. The Rev. Everett H. Greene performed the ceremony at Emmanuel Episcopal Church in Newport, R.I.

LEAD: AMID the impatient traffic, waves of pedestrians, overflowing cafes, multi-screen cinemas and pasta and pizza parlors of the Boulevard Montmartre in Paris lies a tiny building of rococo splendor that is one of the oldest wax museums in Europe. Since its founding in 1882, the museum has closed its doors just once - on the day the Germans occupied Paris.

LEAD: The state of Maine is now in the real estate business, joining 17 other states in setting up an aggressive program to buy land before the crush of development takes away more scenic spots and wildlife areas.

LEAD: Henry Butler, a pianist from New Orleans, will be reunited with one of his teachers and inspirations this week at Sweet Basil. The teacher is Alvin Batiste, one of the most distinctive and virtuosic modern jazz clarinetists. Mr. Batiste, an early associate of Ornette Coleman, is a player who has been heard too infrequently in New York.

LEAD: LIMESTONE demons with wicked smiles decorate the landmark Beaux-Arts facade of the Ansonia Hotel on Broadway at West 73d Street. The faces are fitting symbols of discord for this building, which has been a battleground for tenants and landlords for several decades. Squabbles have revolved around rents, services and repairs, and now a possible conversion to a condominium.

LEAD: The Federal Election Commission has been asked to condone a practice used by political action committees that has been criticized as a way to circumvent Federal limits on campaign contributions.
LEAD: Representative Kenneth J. Gray, a 12-term Democrat, said today he will not seek re-election next year in his Southern Illinois district because of health problems and political opposition.

LEAD: THE FRENCH BISTRO - A small, traditional family restaurant - has become synonymous with hearty, no-nonsense food. Celeri remoulade, giant bowls of herring in cream, terrines of gamey pates, french fries and grilled steak, hearty cassoulets, beef stewed in red wine, chocolate mousse and tarte Tatin are served in an equally unpretentious atmosphere.
LEAD: It is difficult to know what Gary Kasparov's intentions were in Game 10, a draw, of his world championship chess match with Anatoly Karpov in Seville, Spain, Friday.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Interhostel Question: I understand there is an organization called Interhostel that is similar to Elderhostel but specializes in overseas programs. How can I get its catalogue? - E. E. O., Chevy Chase, Md. Answer: Both Interhostel and Elderhostel offer travel and educational programs for older adults.

LEAD: THE Jesus and Mary Chain keeps simple pop pleasure and simple emotions at a distance. At the Ritz on Thursday, opening a two-night stand, the English band had catchy tunes, long-suffering lyrics and alienation strategies aplenty.

LEAD: It was with great interest that I read Fran Schumer's article. As a young faculty member during the early days of coeducation, I can recall many incidents in which male chauvinism, either intentional or unintentional, prevailed.

LEAD: It's not that I doubt Daniel Voll's sincere intentions in trying to understand what his female friend suffered from being raped (About Men, ''The Dark Playground,'' Oct. 4). However, I fail to see the ''shared vulnerability'' he speaks of, after his experience of lying on the very spot, tasting the dirt and recalling his own anxious fear at the idea of homosexual prison rape, after he was almost busted for drugs in college.
LEAD: Pan Am, Aeroflot To Fly Jointly To Soviet Union

LEAD: GLIDING across the stage, a huge screen behind him, Steven P. Jobs has his audience mesmerized. He is expounding on his vision of computerized education. In the future, Mr. Jobs says, sophisticated computer simulations will allow students to walk through Athens with Plato, experience life in 17th-century

LEAD: THE opening sentence of a novel is always important, but perhaps never more so than in novels for young readers. A novel that gets off to a slow start can get off to no start for people with homework to do, television to watch, rock groups to follow, parents to please, chums to phone, places to go, chores to be done.

LEAD: TRANSFUSING ''The Sound of Music'' with a fresh, youthful renewed point of view doesn't seem easy, or even essential, since the last of the Rodgers and Hammerstein collaborations has been doing just fine, pleasing audiences in its own staid, old-fashioned style for almost 30 years.
LEAD: At the age of 90, Dorothy O. White is the author of a book, her first.
LEAD: THE MEDUSA FREQUENCY By Russell Hoban. 143 pp. New York: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $16.95.

LEAD: Verification of the absence of mobile missiles such as the SS-20 is impossible (''Verification: Will It Work?'' by David Aaron, Oct. 11). Not just difficult - impossible. The reason is simple. No one in the West knows how many were produced or are being produced or how many assembly points and subcontractors are involved.

LEAD: GUNGA DIN By Rudyard Kipling. Illustrated by Robert Andrew Parker. Introduction by Kingsley Amis. Unpaged. San Diego: Gulliver Books/ Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $12.95. (Ages 5 to 9) THE JUNGLE BOOK By Rudyard Kipling. Illustrated by Michael Foreman. 175 pp. New York: Viking Kestrel. $13.95.
LEAD: Mayor Koch is not preparing to join the Sandinista Front, but his three-day visit to Nicaragua clearly softened his perception of the Sandinistas.

LEAD: THOSE who can, do, and as for those who no longer can, well, if they're lucky they do what Dave Lewis did after the 34-year-old defenseman realized that he no longer had the skills that sustained him for most of his 15 seasons with four teams. Lewis, a former Islander who joined the Detroit Red Wings before the 1986-87 season, retired after Friday's loss to the Minnesota North Stars and promptly began a new career as a Red Wing assistant coach.

LEAD: THE first wave of products stemming from the biotechnology revolution focused mainly on human health care. But now agricultural biotechnology - the genetic manipulation of crop plants and farm animals - is blossoming as never before. True, only a few products of genetic engineering are on the market, including vaccines to prevent diseases in calves and piglets.
LEAD: Q. I have a lot of oil stains on my asphalt driveway. What should I use on these stains before I apply a sealer?
LEAD: GUESTS at the recent opening of the ''Fashion and Surrealism'' show at the Fashion Institute of Technology really dressed for the occasion. Forget Fendi. Never mind Lagerfeld. Lacroix? No way.
LEAD: The debate among Republicans over the debate today was whether to debate at all.

LEAD: The Rev. Orlando Enrique Costas, dean of the Andover Newton Theological School and a prominent Hispanic Protestant theologian, died of stomach cancer Thursday night at his home in Newton Centre, Mass. He was 45 years old.

LEAD: Half Moon Street Starring Michael Caine and Sigourney Weaver. Directed by Bob Swaim. 1987. Embassy Home Entertainment. 90 minutes. $79.95. To supplement her paltry earnings at a foreign-policy think tank in London, Lauren Slaughter hires herself out to an escort service. Lauren is a young American Ph.D., beautiful and witty.

LEAD: WOODWORKING SHOW At noon Friday, the enthusiasts will start coming out of - or going into -the woodwork at the Hyatt Hotel on Route 70 in Cherry Hill for a show sponsored by the Woodworking Association of North America. (The association, with headquarters in Plymouth, N.H., has 6,700 members, 1,200 of them in New Jersey.)

LEAD: Today, the stylized, sleekly androgynous Art Deco portraits that the Polish-born artist Tamara de Lempicka painted and exhibited in Paris during the 1920's and 30's exist primarily as period pieces. They don't hold a candle to the era's great paintings nor to Art Deco's major achievement - which occurred largely in the area of design.
LEAD: Q. I have a lot of oil stains on my asphalt driveway. What should I use on these stains before I apply a sealer?

LEAD: A picture caption in some copies of the Travel section today carries an incorrect description of a Chevrolet Bel-Air. The car, on display at the Henry Ford Museum in Dearborn, Mich., is a 1956 model, not a 1955.

LEAD: WHEN ''Women in Love'' was first published in 1920, it was the book of a man who had been burned. ''The Rainbow,'' Lawrence's previous novel, was suppressed by the Government in 1915 and his frightened publisher actually incinerated, or cremated it. Lawrence chopped ''Women in Love'' in a last-minute attempt to make it less combustible and it was riddled with errors of transcription as well.
LEAD: Burglars Coveting Rhinestones
LEAD: A civilian who works at a National Guard base has created a device that could save the Army more than $6 million a year, military officials say.
LEAD: A 22-pound lobster escaped the fate of many lobsters when an Alaskan doctor paid to have it taken from Anchorage to Maine and set free in the Atlantic.

LEAD: The police restored order at a prison in Brussels today after 50 people were injured in rioting by inmates, officials said. A police spokesman said about 100 inmates at the Forest Prison smashed furniture and lit fires Friday night. He said order was restored after a few hours when police entered the jail and freed four guards who had been taken hostage.

LEAD: SOME PRESS RELEASES FLY almost unaided into the wastebasket. Others stick to the fingers, and sometimes in the throat. Consider one in behalf of the Milwaukee Symphony, which this weekend is taking part in ''an innovative and revolutionary idea-come-to-life that could change the face of all symphonic concerts to come.

LEAD: In ''The Downside'' by Richard Dresser (at the Long Wharf Theater), a new anti-stress drug is about to be introduced on the American market, and a New Jersey pharmaceutical company has speeded up production in order to beat its competition. Careers and lives are at stake. As one suspects, the drug itself has damaging side effects - the ''downside'' of the title.

LEAD: Just imagine what Mikhail Gorbachev's predecessors would have made of the stock market fall. Capitalism's rottenness is now painfully obvious, they would have proclaimed. Yet, as the world's Marxist-Leninists gathered in Moscow to commemorate the revolution that brought them to power 70 years ago, no such ideas were put forward.
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: THE rare stamp department of Christie's/Robson Lowe, international auctioneers, conducted three sales of stamps and covers last month. The sales, dominated by hard-to-find material that collectors seek, drew active floor and mail bidding which resulted in a $2,484,454 total for the 1,500 lots.

LEAD: In the front of the darkened room, slides blink on and off. On the floor are three television sets and several dozen icepicks, their business ends dangerously vertical. On the back wall are two glowing figures lighted by ultraviolet lamps. It sounds like a torture chamber, but it's a multi-media installation called ''Common Mistakes.
LEAD: Education Secretary William J. Bennett says Chicago's public schools are the worst in the nation and parents should consider private schools for their children.

LEAD: The m.v.p. doesn't just mean the best player, but the man who did the most to help his team win. In the National League, I think Will Clark should win the trophy. In the American League, I think George Bell should win because he was the best offensive and defensive producer in the league. EVAN KANTOR

LEAD: IN 1973, FRESH OUT OF SYRA-cuse University, the video artist Bill Viola went to visit a friend in San Francisco who took him straight from the airport to a camping trip in the desert. ''We drove down to Death Valley and arrived at Zabriskie Point at midnight under a full moon. In the next two days, my life was changed,'' Mr.

LEAD: IF there is one reliable result of state and local elections, it is the claim by interested parties that the outcome is a reliable guide to the course of a coming national contest. And so last week, after two gubernatorial races and a handful of mayoral ones, the Democrats hailed good omens for 1988, and the Republicans, ''bittersweet success.
LEAD: An article Oct. 11 about the rise of computers in typography misspelled the name of a classic typeface. It is Goudy Old Style.
LEAD: More than the foliage is changing color in Delaware this autumn.

LEAD: IN the last decade, beef has steadily lost ground to chicken as a component of the American diet. But University Genetics, in Westport, Conn., hopes to reverse the trend by using biotechnology to breed leaner beef cattle. ''We already have beef that's actually lower in cholesterol and fat than chicken,'' said Randal

LEAD: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York, Diane Elizabeth Hutchinson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Ashton Hutchinson Jr. of Wilton, Conn., and Vineyard Haven, Mass., was married yesterday to Paul Christopher Reilly, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul W. Reilly of Locust, N.J., and Kiawah, S.C.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: David Aaron misstates both the Administration's motives in raising the problem of Soviet noncompliance as well as my own reasons for choosing to leave Government service.

LEAD: THERE was applause in Stockholm when Joseph Brodsky was named the winner of this year's Nobel Prize in Literature. There probably always is at these occasions, since applause is what they are all about, but this particular outbreak of handclaps was reported to have been more animated and partisan than usual.

LEAD: Six horses trained by Peter Ferriola, Aqueduct Race Track's leading trainer, were ordered scratched by track stewards yesterday because of a state investigation involving the possible illegal medication of his horses.

LEAD: HEAVEN AND HELL. By John Jakes. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $19.95.) The concluding volume of John Jakes's North and South trilogy takes place in the years immediately following the Civil War. Once again, the story centers on two families, the Hazards of Pennsylvania and the Mains of South Carolina, who become embroiled in the bitter social and political disputes of Reconstruction.

LEAD: Maria Teresa Mariaca, the daughter of Janette Kling Mariaca and Alberto C. Mariaca, both of New York, was married yesterday at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church in New York to William Kinne Barnett, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Lewis B. Barnett of Blacksburg, Va. The Rev. William D. Roberts officiated.

LEAD: WHEN William J. Bennett, the United States Secretary of Education, emerged from a meeting with Kenneth Wilfred Baker, his opposite number, in London not too long ago, his first words spoke volumes. ''I was impressed,'' he said, ''by his use of the first person pronoun. 'I shall do this. . .' How nice to be able to do that and speak like that!
LEAD: IF YOU CAN'T SAY SOMETHING NICE By Calvin Trillin. 257 pp. New York: Ticknor & Fields. $16.95.
LEAD: FELICITY By Coral Lansbury. 189 pp. New York: E. P. Dutton. $16.95.

LEAD: WHITTLE: The True Story. By John Golley with Sir Frank Whittle. (Smithsonian Institution, $24.95.) Frank Whittle, the Englishman who fathered the jet engine, is to airplanes as Robert Fulton was to ships: he made them less glamorous but a lot faster and more reliable. Born in Coventry in 1907 to a working-class family, he joined the Royal Air Force at the age of 16 in the hope of bettering his prospects.
LEAD: The illustrations on these pages have been taken from The Book Review's choices of the 10 best illustrated children's books of 1987.
LEAD: THE New Haven Police Department plans to increase the starting pay and shorten the time it takes to certify a potential recruit to combat its chronic shortage of officers.

LEAD: The Relativity of Saints Einstein was a reluctant culture hero - yet he saw that he could be a useful symbol as well as a famous scientist. This is from ''Dreams and Delusions: The Drama of German History'' by Fritz Stern (Knopf).

LEAD: State and city officials urge anyone who suspects that a child has been abused or neglected, or is in risk of such mistreatment, to report the suspicions immediately to one of three special telephone hot lines that have been set up specifically to respond to child-abuse reports.

LEAD: THE LEGENDARY PROJECT, TO construct a tunnel beneath the English Channel, dates to 1881, the most recent effort having been aborted in 1974. This year, however, a most auspicious beginning has been made. Photographed above, the access shaft at Sangatte - 55 meters across, 62 meters deep (about 180 by 200 feet) - on the French side of the channel, has solved a problem that dogged engineers in the past.
LEAD: THE RABBI OF LUD By Stanley Elkin. 277 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $17.95.

LEAD: FOR thousands of Long Island women, the business day begins with a stop at a baby sitter's house, or a day-care center, or a reminder to a school-age child not to miss the bus. Many more women who would join the Long Island work force cannot because there is no one to care for their children.

LEAD: IF THERE IS an ideal time to buy a gift for Christmas or Hanukkah, it is undoubtedly before Thanksgiving. Stores and mail-order-catalogue houses are fully stocked with merchandise, salespeople are relaxed and the throngs of holiday shoppers are still a gleam in a shopkeeper's eye. For the student or educator in the family, gifts this year can be both fun and educational.

LEAD: The collapse of his second successive nomination to the Supreme Court tells us much about Ronald Reagan. It shows us the price we pay for having a President who in even his most solemn appointing function is driven by narrow interests of politics and ideology.
LEAD: A WHITE ROMANCE By Virginia Hamilton. 191 pp. New York: Philomel Books. $14.95. (Ages 12 and up)

LEAD: Deborah Ann O'Connell, the daughter of Paulette Leclair O'Connell of San Francisco and Philip Joseph O'Connell of St. Petersburg, Fla., was married yesterday to Tyler Roberts Carder, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Roberts George Carder of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Stamford, Conn. The Rev. Wayne Lavender performed the ceremony at the Rowayton (Conn.) United Methodist
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: The $50,000 Mercedes Grand Prix, the first of the two major jumping competitions at the National Horse Show this weekend, was captured by Ian Millar of the Canadian equestrian team last night on his towering 11-year-old Belgian-bred gelding, Big Ben. The pair staged a repeat performance of their victory in this event here last year.
LEAD: Geography
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: Judith Pearce, a flutist, Elizabeth DeFelice, a pianist, and Donald Palma, a double-bassist, will play works by J.S. Bach, Vaughan Williams, Varese, Ives, Wallingford Riegger and Carl Reinecke tomorrow at 8 in Weill Recital Hall. Tickets at $10, or $5 for students and the elderly, are available at the box office or through Carnegie Charge, 247-7800.
LEAD: AND THE BAND PLAYED ON Politics, People, and the AIDS Epidemic. By Randy Shilts. 630 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $24.95.

LEAD: I hasten to respond to a quote by Suffolk County Legislator Ed Romaine [ ''Suffolk Debates Toxic-Ash Bill,'' Oct. 4 ] . In it, Mr. Romaine says that the problem of solid-waste disposal ''is so large it requires a state or regional approach, and the fact is the state has miserably neglected its responsibilities.
LEAD: President Chaim Herzog of Israel will meet President Reagan at the White House Tuesday at the start of the first state visit by an Israeli President to the United States.

LEAD: THE sun was gradually losing its summer strength, its warmth was diminishing and it seemed to know it had lost its importance. The flowers didn't seem to care about it as much. There were no beachgoers who cared, no worshipers.

LEAD: OCCUPATION. By John Toland. (Doubleday, $19.95.) ''In war,'' Omar Bradley wrote, ''there is no second prize for the runner-up.'' But what about Japan? Maybe the American occupation at the end of World War II wasn't a prize. But it began a political and social revolution that made Japan the economic power it is today.
LEAD: It is laudable that many homosexuals are striving to fill a spiritual need and draw closer to God, and it is the obligation of the churches to assist them in their quest. But, are they?

LEAD: When President Reagan visited Canada's capital in April, White House officials declined a request for a meeting with Edward Broadbent, leader of the New Democratic Party. Protocol required the President to meet with the country's official opposition Leader, John Turner, but not with Mr. Broadbent, whose party has been a left-wing minority in Parliament for 52 years.

LEAD: THE results of New Jersey's record $12 million legislative elections held few surprises: Voters rejected a proposal to build a $185 million baseball stadium backed by state tax revenues and left the State Senate under Democratic control and the Assembly in Republican hands.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Consumer Confidence Seen Economists are optimistic that consumers will recover confidence and spend enough to avoid a recession next year, a survey found. Page 30. A Breakthrough on Arms White House officials and Congressional leaders have reportedly worked out basic elements of a compromise on arms issues.

LEAD: THIS season, Town Hall and Classical Artists International have been co-sponsoring a series of concerts entitled Russian Nights, featuring prominent Soviet musicians unfamiliar to American audiences. The first installment came last month with a recital by Vladimir Krainev, a pianist, and the second concert took place Friday evening with the debut of Grigory Zhislin, a violinist.

LEAD: LAST weekend, 32 economists from around the country and from Europe gathered at the Jerome Levy Economics Institute at Bard College to discuss the work of the late British economist Nicholas Kaldor. Much of the discussion was concerned with the more esoteric aspects of Lord Kaldor's work - his theories about money and economic growth.

LEAD: The mother of Larry Davis's 16-month-old daughter was picked up by the police after Mr. Davis's arrest last December and warned that she faced separation from her four children and prosecution for aiding a fugitive, she said in a three-hour court interview last week with Mr. Davis's lawyers.

LEAD: THEY'RE off, and as they come out of the March gate and head into summer it's Steve Cauthen in the lead with Pat Eddery keeping it close and the others trailing far behind. As they round the turn into September and head toward fall, Cauthen with a mighty effort, extends his lead to 10 races. It seems all over for Eddery, but what's this?

LEAD: THE Utah Jazz have indefinitely suspended Darryl Dawkins in a move that the team president, Dave Checketts, said was not disciplinary in nature. Checketts, in announcing the suspension of the center last night, said Dawkins was upset over the death of his estranged wife, Kelly Barnes Dawkins, on Nov.
LEAD: INCIDENTS IN THE LIFE OF A SLAVE GIRL, Written by Herself, Harriet A. Jacobs. Edited by Jean Fagan Yellin. Harvard University Press. 306 pages. Hardcover $37.50, paperback $9.95.

LEAD: THE WEST HAS LONG been familiar with the art of China and Japan, but Korean art remained relatively unknown until the mid-1970's. Viewed as a mere imitation of its two neighbors, the culture was generally overlooked. One effort to correct this situation is an exhibition of 100 works - ''From the Land of Morning Calm: Korean Art at the Brooklyn Museum.
LEAD: For the first time since 1981, Yale reached the top of the Ivy League in November as the Elis scored a convincing 28-9 victory today over Cornell.
LEAD: Student leaders at Syracuse University refused today to cut off money for a speech by the Nation of Islam leader, Louis Farrakhan, a spokeswoman said.

LEAD: Dr. Felicia Kyung Park and Dr. David Eustace Cummings, who graduated with the class of '87 from the Harvard Medical School and are in the medical residency program at the University of Washington Affiliated Hospitals in Seattle, plan to be married next month.

LEAD: Like an oasis in Texas, Austin rises green and lush between the swamps of Houston and dusty plains of West Texas. Its hills and mesas buck and ripple along the Balcones geologic fault, which rises from the south near San Antonio and reaches heights of 300 feet or more just north of Austin. From the cliffs and upper slopes of the hills, with hawks wheeling high overhead, one can look down on two major lakes created from the Colorado River as it snakes its way through the city and countryside.

LEAD: ''All ahead full,'' the command was given quietly. A button was pushed. A bell rang. The big oil tanker headed for the Strait of Hormuz, and at that moment it became a strategic target in the Persian Gulf war.

LEAD: Advocates of change in China won a solid victory at its 13th Congress of the Communist Party, but the balance between them and more cautious leaders has been carefully preserved, according to a number of academic specialists on China.

LEAD: TRY to get Celso Gonzalez-Falla on a horse on Good Friday. Try, but there's no way it's going to happen. That's the one day of the year that the tax and securities lawyer, who commutes between New York and Texas, won't even consider riding.

LEAD: NANCY was valedictorian of her suburban Chicago high school class when she graduated in 1981. She wanted to be a lawyer. Mike was also his high school's valedictorian that year. He too wanted to be a lawyer.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Robert R. Bellantoni of Monroe Township, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Barbara Jean Bellantoni to James Evans, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Evans of Washington Township, N.J.
LEAD: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 25 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

LEAD: EVERY ballet company repertory needs a slight romantic pas de deux, and the Joffrey Ballet has one in Ben Stevenson's ''Three Preludes,'' a crowd-pleaser created in 1969 and acquired this year by the company, which presented it with a new cast on Thursday at City Center. Set to piano music by Rachmaninoff that was performed here by Stanley Babin, ''Three Preludes'' offers a pastel vision of a studio flirtation between two young dancers and its extension into ballet partnering.

LEAD: IT often falls to the British to say most forthrightly what is on the minds of Europeans when they worry about the United States. Last week in London, Nigel Lawson, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, said it was imperative for the health of the world economy that America slash its huge budget deficit and raise taxes.

LEAD: WITH winter's icy blasts just weeks away, the fickle sun-and-fun crowds have retreated. Restaurants at ferries and on the East End have battened their hatches. Some hope to weather winter storms by enticing the boys and girls of summer back to their warm-weather haunts by offering meals and prices difficult to resist.
LEAD: ''THE legislation has a simple purpose: to right a wrong committed by the United States 100 years ago.''

Michael Farrell of New York and Point o' Woods, L.I., and the late William Boyd Kegg Jr., was married yesterday to Lewis Cass Knox, a son of Mary Jane Walters Knox of Swarthmore, Pa., and the late Lewis Cass Knox.
LEAD: Bobby Humphrey ran for 161 yards and a touchdown to lead Alabama to a 22-10 upset of previously unbeaten Louisiana State tonight.

LEAD: In a battle between two undefeated teams in Westchester County, Roosevelt High School of Yonkers roared back from a 17-0 first-period deficit yesterday to defeat White Plains, 26-23, at the losers' field.

LEAD: Ben Itkin, a co-founder and past president of Itkin Brothers Inc., a distributor of office furniture, died Friday at the Miami Heart Institute after heart surgery. He was 78 years old and lived in Palm Beach, Fla., and Hillsdale, N.Y.

LEAD: Under enormous pressure from Administration officials and his own conservative supporters on Capitol Hill, Judge Douglas H. Ginsburg today asked President Reagan to withdraw his nomination to the Supreme Court.
LEAD: I MUST be the only person who loves it when the power fails.

LEAD: A Federal appeals court panel has ruled that a member of Congress may be sued for defamatory statements made in a letter to the executive branch even if considers the comments part of his official duties.

LEAD: Site clearance is under way in preparation for the construction of a $10 million shopping center on the site of an old drive-in theater in the Village of Fishkill in Dutchess County. The site is at the intersection of Routes 9 and 52, one mile north of Interstate 84.

LEAD: EVERY NOW AND THEN THE DRAMATIST Hugh Whitemore and the actor Derek Jacobi would meet for lunch and ruefully wonder if they weren't jointly launched on an impossible project. ''Breaking the Code'' just didn't seem writable, and its protagonist, the British mathematician and inventor Alan Turing, just didn't seem performable.

LEAD: PRESIDENT Reagan's reconstructed tax system is intact; he has won his big budgets for the Pentagon, although they are subject to raid; all his inveighing against other Government spending has paid off in the sense that even liberal Democrats advocate restraint. Last week, West Germany buckled to American pressure and cut interest rates, helping American banks to cut theirs.
LEAD: FOUR masters of the keyboard are to perform in the state this week, including Karl Haas, who is far better known for his national radio broadcasts than for his infrequent recitals.

LEAD: The lawyer for a union leader charged with 12 others in a bribery case faced the problem of countering secretly recorded tapes portraying the defendants as thugs. The answer was nearly 500 character witnesses, many testifying in groups.

LEAD: GEOFFREY Parker opened the letter and could scarcely believe his eyes. Professor Parker, a historian at St. Andrews University in Scotland, was being offered a job at triple his salary. He had not applied for it. ''This is not an invitation to apply,'' he said, paraphrasing the wording in the letter, from the University of Illinois at Champaign-Urbana.

LEAD: WITHOUT a single tuba, trombone or saxophone, Meredith Gilfeather admits that the Stamford High School marching band does not exactly strike up a rousing rendition of the National Anthem before the fans at home football games.

LEAD: SNAKES, BUTTERFLIES and tigers - encrusted with jewels, carved of stone or crafted in gold - coexist handsomely in ''Antique Animal Jewelry: 1700-1940,'' at the gallery of J. Mavec, 52 East 76th Street. The exhibition, which opens Wednesday, will be on view through Nov. 21.

LEAD: IT was my examination for the draft in 1940 that saved my life - just as that ceremony led to the opposite outcome for so many of my generation. My chest X-ray revealed advanced tuberculosis, and the news that there were to be more germs than Germans in my future. Being infected in both lungs I was considered unlikely to recover -a bit of trivia not revealed to me at the time.

Fergusson of Richmond, was married at St. James's Episcopal Church there yesterday to Graham Yoshio Tanaka, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Y. Clifford Tanaka of South Pasadena, Calif. The Rev. Frank F. Fagan, assisted by the Rev. Thomas R. Smith, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: If THE BLACK DAHLIA by James Ellroy (Mysterious Press, $16.95) were a play, it would be reviewed as overwritten, overdirected, overproduced and overwrought. It is a big, sprawling novel about the relationship of two cops - Bucky Bleichert and Lee Blanchard -in the 1940's. Both were highly regarded professional boxers before entering the Los Angeles Police Department.
LEAD: WHAT WE NEED is a candidate for the Presidency of the United States who doesn't want the job.

LEAD: ON Friday night at the Triplex Theater of Manhattan Community College, Lorn MacDougal danced the premiere of a solo about matters many people might prefer not to think about. Choreographed by Lee Connor, her former partner, ''Daily Living: A Tribute, a Transfiguration'' was based upon Mr. Connor's own battle against AI

LEAD: Alvin A. Dewey, chief investigator of the 1959 killings chronicled in the book and movie ''In Cold Blood,'' died Friday at a hospital here after suffering a stroke at his home. He was 75 years old.

LEAD: HE looked so peculiar that ''high strung horses stopped and wouldn't move'' until he passed, or so the legend goes. He trudged his 365-mile route for 30 years so punctually that housewives in Westchester County and Connecticut had a plate of food waiting every 34th day.

LEAD: Mark Green carried eight consecutive times, the last for a 2-yard touchdown, to complete a three-touchdown Notre Dame rally for a 32-25 victory over Boston College today. Green, who rushed for 152 yards, led a second-half rushing attack that brought Notre Dame back from a 25-12 deficit.

LEAD: Annemarie Colbin's 'The Basics of Healthy Cooking' The Natural Gourmet Cookery School. 101 minutes. $39.95. Annemarie Colbin, who runs a cooking school in New York that specializes in natural foods, has put together a video on grains and beans that is stunningly complete. It would be especially useful for a total novice, let's say a dyed-in-the-wool carnivore who has been told to take up a diet rich in beans and grains and has no idea where to begin.

LEAD: The Brooklyn Army Terminal, completed as World War I drew to an end, served the Army in World War II and the Korean War. Then the waterfront facility fell into decay as goods and manpower began to move by air.
LEAD: An essay on the Opinion page on Oct. 25 about the radio drama ''War of the Worlds'' misstated the year it was first broadcast. It was 1938.

LEAD: ''THE bus from Moscow to Leningrad,'' we were informed by Irma, the Finnish guide who had taken charge of our 30-member tour group on our arrival at Helsinki airport about a week earlier, ''was made in Finland.'' Not an exciting piece of news, but very much in the spirit of Irma, who had introduced us to Finnish history by emphasizing the effort of the Finns to remain independent of the big neighbor we were about to visit.
LEAD: JUST AS LONG AS WE'RE TOGETHER By Judy Blume. 296 pp. New York: Orchard Books/Franklin Watts. $12.95. (Ages 10 to 13)

LEAD: Tai-Pan Starring Bryan Brown, Joan Chen, John Stanton. 1986. Vestron Video. 127 minutes. $79.98. ''Tai-Pan,'' a misguided film epic set in the early 19th century, attempts to recount British maneuverings in the China trade and the seizure of Hong Kong. Based on James Clavell's best-selling novel, the movie offers a somnolent story notable only for its lethal concentration of swaggering merchants and sniveling ingenues.

LEAD: About 34,000 members of the Army Reserve, National Guard and civilian employees were moving out this weekend for a two-week test of their ability to mobilize for war. Mari M. Perrotti, spokeswoman for the 99th Army Reserve Command, based near Pittsburg, said the exercise would cover 12 states from Maine to Virginia.

LEAD: OPERA IS DRAMA, AND, AS JOSEPH KER-man argued more than 30 years ago in his provocative ''Opera as Drama,'' the composer is the dramatist. That is still one of the trickiest truths of opera to understand. Misunderstanding it can skew performance priorities, and often does. What does it mean that the composer is the dramatist?
LEAD: CONTROL of New York City co-ops -who lives in the apartments and how they are used - has long been a prime concern for tenant-shareholders.
LEAD: WHEN I was 13 years old, I took tap-dancing lessons from Gene Kelly's sister Louise at her studio in Johnstown, Pa.
LEAD: By a narrow margin, New York voters have approved extending and widening trails at three state-operated ski centers in the Adirondack and Catskill Mountains.

LEAD: William F. Buckley Jr.'s account of his adventurous descent to the graveyard of the Titanic kept my interest (''Down to the Great Ship,'' Oct. 18). But it did not whet my enthusiasm for any further raiding of the lost ''ark.''

LEAD: ''I NOW FIND MYSELF DOING THE most demanding, difficult, massive, Gothic role that even I have ever attempted,'' says the actress whom Tennessee Williams called ''the great Elizabeth Ashley.'' LEAD: IN THE first days of the 1985-86 school year at Harvard, the course called ''World Religions, Diversity and Dialogue'' was so popular that all the seats were taken and some students were sitting cross-legged on the floor of a great lecture hall. With two hands, the professor pushed her blonde hair behind her ears and made a statement that was to reverberate in my mind for the rest of the school year.

LEAD: TO find the place where poetry and technology meet, one need only go as far as the Hastings-on-Hudson Middle School. There, in a basement laboratory, students have been working with holography - the young science that confounds logic with its optical magic.

LEAD: THE county has a new orchestra, the all-professional Empire State Pops, and if you would like to be able to say you heard it when, now is the time: at 8 P.M. Saturday at the Music Hall Theater in Tarrytown.

LEAD: Nelson R. Mandela, the 69-year-old jailed leader of the outlawed African National Congress, would ''bend all his efforts'' toward a peaceful solution in South Africa if he were freed, his colleague Govan A. Mbeki said today.

LEAD: The presidents, kings and emirs of the Arab world began to converge on this hilly capital today amid concern that failure to close ranks behind a united policy could polarize the Arab world into blocs of moderates and radicals for a long time to come.

LEAD: Coach Dick MacPherson of Syracuse got into a rather heated discussion with the Naval Academy's deputy commandant, Capt. Ed Kristensen, on the field today. It seems that the coach and his quarterbacks, going through warm-ups, were standing in the way of the brigade of midshipmen marching into the stadium before the kickoff.

LEAD: The engagement of Melissa Beth Rutkin to Michael Gordon Kaplitt, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Martin J. Kaplitt of Kings Point, L.I., and North Miami Beach, Fla., has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Philip Rutkin of Kings Point, parents of the bride-to-be.

LEAD: THIS FALL there is at least one pair of happy freshmen roommates at Brandeis University in Waltham, Mass. ''It was a perfect match,'' said Melissa Telzer, a New Yorker, about her roommate from Mount Vernon, N.Y. ''We were both assistant managers at Benetton stores. We both enjoy going to parties and sleeping late.
LEAD: IN recent years, individuals have been pouring liquid assets into their portfolios. Their emphasis has been on stocks, bonds and mutual funds, all of which are easily converted to cash.

LEAD: IT WAS THE LAST OF THE BIG killings in advertising,'' says Robert E. Jacoby. He sits in the brightly lit living room of his sprawling ranch home in Saddle River, N.J., puffing on one of the large cigars he habitually smokes.

LEAD: IN a cavernous hangar at the headquarters of Embraer, as the Brazilian Aerospace Corporation is known, work has begun on the first of 20 twin-prop Brasilia aircraft on order from Texas Air. Near the plant's runway, technicians are testing five single-engine Tucano trainer planes, with the colors of the Peruvian Air Force.

LEAD: IN ''ORPHEE,'' HIS 1949 FILM TREAT-ment of the Orpheus legend, Jean Cocteau pictured Hell as an administrative office run by French bureaucrats. This French penchant for mordant allegory and metaphor should be kept in mind with respect to the two dance-theater pieces performed by the Compagnie Maguy Marin in the Brooklyn Academy of Music's current Next Wave

LEAD: It is obvious what is wrong with the Giants. Isn't it? They spent too much time writing books. Or, they did not spend enough time putting a strike team together. Or, everyone points for a Super Bowl team.

LEAD: To her friends and neighbors, 92-year-old Ida Saltzman was sweet, friendly, sometimes headstrong but, like many grandmothers, always concerned about how you were and whether you were eating right.

LEAD: 'Today, probably for the first time ever, there are about as many people, women, prepared to vote for you because you are a qualified woman as there are people, meaning men, ready to vote against you because you are a woman. Sex prejudice, you might say, the proclivity to either accept or reject you as a woman, is more closely balanced today than it has ever been - which is to say that being a woman is less of a disadvantage now than it has ever been.

LEAD: What theater lovers these New Yorkers be! The New York Shakespeare Festival will present all 36 plays of William Shakespeare in a six-year-long, $33 million series, Joseph Papp, the festival producer, announced last week. They will be performed by an all-American company, including such stars as Meryl Streep, James Earl Jones, Robert De Niro, Raul Julia and Kevin Kline, who honed their craft in the Shakespeare festival at one time or another during its 34-year history.
